HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Interest Rates Cut by Canada

DATELINE: OTTAWA, July 19Reuters

 BODY:
The Bank of Canada cut key short-term interest rates today, citing a sluggish economy and an inflation rate near the bottom of the central bank's target range.
The cut, which surprised many investors, followed the release today of weaker-than-expected retail sales and inflation data. 
 The bank lowered its key bank rate -- the rough equivalent of the United States discount rate, the rate the Federal Reserve charges banks to borrow -- by a quarter of a percentage point, to 4.75 percent.
The move lowered the target range for the overnight lending rate to 4.25 to 4.75 percent from 4.5 to 5 percent. Short-term rates have fallen 3.5 percentage points since the Bank of Canada began its easing cycle on May 8, 1995. The bank's last previous rate cut was on April 18.
The bank said it cut rates because sluggish demand in the economy meant downward pressure on the already low rate of inflation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off vs. Mark and Yen, Following Stocks Down Again

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended slightly lower against most leading currencies yesterday, hurt by a drop in the United States stock market and by speculation over higher Japanese interest rates.
While the drop in stocks yesterday was moderate, sharp declines earlier this week have caused currency traders to worry that foreign investors may be selling off United States assets and converting the proceeds into other currencies, which would reduce demand for dollars. 
 As a result, the United States stock market and the dollar have been "pretty tightly correlated this week," said Randolph Donney, director of research at Pegasus Econometric Group. "There's less correlation when the market's up than down."
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar stood at 107.95 Japanese yen, down from 108.46 yen on Thursday. It was also trading at 1.4865 German marks, down from 1.4920 marks. The British pound settled at $1.5455, unchanged for the second consecutive day.
Throughout the trading day in New York, the dollar tracked the stock market closely. Against the yen, the dollar was hurt by speculation that the Bank of Japan would soon raise interest rates. Higher rates tend to make a nation's currency more valuable.
Eisuke Sakakibara, director general of international finance at the Japanese Ministry of Finance, did not rule out a rate increase as officials have recently. "I don't think we should take it as given," he said in comments published yesterday about the possibility of higher rates. Currency traders read his comments as leaving open a slight possibility of an increase in rates.
Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at the Bank Leumi Trust Company, said Japanese officials in the last few days have been backing away from strict denials that rates would rise.
At the same time, currency traders are concerned that comments on Thursday by the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, suggested that a rise in United States interest rates would happen later than expected. While the prospect of higher rates has weakened the stock and bond markets, it has recently bolstered the dollar.
In other currency trading, the dollar fell to 1.2147 Swiss francs from 1.2198 Swiss francs and to 1,511 Italian lire, from 1,518 lire. The dollar rose to 5.0345 French francs from 5.0335 francs.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
This Wine Has a Presidential Seal

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: ANILLACO, Argentina

 BODY:
With his four sons, Saul Menem, a poor Syrian immigrant who spoke little Spanish, started a small winery in this arid farming village in northwest Argentina 65 years ago.
It was an ambitious venture, undertaken mainly for personal consumption, because most Argentine wines were produced farther south, where the soil is richer and the climate more suitable for vineyards. 
 But Mr. Menem's vines took root, and his wine soon gained a following. As for his sons, Mr. Menem once said: "Amado is the worker, Munir is the administrator, Eduardo is the one who defends us, and Carlos is the one who enjoys the wine."
Today, Menem e Hijos S.A. (Menem & Sons) may not produce the best wines in Argentina, but its label is certainly among the best known. And sales of Menem wines have risen sharply in recent years mainly because of the son who showed the least interest in the business, Carlos Saul Menem, the President of Argentina.
Mr. Menem, who was elected to a second term last year, remains immensely popular in Argentina, and as his political fortunes have risen so have those of his family's winery.
Since Mr. Menem first took office in 1989, the Menem winery has seen its sales climb more than 60 percent, company officials said. Although the privately owned winery does not discuss its sales and profits, the officials said that the winery produced about a million bottles of wine last year making it a modest-sized winery here among the country's growing wine business and somewhere between a tiny boutique and a smallish winery in the United States.
"Its sales are rising because of the popularity of the family name," said Dereck Foster, a leading Argentine wine critic. "People who don't know a lot about wine are buying Menem wine because the name speaks to them."
"You can say a lot of bad things about the President, but you can't deny that he's bringing Argentina into the first world," Leopoldo Muzon, 43, owner of a video store, said, referring to Mr. Menem's success in stabilizing the Argentine economy. "I don't mind buying the wine of a man I respect."
It has also become chic to bring a bottle of Menem wine to dinner parties or to give a bottle to foreign visitors as a memento of Argentina. And some presidential aides said the wine was sometimes served at official Government functions and receptions, an assertion the Government would not confirm or deny.
For Maria Jose Chacon, 36, a lawyer, Menem wine turned out to be the perfect Christmas gift. "My best friend and I exchanged gag gifts at Christmas. She gave me an electronic head massager that she ordered from television. That was funny. I gave her a case of Menem red wine. That was hilarious."
And how does Menem wine taste? Mr. Foster, the wine critic, said that for a basic table wine, the Menem label was far superior to comparable inexpensive wines produced in Europe. A bottle of Menem wine ranges between $2 and $6.
"These cheap Argentine wines will beat the pants off anything in the same price category from France," Mr. Foster said. "Let me just say that if I were deprived of the higher-end wines, I would prefer to open a bottle of Menem wine before drinking much of the other stuff that's on the market."
Menem winery officials said they had worked hard recently to improve the quality of their wines by investing in new production and bottling technology. The winery has also built a new bottling plant in Anillaco and licensed its label to a producer in the southern wine-making province of Mendoza. Menem is also seeking to increase its exports, as is the rest of the Argentine industry.
Few people know that Argentina is the third-biggest producer of wine in the world, after Italy and France. It has more than 490,000 acres of vineyards and produces a wide variety of wines from different grapes, including chardonnay, sauvignon, bonarda and criolla.
Until recently, however, Argentina had done very little in the way of exporting and advertising its wines compared with Chile, which has become the No. 3 exporter of wine to the United States, after Italy and France.
But after investing heavily in new technology and international promotion campaigns in recent years, Argentina is starting to see results. Last year, foreign exports of wine increased almost 900 percent, to 59 million gallons, compared with 6 million in 1994, according to Argentina's National Wine Institute.

HEADLINE: Stirrings in Indonesia

 BODY:
Thirty years of military rule has stifled the political life of Indonesia, the world's fourth-most-populous country. Now, with President Suharto nearing the end of his sixth and possibly last term, open debate about the country's future and institutions is beginning to revive.
That is a trend Washington should encourage, and not just for idealistic reasons. Prolonged dictatorship has allowed corruption to flourish, leaving Indonesia without an independent legal system for resolving commercial disputes that sometimes involve American and other foreign companies. Secretary of State Warren Christopher's current visit to Indonesia provides a timely opportunity to make clear where America stands. 
 The most notable challenge to Mr. Suharto has come from Megawati Sukarnoputri, whose father, Sukarno, ruled Indonesia from independence in 1945 until 1966. Ms. Megawati, elected in 1994 as head of one of Indonesia's two tame legal opposition parties, has tried to transform that party into a serious opposition force. Last month a Government-backed faction deposed her from the party leadership, depriving her of the platform from which she hoped to run for president in 1998. But she has vowed to fight on and is seeking reinstatement through the courts.
Whatever happens in Ms. Megawati's case, a return to enforced political passivity is unlikely. The Indonesia that General Suharto took over 30 years ago was desperately poor, exhausted by Sukarno's confrontational foreign policy and riven by tensions between soldiers, Muslims and a powerful pro-Beijing Communist Party.
The Suharto regime crushed the Communists in a bloody purge, imposed political order and gradually rebuilt the economy. Now, at the price of political liberty, Indonesia is one of Asia's emerging economic powers, with large new middle and working classes straining for a larger voice in their own affairs.
During the cold war, Washington too often overlooked the Suharto Government's repressive ways along with its forcible annexation and occupation of East Timor. Today a more forthright approach is needed.
America should stand behind the efforts of Indonesia's impressive network of independent civic organizations to smooth the transition toward a more democratic future. As Indonesia's second-largest trading partner and one of its largest sources of foreign investment, the United States could exert a significant positive influence.
The Clinton Administration has been understandably eager to increase American business involvement in booming Southeast Asia. But Washington should not pursue business promotion at the expense of efforts to encourage respect for labor standards, human rights and the environment. In Jakarta, Ambassador Stapleton Roy has set a good example by standing up to pressure from Freeport-McMoran Copper & Gold Inc., which wants Washington to withdraw financial support from a local environmental organization that has challenged the company's mining practices.
The Administration is right to pursue economic opportunities in Indonesia. But it best serves American values and longer-term business interests by supporting those Indonesians now pressing for increased democracy and human rights.

HEADLINE: Dow Jones and the Nikkei: Partners or Strangers in the Night?

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 19

 BODY:
For much of this week, the Tokyo stock market followed Wall Street on its roller-coaster ride. When stocks in New York plunged on Monday, they fell sharply in Tokyo on Tuesday. When Wall Street began to recover in the next two days, so did Tokyo.
Today, however, Tokyo went its own way. While the Dow Jones industrial average staged a strong rally on Thursday, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks fell 90.13 points today to close at 21,476.29. 
 Are the world's two largest stock markets fatally attracted or not?
Many analysts say that in the long run, movements of the two markets are not well correlated. Indeed, if the New York market hits new air pockets, it could make Japanese stocks an attractive alternative, especially as the Japanese economy has just begun recovering from a four-year slump while the American economy might be about to enter a downturn.
"People may now take another look at Japan and see it as a very attractive market," said Kevin Hebner, a strategist here at SBC Warburg Securities. "Our view is that the driver of the Japanese market is earnings momentum," not what happens in New York. The fall of stock prices here in response to Monday's plunge on Wall Street was "largely psychological and it's incorrect," he said.
One need only look at history. The day after the Dow fell 22.6 percent in the "Black Monday" crash of Oct. 19, 1987, the Tokyo market fell 14.9 percent. But the Nikkei average recovered to pass its pre-crash level by March 1988, while the Dow did not do that until mid-1989, said Ken Okamura, a strategist here at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.
Conversely, in the last few years, as Wall Street has experienced the longest bull market in history, the Tokyo market has languished.
To be sure, there are some good reasons that market movements might be correlated, at least in the short run.
If high-technology companies in the United States are seeing poorer-than-expected earnings, their suppliers and competitors in Japan would also. If the American economy turns down, it would hurt Japan's economy as well. A sharp drop on Wall Street could also weaken the dollar against the yen, which would hurt Japanese exporters and thereby weaken stocks in Tokyo as well.
Another factor is that foreign investors have been aggressive buyers of stocks in Japan in the last year or so, buoying the market, while Japanese investors have sat on the sidelines. Indeed, foreigners owned 9.4 percent of all the shares on the Tokyo exchange in 1995, compared with only 3.6 percent in 1987.
Hence, if American and other foreign investors become wary of stocks, and if the American public stops pouring money into equity mutual funds, foreigners might pull out of Japanese stocks. Indeed, selling by foreigners appears to be behind some of the weakness in the Tokyo stock market this week.
Still, said Kathy Matsui, a vice president and strategist at Goldman Sachs (Japan) Ltd., "Relatively speaking, compared to Southeast Asia or Latin America, the Japanese market has tended to be more resilient to declines in the United States."
If Japan's market keeps going its own way, the case could be made for emphasizing Japanese stocks at the expense of American ones. While the Dow has fallen a bit from its all-time high, the Tokyo market is still well below its peak of about 39,000 in 1989. And the economic cycles are in different stages as well.
"The U.S. economy has continued its expansion for three to four years while the Japanese market has just started to show a rebound," said Kazuyuki Suzuki, assistant general manager of the equity division at Daiwa Securities.
Mr. Okamura of Kleinwort Benson expects the Nikkei average to reach 24,000 by the end of the year. Mr. Hebner of SBC Warburg expects to see 23,750 by then.
But there is reason for caution. The Tokyo market has been losing steam in recent weeks, a trend that started even before the first sharp drop occurred in New York on July 5.
The Tokyo market had been rebounding this year because of prospects for recovery and the weakening of the yen against the dollar.
But after peaking at 22,666.80 on June 26, the market has fallen 5 percent, partly on expectations that the Bank of Japan will raise interest rates and on fears that the economic recovery will be mild. Upward revisions in earnings projections in the next few months could give new life to the market.
But without them, the Tokyo market might languish on its own, even if it is not dragged down by New York.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Spanish Companies in Crossfire of U.S.-Cuba Battle

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MADRID, July 19

 BODY:
Before Fidel Castro took over Cuba, Irenee du Pont Sr. owned a three-story beach house, a golf course and a private dock on the island's northern coast as a retreat from his family's Delaware chemical company.
Today, the Spanish-style home trimmed with mahogany stands in the midst of Cuba's most popular beach resort area, Varadero, and at least two of the 30 modern hotels there were built on land Mr. du Pont once owned, according to a Government official, a Spanish hotel executive and a report in Spain's largest daily, El Pais. 
 The Helms-Burton Act, which President Clinton signed in March, opens the way for the punishment of companies "deriving benefit" from American property that the Communist Castro regime has confiscated since the 1959 revolution. But two major Spanish hotel operators are staying put to protect their stakes in Cuba's growing tourist business.
"You can't just leave the day after making an investment," said Antonio Fernandez Casado, sales director for the Tryp hotel chain of Madrid, which has put $50 million into Cuba in the last few years and manages the former Havana Hilton and four other hotels. "We'll start to worry when you can't buy Coca-Cola and Winstons there."
Across Cuba, dozens of Canadian, European and Mexican companies, with investments ranging from mining to telephone service are taking a similar tack, while questioning whether they will ever be sued in United States court by American citizens claiming title to confiscated property in Cuba, as the Helms-Burton Act permits.
And further complicating such decisions, President Clinton announced an election-year compromise this week that delays any lawsuits until at least February 1997. He was torn between the potent Cuban-American voting blocs in Florida and New Jersey and the threats from outraged nations vowing to penalize American businesses in like measure if their own companies were hurt.
Yet Washington can still wield another part of Helms-Burton. This section prohibits foreign executives, controlling shareholders and their family members from entering the United States if their companies are in violation of Helms-Burton.
The American threats have been effective in some quarters. Two Madrid hotel companies, Occidental Hoteles and Paradores Nacionales, were just getting into Cuba but backed out. An Occidental spokeswoman said the decision had been made out of "respect for the American law."
But most of the 50 Spanish companies already in Cuba, from hotels to banks to tobacco companies, have not wavered, although it is not clear how many of them might be using confiscated property. The companies are attracted to Cuba mainly by low wages, but also by close ties between the two nations, even in the post-colonial era. Mr. Castro's father was born in Spain and immigrated to Cuba early in this century, seeking opportunity.
The first Spanish company expected to get a warning from Washington over Helms-Burton is the nation's largest hotel operator, Sol Melia S.A., of Palma de Mallorca, which had $1 billion in sales last year. It has 189 hotels in 25 countries, including 6 in Cuba totaling 2,100 rooms.
The company's luxury 340-room Hotel Melia Las Americas in the Varadero resort is next door to the old du Pont home, now a restaurant, and almost surely was built at least partly on former du Pont land, according to Mr. Fernandez of the rival Tryp chain, the report in El Pais and the Spanish Government official said.
The du Pont family had no comment on how its former property was being used at the beach resort, a family spokeswoman in Wilmington, Del., said.
The Du Pont Company, which had chemical interests in Cuba, issued a statement this week in response to President Clinton's announcement. The company said that "the global economy is dependent on reliable rules of trade and those rules would be jeopardized by the friction that would result," if the Helms-Burton Act took effect.
The Sol Melia chain said it was "not aware" if it was benefiting from confiscated property in Cuba but acknowledged that its hotels "could be located on land which is, or otherwise makes use of, confiscated property," according to the prospectus for the family-owned company's first offering of stock on July 2.
Despite the potential problems with Helms-Burton, Sol Melia's offering was oversubscribed 23 times, making it the most successful initial offering ever on the Madrid stock market. It raised $275 million for the company's expansion plans, which include two more hotels in Cuba and dozens more around the world.
Sol Melia has strongly hinted that it may drop its 271-room Sol Miami Beach hotel in Florida and remain in Cuba, where it is the biggest hotel operator, if the American law is fully applied. Cuba represented 7 percent of company revenue in 1995, compared with less than 1 percent for Florida, company spokesmen said.
Mr. Fernandez said the Helms-Burton Act was helping the more-established companies in Cuba by scaring off newcomers. Cuban-Americans are worried, he added, that some of the best deals on the island already have been locked up by non-American companies.
The new law, he said, was not just a political move against Castro but was also meant to slow European investment in Cuba.
Cuba has just 23,000 hotel rooms -- about the same number as in Madrid. Some 15,000 of the Cuban rooms are obsolete and below international standards, Mr. Fernandez added. With 1,200 miles of coastline, good weather almost all year and many still-pristine beaches, there is plenty of room for expansion.
Both the report in El Pais and the Government official said that another shareholder in the Hotel Melia Las Americas was the Sherritt International Corporation, a Toronto mining company whose executives have already been notified that they will not be allowed into the United States because of Sherritt's mining activities in Cuba.
Sherritt did not respond to telephone calls about its interest in the Varadero hotel.

HEADLINE: High-Tech Rubber Hits the Road;
Tire Makers Struggle to Stand Out From the Crowd

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
For the first nine years of its televised life, the Michelin baby did little but look cute as it frolicked around a tire. That was plenty: even competitors concede the cuddly tyke made Michelin's name synonymous with tire safety.
Last year, though, the baby began sharing center stage with products and technology. Dressed in safari garb, it watched a sport utility vehicle negotiate a rocky desert terrain -- the first Michelin baby ad that actually demonstrated how tough tires had become. In another commercial, the baby was dressed up as a scientist, and an adult voice-over explained Michelin's latest technology. 
 "We used to be secretive about technology," said Michael W. Cain, Michelin North America's technical-marketing manager. "But now we want to tell all about it."
Tire marketing, which used to seem as bland and predictable as, well, tires, is getting a lot more interesting. Companies that once simply touted the excellence of their tire lines now stress the strengths of specific tire technologies. And they are selecting distinct demographic groups as targets for each of their products, trying to differentiate not only, say, Bridgestone from Goodyear, but Bridgestone's Bridgestone brand from the company's Firestone brand.
It is no easy task. "People identify with their cars, but most of them can't even tell you what kind of tires they have," said Peter J. Tate, chief operating officer of DDB Needham New York, Michelin's advertising agency.
Apparently, the decades and dollars the tire companies have spent fine-tuning their products so that even the cheapest tires perform adequately have worked as much against them as for them. Consumers are now pretty certain that whatever they buy will be safe and durable. And, since they never found buying tires much fun to begin with, many of them simply lump tires together as those indistinguishable black things that their cars ride on.
"Judging by the questions we get, most people think a tire is a tire is a tire," said Kristen Karczewski, director of the Tire Industry Safety Council in Washington.
The inevitable result is that brand loyalty has given way to bargain hunting. According to Modern Tire Dealer, some 28 percent of replacement tires sold in this country are private label, and sell for far less than their branded equivalents.
"People who will spend $50 for a restaurant meal are still looking to get four tires for $100," said Saul H. Ludwig, an analyst with McDonald & Company Investments in Cleveland.
The bargain hunters are not necessarily misguided. Consumer Reports, in a lengthy guide to buying tires published in January, conceded that all of the tires scored were "impressive," and that "there wasn't all that much difference, over all, from the best to the worst tires."
Tire companies, of course, dispute that. But most concede that the perception of tires as a commodity product is their fault.
"Our industry has not made consumers understand how unique tires are," said David B. Murtaugh, manager of marketing communications for Michelin North America's Michelin brand in the United States. His competitors agree. "Tires are highly engineered products, but consumers just don't realize that," said Samir F. Gibara, who just succeeded the legendary marketer Stanley Gault as head of Goodyear Tire and Rubber.
Neither do investors. Tire company stocks trade as though tires were cyclical commodities like rubber or chemicals. Their performance generally trails the market. Goodyear's stock, for one, has dropped by more than 5 percent so far this year, while the Dow Jones industrials have advanced slightly more than 6 percent.
Now, the tire companies are trying to heighten the awareness level. Goodyear has blanketed the airwaves with ads for the Aquatred, its wet-weather tire. Michelin is pushing its X One's XSE Technology, which the company says provides wet traction without sacrificing long wear. Bridgestone/Firestone makes similar claims for its Potenza S-02, developed with the company's Uni-T group of technologies.
More than a soupcon of gimmickry has crept in. Goodyear and Bridgestone recently introduced tires with lifetime warranties, knowing full well that most cars are traded in well before their replacement tires wear out. "Consumers see a lifetime warranty as an indication of the manufacturer's confidence in its product," said Arthur J. Michalik, manager of Bridgestone Consumer Tires Marketing.
Michelin, in contrast, has opted for a six-year warranty, because "consumers find a finite warranty a lot more credible," Mr. Cain said.
But why is all this marketing savvy appearing now?
First off, tire research has yielded some gems. Just three decades ago most tires were held together with cotton cords and lasted less than 10,000 miles. But with the switch to steel-belted radial tires made of more durable rubber compounds, tires typically last five times as long.
Most tire companies have developed low-friction tread designs that make the engine work less to turn the wheels and thus promote fuel economy. Several have attacked the wet-weather skidding problem. The tread design of Goodyear's Aquatred, for example, shoots water out the grooves, rather than letting it accumulate. Similarly, Michelin's X One has wide, deep grooves that wrap straight around the tire to maximize water removal, as well as lateral grooves that scoop up water.
Bridgestone's Uni-T technologies include a new bead -- the part that holds the tire to the wheel -- that lets tires fit tighter and vibrate less, as well as a process to produce a reinforcing material known as carbon black particles in chains instead of clusters, which Bridgestone says enhances wear resistance.
And most companies say they can blend their best tires' attributes, so that consumers do not have to choose between a tire that takes corners well and one that gives the smoothest ride, for example, but can get both in the same package.
The companies have also speeded up the transfer of new technology to the marketplace. Their researchers, marketers and production people now collaborate on products from their inception, and use computers to fine-tune ideas. The result? The time it takes to get a new tire to market has been halved at Michelin, to a little over two years. Goodyear says it can now do the start-to-finish process in 15 months.
"It takes less than two years to get a car to market, so we can certainly do it with a tire," Mr. Gibara said.
Tire distribution has changed as well. Goodyear, which used to sell only through its own dealers, now competes with other brands at Sears. Firestone owns 1,500 stores, but also sells through independent dealers and mass merchandisers.
The companies have had no choice but to add outlets. "People used to buy tires from the man they sat next to at church," said Anne S. Evans, president of the International Tire Association in Farmington, Conn. "Now there's no dealer loyalty."
And, industry consolidation has meant intensified competition among fewer companies. Japan's Bridgestone bought Firestone Tire and Rubber in 1988; Modern Tire Dealer says the two brands together control 12 percent of the replacement tire market. France's Michelin, which owns B. F. Goodrich and Uniroyal, has a 15 percent share. Goodyear, the leader in North America, has 16 percent. Together, the Big Three control 43 percent of the market.
The combined companies have deep advertising pockets. Last year Firestone participated in the Indianapolis 500 for the first time in two decades, as part of Bridgestone's attempt to give a lift to the flagging brand. Apparently it worked: Firestone's higher-priced performance tires now make up 25 percent of Firestone's unit sales, up from 15 percent in 1993. On Aug. 1, Firestone will start broadcasting commercials that talk about the transfer of tire technology from the Indianapolis 500 to passenger vehicles.
But the mergers have brought an interesting problem: companies that once competed are now part of the same corporate family, and must not eat into each other's sales.
"We had to get our brands to complement each other," said Mr. Michalik, who says that ads for the Firestone brand are aiming at Goodyear's value-conscious customers, while the higher-end Bridgestone brand is going after Michelin.
Similarly, Michelin is aiming its Michelin brand at owners of expensive cars; it pitches its B. F. Goodrich brand to young men who like speed, and it just started heavily advertising its Uniroyal brand's durability to older bargain hunters.
"We are very cognizant that our brands could cannibalize each other, so we're letting each stake out its own turf," said John T. Hargrave, director of marketing communications for all of Michelin's brands.
All of these factors, combined with software that makes it easy to animate technological ideas, would probably have spurred a marketing renaissance on their own. But the seminal change in the tire industry came from a person. Stanley Gault, the Rubbermaid Corporation's former chief executive-cum-marketing guru, became Goodyear's chief executive in June of 1991. Tire marketing has not been the same since.
"Stan Gault brought a marketing and product perspective that wasn't there before," said Stephen E. Brown, general manager of J. Walter Thompson Detroit, which handles the Goodyear account.
Indeed, soon after Mr. Gault arrived at Goodyear, he hustled the Aquatred into the market amid a promotional blitz. The brand became synonymous with wet-road safety -- even though Michelin had a wet-road tire first. "What good is having a great tire if you don't tell people about it?" asked Stephen Girsky, a tire industry analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company.
Mr. Gault quickly found ways to let Goodyear's different brands play off each other's strengths. The company now has Aquatred versions of the Eagle (its highest-end tire), the Wrangler (for light trucks) and, most recently, the Aquatred II, an "improved" Aquatred.
Of course, Goodyear's consumer-products-type marketing has left the company vulnerable to consumer-products-type mistakes. A few years ago, Goodyear retired its Arriva tire, a steady seller, because "there was nothing new and exciting about it," a Goodyear spokesman recalled. Customers protested, and Goodyear reintroduced the tire in the line it sells through Sears.
Classic Coke, anyone?

HEADLINE: Frederick J. Stock, 88, Pharmaceutical Executive

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Frederick J. Stock, a pharmaceutical-industry executive who supervised the nation's large-scale production of penicillin and other "miracle drugs" during World War II, died Tuesday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 88 years old.
Mr. Stock, who earned a degree in pharmacy from Purdue University, West Lafayette, Ind., in 1928, was manager of the prescription departments of the Walgreen Corporation drug-store chain when American industry mobilized for war in 1941. He was assigned to the Office of Production Management, a unit of the War Production Board, and later was named chief of the office's drug branch. 
 In that role, Mr. Stock supervised the large-scale production of penicillin and sulfa drugs, the first of the stream of wonder drugs that would revolutionize the postwar treatment of infectious diseases. He was also responsible for the allocation of drugs between the military and civilian markets, as consumer demand for the precious new medicines quickly outstripped supply in the constrained wartime economy.
In early 1944, with penicillin supplies still inadequate, Mr. Stock led the War Production Board's effort to encourage drug companies, normally competitors, to share patents and research technology with each other so that production of the new drug could be increased. In 1949, Purdue awarded him an honorary degree in recognition of his wartime contributions to pharmacy.
After the war, Mr. Stock joined Charles Pfizer & Company as it made its entry into the prescription drug field. While there, he oversaw the company's global introduction of the early antibiotic Terramycin. In 1952, he joined the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation, and stayed on after its merger with E. R. Squibb & Company, from which he retired as senior vice president and general manager in 1972. In 1989, Squibb merged with Bristol-Myers to form the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company.
Mr. Stock also served as a trustee of the Hudson River Museum, an officer of the Yonkers Historical Society and a governor of Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville.
He is survived by his wife, Margaret Wilson Stock of Bronxville; two daughters, Suzanne Macdonald of Villanova, Pa., and Carol Mahony of Edina, Minn. and Vero Beach, Fla.,; 10 grandchildren, and 6 great-grandchildren. A son, Frederick J. Stock Jr., a former executive of the New York Stock Exchange, and three grandchildren died in 1973.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Retreat As Fed Stance Is Reassessed

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Treasury market retreated yesterday as investors reassessed the views of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, on the economy and concluded interest rates were likely to inch up soon.
Treasury prices rallied on Thursday after Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee that he expected economic growth to slow this year, which would forestall the need for higher interest rates. Yet the Fed chairman also warned that the central bank might have to raise interest rates anyway to insure a slowdown, and it was that view that was the focus of attention in the market yesterday. 
 "People thought about the testimony and felt Greenspan indicated he is ready to tighten credit," said James Padinha, an economist with the analytical firm of MMS International. He said several of Mr. Greenspan's comments gave a clear hint that short-term interest rates would soon rise.
"Greenspan said, 'The timing and extent of that downshift are uncertain,' " said Mr. Padinha, who stressed that recent economic data did not show the kind of slowdown the Fed had earlier forecast.
 In addition to renewed speculation over an increase in interest rates, many market participants decided to take profits on Thursday's rally ahead of next week's sales of new two-year and five-year notes.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 21/32 , to 8727/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.98 percent, from 6.92 percent on Thursday. Prices of shorter-term maturities also fell, with the yield on the two-year note rising to 6.20 percent, from 6.13 percent on Thursday.
Traders said bonds were also under pressure from talk that a consulting firm based in Washington was telling its subscribers that the markets had misread Mr. Greenspan's testimony.
"They are saying it is surprising how markets rallied on Greenspan's testimony on Thursday because nothing he said ruled out a tightening," one dealer said.
In any case, the market yesterday was clearly re-evaluating the inflation threat and the chance of the Fed responding with higher interest rates.
"The Fed always believes in the importance of keeping inflation down, as it should," said Alan S. Blinder, a former vice chairman of the Fed.
Mr. Blinder, now an economics professor at Princeton University, said Mr. Greenspan's testimony reflected a shift at the Fed regarding the risks to the economy: from fears of a recession earlier this year to the need for heightened vigilance on inflation.
"I don't believe there has been any fundamental change of views, but an evolution, yes, rather than a big change," Mr. Blinder said.
Among economic data yesterday, the University of Michigan said that its preliminary July index of consumer sentiment stood at 93, compared with 92.4 for June, traders said. The university's survey is issued only to subscribers.
Signs of consumers' ability and willingness to spend are important in determining the direction of the economy since consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of growth.

HEADLINE: Colorado Booms, and Some Worry

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: DENVER, July 19

 BODY:
With 600 head of Santa Gertrudis cattle grazing on 4,000 acres of grass dotted with ponderosa pine, Cherokee Ranch is a Charles Russell tableau, squeezed into a 1990's frame.
"Some of the new houses come right up to the barbed wire," said Tweet Kimball, the ranch's owner, who in recent years has watched neighboring ranches fall one by one below the bulldozers of Highlands Ranch, the fastest-growing suburb in the United States. 
 Of the nation's 30 fastest-growing counties in the first half of the 1990's, 11 were in Colorado, according to figures released recently by the Census Bureau. Six are within 75 miles of Denver, including the two fastest growing, the affluent southern suburbs of Douglas and Elbert.
Indeed, with the state's population jumping by 15 percent since 1990, growth usually outstrips crime as the No. 1 concern of Colorado poll respondents. They say scenic countryside is disappearing and traffic building.
In Douglas, only four miles north of Mrs. Kimball's pastures, construction workers are furiously hammering copper-clad roofs, preparing for the opening next month of Colorado's largest shopping center, Park Meadows. Situated at the junction of two Interstate highways, the shopping center has 100 stores, 7,200 parking spaces and a Rocky Mountain lodge motif, including timber ceilings.
With the mall already 93 percent leased, Park Meadows is part of a wider boom enveloping metropolitan Denver, home to slightly more than half of Colorado's 3.8 million people. Around the area, builders are breaking ground or obtaining financing for 9 indoor skating rinks, 17 hotels, 23 golf courses and the first speculative office buildings since the oil boom collapse of the early 1980's.
"Denver is a terrific city," said Hanna R. Smith, a 22-year-old corporate publicist who moved here last year from Rochester. "I can walk anywhere downtown; the bar scene is very friendly."
Saying that two friends from college stopped here for a weekend on their way to Seattle, Ms. Smith added, "They drove to Seattle, turned around and came back here to live."
Housing costs have responded to the growth. So far in the 1990's, housing prices in the Denver area have jumped 50 percent, a rise that is second only to that of Salt Lake City for the nation's 50 largest metropolitan areas. Colorado Springs, the state's second-largest city, ranked second among smaller cities nationwide for price increases in single-family houses. Tucson, Ariz., was first.
Colorado has boomed in the past -- with gold in the 1860's, silver in the 1880's, military spending in World War II, and oil and gas in the late 1970's. Each boom has also been followed by a bust.
This time, many analysts say, the state has diversified enough to avoid being dragged down by the crash of one sector or commodity.
Philip M. Burgess, president of the Center for the New West, a study group here, said: "The energy boom camouflaged the six new pillars of the Colorado economy: telecommunications, high technology, recreation, real estate, a transportation hub, and a regional trade center. The economic base of the state has become very broad."
Greater Denver, for example, now has the nation's largest concentration of cable television company headquarters. And since 1990 the city has become a regional center of the mutual fund industry, with the assets of portfolios managed by mutual funds based in Denver jumping to $50 billion from $5 billion.
What is happening here is part of a larger Western trend away from resource-based economies like ranching, mining and logging. Once addicted to oil and gas, Denver now has less than 1 percent of its work force employed by energy companies. Statewide, employment in the military industry has fallen by half from a recent peak of 9 percent of the labor force.
In contrast to the painful closings of military bases in some parts of the nation, the closing last year of Lowry Air Force Base east of Denver brought immediate plans from developers to build two golf courses and 350 houses on the site.
Flexing its international muscles, Colorado last year exported $4.7 billion in manufactured products, slightly more than the state's total output from ranches and farms. Since 1992, the state's international exports have grown by 80 percent, the fastest for any state.
"Colorado has a well-disguised technology base," said Morgan Smith, director of the state's International Trade Office. "We're exporting medical, computer and tele comunications equipment, as well as environmental cleanup technologies."
Always strong in recreational tourism, Colorado is undergoing about $1 billion in long-term investment in ski resorts, largely at Keystone and Vail.
Colorado's varied economic base has also brought lower unemployment in the 1990's than the national average. In recent years, unemployment here has averaged one or two percentage points below the national average. Last year, Colorado's job growth was 4.7 percent, double the national average.
After losing population in the late 1980's, Colorado has gained population at triple the national average since 1990. The 450,000 increase in the state's population since 1990 is largely the result of people moving here. Many people take pay cuts to do so.
"I know one woman in property management who took $26,000 as a starting salary here, when she had been making $45,000 in Los Angeles," said Lisa Hein, who works with Preferred Leads, a Denver employment agency. "Most of the reasoning we hear is for the quality of life here."
Even with housing prices, the cost of living here remains lower than in cities like Boston and Los Angeles.
Low crime rates are also attracting new residents.
Ringing Denver, the suburban counties of Arapahoe, Boulder, Douglas Jefferson Counties are home to 1.3 million people. In the first half of the year, six homicides were registered in the four-county area. On an annual basis, that would be slightly less the 1994 rate for Japan of 10 homicides per 1 million inhabitants.
Even in the city of Denver, where 33 homicides were recorded in the same period, concern about crime is low. "Sylvie, just leave your purse in the car," Ty Jurras, a former Los Angeles resident, shouted to his wife one recent evening as they prepared to leave a city parking lot to attend a two-hour play.
It is the crowded highways that have become the bane of many residents. Every weekday morning long lines of traffic snake out of the mountain suburbs, causing commuting times to lengthen each year. Forsaking the Westerner's traditional attachment to the steering wheel, a quarter of all people who work in downtown Denver now commute by bus or rail.
"I don't want the Front Range to become one solid city," Gov. Roy Romer, a Democrat, said in a recent interview, referring to a 160-mile corridor from Fort Collins to Pueblo. Running along the eastern edge of the Rockies, this stretch of plains and hills is home to about 80 percent of the state's population.
"Don't let the cities grow together," the Governor said. "Keep some space; keep some cornfields."
This November, several towns are expected to vote on proposals to restrict the number of building permits granted annually. In Golden, a western neighbor of Denver, officials operating under tight new curbs voted by residents will issue only 71 permits for new homes this year, down from 275 last year.
Hoping to preserve open spaces and to curb strip-mall development, Coloradans voted in 1994 to funnel all profits from the state lottery -- about $40 million a year -- to Great Outdoors Colorado, a public entity that buys land threatened by commercial development.
At Cherokee Ranch, Mrs. Kimball has set up a foundation to keep the land as wild as when she bought it in 1954. On the far side of her fences, the Highlands Ranch development has grown to 33,000 residents from 4,000 in 1984. In 25 years, developers project it will have 96,000 inhabitants.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The two fastest-growing counties in the United States in the first half of the decade are near Denver. One of them is Douglas, where a nearby 100-store shopping center and new houses reflect the suburb's affluence. (Ellen Jaskol for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Keeping Track: Rapid Growth in Colorado" shows the location of the fast growing counties in Colorado. (Census Bureau)

HEADLINE: INSIDE

 BODY:

Growing Divisions in Mexico
An economic crisis is exaggerating an already wide income gap between rich and poor and giving rise to startling contrasts and clashes. Page 3.
 
 
Teachers for Newark

HEADLINE: Stocks Finish Busiest Week With 37.36 Drop in Dow

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks ended lower yesterday, capping the busiest week of trading in Wall Street history and one of the most volatile, as investors fretted anew about corporate earnings.
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 37.36 points, closing at 5,426.82. For the week, it was down 83.74 points. 
 Volume was active once again on the New York Stock Exchange at 408.1 million shares. For the week, Big Board volume totaled 2.49 billion shares, passing the previous weekly volume record of 2.30 billion set Oct. 19-23, 1987, when the market crashed.
"I'm glad this week is over," Hildegard Zagorski, an analyst at Prudential Securities, said yesterday. "It was a wild week, with lots of gyrations -- quite dramatic, quite scary -- and lots of programs. Today was a cautious regrouping day."
Analysts said yesterday's trading was also affected by the double-witching expirations of the July Standard & Poor's 100 index options and the July S.& P. 500 index options.
Stocks were depressed early this week by heightened concern that earnings for the latest quarter would be weaker than expected. But by midweek, the market snapped back on bargain-hunting that was induced by some solid earnings reports.
The rally was also aided by testimony in Congress this week by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. Traders took his remarks as an indication that the central bank did not plan to raise interest rates right away. But the earnings fears flared again yesterday, mostly in the technology stocks.
The Nasdaq Composite index, which is heavy with technology stocks, fell 12.14 points, to 1,097.68.
Netscape fell 3 1/2, to 53, after rising 31/16 on Thursday. It reported second-quarter operating profits just 1 cent above analysts' expectations.
Iomega lost 5 1/2, to 22 1/2, topping the Nasdaq actives list. It also reported quarterly results that beat the analysts' consensus by 1 cent, but some traders were hoping for stronger results.
"By and large, earnings have been coming in fine," said Phil Orlando, chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management.
Of the 222 companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 index that have reported results so far, 57 percent had positive surprises, 27 percent negative surprises and 17 percent were on target, according to IBES, which tracks corporate results.
Key companies reporting next week include I.B.M., Microsoft, Compaq and big oil companies.
Airline stocks were weaker in the aftermath of the T.W.A. 747 crash off Long Island. Mr. Orlando said that shares were pressured by concerns that international travel may fall and security costs for carriers may rise. AMR, parent of American Airlines, fell 2 3/8, to 78 3/4; UAL, parent of United Airlines, 1 1/2, to 46 1/4; Delta Air Lines 2 1/8, to 72 3/4, and Trans World Airlines 3/4, to 9 1/2.
Sunbeam soared 6 1/8, to 18 5/8. Late on Thursday, the company said it had named Albert Dunlap, who has a reputation for being an aggressive cost-cutter and was formerly chairman of Scott Paper, as chairman and chief executive.
Gillette rose 2 1/2, to 63, on stronger-than-expected quarterly earnings and news that its Russian joint venture had acquired a Russian maker of double-edge blades under the Sputnik brand name.
The Big Board composite index fell 2.19 points, to 342.91; the S.& P. 500 index fell 4.83, to 638.73, and the American Stock Exchange market value index fell 2.87, to 548.76.

HEADLINE: Judge Clears Accord on Class-Action Suit Against Archer Daniels

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 19

 BODY:
A Federal judge gave final approval today to a $45 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit accusing the Archer Daniels Midland Company and its competitors of fixing prices for the animal feed supplement lysine.
The action came despite the refusal of an Archer Daniels executive to testify. 
 United States District Judge Milton Shadur shared the concerns of the settlement's critics, who complained that Archer Daniels, which is based in Decatur, Ill., and its competitors had provided little documentation to show if and how much customers were bilked. But Judge Shadur added, "Is anyone obligated to put their neck in a noose?"
Kenneth Adams, a lawyer who represents some of the 33 parties that opted out of the settlement, said an appeal was possible.
Terrence Wilson, head of the Archer Daniels corn processing division, was called to testify about the company's lysine pricing but asserted his right against self-incrimination and did not appear.
The Justice Department currently plans to disclose the scope of its criminal investigation into the Archer Daniels lysine deals in September, according to law enforcement sources and people familiar with the case. Federal prosecutors have told Michael Andreas, an Archer Daniels vice president, and Mr. Wilson that they will be indicted as early as September.
Judge Shadur said, taking all the factors together, that the proposed settlements were "fair, reasonable and adequate, which is the ultimate determination."
Archer Daniels will pay $25 million to settle complaints that it manipulated the market for lysine, an amino acid that speeds muscle growth in animals. In addition, the American units of Japan's Ajinomoto Company and Kyowa Hakko Ltd., both major distributors of lysine, are to pay $10.2 million each, bringing the total to more than $45 million. A fourth company, Sewon America, did not settle; the class-action case against it continues.
The parties not in the settlement, including the multibillion-dollar agricultural cooperative Farmland Industries, are likely to file new lawsuits against the companies, Mr. Adams, the lawyer, said. Purina Mills Inc., which purchased about a third of the lysine during the reported price-fixing period, had already filed a separate lawsuit.
In court, Mr. Adams presented a study by a Purdue University agricultural economist who estimated lysine buyers were cheated out of as much as $180 million because of price-fixing that took place from 1992 through 1995.
But Judge Shadur argued the numbers were flawed. He said they overestimated the length of the period of price-fixing, basing his conclusion on published interviews of Mark Whitacre, an Archer Daniels executive who secretly taped meetings for the F.B.I. where the reported price-fixing took place. The judge also said that the market price of lysine would normally be higher than the Purdue study because the lysine market was not a highly competitive market as the study had assumed.
Settlement of the lysine civil case came with unusual speed; such antitrust lawsuits often take years to wind their way through the courts.

HEADLINE: Income Gap in Mexico Grows, and So Do Protests

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TEPOZTLAN, Mexico

 BODY:
One simmering Sunday in May, a hundred peasant farmers stormed a luxurious hillside mansion here and, in a scene out of an old newsreel of the 1910 Revolution, pounded on the gates with machetes and their clenched fists until the wealthy owners abandoned their brunch and fled.
Peasants now stand guard at the exclusive grounds about 35 miles south of Mexico City. They have painted "House of the People" on the imposing wooden doors, but they still find themselves ogling such luxuries as the artificial lake just inside the gates and the mounted bison head on the warehouse wall. 
 "The only thing that one can feel is embittered," said Guillermo Noriega Garcia, 56, a farmer who took part in the assault on the 20-acre estate that stands in the middle of parched subsistence farms. "How can it be that one man has everything and others don't even have water?"
The episode is just one sign of how the current economic crisis has deepened already serious divisions in Mexico. It has exaggerated the gap not only between rich and poor, but also between the industrialized north and the rural south, between Spanish-speaking Mexicans and the 10 million who are Indians and between those whose lives are increasingly tied to the United States economy and those who are entirely dependent on the fortunes of Mexico.
The degree of income disparity in Mexico is among the worst in the world and is steadily growing more extreme. Excluding African countries, Mexico has the largest gap between rich and poor of all but six nations in the world, United Nations and World Bank figures show.
Today the richest 10 percent of Mexicans earn 41 percent of the country's income, while the bottom half of the population receives only 16 percent of all national income. The Government admits that the number of Mexicans living in extreme poverty has grown to 22 million, an increase over the last 15 months of 5 million people.
The growing gap has given rise to many clashes and to startling contrasts throughout Mexico. On the outskirts of the wealthy northern city of Monterrey, residents of a shantytown recently stopped a freight train in the dead of night. Officials say the train was disabled when it slowed down to go through the area. When word got out that the train carried tons of corn, whole families rushed out to fill pots and sacks full of grain.
On the other hand, as the Mexican market for bargain-priced Volkswagen Beetles dried up in 1995, Mercedes-Benz sales actually rose. This year, as the worst economic crisis in 60 years continues, the car maker is on target to sell 50 percent more cars in Mexico than last year.
A few large Mexican companies benefited handsomely when Mexico entered the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994 and when the devaluation of the peso in December of that year made Mexican exports cheaper. But business leaders say 17,000 companies have folded since the crisis began. While a second Gucci boutique recently opened in the swank Polanco section of Mexico City, a United Nations report said the number of children who live and work on the streets of the capital has doubled in three years.
The polarization between classes in Mexico is a "historic problem that is always present but never resolved," the historian Lorenzo Meyer wrote. Mexico now faces severe political and economic problems, but the most serious crisis, he wrote, "is the enormous distance and antagonism between the classes and groups that form the Mexican social fabric."
One factor aggravating the tensions is the insistence by the Government of President Ernesto Zedillo, like the Governments of his two predecessors, on pursuing an economic policy of privatizations, free markets and integration into the global economy. Such a policy is endorsed by the United States and the International Monetary Fund, but it has failed to raise the standard of living for most Mexicans.
Big gains in real wages and economic growth from 1963 to 1984 were wiped out as the previous two presidents religiously followed their open-market policies. Real wages today are below what they were in 1981. The debacle of Mr. Zedillo's first 18 months in office only worsens that record.
Criticism of the economic model is widespread. "An absolute and total disaster," said Vicente Fox, an opposition-party Governor from the central state of Guanajuato. Even Mr. Zedillo has called for a public debate about Mexico's economic direction.
But alternatives are scarce. Beyond some technical tinkering, the only consensus so far has been that the economic modernization of Mexico should be more humane -- which in most cases means more direct Government intervention to help small- and medium-sized manufacturers stand up to the competition.
Although the class gap in Mexico has deepened, the political scientist Jorge G. Castaneda believes that there is little danger of social conflict. The reason is the substantial and growing number of Mexicans whose lives are tied to the United States economy.
Those Mexicans, Mr. Castaneda says, include both rich exporters and the poor farmhands who cross the border and send home their earnings. What they have in common is dependence on the American economy, which buffers the shocks of Mexico's economic problems.
"A nationwide social explosion, such as the Revolution of 1910, is virtually impossible while such a large, regionally well-distributed, broadly based segment of the population is thriving," Mr. Castaneda wrote recently in Foreign Affairs magazine.
Others believe that the danger of a spark to set off social revolt is actually much greater. Manuel Camacho Solis, the former Mayor of Mexico City who broke ranks with the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party and is now part of a developing alternative political force, said in an interview that recent polls showed 22 percent of the capital's residents believe that violence is justified to correct social imbalances -- a figure far higher than at any time in the last decade. Recently, public schoolteachers demanding a living wage paralyzed the city with demonstrations that at times turned violent.
"It doesn't take 50 percent of the population to make the country ungovernable," Mr. Camacho said. "If just 5 percent take to the streets, that could be enough."
It was a comparatively small band of guerrillas in Chiapas who in January 1994 shocked Mexico with an insurrection that is still not resolved. And in June, as few as 50 masked men, and perhaps a few women, declared themselves another revolutionary army. That was enough to send shivers down the spines of many Government officials.
Recent incidents have worried many in Mexico because they seem to reflect a loss of respect for the rule of law and a frightening lack of Government control. The train robbery near Monterrey was reminiscent of the 1910 Revolution, when peasants routinely assaulted trains.
But in the modern version, the attackers included children and housewives like Argelia Espinosa, who was almost arrested for trying to bring home a bushel of corn. "We would have milled the corn and used it to make tamales and tortillas," said the 37-year-old woman, whose husband, Alberto, was arrested with a sack full of corn on his shoulder. "It wouldn't have gone to waste."
For the Rev. Rodolfo Reyes, a local priest, the assault was a manifestation of Mexico's smoldering economic and social crisis. "I see it as a sign that says 'Hey, be careful,' " he said.
In June, in a similar episode, a train full of wheat was sacked in the state of Durango.
The assault on the Tepoztlan mansion roused fears that have haunted wealthy Mexicans since the Revolution, when peasants banged on the doors of big haciendas demanding the return of the land to the people.
The mansion, called La Quinta Piedra, is owned by Guillermo de Jesus Occelli, the brother-in-law of former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. Mr. Occelli says he bought the 20 acres legitimately. But for the last five years, local people have insisted that the transactions were fraudulent and that the land, like much of the land in Mexico since the Revolution, belongs to the community.
This is an old battle here, where Emiliano Zapata began his struggle for liberty and land at the beginning of this century.
The peasants here finally decided this year that they had had enough. After meeting in a general assembly on May 12, they made their way to the huge front gate of the Occelli estate, peasant leaders said. Inside, the family was enjoying a Sunday brunch. Some peasants banged on the door with machetes. One may even have tried to start a fire, a newspaper account said.
The gates eventually lumbered open, and the family and guests rushed off, peasant leaders said. For the first time, local peasants passed through the great doors and gawked at the splendor they had until then only imagined. People who lived four or six to a room wandered wide-eyed through the house and past a dining room table large enough to accommodate a dozen people. Peasants who rely on water from a tanker truck during the dry season stared at the hotel-sized pool and the fountains that seemed capriciously to splash water everywhere.
The peasants say they now have a list of other property holders in the area who, they contend, also bought land illegally. What happened at La Quinta Piedra ought to be taken as a warning, they say. What started as a land dispute has turned into an open struggle between rich and poor.
"We tried to talk to the rich people, but they never paid attention to us," said Nicanor Demesa Ortiz, who took part in the takeover. "But what we did here was to show that no one, no matter how powerful or influential, is immune to the power of the people or to what is right."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;
Dole Holds His Tongue, But Strain Is Showing

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, July 19

 BODY:
Bob Dole is striving these days to curb the unscripted remarks that have distracted his Presidential campaign, but it became clear this week that the switch might not be so easy. The former Senate majority leader spent his career fielding questions, and he is now responding to the silence imposed on him by his campaign with a collection of shrugs, grins, grimaces and grunts.
"No comment, no comment," Mr. Dole said the other day, arching his eyebrows and casting his eyes upward to the boom mikes and the heavens above, struggling to ignore questions about his view of reports of past drug use by some White House employees. "I've taken my vow of silence." 
 This is not the first time that Mr. Dole's campaign aides have tried to encourage him not to answer passing questions, concerned that his off-the-cuff remarks -- as when he compared the dangers of tobacco to those of drinking milk -- might be hazardous to the campaign's health. And it seemed -- at first, at least -- that it might work this time.
Mr. Dole ignored questions yelled at him at a photo session in Washington early this week. Moments later, as he left the lunch, members of his staff swiftly roped off reporters on one side of the sidewalk. Using a network of walkie-talkies, they maneuvered Mr. Dole out the farthest door and into his waiting car.
On this trip through the Midwest, Mr. Dole heeded the pleas of his staff and never ventured to the back of the plane, where the press sits. That was a change of habit for the passenger in the first-class cabin, who often sits alone and is known to wander back to chat whenever he grows bored or restless.
But the wall shows signs of cracking. When Mr. Dole was asked the other day whether his silence reflected a new campaign gambit, his eyes lit up. He raised a hand to his mouth and pinched his lips together. That was taken as a yes. And as the week went on, the candidate, in ignoring questions, took on the look of a schoolboy forced to eat his peas.
By today, Mr. Dole could barely restrain himself, communicating with his gestures a sort of detached bemusement at the whole exercise. When a television correspondent yelled a question to Mr. Dole about why he was not answering questions, the candidate raised an eyebrow, tilted his head to the right, put a hand to his mouth, grinned -- and then, resisting temptation one more time, headed for his plane. Even Mr. Dole's staff took that as a sign that his "vow of silence" would not hold for long.
Friendly Criticism
Mr. Dole learned again this week that yesterday's political rivals do not necessarily make for today's political friends. He spent much of this week pushing his school voucher program at parochial schools, including a speech here today at St. Rocco Church. To bolster his case, he brought along two former Secretaries of Education, Lamar Alexander and William J. Bennett. Mr. Bennett was chairman of Mr. Alexander's failed campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination that Mr. Dole is presumed to have won, and he was one of the earliest Republicans to criticize Mr. Dole's campaign publicly.
Mr. Bennett is also one of the leading advocates of Mr. Dole's adopted school voucher program. While Mr. Bennett gamely stayed at Mr. Dole's side this week and talked up the merits of the policy, it was clear that he remains less than enthusiastic about the course that Mr. Dole's campaign has taken. The differences could not have been more apparent than in how they reacted to reports of past drug use by some White House employees.
Mr. Bennett rushed out to seek reporters to condemn the news. "You don't inhale, you get a job in the White House," Mr. Bennett said. "You do inhale, you get a job in the White House."
Mr. Dole dealt with the same subject with a fleeting allusion, hidden in an introduction of Mr. Bennett, that was no doubt lost to most in his audience at the Cardinal Stritch College in Milwaukee.
"Bill Bennett, former Secretary of Education, drug czar," Mr. Dole said. "Lots of news about drugs in the paper today." And that was that.
Mr. Bennett showed concern that Mr. Dole was emphasizing economic issues in his campaign, rather than the social ones that have interested Mr. Bennett.
"I don't think people's concerns about what's wrong with this country are economic," Mr. Bennett said. "They're cultural. Moral. Spiritual."
Mr. Bennett, continuing his gentle critique of Mr. Dole's campaign for reporters in the back of the plane as Mr. Dole remained up front, said: "I don't think we've made our case clearly."
Age as a State of Mind
As Mr. Dole approaches his 73d birthday on Monday, which he will celebrate in Russell, Kan., age seems to be on his mind. Here at St. Rocco Church, Mr. Dole took the opportunity to aim a good-natured joke at his old friend Strom Thurmond, the 93-year-old South Carolina Senator.
"I know you're celebrating your bicentennial," Mr. Dole said, "and I'm sorry Senator Thurmond couldn't be with me because he was here for the first one."
Mr. Thurmond is often a foil for Mr. Dole's jokes about aging, but Mr. Dole, who is bracing for a wave of news coverage this weekend about his age and questions about his fitness, did not leave it at that.
"He's a very unique individual," he said. "If you ever have any doubt about, you think you're getting old, just come up to Washington and follow Senator Thurmond around for a day. Or two. And drink your orange and your grapefruit juice and take your vitamins as he does. And you just keep going on and on and on. Like that little Energizer Bunny."

HEADLINE: TOP BOSNIAN SERB AGREES TO RESIGN

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, July 19

 BODY:
Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb political chief who led his people in a brutal war of ethnic separation, has agreed to give up political power immediately, the special United States envoy, Richard C. Holbrooke, said here today.
The agreement removes an obstacle to September's national elections in Bosnia and Herzegovina and could aid the flagging peace effort by removing from visible public life a man indicted for genocide and other war crimes. 
 But Mr. Holbrooke acknowledged that it fell short of the goal of removing Dr. Karadzic from Bosnia and putting him on trial at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, something Western nations have long demanded.
"This is a minimal acceptable package," Mr. Holbrooke said. Only a few days ago Mr. Holbrooke told Western and Bosnian officials that if Dr. Karadzic did not agree to leave Bosnia, the West would reimpose economic sanctions on Serbia. For now, Dr. Karadzic remains in his mountain hideaway of Pale, near Sarajevo, and the threat of sanctions has withered.
The signed agreement was negotiated with President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, who in turned exerted pressure on the Bosnian Serb leader.
The Bosnian Government and Western officials had considered Dr. Karadzic's presence as head of the major political party in the Serb part of Bosnia, and his control over the police, news media and politics there, as serious obstacles to fair elections.
Still, Dr. Karadzic's hard-line nationalist colleagues remain in power and there is wide suspicion that he will continue to exert influence behind the scenes. Mr. Holbrooke cautioned that in order for the Bosnian elections to be run successfully, the agreement, which was signed by Dr. Karadzic, his replacements in the Bosnian Serb power structure and Mr. Milosevic, had to be "implemented correctly."
In Sarajevo, the news of the agreement was welcomed by the Bosnian Government, which removed itsthreat of boycotting the election if Dr. Karadzic remained in office. Ejup Ganic, the Bosnian Vice President, said Dr. Karadzic's agreement would enhance the prospects of fair elections.
But Mr. Ganic said he remained concerned that Dr. Karadzic, whose campaign posters are plastered all over Serb-held Bosnia, would remain a powerful influence unless he was sent to The Hague.
The international tribunal there says Dr. Karadzic bears responsibility for the Bosnian Serb policy of "ethnic cleansing," in which hundreds of thousands of Muslim civilians were uprooted or killed. In the most notorious case, thousands of Muslim men and boys are believed to have been massacred after the Serbian conquest of the town of Srebrenica last year.
In the agreement, Dr. Karadzic said he had handed over power as president of the self-styled Bosnian Serb republic to Biljana Plavsic, his equally nationalist deputy. Another loyalist, Aleksa Buha, replaces Dr. Karadzic as chairman of the Serb Democratic Party. The one-page agreement, signed Thursday night, also stipulates that Dr. Karadzic will not appear in public or on radio or television -- forums that Dr. Karadzic, a clever propagandist, has used to great effect.
Mr. Holbrooke said there was "no guarantee" that Dr. Karadzic would conform to the intent of the agreement, and suggested it was possible he could remain a strong behind-the-scenes influence.
But the envoy appeared hopeful that the dynamics of Bosnian Serb internal political rivalry combined with Mr. Milosevic's interest in avoiding reimposition of economic sanctions could mean the end of Dr. Karadzic's power.
Early this week Robert Frowick, an American diplomat who is supervising the elections in Bosnia, said Dr. Karadzic's political party could not take part if he did not resign his post. This added to the pressure on Dr. Karadzic to resign.
Today Mr. Holbrooke said that if Dr. Karadzic defied the new agreement, his political party would be banned during the election campaign and that Belgrade would face economic sanctions. He did not spell out what actions would set off these responses.
"As of this morning, Radovan Karadzic is no longer president of Republika Srpska and he has relinquished the office and all powers associated," with it, Mr. Holbrooke, using the Bosnian Serbs' name for their breakaway region, said at a news conference this morning after 10 hours of talks.
"I want to stress he knew what he was signing," Mr. Holbrooke said. "He knew he was signing the end of his political career."
To insure that Dr. Karadzic signed the agreement, which was faxed to him in Pale, the Bosnian Serbs' headquarters, Mr. Milosevic's chief of state security, Jovica Stanisic, was dispatched to Pale by helicopter Thursday night as a witness, Mr. Holbrooke said.
Mr. Stanisic, one of Mr. Milosevic's most trusted operatives, returned after midnight to Mr. Milosevic's Belgrade residence with the original signed document. Mr. Holbrooke and his team were waiting there with the Serbian President.
Mr. Holbrooke said the most powerful politician in Serb-held Bosnia would now be Momcilo Krajisnik, the president of the Bosnian Serb parliament, who is as much against a multi-ethnic Bosnia as Dr. Karadzic is.
But Mr. Krajisnik is easier for the United States to accept because he is not indicted for war crimes and his candidacy in September as the Bosnian Serb member of the planned tripartite Bosnian presidency does not therefore fly in the face of the Dayton accords.
Mr. Krajisnik has been described as both a rival and an ally of Dr. Karadzic. Mr. Holbrooke appeared to be counting on Mr. Krajisnik's appetite for power to overtake his friendship with Dr. Karadzic.
Dr. Karadzic's replacement, Mrs. Plavsic, who assumes the title of temporary acting president of Republika Srpska, is as defiant about the Dayton, Ohio, peace accords as Dr. Karadzic. But she has not been indicted by The Hague tribunal.
The new head of the Serb Democratic Party, Mr. Buha, is also a hard-liner and loyal to Dr. Karadzic. He is the Bosnian Serbs' "foreign minister," and along with Mr. Krajisnik was present as part of an unofficial Bosnian Serb delegation at the Dayton talks last year. Both men were described as being very angry when Mr. Milosevic, their formal representative at Dayton, showed them the agreement on the closing day in Ohio.
Mr. Holbrooke's two days of negotiations started when he arrived in Belgrade on Wednesday afternoon and told Mr. Milosevic that the Serb Democratic Party would be banned from the Bosnian elections and economic sanctions would be re-imposed on Serbia if Dr. Karadzic was not removed from the political scene.
Further pressure was applied on Dr. Karadzic by the Russians, often an ally of the Serbs. Moscow sent a message to him Thursday night suggesting that he step down, a senior Western diplomat said. The British sent a similar message, the diplomat said.
On the second elusive goal of his negotiations with Mr. Milosevic, the dispatch of Dr. Karadzic to The Hague, Mr. Holbrooke said he faced a stone wall.
Mr. Holbrooke said he informed Mr. Milosevic on Wednesday that Dr. Karadzic and the military leader of the Bosnian Serbs, Gen. Ratko Mladic, who is also indicted for war crimes, "have to go to The Hague." The answer, Mr. Holbrooke said, was: "They won't."
The envoy said there was "no chance" that Mr. Milosevic, whose security police force has heavily infiltrated the Bosnian Serb police and whose Yugoslav National Army formed the backbone of the Bosnian Serb army, would order the arrest of the two leaders.
"If we won't do it with 60,000 troops in the country, why would Milosevic do it and launch a Serb civil war?" Mr. Holbrooke said, referring to the number of NATO-led troops in Bosnia. "There are certain things he won't do."
Mr. Holbrooke's comments appeared to indicate that he believed the only way Dr. Karadzic would end up in The Hague was if he turned himself in or accidentally encountered NATO-led forces and they arrested him. NATO commanders, reflecting political instructions to avoid casualties, say they will not order their troops to search for Dr. Karadzic.
There has been some speculation among Western diplomats that Dr. Karadzic was toying with the idea of turning himself in to the tribunal. Dr. Karadzic is reported to have been paying very close attention to the televised proceedings of the tribunal.
The diplomats point out that Dr. Karadzic has also hired two criminal lawyers from law firms in the United States. These lawyers have been in The Hague monitoring proceedings and attacking the procedures, but they could possibly be sounding out prosecutors on the possibility of a plea bargain, the diplomats said.
General Mladic has become less of a target for Washington because since the signing of the Dayton accords, he has virtually disappeared into his military headquarters in eastern Bosnia and is rarely seen. Mr. Holbrooke apparently believes Dr. Karadzic will follow suit.
