HEADLINE: Drifter Charged in Case That Gay Groups Said Showed Police Bias

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
At first, the killing of Sylvia Lugo seemed to be one of a series of robberies, sexual assaults and beatings of women in the brownstone neighborhoods of Park Slope and Boerum Hill.
But in the following months, the killing took on a wider significance. Groups representing the area's large gay and lesbian population said the failure to find Ms. Lugo's killer reflected the Police Department's laxity in pursuing crimes against lesbians. And they accused the police of downplaying the killing as a crime of passion. 
 Yesterday, a little more than a year after Ms. Lugo's death, the police said they had found the killer, and charged Alex Villanueva, a 19-year-old drifter, with her death, which they said occurred during a push-in robbery, in which the robber forces his way in when the victim opens the door. They also charged him in three other incidents, including the attempted murder and rape of Ms. Lugo's roommate and lover.
The arrest concluded a crime spree by Mr. Villanueva that started at least two years ago, the police said. Police officials would not say how they linked Mr. Villanueva to Ms. Lugo's killing, but they said they broke the case after he was arrested in the March 30 shooting of Gabrielle Kearns in the streets of Fort Greene, Brooklyn, during an attempted robbery.
Yesterday, advocates for gay and lesbian rights continued to criticize the Police Department's handling of the case, saying that it was solved only because the police stumbled onto the confession.
"If the police had, in fact, conducted a thorough investigation and not operated under an assumption they would have caught this man before another innocent person was injured," said Christine Quinn, executive director of the Gay and Lesbian Anti-Violence Project.
The tense relations between some lesbian groups and the police in brownstone Brooklyn stem in part from an earlier incident. In April 1994, a lesbian reported that she was raped in Prospect Park. But a police official suggested that detectives had doubts about her story -- an assertion that was later disavowed by the department.
Police officials strongly denied yesterday that their handling of the investigation into Ms. Lugo's killing reflected any anti-lesbian bias.
"The investigative process is a search for the truth," said Inspector William Taylor, commanding officer of Brooklyn North detectives.
The facts, the police say, were these: On July 5, Sylvia Lugo and her lover arrived home at their Boerum Hill apartment late at night. As they entered, an armed man forced his way inside with them. He shot Ms. Lugo fatally in the head as he was raping her companion, and then, in a struggle for the gun, shot the companion in the leg. He escaped with some jewelry in the couple's rental car, which was later found on a Brooklyn street.
As time passed and it seemed that the police were no closer to making an arrest, some of Ms. Lugo's family publicly accused her lover of being the suspect. Some detectives told reporters that her rape test results were inconclusive, that the bullet wounds to her leg appeared to be self-inflicted and that witnesses had told the police that they heard two or more females arguing loudly but heard no male voice.
"An enormous cloud has been lifted and we are relieved at that," Susan Tipograph, the lawyer for Ms. Lugo's companion, said after the arrest.
Ms. Tipograph said that the woman, a social worker whose identity is being withheld, has been unemployed since the incident, which left her with serious leg injuries.
After Mr. Villanueva was arrested in the case of Ms. Kearns, detectives began to question him as to the possibility of having committed other crimes, a common investigative method. The detectives said he was reluctant at first, but said he would trust them.
"He wrote down everything in his own handwriting and his own words," said one of the detectives, Harry Antoine of the 88th Precinct. "He described locations and addresses and we were able to put everything together through calling the precincts concerned."
Mr. Villanueva also confessed to the killing of Michael Turrell in May 1995 during an attempted robbery at his home, detectives said.
The police have also arrested Malik Torres, 19, and Glenford Richards, 16, both of Brooklyn, in the shooting of Ms. Kearns.

HEADLINE: Newark to Get More Teachers But Fewer Jobs

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: NEWARK, July 19

 BODY:
More than 600 employees of the state-operated school district here will lose their jobs as part of a plan to move money from the central administration to classrooms, state education officials announced today.
Dr. Beverly L. Hall, the Superintendent appointed by the state when it took control of the district last July, said that the job cuts would save $26.3 million that would instead be used to hire more classroom teachers and school security guards, create more full-day kindergarten programs and provide guidance services to all elementary pupils, among other things. She said the reorganization plan "delivers on the promise to put children first," eliminating unnecessary or duplicated jobs and funneling resources into educational programs and staff. 
 Of the 634 jobs to be eliminated -- 7 percent of the school system's total work force of 8,300 -- 124 are administrative and supervisory workers in district headquarters and an additional 317 are cafeteria workers, custodians or school bus attendants.
Although no classroom teachers will be affected, 89 speech specialists and members of child study teams, who evaluate children with disabilities and put them in special education programs, will not have jobs in September. The others are mostly school aides and clerks.
The plan calls for 28 new teaching positions and 80 "school staff development" jobs, which cover such duties as teacher training and curriculum planning.
Joseph DelGrosso, the president of the Newark Teachers' Union, called the plan "unfair and illogical," saying that the people who would be out of work were not the ones who had caused the widespread problems in the school system. He also expressed anger that Dr. Hall had created three new positions, with combined salaries of $210,000, in her own office.
"The vast majority of these people losing work are minority women living here in Newark," Mr. DelGrosso said. "Newark is economically devastated as it is, and now we are putting all these people out on the street with no hope."
Dr. Hall expressed regret about the job losses, but called the streamlining crucial, saying that the Newark district spent far more on cafeteria, custodial and pupil transportation services than was needed.
"It was a difficult decision, but I had to ask what was the mission of this organization," she said in an interview. "The mission is to educate children, and the resources must be directed toward the children and the schools."
The reorganization comes one year after the state seized control of the troubled Newark district, evicting top administrators and the elected school board. State law requires that superintendents in state-operated districts must produce a plan to reorganize the central adminstration within one year of the takeover.
During the last 12 months, Dr. Hall, a former deputy schools chancellor for New York City, has been working with outside consultants to pinpoint areas of waste and develop plans to improve class instruction. In announcing the plan today, she described the system she joined last summer as one in which board members and administrators profited and school children suffered.
"Prior to state intervention, the opulent and excessive world of the adults sharply constrasted with the deprived world of the children," Dr. Hall wrote in a description of the reorganization. She portrayed a system with "abysmally low" test scores, decrepit buildings and an administration that spent lavishly on restaurant meals and conference trips.
The State Education Commissioner, Leo F. Klagholz, said he supported the plan, noting that although Newark spends well above the state average per pupil, it ranks near the bottom in the proportion of money that reaches the classroom.
"One reason the Newark school district experienced decades of failure is that too much of the available resources were spent on a bloated central office bureaucracy," Dr. Klagholz said in a statement.
Dr. Hall said that several top administrative officials, including some on loan from the State Treasury and Education departments, had worked closely with her on the plan. Also, teams of outside consultants studied where money could be saved, and Dr. Hall's plan was based in part on their reports, she said.
Although no classroom teachers will lose their jobs under the plan, Dr. Hall left open the possibility of future cuts. Principals have recommended that certain programs in their schools be added or eliminated, she said, and those suggestions might eventually lead to the loss of classroom jobs. An evaluation of every principal in the district is almost complete, and at least 17 principals who have chosen to retire will be replaced in September, she said.
Phillip Danzig, a senior architect whose job will be eliminated under the plan, said that although some of the cuts sounded reasonable, he was upset that Dr. Hall and her staff had not discussed their strategies with district employees.
"Although on paper they make a lot of sense, they've neglected the human factor of morale," he said.
Dr. Hall said the district was creating a career center to help displaced employees file for unemployment benefits and look for new jobs. Training and counseling will be provided, Dr. Hall said. Although she expected the mood in various school offices to be somber in the coming weeks, she said she did not think it would prevent progress.
"Yes, morale is going to be low and people are going to be sorry this is happening," she said. "But there are people here who knew this had to happen. Our staff will work through it with them, yet set high expectations for them because we still have a big job to do."

HEADLINE: ATLANTA: DAY 1;
Promised Renewal Has Been Less Than Olympian

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 19

 BODY:
In the buoyant, everything-is-possible afterglow of Atlanta's victorious bid for the 1996 Summer Olympics, politicians and planners dreamed of using the Games as leverage to revitalize 15 of the city's most blighted and forgotten neighborhoods.
The Mayor at the time, Maynard H. Jackson Jr., captured the overheated optimism of the day by speaking of "the twin peaks of Atlanta's Mount Olympus," referring to the city's hopes for producing both a magnificent 17-day spectacle and a permanent legacy of civic renewal. 
 But as Atlantans welcome Olympic visitors to town, the second peak looks more like a foothill. An early wish list called for spending more than $500 million to demolish ramshackle houses, repair deteriorating streets and sidewalks, design new parks, install street lights and sewer lines, and build a vast new inventory of affordable housing. Three years later, perhaps a fifth of that amount has been spent, most of it in only five neighborhoods immediately adjacent to Olympic venues.
But while some residents complain about yet another round of broken promises, the modest investments have produced the only improvements seen in some poor, black neighborhoods for decades. In particular, the Summerhill neighborhood, site of a 1966 race riot, has shown signs of rebirth after being devastated in the 1950's by the construction of an interstate highway and then in the 1960's by the erection of the Atlanta-Fulton County baseball stadium.
In some quarters, the freshly poured asphalt and pastel-painted houses have excited hopes that the momentum can continue after the closing ceremony. The changes also have revived some long-lost faith in government.
"It's amazing that you could live in a poor section of town and see this happen that quick," said Moses Steele Jr., a Summerhill resident. "It looks good around here."
But in other areas, the failure to do more has reinforced a deep cynicism about urban renewal in Atlanta, which has the fifth-highest poverty rate among large American cities. And it has raised fears that any progress already made will be squandered once the city loses its Olympian incentives to tidy up for more than 1.4 million house guests.
After all, it was largely the threat of ugly neighborhood protests during the Games that helped persuade city officials to make improvements.
When the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games began discussing a plan to build Centennial Olympic Stadium right next to the baseball stadium, the surrounding neighborhoods mounted protests. The city ultimately bought peace, at least with some neighborhood leaders, by passing a $149 million bond act that provided much of the $76 million spent by the Corporation for Olympic Development in Atlanta, a city agency that made improvements in roads, sidewalks, parks, lighting and sewer systems.
"We didn't necessarily threaten them but we said to them that media people from all over the world would be in Atlanta and we didn't think they would turn their backs on reporting the conditions here," said Douglas Dean, a savvy former state legislator who heads the Summerhill Neighborhood Development Corporation.
Mr. Jackson remembers the message from Mr. Dean and others as being pretty blunt. "I think it was made plain and they meant it," he said. "And who could blame them? If you're going to have a neighborhood invasion and get nothing for it, there are going to be protests."
Mr. Dean, realizing that a second stadium would be built with or without Summerhill's acquiescence, accepted the bargain and began the work of remaking his neighborhood. Other neighborhood leaders never put down their protest placards, and there is now significant tension between the two factions.
"Anytime you go downtown and go behind closed doors and sell peoples out, in my book all you is is an Uncle Tom," said Ethel Mae Mathews, a longtime community activist from the Peoplestown neighborhood. "See, my hand ain't in Mr. Charlie's pocket."
City leaders say they are proud of what they have achieved in Summerhill and Peoplestown and other poor, black neighborhoods such as Mechanicsville, Vine City and the Old Fourth Ward. Their efforts are only disappointing, they say, when measured against the foolishly high expectations set six years ago.
"The expectations after the Games were awarded back in 1990 was that everybody in Atlanta would get a new house, new car, new spouse, new job, that everything would suddenly change," said Mayor Bill Campbell. "And things have changed. It is only that the change has not been perhaps to the degree that everyone thought."
Even Summerhill remains a work in progress. Many of the most dilapidated shotgun shacks have been leveled, but others remain, their windows broken and boarded and their yards invaded by kudzu.
Newly paved streets leading to the stadiums are lined with freshly poured sidewalks and antique street lamps. But they also wind past vacant lots, strewn with garbage and glass, that have been adorned with Olympic plantings of pink begonias.
Seventy-six attractive new townhouses, built by John Wieland, one of the area's most established suburban developers, have been built just around the corner from some of the most decrepit housing in the city. In a neighborhood where tenants are accustomed to paying rents of a few hundred dollars, the Greenlea Commons townhouses are selling for up to $139,900. Sixty-one are sold or under contract, some to white families.
Nearby are 10 new single-family homes in a development called Terry Place, financed by Nationsbank and selling for up to $80,000. "It's the first new housing built in that neighborhood in an awful long time," said Jim Lientz, president of Nationsbank of Georgia. "It's certainly not without risk, but we can't build them fast enough."
In other neighborhoods near Olympic venues, Habitat for Humanity has built 100 houses for low-income residents, and the International Brotherhood of Painters and Allied Trades has painted 250 existing houses without charge.
But few of the newly constructed houses in Summerhill have been purchased by residents of the neighborhood, where the 1990 census showed that 93 percent of the 4,169 residents were black, 87 percent were renters, and the average per capita income was $5,694. Throughout the city, residents of about 150 households have been displaced by Olympic cleanup projects, often to better housing but in unfamiliar neighborhoods.
Gentrification remains a concern for neighborhood residents. But government leaders are more worried about how to maintain the momentum for development once the Olympics leave town.
"How can you keep the sense of urgency going without a date that you can't push back?" asked Richard A. Monteilh, executive director of the Metropolitan Atlanta Olympic Games Authority, a state oversight board. "That's what held us together all this time and that's the challenge that faces us now. My knowledge of human nature says that it's an uphill battle."

Atlanta's Summerhill neighborhood, site of the Olympic Stadium (background), has benefited somewhat from renewal in concert with the Games. (Photographs by Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Field of Visions Is His Dream;
Catskills Man Sees Tourist Draw In World's Largest Kaleidoscope

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: SHANDAKEN, N.Y.

 BODY:
Wading hip-deep in the sparkling Esopus Creek, two men cast delicate trout flies into green swirling pools. In a forested retreat in the woods nearby, Zen Buddhists meditate.
A hundred yards away, inside a former grain silo painted with blue sky, white clouds and a pair of eyes, 12 tourists stand in darkness and throbbing music and stare up at a seemingly levitating orb of swirling patterns, including images of crouching American Indians, past presidents and marijuana leaves. 
 In the hills and valleys around the counterculture haven of Woodstock, almost anything goes. Even, with some grumbling, a walk-in kaleidoscope.
The psychedelic silo, billed as the world's largest example of the familiar tubular toy, opened earlier this month as the highlight of a new complex that combines elements of an art gallery, curio shop and restaurant and is aimed at revitalizing the sleepy tourism industry along the main corridor into New York's Catskill Park.
"It's amazing," said Norman Tecker, a visitor from Philadelphia who noticed the oddly decorated silo while driving along Route 28 with his wife, Edith. They paid $5 each for a 10-minute 13-second visual and sonic journey through American history, as interpreted by local artists and musicians.
"This comes right out of that movie," Mr. Tecker said, referring to "Field of Dreams." "Build it and they will come."
That was certainly the goal of Dean Gitter, the Catskills developer behind the $3 million complex, called Catskill Corners. Mr. Gitter, long considered by neighbors as something of a local P. T. Barnum, owns almost a mile of frontage on both Route 28 and the adjacent Esopus Creek.
Mr. Gitter said he believes that the only hope for reviving the local economy, which is reeling from 13 percent unemployment, lies in tourism. About 70 percent of Shandaken is taken up by state parkland, and development on the remaining acres will soon be constrained as New York City institutes stricter regulations in the region, which lies within the watershed of the city's Ashokan Reservoir.
Mr. Gitter, sporting a silver ponytail, a cigar and a polka-dot bow tie, was every bit the impresario as he mingled early in July with several dozen tourists who had been lured by the silo's staring eyes, painted by a Tibetan artist as a symbol of wisdom and harmony.
Harmonious was not a term many visitors used to describe the decor at the complex, which includes a restored 19th-century barn and farmhouse, a restaurant with a vintage firetruck emerging from a wall and a 20-foot-tall model of a trout leaping out of a muddy pond. The barn contains exhibitions of nature photography and the work of several painters.
Some neighbors have complained that Mr. Gitter sold the community on the plan by focusing on the restoration of the old farm buildings. "We were pretty hopeful that something wonderful would be there," said Kathy Nolan, a spokeswoman for the Zen Mountain Monastery, which has a 40-acre nature preserve across the creek from Mr. Gitter's land. But the final product leans too far toward the "carnivalesque," she said.
Particularly disturbing for visitors to the monastery, she said, are the eyes on the silo, which are meant to be the eyes of Buddha. "In India, this is an extremely important religious symbol," she said. "There, it's never used to sell kaleidoscopes."
But people stopping at Catskill Corners were at the very least amused, and in some cases awestruck, by the kaleidoscope.
In groups of up to 20, people entered the base of the silo and leaned against cushioned neck supports that allowed them to gaze straight up into a pool of darkness. Overhead was a 2.5-ton, 37-foot-tall pyramid of mirrors with a small triangular gap at its peak where video art played on a rear-projection screen. The mirrors multiplied the single video image into a circular cluster of 254 facets that appeared to be a total of 50 feet across. As one group of visitors settled in, they were bathed in light from a video display designed by Isaac Abrams, a pioneer in the psychedelic art movement of the 1960's, and his son, Raphael, a computer artist. The room pulsed with a musical score by Gary Burke, a local composer and drummer who has worked with Francis Ford Coppola and Bob Dylan.
Mr. Abrams, who calls the kaleidoscope the "first cathedral of the third millennium," said the cascade of fragmented images was a voyage through American history, from wilderness to world power. Mr. Abrams and his son are planning a new show for Christmas, and another that is purely meditative, with viewers lying supine on the floor.
Overhead, the shifting displays took on the look of an animated stained-glass window as they accelerated toward a crescendo. As the viewers gaped at the pulsing blob, they formed a pose remarkably like that struck by actors in films about encounters with alien spacecraft.
Leaving the silo, the visitors were ushered directly into the Kaleido store, where they were confronted with dozens of kaleidoscopes, rendered in everything from cardboard at $6.95 to hand-crafted alabaster, stained glass and rosewood costing up to $2,400.
The giant scope, which cost $250,000, was conceived three years ago out of frustration over what to do with an empty silo, Mr. Gitter said. In a conversation with his architect, he recalled, "I said, 'I don't know, why not make it into a giant kaleidoscope?' "
The architect took him seriously and soon they were in touch with Cozy Baker, the president of the Brewster Society, a Maryland group devoted to the appreciation of kaleidoscopes that is named for Sir David Brewster, the Scottish scientist who invented the optical contraptions in 1816.
Ms. Baker -- whose collection of 1,000 scopes includes a 12-foot-long model that, until now, was the world's largest -- immediately referred Mr. Gitter to Charles Karadimos, a stained-glass artist and kaleidoscope designer who had thought about turning a silo on his Maryland farm into a scope several years ago but lacked funds. "It's thrilling that this has finally come about," Ms. Baker said.
Mr. Karadimos has since returned to designing smaller variations, Ms. Baker said, including an 18-karat-gold, gem-encrusted kaleidoscope. It is the size of a lipstick case.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Jobless Rate Unchanged

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
For the second month in a row, New Jersey's unemployment rate stood at 6.1 percent in June -- half a percentage point lower than it was in April, the state Labor Department reported yesterday. The state added 5,100 service jobs, but lost 2,600 jobs in manufacturing. Despite the improvement, New Jersey's unemployment rate exceeds the national rate, which was 5.3 percent in June.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
German Data Lift Hopes For an Early Rate Cut

 BODY:
German money-supply growth slowed abruptly in June, the Bundesbank said yesterday, providing new evidence of a sluggish economy and fanning hopes for interest-rate cuts as soon as next week. The Bundesbank said the M-3 money supply, a leading indicator of inflation, grew at an annual rate of 9.6 percent in June, slowing from a 10.5 percent rate in May. 
 Many economists said the central bank might trim its chief money market rate, the 3.3 percent securities repurchase rate, by up to 20 basis points next Thursday, its last policy-making meeting before a four-week break. The repo rate, which sets a target for overnight lending and is comparable to the United States Federal funds rate, has been frozen since early February. (Bloomberg Business News)

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Rambling in Sleepy Hollow Country

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO 

 BODY:
WHILE I was waiting for a New York Waterway shuttle bus at West Houston Street and Seventh Avenue in Lower Manhattan on the last Friday in May, a man mistook me for a tourist and offered to give me directions. I was three blocks from my apartment.
But I was wearing a backpack and probably had a dazed expression, because I'd been trying to imagine what downtown New York looked like in 1789 -- when Washington Irving (then 6 years old) and his Scottish nurse ran into George Washington in a shop nearby. The President blessed the lad, who grew up to write "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow" and, under the name Diedrich Knickerbocker, "A History of New York," becoming one of America's first literary lions. 
 I was on my way to Sleepy Hollow country; the day was glorious and I had a ticket in my pocket for a New York Waterway Kykuit Cruise. It included a boat trip up the Hudson River to Tarrytown, with a late afternoon return to Pier 78 in New York; bus transportation and admission to Philipsburg Manor, a Dutch colonial farmhouse on the banks of the Pocantico River, and a tour of Kykuit, the Rockefeller estate in the Sleepy Hollow hills above town -- all for $50 (though right after I booked the package the price went up to $60).
Another trip on the same boat, the Sleepy Hollow Cruise ($35), tours Philipsburg Manor and Sunnyside, Washington Irving's eclectic country home in Tarrytown. But tickets to Kykuit, which opened to visitors in 1994, are hard to come by. (In mid-July, Historic Hudson Valley, which handles Kykuit tours for $18 a person, had no Saturday tickets available until early August, and fall weekends were heavily booked.)
I'd decided to make a Knickerbocker holiday out of the one-day cruise by staying over in Tarrytown and taking a Metro-North train home (for $5.50 off-peak) three days later. While there, I'd visit the Sleepy Hollow restorations on foot, via the Old Croton Aqueduct Trail, which meanders along the river all the way from the Croton Dam in Cortlandt to the IRT local subway stop at 242d Street in the Bronx (though finding the trail can be tricky from there).
 When I got tired, I would hop on the train for trips between villages like Tarrytown and Irvington, which lie about three miles apart. I could have rented a car and driven up from New York, but that didn't sound like half as much fun.
The New York Waterway shuttlebus dropped me in front of a tidy complex of gray clapboard buildings surrounded by a white picket fence at the end of West 38th Street. I paused in the souvenir shop and actually considered buying a snow globe with little plastic replicas of Manhattan sights like the Empire State Building inside (for $2.50). Instead, I lined up with about 80 sightseers to board the Robert Fulton, a 97-foot vessel with room for 275, built in 1993. It had an enclosed lower deck with a snack bar where other passengers picked up their enticing box lunches (preordered for $9.50) and I wolfed down two hot dogs (for $2.10 each).
I sat on the airy upper deck and listened as the guide pointed out the 392-foot Gothic belfry of Riverside Church, one of the many beneficences of the Rockefeller family that I was to appreciate during this trip; Spuyten Duyvil at the juncture of the Harlem and Hudson Rivers, evoking a time when Westchester County was the domain of Dutch overlords like Adriaen Van der Donck and Vredryck Flypsen; the stern-faced Palisades, which line the west bank of the Hudson for 14 miles; and the Tappan Zee Bridge at Tarrytown, spanning the river in a place so wide the Dutch thought it oceanic.
We made land an hour and a half later in Tarrytown. Two buses waited to take us to Philipsburg Manor in North Tarrytown, the core of the 52,000-acre estate granted to Vredryck Flypsen by William and Mary of England in 1693. The Kykuit tour was scheduled to depart from there at 1:20, which allowed just 45 minutes to see the sweet, whitewashed Dutch farmstead and mill that look like something out of a children's book -- with a fragrant kitchen garden, shady barn, dopey-eyed sheep and a spotted cow.
In the low-ceilinged manor house a guide in long skirts and a bonnet showed me antique maps, Delft ware and a Turkey carpet, and in the mill a fellow in dusty white breeches was teaching schoolchildren how to grind wheat. It reminded me of wandering at age 8 with my family through Colonial Williamsburg, which like Philipsburg Manor and the other Historic Hudson Valley properties, was salvaged and restored by John D. Rockefeller Jr.
His father, John D. Rockefeller, was born in 1839 in upstate New York and later started Standard Oil. The family moved first to West 54th Street in New York City, and then built a rather simple country retreat on the ridge above Tarrytown in 1908. But Kykuit did not stay simple for long; by 1913 it had become a 40-room Beaux Arts-style mansion, eventually surrounded by 3,000 acres of verdant farmlands and lush gardens -- bursting with rhododendrons in the spring.
As the Rockefeller financial empire grew, John D. Rockefeller Jr. filled Kykuit with an exquisite collection of Oriental ceramics. But the tastes of Nelson A. Rockefeller, former Governor of New York, are most apparent at Kykuit. The basement level of the house is a gallery of the modern art he collected, including Picasso tapestries, paintings by Robert Motherwell, and Andy Warhol silkscreen portraits of Nelson Rockefeller and his wife, Happy. Outside, along the Linden Allee, around the rose garden, and at the fringes of a putting green lie sculptures by Giacometti, Moore and Brancusi, among others -- relatives of those in the Sculpture Garden at the Museum of Modern Art, one of whose founders was Abby Aldrich Rockefeller, the governor's mother.
Back on the bus to the boat two and a half hours later, I asked the driver to let me off in Tarrytown (technically it's not allowed). With map in hand, I headed about a mile up a steep hill surmounted by the beautiful blue dome of Butler Hall at Marymount College, where I'd reserved a room in a dorm for $25 a night. I'd learned that this was possible by reading a book called "On Campus U.S.A. and Canada." Indeed, all around New York City, colleges and universities like Fordham, Hofstra, SUNY Farmingdale and Concordia College in Bronxville offer dorm rooms to independent travelers in the summer for low prices. But they aren't always easy to book, because the educational institutions cater chiefly to conferences and groups and don't have the housekeeping resources of hotel chains.
Actually, there's a Courtyard by Marriott about two miles from Tarrytown (with weekend rates sometimes as low as $89), and a Hilton about a mile south of town (with attractive indoor and outdoor swimming pools and weekend specials for $125, including breakfast). The closest B & B's, the gracious Alexander Hamilton House in Croton-on-Hudson (where the least expensive double costs $95) and pleasant Krogh's Nest in Hartsdale (with double room rates that start at $65) were too far away to suit a walker like me. So it's slim pickings for frugal travelers on foot in the environs of Tarrytown -- as pretty a Hudson River village as ever there was, full of nice restaurants and antique shops, but in desperate need of its own B & B.
Marymount solved the accommodations problem for me admirably. The small liberal arts college for women founded in 1907 has a compact, handsomely landscaped campus with Hudson River views. From the window of my fourth-floor room in St. John's Hall (inhabited largely by international students the weekend I was there) I could watch the sky grow a mottled pink and the lights of the bridge twinkle over the darkening Tappan Zee.
The dorm room was bare but for two freshly made single beds, a desk and two bureaus. The large clean bathroom (towels and soap provided) adjoined both my room and the one next door, which was empty during my stay. (Some rooms share more traditional dorm-style communal bathrooms.)
There was no air-conditioning; the elevator was on the blink; and early on Saturday morning a prankster set off the fire alarm, which is why I found myself outside on the lawn in my pajamas at 4 A.M., listening to knots of students chatter in Italian, Russian and French. But there was an indoor pool on campus that I was free to use, and low-priced breakfasts were served at the Teahouse in Marian Hall. (It is closed for the summer, but at Rita Hall, which serves three meals a day, an all-you-can eat breakfast costs about $4.)
AT dinnertime, I sauntered down to Tarrytown, trying whichever eatery caught my fancy. A convivial pub on Broadway, Horsefeathers, served juicy cheeseburgers for $7.45, and at a rather fancy Brazilian Portuguese restaurant called Caravela I had a bowl of delicious shrimp soup and a half carafe of white wine, followed by a double order of delicately spiced mussels -- a splurge that cost $28. Another night, over a plate of London broil for $12.95 at the Main Street Cafe, the waitress told me that Rockefellers sometimes stopped by; when I asked how she knew, she said she could tell by their credit cards.
For three days, the weather remained gorgeous, which made a joy of my two-mile walk south (partly along the Aqueduct Trail and partly along busy Route 9) to Lyndhurst, a striking Gothic Revival mansion completed in 1866, owned by the railroad and telegraph magnate Jay Gould. During a tour of the extravagantly decorated house (for $7), with vaulted ceilings and light streaming in through Tiffany-style windows, a fellow sightseer whispered in my ear, "Rich or poor, it's good to have money."
Cozy, quirky Sunnyside, which lies right beside the river and the train tracks about a 15-minute walk away, is much more modest in scale. But in designing the house he shared with his brother and a passel of nieces, Washington Irving let his romantic imagination run free, decorating the simple cottage with weathervanes, wild wisteria vines, a quaint stepped roof and a Spanish tower. After my tour there (for $13, which included admission to Van Cortlandt Manor), I picnicked on the lawn, then strolled about a mile into Irvington, where I caught the train back to Tarrytown (for $1.75).
On Sunday I put on my go-to-meeting clothes and set out walking again, about two miles northeast of Marymount, to attend a service at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills, with breathtaking stained-glass windows designed by Matisse and Chagall, commissioned by various members of the Rockefeller family.
Then I rambled over paths in the Rockefeller State Park Preserve, listening for the hoofbeats of the Headless Horseman and winding up on Route 9 at the Old Dutch Church of Sleepy Hollow, built in 1685; caught the train at Philipse Manor Station for a 10-minute ride to Croton (for $1.75); and toured graceful Van Cortlandt Manor, dating to the 1680's, situated at a bucolic spot where travelers on the Old Albany Post Road ferried over the Croton River. The house has a gently pitched roof, Dutch doors, Delft tiles around the fireplace in the dining room and a Van Cortlandt family Bible, dated 1710.
I won't say I didn't have a few blisters by the time I boarded the train for home. But I calculated that I had walked no more than 15 miles during my three days in Sleepy Hollow country -- and more to the point, spent only about $275, including the cruise, train tickets, house tours, lodgings and meals.
There's an old Rockefeller family proverb that says: "Willful waste makes woeful want." To this I'd add a corollary: Spend carefully, want nothing.
 
The bottom line in Washington Irving country
 
Logistics
New York Waterway, (800) 533-3779, offers a variety of sightseeing trips, including the Kykuit tour that departs from Pier 78 at 38th Street and 12th Avenue, at 10:45 A.M. every day except Tuesday until Sept. 2; then Friday through Sunday until Nov. 3. The price is $60. Seventy-two Kykuit packages are available on each trip.
Metro-North offers train packages for the Kykuit estate too, on weekends only to Oct. 27. The $31 ticket includes train fare, shuttle bus transportation in Tarrytown and admission to Kykuit. A Sleepy Hollow Restoration excursion is also available on weekends. For further information on the packages, regular train schedules and fares, call (212) 532-4900; outside New York City, (800) 638-7646.
To book a Kykuit estate tour, contact Historic Hudson Valley, 150 White Plains Road, Tarrytown, N.Y. 10591; (914) 631-9491. If you can't get a ticket to Kykuit for the date of your choice, consider taking a tour of the estate's gardens for $18; reservations are necessary. For general information about Historic Hudson Valley properties: (914) 631-8200.
Lyndhurst is the only home mentioned above that is not part of Historic Hudson Valley; for information, call (914) 631-4481.
Besides the cruises and trains, you can reach Tarrytown by taking the subway to 242d Street and Broadway, and then switching to a Bee-Line bus. For Bee-Line schedule information, call (914) 682-2020.
In Tarrytown, Enterprise Rent-a-Car, 347 North Broadway, (914) 631-5474, has economy cars for a three-day, Friday-to-Monday weekend rate of $89.99, with unlimited mileage in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
In Croton-on-Hudson, a short walk from the train station, Erin's Car Rental, 379 South Riverside Avenue, (914) 271-2093, offers a daily rate of $42.95 for economy cars, which includes unlimited mileage.

Information
If you intend to tour the area on foot, good maps are essential. HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Age Pays Off, If You Ask

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
A CLERK taking your reservation is not going to ask if you are entitled to a senior discount. So if you are shy, you may pay more than necessary for a flight, a night or a bite. You get no discount if you don't ask.
This may be a psychological hazard. For example, I was delighted to get a Metrocard for the New York City transit system: With a picture and a "senior citizen" label on the back, this card lets me ride the bus or subway for half fare -- 75 cents. But I got a rude shock when I swiped the card through a display mechanism, which said "elderly"! Me, elderly? I was not the only unhappy traveler. Termaine Garden, a Transit Authority spokesman, said the electronic display of "elderly" was changed to "senior citizen" about June 1, after many complaints. 
 Senior citizenship has a varying entry age. For most discounts provided by Government agencies, the age is 65, when one is eligible for a Medicare card, which is used as essential identification. For airline discounts, it is usually 62. For hotel discounts, the age is a youthful 50.
Here is basic information about discounts you can ask for on airlines and in hotels. Always ask, preferably when making reservations.

 
 
Coupons Clip Air Fares
 The airlines' plain-vanilla discount is 10 percent off any ticket price for travelers 62 or over. If you have just turned 62, tell your travel agent to note it in your personal record so you do not miss out. Most airlines give the same discount to a senior traveler's companion.
A better value for costly trips is a senior coupon book: The seven major airlines sell coupon books to those 62 and older, and sometimes to their travel companions. Except for a USAir child's program, only the identified holder can use a coupon, and the younger companion can use coupons only on the same itinerary. This way you may get a one-way trip to the opposite coast for $135 or less. The coupons come in books of four -- and books of eight, at a still-cheaper rate, now only on Trans World Airlines and Continental. The coupons expire in a year. Reservations must be made at least 14 days ahead.
Coupons may be used for a one-way trip, meaning travelers need not stay over a Saturday night although a return reservation must still be made 14 days ahead.
The 10 percent Federal tax on airline tickets lapsed and was not in force in mid-July. Except for Continental, the airlines have accordingly reduced coupon costs 10 percent.
T.W.A. sells books of four coupons for $498, or $124.50 a trip; eight for $938, or $117.25 each. One coupon is needed each way in the lower 48 states, to Puerto Rico, Mexico or the Dominican Republic; two each way for travel to Hawaii. The four-coupon book comes with a voucher good for a 20 percent discount on a trip to Europe; two vouchers are in the eight-coupon book. A companion traveling with the senior traveler may buy coupon books, too, but at a cost $100 higher for either book. Call (800) 221-2000.
Continental did not subtract 10 percent from its coupon prices when the Federal tax lapsed; the price for a book of four coupons is $579; eight, $999. One coupon is needed each way for travel in the United States and Canada, Mexico, the Caribbean and Bermuda; two for Alaska, Hawaii. There are holiday blackouts. In addition, Continental has a program permitting virtually unlimited travel -- one trip a week -- for a specified period. This Freedom Passport costs $999 for a four-month domestic pass; $1,999 for a 12-month pass; the world passes cost $4,499 for 12 months. Companions of any age may buy passes at the same price, but must travel with the primary holder. These also have blackout dates. (800) 441-1135.
American has a four-coupon book for $541. One coupon is needed each way for travel in the lower 48 states, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands; two for Hawaii. There are no blackout days. (800) 237-7981.
Northwest sells a book of four coupons for $540, with no blackout dates. A trip in the lower 48 states, to Canada or to Puerto Rico requires one coupon each way; two coupons are needed each way for Hawaii or Alaska. (800) 225-2525.
United Airlines sells four coupons for $541. One coupon allows a trip in the lower 48 states; two are needed each way for Alaska or Hawaii. A blackout period applies to Hawaii, Dec. 15 to Jan. 10. (800) 633-6563.
USAir sells four coupons for $542. One or two children 2 to 11 may also use the coupons when they accompany the senior traveler. One coupon each way is needed in the United States, Canada, Mexico, Puerto Rico or Virgin Islands. One coupon provides a round trip between Florida cities. (800) 428-4322.
Delta sells its book of four coupons for $542. One coupon is needed each way for travel in the lower 48 states, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands; two each way for Alaska or Hawaii. No blackout dates. (800) 221-1212.
Most foreign airlines provide only the basic 10 percent discount. British Airways has an important plus. Starting at age 60, it waives the fee for change of flight and the penalty for canceling a reservation before the trip begins. (800) 247-9297.

 
 
Hotel Deals Vary
 Rare is the hotel that does not give at least 10 percent off for members of the American Association of Retired Persons or its Canadian equivalent, the Canadian Association of Retired Persons, and bear in mind that this requires only that you be 50. Ten percent is roughly a standard discount; younger people who belong to the Automobile Association of America frequently get the same thing. Ask when you reserve, and when you arrive.
Joan Rattner Heilman, author of the standard compendium on senior discounts, now in its eighth edition, considers Marriott, Omni and Choice to provide the best deals for seniors.
Marriott will provide a 50 percent discount on available rooms at 200 hotels for A.A.R.P. members in return for a pretty stiff requirement: reserve and pay 21 days in advance, no refunds possible. (800) 228-9290.
The Omni plan applies at most of its hotels in the United States and Mexico. It provides a 50 percent discount for A.A.R.P. members making reservations. (800) 843-6664.
Lodgings in the Choice chain -- Clarion, Comfort, Quality, Sleep, Friendship, Econo Lodges and Rodeway -- provide a 30 percent discount for those over 50 who reserve in advance and ask for it. (800) 221-2222.
Ms. Heilman's book, with the mind-boggling title "Unbelievably Good Deals and Great Adventures That You Absolutely Can't Get Unless You're Over 50" (Contemporary Books), is sold in most bookstores for $9.95. Morton Booksellers, 812 Stuart Avenue, Mamaroneck, N.Y. 10543, sells it by mail for $13.
If you are 50 and A.A.R.P. has not sent an invitation to join you can receive one by writing to 601 E Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20049. Membership costs $8 a year for one person or two at the same address.
Because there are now 32 million A.A.R.P. members, hotel clerks tend to assume everyone of a certain age belongs. When a hotel provides an A.A.R.P. discount, and I reach for my wallet, the clerk usually waives this formality. If you are youthful-looking and forgot your card, clerks will usually accept a driver's license with a birth date on it.

HEADLINE: Strangers in a Familiar Land

BYLINE: By SUZANNE BERNE; SUZANNE BERNE teaches writing at Harvard University.

 BODY:
FOR every single summer of my childhood, my family packed a stack of suitcases in late June and traveled up the East Coast to a foggy little seaside town on Cape Cod, and there we remained until Labor Day. In that same town my uncle and cousins and grandfather were also "summer people," and had been for years. My great-grandfather had summered on Cape Cod as far back as the turn of the century. But the year I turned 8, my father -- who loved the Cape and hated the end of summer -- made the radical decision not to migrate in September with everyone else we knew. He put our house in Virginia up for sale (our "real house," as I persisted in thinking of it); my younger sister and I were enrolled in the local public school, and it was understood that from now on we were no longer summer people, we were "year-rounders."
On the first day of school I was surrounded on the playground and accused of being a summer person. I had been sighted on a sailboat; my family was a known summer family. "Bet your dad has a million bucks," one girl said, dark eyes narrowing. A grim-faced boy said, "Bet you have a swimming pool." I protested that neither was true. No one believed me. "So what's your dad do?" growled the first child. My father happened to be writing a book; dimly I realized this answer would not serve. "He stays home," I admitted at last, because it was all I could think to say. My classmates decided my father must be unemployed and that I was therefore all right, and no one accused me of being a summer person anymore. 
 My new status lasted only until Thanksgiving, when my father accepted a teaching job in Washington, D.C., and so I offer this anecdote to illustrate the worst aspect of being a summer person, which is what I have been ever since.
It involves, for me at least, a certain disequilibrium, the sliding impression that I may not be wanted where I want to be. In my experience, the inhabitants of resort towns resent summer residents. Summer people are frequently perceived as rich (richer than the townspeople, anyway), imperious, demanding and possessive about any available body of water. With summer people come squadrons of Volvo station wagons and Ford Tauruses, parades of golf pants and boat shoes, whole arsenals of flashy sports equipment. With summer people come the necessity for beach stickers and reservations at restaurants and venomous disputes over whether it's trespassing to walk below the high-tide line.
In the fall, I've been told, when the summer people and the tourists decamp, those who are left feel Cape Cod is theirs again. And herein lies the paradox of being a summer person: you can be deeply, passionately, even historically attached to a place that considers you an invader. No matter how many years you have been a colonist, the colony will never be yours. On Labor Day, smiling Cape residents crowd the overpasses along jammed Route 6, holding aloft hand-lettered signs that read: "See you next summer!" and "Bye Bye!" Some farewells are not so good-natured. My mother knows of a hardware-store owner on the Cape who, when asked by a wealthy dowager what on earth the local residents did after the summer folk departed, replied: "Madam, we fumigate." This story may be apocryphal, but the sentiment is not. That many resort-town residents rely on seasonal visitors for their livelihood does not always increase their affection.
Then again, many summer people appear to regard year-rounders as a kind of grumpy servant class that exists to mow lawns and sell overpriced groceries. A friend who became a year-rounder on Martha's Vineyard a decade ago once pointed out that summer people either behave too familiarly in their negotiations with the natives -- the "feudal lord approach" she called it -- or ignore them altogether. Summer people, she concluded, "don't really see the people who live where they vacation."
But here's another paradox: despite whatever complaints they engender, summer people love their summer homes, love them perhaps more carefully and inhabit them more thoroughly than where they live the rest of the year.
Our summer place on the Cape, for instance, is where we pay attention to tide charts and cirrus clouds, to the shifting sun and the smell of rain, where we forget to turn on the evening news and listen instead to mourning doves sighing in the locust trees. Our summer place is where both my husband and I might be home in the middle of the day in the middle of the week, where the baby cries less and the dog loses weight. Our summer place is really my mother's house, which she bought years ago after my parents divorced; she wanted to make sure that she would always have a place on Cape Cod. On some weekends my sisters and I all sleep down the hall from each other, nearly one family once again.
A summer place is home the way home ought to be, or so nostalgia tells us. This is the life, people say while on vacation, meaning they feel untroubled and gratified. This is the life, they murmur, already wistful. Because it is the life -- the one we dream of having on snowy afternoons in February when the children have fevers and there's nothing for dinner and you find yourself staring out the window, imagining warm green grass and a reach of bright water.
AND yet, to be a summer person is to be at odds with your summer home for the simple fact that it's regarded as temporary, and there is in all homes an intrinsic demand that you stay there. Even if, as in my case, that summer home helped determine where you chose to settle. You may love your summer home more than anywhere else in the world, but you would not say "I am from Cape Cod," if you live in New York or Boston most of the time; you do not claim to be of a summer place. Your intimacy is always limited, always a summer love, which must make your brief appropriation of that place all the more galling to its more constant denizens.
Even the term "summer person" implies someone transient, feckless, a fair-weather friend. A summer person is something more than a tourist and less than a resident, a kind of lingering house guest who stays a week or a month or a clutch of long weekends. When one set of summer people returns to their real home, they are usually succeeded by other summer people in the same house, who themselves will be succeeded, and so on. No one mourns their absence. And still each family has its own special claim to this place that they imagine will renew them, and often, amazingly, it does.
The year I turned 8, when our experiment in living year round on the Cape ended so quickly, I was sorry to leave. I'd grown to like my classmates and felt they liked me, too. The day before I left they gave me a farewell present, a little Scholastic paperback about Helen Keller and Annie Sullivan. I was touched and kept the book for years. It's only now that I begin to wonder at its subject, which of course was the relationship of an impoverished young teacher and a rich deaf-and-blind child. I'm sure the book was an innocent choice. On the flyleaf was written, in cherry-pink Magic Marker, "See you next summer."

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Sidney J. Holbrook;
Clean Air, Clean Water, Tough Rules

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
SIDNEY J. HOLBROOK manages 1,100 employees and a $90 million budget in an effort to keep the state's air and water clean, the fish and wildlife healthy. As Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, he is also responsible for boating safety, hunting, controlling forest fires and monitoring Long Island Sound. The department also oversees its own saw mill in Portland Depot to supply boards for picnic tables and a 13-acre seedling nursery in Voluntown.
"Some people complain about the stringency of the environmental regulations here but I think it helps to to establish a quality of life in Connecticut that is second to none," Mr. Holbrook said. "You can feel safe breathing the air and drinking the water." 
 Mr. Holbrook came to the job early last year after 12 years in the State House of Representatives, including 10 years as Republican whip. Recently, he discussed some of the challenges his agency faces in an interview at his Hartford office. Following are some excerpts from that conversation.
Q. Could Connecticut's parks, forests and beaches be better utilized?
A. Connecticut has 126 parks and forests and they are absolutely a hidden treasure. Although at this agency 80 percent of the focus is on air, water and waste, personally my love is natural resources and outdoor recreation. I try to get out every week or so to a different park.
We are responsible for four state beaches -- Sherwood Island, Rock Neck, Hammonasset and Silver Sands in Milford. Local beaches are the responsibility of the municipalities and the Department of Health. By next year Silver Sands, the newest park, will have better beach access, better parking, new dunes, a beach and boardwalk.
Our campgrounds were sold out over Memorial Day. They're doing very well. The staff does a good job even though the staffing is thin. Currently 50 percent of the staff in wildlife management are prisoners.
 Q. Will the state add new parks?
A. I believe there will be new parks, yes. Will they be the kind of parks we think of in the traditional way? Probably not.
What we are doing in some of our state forests is developing more recreational areas that in essence turn those into parks. We're working more with utility companies to obtain easements and make their land available to public access. They have a tremendous amount of land. They have been very receptive to opening their lands. It doesn't have to necessarily be managed by us. The goal, the bottom line, is to provide more space to the public.
We work in partnership with groups like the Nature Conservancy that has acquired much land. A good example is Selden Island where we acquired an easement on an island in the Connecticut River.
Q. What about the urban areas?
A. We have a program where we work with the alternative incarceration program. It's about 14 months old. We go into cities to illegal dumping sites, lots that have been abandoned, and restore the sites to as pristine a quality as we possibly can.
These people, parolees or those sentenced to perform community service, clean and restore the sites in New Haven, Bridgeport and Hartford. We have cleaned up over 150 sites.
We find that when the sites are cleaned up they are not trashed again. I personally would like to see these sites stay more focused on nature than recreation but this is something the cities have to determine.
Q. What is the quality of Connecticut's air this summer?
A. With deregulation and restructuring of Midwestern power generating plants we have a problem. They don't have the same regulations or requirements as we do here in New England. They generate a tremendous amount of pollutants.
We have close monitoring of all emissions into the air within Connecticut. The Toxic Release Inventory released by the E.P.A. showed Connecticut is the leader in New England as far as reduction of toxic releases by industry -- 69 percent since 1988.
Q. Does your agency have any role in the possible power shortage this summer?
A. We only get involved in making sure they burn the cleanest fuels they can and that they come up with a conservation plan. The power companies are going to open some of their old fossil fuel facilities. They are supposed to do public service announcements to let people know if there is a problem with the demand going up and the generation down. I think it's important for the public to aware that this is a serious situation. We have basically lost our main source of generation in the state through the loss of Millstone. We hope for a cool summer.
Q. Some people believe that Connecticut is too densely populated for hunting to be safe. Do you think so?
A. Absolutely not. I don't believe that at all. There are certain laws and requirements that insure that safety of people is the No. 1 concern. We have setback requirements as far as shooting from roads and from homes or any dwelling.
We have a tremendous amount of state forests that are available to hunting. There's a lot of private lands open to hunting but it is constantly diminishing. That's why we try to constantly look for lands that we can buy or obtain through easements to make available to the sportsmen of the state.
Hunting is not only a sport but a wildlife management tool. We were embroiled in a controversy about a controlled deer hunt at Bluff Point in Groton. The deer population got out of control and we had hunters go in and take the deer. Some people actually suggested we release cougars in there. It was a very difficult time for me personally because I was harassed. It was a hot one.
Canada geese cause problems. We think one of the reasons we have had high coliform counts at Rocky Neck Sate Park is due to the number of geese there and the fecal matter getting into the water. We've had to close the beach already.
It is my intention to establish a hunting season on them this year. Last year the season was closed by the Federal authorities. Those were migratory geese. The geese we have are basically staying there.
Q. Will this be a bad summer for mosquitoes?
A. Here in Connecticut we have one of the only tidal wetland restoration programs in effect. We take out phragmites to keep a flow moving in and out of the tidal wetlands. That is long-term control because without stagnant water the mosquitoes can't breed.
As far as the short-term solution goes, we do not have the funds to do anything and I believe it falls under the Department of Health's jurisdiction. The municipalities also have to take steps.
Q. What is the condition of the Sound?
A. I lived in Westbrook all my life. I boated, swam, fished in the Sound. The advancements that have been made in over 25 years have been phenomenal. It is much cleaner.
Nonetheless, it is a never-ending battle. The storm sewers and the sanitary sewers are connected and when rain overloads them there is automatic discharge from the sewage treatment plants. We are putting in sediment basins, traps to catch oil, sand and debris that would normally flow out to the Sound. We are requiring this of all new construction and also where retrofitting is planned.
Statistics show that places where the environment is not kept clean there is an effect on the economy. Where regulations are adhered to that the economies are better. Long Island Sound is a perfect example of that. Think of the boating industry, the fishing industry. Think of the tourism, the restaurants. The Sound is a $5 billion asset. The Sound is not only Connecticut's greatest natural resource, it is Connecticut's greatest economic resource. That's dependent upon a healthy, clean Long Island Sound.
Q. What about chemical contaminants like mercury and P.C.B.'s?
A. Mercury is ubiquitous. It is due to out-of-state air pollution and to the inadequate disposal of fluorescent light bulbs. We have just permitted a new recycling facility in Windsor for a private company to recycle fluorescent light bulbs. It will be the first one in the state. A new mercury study by the E.P.A. is due out in November that will tell us a lot.
P.C.B.'s usually come from industrial pollution, especially in the Housatonic. We believe these are chemicals that industry put in the water in Massachusetts, although Connecticut did contribute to the problem.
Q. What is the status of the Superfund program to clean up toxic waste?
A. We have a lot of SuperFund sites; the Raymark site is almost completed. It is very expensive to deal with these sites. Who funds this cleanup?
There is some concern that the insurance companies are paying more than their fair share and that the liability is not being spread out enough.
It is a very difficult issue for me. It's actually a Federal concern. Without question these sites have to be cleaned up. It comes down to whether you want to fund it through tax dollars or do you want to fund it through business and industry. I am not a hundred percent convinced it should be funded directly through industry. I don't think it's fair that the public pick up the tab either. There's got to be some kind of balance.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sidney J. Holbrook, the state's environmental commissioner. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The View From: Greenburgh;
Ballroom Dancing Is Just a Step Away From the Olympics

BYLINE: By LYNNE AMES 

DATELINE: GREENBURGH

 BODY:
HIGH diving or broad jumping it is not, but ballroom dancing is athletic. So say proponents of the pursuit, observing that, like figure skating, it takes excellent muscle control, coordination and stamina. Indeed, for the first time ever, ballroom dancing has received provisional recognition from the International Olympic Committee.
That does not mean that when the games opened in Atlanta last Friday, men and women in tuxedos and ball gowns were waltzing through competitions. Not yet. Within a few years, however, they could be competing alongside other athletes for gold, silver and bronze medals. 
 This is good news for those who love to tango and fox-trot, who love the mambo and the merengue. Betty Diamond, an instructor at and co-owner of Guys N' Dolls dance studio on Tarrytown Road here, said: "Ballroom dancing is a sport. It has an esthetic component, but it is also very athletic." Interestingly, she said that dances known as "smooth" -- waltz, fox trot -- actually take more intense muscle control than those in the Latin category -- cha-cha, samba, and so forth -- which entail a lot of fast, showy footwork. "In smooth dancing especially, you're using a lot of muscle control," she said. "It's more subtle, but also more rigorous. Ankles, thighs, hips, shoulders -- all must be in perfect control."
On a recent night at Guy N' Dolls, Ms. Diamond and another instructor and owner, Don Fischer, demonstrated. Mr. Fischer had on white tie and tails; Ms. Diamond was wearing a gown specifically designed for ballroom dancing, a confection of white silk and rhinestones with plunging back and swinging skirt. On her feet were white satin shoes, each studded with 288 rhinestones, which she had applied by hand.
As the strains of "Lara's Theme" from "Doctor Zhivago" came from the sound system, Ms. Diamond and Mr. Fischer whirled around the 3,500-square-foot room in a graceful waltz. After the applause ended, they asked the men and women attending their weekly Friday group lesson and dance party to line up for a little practice.
"One-two-three, one-two-three," Ms. Diamond intoned rhythmically, sounding like Anna in "The King and I" when she was teaching the King of Siam to dance. "One-two-three, back-back-back, step back, ladies, curve back with your gentleman partners, one-two-three."
Although Guys N' Dolls has been open only a year and a half, it has already gained a following. The studio offers private and group lessons as well as weekly dance parties and special events. Recently they held a Red Shoes Night in which anyone wearing red shoes was admitted for half price. Although some come in casual clothes, there are plenty of men who wear suits and ties to the dance parties and women who show up in short, glittery dresses. Some people come in pairs; others hope to find the right dance partner when they get there. "Ballroom dancing is a wonderful social activity," Marian Reilly, another of the owners, said. "It's not like going to a bar or being part of a singles' scene."
Ms. Reilly added that ballroom dancing "saved my life." A trim, energetic woman who will say only that she's in her 30's, she came to America from Ireland 10 years ago. Several years later she found herself going through a rough divorce and needing not only income -- she works as a waitress during the day -- but also a place to escape her loneliness. She began going to ballroom dance classes and parties and, 18 months ago, decided to open her own studio. Her partners are Mr. Fischer, Ms. Diamond, who also owns a title insurance company, and Dennis Satriani, who is also with Ms. Diamond's title company.
"When you learn to ballroom dance, you really are accomplishing something: you're learning a craft," Ms. Reilly said. "I went to a wedding last week; they had hired this lovely 10-piece band, and here were all these people out on the floor who couldn't dance."
No such problems loomed for the group at Guys N' Dolls on a recent Friday night. Among them were Esperanza Blair, a 43-year-old who works in finance, and Syrus Partian, 44, a chiropractor. Ms. Blair, a petite woman with dark hair cut Cleopatra style, was wearing a batik cotton sarong and the requisite dance shoes (suede soles for better traction), Mr. Partian had on men's suede-soled dance shoes and stylishly cut slacks. Together they did the rumba, the tango, the cha-cha and the Lindy, looking both like accomplished professionals and like a couple between whom romantic sparks were flying.
"We met here when the place first opened, and now we live together," Ms. Blair said. "But when we first danced together we were actually fighting. I felt he wasn't dancing well enough!"
Alpha Chiang, a 69-year-old economics professor and author, and his wife, Emily, 64, were married long before they began ballroom dancing, but now, they say, it is one of their favorite shared activities. "Usually, it's the woman who has to convince her husband to come dancing," Mr. Chiang said. "But I'm dragging her here every day. I'm supposed to be preparing a textbook on mathematical economics, but I'd rather be here dancing."
Elaine Warshaw, a teacher who would not reveal her age, said she leaves her husband, a lawyer, at home when she comes to Guys N' Dolls. The New Orleans native does a mean Lindy and, she said, she has music in her blood. "My husband's very cerebral, so I come here and dance with my teachers."
Lisl Deak also dances with the instructors. Like Mrs. Warshaw, Mrs. Deak would not reveal her age, but she did say that she is a widow, that her late husband, Nicholas, was in international banking and that she lives at the Westchester Country Club in Rye. And this evening she was impeccably dressed in a full white-and-black silk skirt, a black silk blouse and pearls; it is the type of outfit, she said, that she wears three nights a week to Guys N' Dolls. "I dance with Don, my teacher; we do very well together," she said. "I particularly like the waltz. I enjoy it here. It is my second life."

HEADLINE: Wage Bill's Rule on Tax-Free Bonds Could Dampen Plans for Lilco

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
A PROVISION in the minimum-wage bill could mean the loss of some tax-exempt financing for Lilco, a move that could cost customers more than $30 million a year, officials have warned.
The provision is being challenged by Senators Patrick D. Moynihan and Alfonse M. D'Amato, who have said they will try to revise the final bill that emerges from a House-Senate conference. 
 The provision, backed by the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, William V. Roth, Republican of Delaware, involves changes in how utilities issue tax-exempt bonds.
The changes would benefit the Delmarva Power and Light Company of Wilmington, Del., which serves Delaware, Maryland and Virginia. That utility wants to avoid retroactive penalties on previously sold exempt bonds if it expands its gas business beyond two counties in Delaware.
The potentially negative effects in New York affect the Consolidated Edison and Brooklyn Union Gas Companies, as well as Lilco.
Mr. D'Amato's office estimated that the provision could cost New Yorkers $65 million a year, including the $30 million on Long Island, by requiring the refinancing of some of the billions of dollars in outstanding tax-exempt bonds.
"Without these tax-exempt bonds the cost of borrowing money would increase and that would increase the cost of electricity," said a spokeswoman for Lilco, Andrea Staub.
Mr. D'Amato, calling the proposal "an outrage," said, "Make no mistake about it, this is a back-door tax increase on residents of Long Island, New York City and Westchester County."
Leaders of the Long Island Power Authority, the state agency in charge of carrying out a rate-reduction plan, said they expected that the legislation would be changed in the final bill. "I heard it was dead duck," the chairman, Frank L. Zarb, said.
But in a letter to Mr. D'Amato and Mr. Moynihan this month, the chairmen of three utilities -- William J. Catacosinos of Lilco, Eugene R. McGrath of Con Edison and Robert B. Catell of Brooklyn Union -- wrote:
"This is a matter of utmost importance to each of us and the customers we serve. Any action that jeopardizes our ability to issue lower-cost financing will have an adverse effect on our effort to improve the economy and job- enhancement prospects for the region."
The executives said that the changes "could jeopardize the basis on which existing bonds were issued and require unwarranted refundings and millions of additional costs to New York utility customers" and would "create confusion in an already complex realm."
Touching on issues that could be crucial for Lilco and any plan for a state take-over of the utility, the letter said the revision would create uncertainties about the tax liabilities of "successors in interest."
The former chairman of the power authority, Richard M. Kessel, now a trustee of the agency, said Congressional interest in limiting tax-exempt financing in general was casting a shadow on state takeover plans for Lilco.
"If it is the desire of Congress to cut off tax-exempt utility financing," Mr. Kessel said, "that may make it impractical or even impossible for the authority to raise billions of dollars on the tax-exempt market."
Mr. Kessel said the new provision would mean an rate increase of 1 to 1.5 percent on Long Island.
Another tax issue could also affect a plan to reduce rates that the trustees of the power authority approved in February. That plan, shich Gov. George E. Pataki supported, envisions the sale of Long Island Lighting Company generators to other companies and the sale by the authority of $4.5 billion in tax-exempt bonds to buy Lilco transmission and distribution systems and to refinance the utility's debt. It projected an initial rate reduction of 12 percent. But negotiations between the authority and Lilco have stalled, pending an advisory opinion from the Internal Revenue Service on whether Lilco would face a $2 billion capital-gains tax on the sale of assets. If the I.R.S. denies an exemption, the plan would be highly unfavorable for Lilco and its shareholders.
Mr. Zarb, the top Federal energy official in the Ford Administration, said Lilco executives consulted last week in Washington with Treasury Department officials and would soon submit a formal inquiry to request a clarification of the tax questions.
The authority, Mr. Zarb added, would move ahead regardless of the I.R.S. opinion. "We are going to do something to improve the situation, and if the I.R.S doesn't do what they should do, then we are working on other options," he said. "There are other avenues available to us."
Mr. Zarb and his new executive director, Seth D. Hulkower, said they would not discuss the options before the I.R.S. issued its opinion. "I don't want to prejudice any of the negotiations by discussing these matters too early," Mr. Hulkower, a former vice president of Merrill International, an energy company in Massachusetts, said. "But we have alternatives if we are not happy with the I.R.S. opinion. The final plan will promote competition in the supply of electricity. But we are working on the details of how that would actually come to pass." he said.
Mr. Hulkower, who grew up in Port Washington and lives in Manhattan, said he expected a "structure" that would provide "double-digit rate reduction, a safe reliable system and the introduction of competitive pressure to the electric-supply system on Long Island" by the end of the year. "But all the transactions involved will take longer than that," he said.
Mr. Hulkower dismissed a suggestion that the authority, created in 1986 to alleviate high rates, appeared to continue to be at the beginning in its efforts for reductions. "A lot of people have been involved with this over time," he said. "It is a cumulative process."
Mr. Kessel said the plan that the board approved in February had been set aside. "That plan is gone," he said. "It isn't even being discussed. There is going to have to be an alternative."
Mr. Kessel said last week that he frequently spoke with Mr. Zarb and knew confidential information about possible alternative plans, but would not comment on them. "It's probably better to wait until we come up with something that makes sense," he said.
Mr. Zarb, whom Mr. Pataki appointed as chairman of the Republican-controlled board to succeed James F. Gill, has made an effort to consult with Democrats, including Mr. Kessel.
Lilco has declined to comment on negotiations with the authority that could lead to disbanding or a buyout of the utility. Ms. Staub denied a report that Mr. Catacosinos had asked the authority to lay aside any plans and make its best offer to buy the common stock.
An energy economist, Charles M. Studness of Manhasset, said the secrecy surrounding the plans was troubling. "Are people trying to do something in the public interest, or is there a hidden political agenda?" Mr. Studness asked. "Any Long Island person has to wonder how much of this is being driven by Wall Street and how much by the interests of Long Island."
He said Wall Street interests were served by any plan that would produce large fees for financiers and lawyers.
Mr. Studness said the State Public Service Commission could offer a quicker and less expensive solution by cutting rates. "Even with a favorable tax ruling," he said, "I don't think Lipa could achieve as large a reduction in rates as you could have through P.S.C. action and competition."
The commission is reviewing the rate structure and other financial issues.
Asked whether he agreed that the commission could lower rates sooner and more quickly than the authority, Mr. Zarb said he could not make an evaluation and was concentrating on what the authority could do. Mr. Zarb said he was perplexed by criticisms by the chairman of the Assembly Energy Committee, Paul D. Tonko, Democrat of Schenectady. Mr. Tonko said Mr. Zarb was one of several advisers on Mr. Pataki's transition team in 1994, a panel that issued a report opposing a large tax-exempt bond issue to lower Lilco rates.
Mr. Tonko said Mr. Zarb now appeared to be embracing a plan that entailed such a bond issue and was contrary to the report. "He inherited something that he probably never would have endorsed," said Mr. Tonko, who opposed the envisioned sale of tax-exempt authority bonds. He said regulated competition between private companies was a better way to lower rates.
Mr. Zarb said the report had "pretty much the same observations that you would make today."
"I have no idea what that was all about," he said of Mr. Tonko's criticisms.
