HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Union Square;
And Now, Offices Blossom Around the Revived Park

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
"WHEN we opened in 1985, people said we were crazy to put a restaurant in this neighborhood and crazier to name it after Union Square Park," said Paul Bolles-Beaven, managing partner of the Union Square Cafe.
The restaurant, at 21 East 16th Street, has since become a fixture in the neighborhood, which has undergone a renaissance in recent years. The improvements in restaurants and retail stores are being reflected in a demand for nearby office space, which is now considered an attractive alternative to midtown. 
 A greenmarket operates in the park four days a week, giving city dwellers an opportunity to stock up on fresh produce, baked goods, flowers, fish and meat and bringing middle class people to a park the once seemed occupied by the homeless.
Retailers such as Barnes & Noble have taken long-vacant buildings and turned them into attractive places to shop. "That building that Barnes & Noble is in now was a total eyesore on the north side of the square," said Barbara Roberts, president of FPG International, a stock photography company on the east side of the square.. "When we moved here in February of '91, it seemed like half the real estate was vacant and we were the only ones here," she added.
Lured by the increasingly welcoming ambiance of the area, new restaurants have opened, which has had increased pedestrian traffic even further.
"This is a destination now," said Steve Hansen, who opened the Blue Water Grill seafood restaurant in an old bank building facing the park three months ago. "People know if they cannot get into restaurant A, they can walk a few feet and go to restaurant B or restaurant C."
Mr. Hansen said he was investing $2 million to remodel the facility, which will have 140 tables on three levels when renovation of a downstairs floor is completed.
"With all the improvements that have been made, the Union Square area has become a hip part of New York both day and night," said Glenn Markman, a senior managing director of the Grubb & Ellis, N.Y., brokerage firm.
"You have publishers, advertising agencies, marketing firms and Internet companies interested because it feels different from midtown or downtown, for that matter," he said.
"Midtown is too sterile for a lot of people," said Martin Turchin, vice chairman of Edward S. Gordon Company. Discussing Midtown South, which the Gordon company defines as the area between 23rd Street and City Hall, Mr. Turchin said: "In the past people moved there for lower rents. Now they go for a better neighborhood."
IT was Mr. Turchin who brokered the decision by C.S. First Boston to lease 1.1 million square feet of space at 11 Madison Avenue between 24th and 25th Streets, in a building owned by Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. More recently, Emanuel/Emanuel Ungaro decided to move out of the garment district and lease 75,000 square feet, or most of the 10th floor, of the same building.
"Because of First Boston, Met Life said it would spend $300 million to rehabilitate the building," said Joseph A. Fabrizi, an associate director of Cushman & Wakefield. "That was a major commitment to the neighborhood. It said that it was acceptable enough for your employees to go there everyday and leave after dark."
He said Union Square, which sits atop the major subway station in the area, was formerly considered so unsafe that most employers did not even consider the area. "Ten years ago you could not give space away around there," Mr. Fabrizzi said. "The B.I.D. had a lot to do with cleaning the area up."
That group, formally the 14th Street-Union Square Business Improvement District, has crews that sweep streets and security guards that patrol on bicycle and foot to ease the concerns of workers, shoppers and residents. Like other such organizations, it is supported by special taxes from local businesses to supply services that have been scaled back by the city.
"I see real estate advertisements now that say 'view of Union Square Park,' said Robert W. Walsh, the executive director of the group. "That's something that was not mentioned in the past."
He said that, in addition to the retail developments, the area had been enhanced by hospitals, which are trying to move their services closer to their customers. When an earlier tenant collapsed, Beth Israel Medical Center bought the commercial space at Zeckendorf Towers, which faces the park from the east, and converted it into an ambulatory-care unit with 20 separate offices for doctors..
He said educational institutions provided another economic engine for the area, with New York University and the New School nearby. N.Y.U. has purchased the site of the old Luchow's restaurant on 14th Street and has said it plans to use it to build student housing.
In another improvement, the city is rebuilding the subway station under the park, to improve accessibility and attractiveness, with completion expected by 1998.
If the building at 11 Madison Avenue is one of the economic anchors of the area, it is also untypical. Built as the base of what was originally intended to be a taller tower, the building has some floors with almost 100,000 square feet of space.
M OST of the buildings in this area are older with floorplates of 10,000 to 20,000 square feet," said David Goldstein, a broker with Julian J. Studley. He said the issue of Class A versus Class B space was essentially nonexistent.
"Class A generally implies new construction," he said. "Most of the buildings here are older and in their second and third generation."
Nevertheless, Class A is the category the 64-year-old 11 Madison Avenue will be marketed in because of the renovation, said Mark Mandell, the building's leasing agent, who is with Cushman & Wakefield.
"We are having the facade cleaned, new windows installed and the entire guts of the building renewed," he said. "We will move it up to a Class A building. It will be a Midtown North quality building at rents that are a third less."
Brokers representing both landlords and tenants say that space is becoming harder to find and that effective rentals are increasing, largely by a reduction of the concessions packages offered by landlords during the recent period of slack demand. Most say rentals in Midtown South ranged from the $18 or $19 a square foot to $24 to $26 a square feet, compared to $24 or $25 to $30 to $31 a square foot in midtown.
I T is very tricky to compare one building to another and one submarket to another, but my gut says the spread is closer to $5 a foot than $8 or $10 a foot," said Mr. Markman of Grubb & Ellis. "Overall concession packages are becoming smaller, with less free rent and effective rental rates are inching up."
"The vacancy rate in Midtown South is at about 10 percent and there is a scarcity of large blocks of space," said Mr. Goldstein, of Julien J. Studley firm, which represents tenants. "The scarcity of space is having an upward effect on rental rates due to fewer concessions."
But brokers and tenants say the urge to move to the area is motivated less by economics than by the chance to locate in a newly attractive neighborhood. "No one is going to be motivated to move for $5 a foot," said Mr. Turchin. "The decision is not solely about economics; lifestyle is important as well."
Ms. Roberts, of FPG International, said she was convinced that the Union Square location has helped build her business, an agency that supplies stock photographs. "The photo editors and art directors like coming here to do their own research and that means almost a guaranteed sale."
She said that when she moved to 32 Union Square, she had 80 employees and occupied one floor of about 12,000 square feet. Now she occupies close to 50,000 square feet on three floors and a penthouse and has 230 employees.
She said the nature of the business required people to work until 8 P.M., which is after dark in the wintertime.
"When we first moved in I was a little nervous about people going home at night, and we got the B.I.D. security people to escort them," she said. "Now we don't worry very much."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Union Square looking north, flanked by Broadway on the left and Park Avenue South. New Barnes & Noble bookstore is at center top on East 17th Street. (Carrie Boretz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Biking for Backing For a Soup Kitchen

BYLINE: By BRENDA A. SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
YOU could say that 31-year-old Ray Aramini's quest is one of bread, sweat and gears.
Mr. Aramini, a probation officer dealing with juveniles in Willimantic who lives in the rural township of Windham Center, last week started off on a 500-mile, 5-day bicycle ride in the hope of raising $100,000 for a Bike for Bread program to expand the Covenant Soup Kitchen in Willimantic. 
 He set off last Wednesday, starting with one wheel in Canada and one in Maine, and is continuing through New Hampshire, Vermont, Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut.
The Covenant kitchen serves 26,000 sit-down lunches, 14,717 breakfasts and another 4,000 bag lunches each year.
Just as important, Mr. Aramini would tell you, the kitchen has provided solace to thousands of families, since first opening its now familiar little red door in St. Paul's Episcopal Church 15 years ago.
The kitchen doesn't receive Federal or state grants, "so we're not intrusive" in the lives of the people who come to the kitchen, says the operations director Gene Kupec. In these hard times, she added, "I've been seeing a lot of new faces."
The kitchen has grown to the point where it is overtaking church space, and it is badly in need of repair, including updating for access by people with disabilities. Thus Mr. Aramini's fund-raising efforts.
Volunteers like the bike rider have become essential as paying staff has become more difficult. "We're losing our workfare people because their hours have been cut back," Ms. Kupec said. "We've depended on them in the past to help, because they come in on a regular basis."
Mr. Arantini, who grew up on the family farm in Columbia (affectionately dubbed the Big-A Ranch), first went to the soup kitchen four years ago becuase he was hungry -- not for bread, but for purpose.
At the time, he was recovering from back, neck and shoulder injuries from a car accident which, for a while, left him too weak to stand for more than a few minutes at a time. As a volunteer working at the kitchen he could help at his own pace with dishwashing or serving food.
He has continued to volunteer in the kitchen since his recovery, and now he'd like to give something back. "Hunger is not just for food -- people need acceptance, love . . . I've taken away vastly more than I've given people," he said.
This wasn't Mr. Aramini's first experience with soup kitchens or good causes. When he was 19, he joined his cousin Gary Aramini in a run from California to New Hampshire -- 3,500 miles in 119 days -- to raise funds for cancer research
He also spent two years in South Kingston, Jamaica, with a tiny Roman Catholic men's order called Brothers of the Poor, helping to establish a soup kitchen there.
His ride includes a stop at the Keene Community Kitchen where he worked for two and a half years while attending college, and where a professor, Gerald Lenthall, helped him realize that this was the kind of work that suited his nature.
His mother, Nancy ("Mrs. A," as her husband, Raymond, calls her), a former nurse, says her youngest child has always been a ball of energy and goodwill. His older siblings, Dan and Nancy, were easier to track, but she used to dress Ray in red, she said, so she could find him in crowded places like supermarkets.
"Dan would be pushing a cart, Nancy would disappear reading, and we'd find Ray with a little old lady. They'd be having a grand conversation about gold coins or her old bottle collection," she says.
Mrs. Aramini guesses that it was a school trip to impoverished areas in the Appalachian mountains that first sparked her son's humanitarian projects.
In the last three months, Mr. Aramini has been swimming, lifting, biking and hiking to prepare for the ride. And with the help of a growing circle of volunteers -- who have also been selling T-shirts, bumper stickers and baseball caps for the cause -- he's been talking, talking and talking.
"Increasing awareness of the problems of the poor is a very important part of all this," he said.
He hopes that other riders will join him as he makes his way from state to state. Part of the Bike for Bread message is that all soup kitchens need support, particularly at a time when many people are without jobs for the first time in their lives. And many of the victims of unemployment are children.
Fund-raising efforts have drawn in everyone from the American Cribbage Conference to Fleet Bank, which recently presented Mr. Aramini with a $3,000 check and a Winnebago to track the route.
For more information about the Bike for Bread project, the telephone number is 860-423-2737 and the address, Post Office Box 463, Willimantic, Conn. 06226.

HEADLINE: Another Plan for Baby Boomers

BYLINE: The Associated Press 

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT will take to the airwaves soon with a $15,000 advertising campaign to persuade baby boomers to plan for the future.
The initiative comes four years after the state began encouraging its residents to plan for old age by purchasing long-term care insurance. Under the program, the state teamed up with selected private insurers that agreed to meet state standards for long-term care. But while one million people are candidates for such insurance, only 2,600 policies have been sold. 
 "The hardest thing to do is for people to look in the mirror and look 30 or 40 years from now and being frail and dependent," said David Guttchen, 34, director of the Connecticut Partnership for Long-Term Care.
Through the program, residents can buy individual policies directly from the insurers or through group packages offered by some employers. The policies are not subsidized by the state or by employers, but there are some compelling reasons to get the coverage.
"Basically, what the state does is give these insurance companies the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval," Mr. Guttchen said.
Similar long-term care partnerships exist in three other states: New York, California and Indiana.
Unlike some nonpartnership plans, state-endorsed policies appreciate so that their value keeps pace with inflation. Most policies also offer the option of using insurance money to pay for home care -- an option not always available if elderly people get into financial difficulties and must have their long-term care paid for by welfare.
The state promises that people who buy partnership policies will receive a lifetime of care without draining their life savings.
State officials gave the following example:
An 80-year-old widow has a $100,000 house and $50,000 in mutual funds and bank accounts when she becomes too frail to care for herself.
After staying home for two years with the help of visiting nurses and homemakers, she enters a nursing home. Years earlier, she had bought long-term care insurance, and the policy plus Medicare and some other programs were worth enough to cover her care, both at home and in the institution for about three years.
If she had held a nonpartnership policy, the widow would have been forced to sell her home and run through her savings when the insurance money ran out. She would have to be virtually broke before the state would pick up the tab for her care.
A partnership policy would allow her to apply for Medicaid, the state-paid insurance for the poor, while keeping assets equal to the amount that insurance has already paid out.
So if the widow's policy paid for $150,000 worth of care, she could keep $150,000 worth of assets and still have her care paid for by Medicaid.
Why is the state being so apparently generous?
The answer lies in the growing Medicaid budget. At $921 million now, the cost of keeping impoverished old people in nursing homes already eats up 10 percent of the state budget.
A state study commission estimates that the Medicaid bill for nursing home care will grow to $1.4 billion by 2000. And that's 10 years before the state's huge population of baby boomers starts turning 65.
With the partnership program, the state hopes to reduce its long-term care costs by 7 percent by 2030, Mr. Guttchen said. Meanwhile, he said, the state might be able to help some people retain more of their dignity and their savings as they age.
Even with the asset-protection feature, the state thinks it can save money by making more private money available to pay for nursing home care. And because the average nursing home stay is only 2.5 years, there's a chance that insurance can eliminate the need for Medicaid in some cases.
For more information, one may call the Connecticut Partnership for Long-term Care at (800) 547-3443.

HEADLINE: Getting Into Business, and Surviving

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM 

 BODY:
IT was nearly midday, and inside a hotel conference room in Cromwell, Aldonna Ambler was asking a hushed, spillover crowd how they would eliminate potential rivals.
"C'mon," she urged them, "let's get devious." 
 Suggestions poured forth, but she dismissed them as either tepid or likely to backfire. Finally, she offered a divide-and-conquer strategy.
"Maybe they have a great salesperson," Mrs. Ambler said. "You can try to hire that person away." Even if the person is not hired, she added, it is possible to use a job interview as a means of extracting potentially valuable information about a business rival. "You don't always have to be a charlatan, but you don't always have to take it, either."
One thing about which this audience of small-business owners knows well is "taking it." From investment pullouts to credit crunches, from layoffs to shutdowns, they have been taking it on the chin since the recession of 1989. Even now, with the fog lifting, the state is still lagging behind most of the country in economic growth.
Mrs. Ambler in fact had been preaching growth strategy long before the recession even began, as a charter workshop leader for the state's pre-eminent small-business seminar, the Success Symposium. Begun in 1987, before that year's Wall Street crash, the thrice-a-year seminars have been sponsored by SNET and the Small Business Administration.
Doing unto others before they do unto you was but one small part of Mrs. Ambler's presentation, entitled "Growth Strategies and Survival Tactics." Like others at the seminar, her overall message was one of optimism and resilience. "The best ideas come from fun, not frowns," she said.
Establishing a small business is an uphill trudge, and the odds against success are daunting. Traditionally, one-third of all small-business start-ups fail within a year, and two-thirds within five years. In Connecticut, a stubbornly depressed economy has made conditions particularly tough.
But the forecast is not so dire, according to the S.B.A. administrator in New England, Patrick McGowan. An economy in transition, easier credit terms, and developing niche markets in the wake of large corporate downsizing all bode well, he said. "It's a great time to start and grow a small business," he said.
Connecticut is dependent on small business as never before. Of an estimated 93,000 total businesses operating in the state, 98.7 percent are categorized as small, a definition that encompasses manufacturers with 500 or fewer workers, or retail, service and other businesses employing 100 or fewer people. Since 1993, small businesses have accounted for two out of three new jobs created in Connecticut.
Thus, seminar organizers see their work as vital. For a $99 fee, small-business owners and executives may attend up to five workshops on topics ranging from "Getting the Appointment" to "Customer Service Vs. Customer Serve Us." The all-day symposium also offers free workbooks and "a networking luncheon."
At the recent seminar, Noel de Caprio, owner of the Noelle Spa for Beauty and Wellness, offered introductory remarks, describing how she managed to jump various hurdles, including getting her Stamford salon up and running again 24 hours after it was gutted by fire.
"Determination is very important," she said. "You can do anything if you put your mind to it."
Mrs. de Caprio and S.B.A. officials spoke about the recession as a thing of the past, an outlook with which Peter Gioia of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association concurred. "The recession has been over since the last quarter of 1993," he said. "We have been in a position of slow growth, which has accelerated over the last 12 months."
But Connecticut has only partially recovered from the recession's effects. Of the more than 150,000 jobs the state lost between 1989 and 1993, a great many of them in the once-booming weapons industry, less than a third have been returned.
"We're going through what Texas went through in the downsizing of their oil industry," said Jo-Ann Van Vechten, head of the S.B.A.'s Hartford district. "They diversified, and now they have a healthy economy. We have to go through that kind of transition, which is what we are doing right now."
The small-business owners at the seminar did not seem particularly enamored by the idea of being pioneers of economic change. Nor did they share the view that the recession was totally over.
Frederick Stroiney, president of the Windsor Locks Savings and Loan, called business in the Hartford area "still fairly flat," with losses in the insurance industry hitting particularly hard.
As Lisa S. Murphy, who runs a computer tutoring business in Glastonbury, Techniques P. C. Training and Development, put it, "Our business serves other business, and people are still watching the bottom line before spending."
John Simboli, a partner in the Wyant Simboli Group of Norwalk, a graphics design firm that specializes in World Wide Web pages, remembered a time not long ago when he and his wife were thinking about moving to Texas or Florida because business in the state was so bad.
Now, he said, he sees "slow, measured growth" and "I don't think we were stupid in staying."
Mrs. Ambler, a New Jersey-based business consultant, recalled conducting her growth workshop with a much smaller audience when the recession was at its height. "There's a lot less fear now than there was three or four years ago," she said. "The recession snuck up on some people. Now we deal with people who were with big companies that downsized. They may not want to be an entrepreneur, but this is good for them."
Well, maybe not for all of them. It takes certain skills to be an entrepreneur, seminar organizers agreed.
"This seminar helps a lot of people who think they want to entrepreneurs but who really don't," Ms. Van Vechten said. "They aren't flexible or innovative. They don't want to spend long hours. The traits we are talking about are inborn or learned because people want to have them." Some people, she added, are just more suited to be employees.
Jonathan Costa, a learning coordinator at the Education Center in Litchfield, said his company, which normally has public schools as a customer base, needs to reposition itself in the wake of state budget cuts, and that the seminar was giving him ideas on how to do so.
"The days when you could simply serve public institutions are gone," he said. "You need to market yourself effectively."
Mr. Stroiney called the seminar "a refresher." Even though the Windsor Locks Savings and Loan has been around 80 years, he said, it remains one of the state's smallest financial institutions, with only eight employees. Attending the seminar, he said, stoked thoughts of growth.
"We aren't going to be mortgage lenders forever," he said. "There are opportunities. I'm thinking about larger banks closing up branches. Smaller banks can pick up the slack."
The seminars, begun in 1987, were designed to educate small businesses on the basic elements of success, according to its first director, the SNET executive Arthur K. Olsen. "We said if we can help small businesses grow, and reduce the failure rate, that would be good business for us," he said.
While telephone companies have set up small-business symposiums in other states, Connecticut's is the longest-lived. SNET's current manager for the seminars, Terri Smith, said no single symposium has yet failed to sell at least 250 tickets.
For their part, S.B.A. officials said the program complements an easier credit policy established in 1994, under which loans to small businesses leaped from 60 in 1990 to 773 in 1995.
Still, Mr. McGowan emphasized the ultimate success of a start-up depends on the person managing it. "I tell them it's like being in a room with 100 doors, and 75 are locked," he said. "Only 25 will open. Or maybe only 5 will open. The test you go through as an entrepreneur is to find those doors."
Seminars later this year will be held on Sept. 20 at the Trumbull Marriott Hotel and on Oct. 25 at the Four Points Sheraton in Waterbury. More information is available by calling 800-356-6868.

HEADLINE: Coke at a Price

 BODY:
To the Editor: I have just returned from Paris, with a cautionary tale.
Although you can find Diet Coke in French stores, most cafes and restaurants don't have it. When they do, it's usually a very small bottle, never served with ice, and costs at least $6. One afternoon my traveling companion and I, both tired and thirsty, flopped down at a cafe called Le Soleil d'Or not far from Notre Dame. When I asked the courteous waiter if they had Diet Coke, he said: "Certainly. Would you like a small, medium or large?" Without even thinking I said, "Large, please," figuring it would probably be about 12 ounces. 
 To my astonishment the waiter reappeared with a stein containing about a quart of soda, plus tons of blessed ice. My friend said, "Gee, I hope that doesn't end up costing too much," but I said I didn't care. An hour later we asked for the check. The cost of my soda? 96 francs -- $19! It was too absurd to get upset; I practically fell on the floor laughing. And no, I'm not rich, nor did I dispute the bill, since I'd already finished the soda. Next time I'll economize and order Dom Perignon.
 
ANNE POWELL
North Andover, Mass.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Divided As Two Battle For Congress

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
IN a race that has attracted national attention because it has divided some conservative members of Congress and reflects the Republican Party's split on abortion, Joseph J. DioGuardi is the candidate who won't go away, and Representative Sue W. Kelly is the incumbent trying to deliver the final knockout punch.
The two will face each other in a primary on Sept. 10 for the Republican nomination for the House of Representatives in the 19th District. The predominantly Republican district includes northern Westchester, Putnam, part of White Plains and a part of Dutchess and Orange Counties. 
 For Mr. DioGuardi, a certified public accountant who served in Congress from 1985 to 1988, it has become almost a biennial venture for him to try to regain a seat in the House of Representatives. After his defeat to Nita M. Lowey in 1988 and again in 1992 in what is now the 18th Congressional District, he moved to Mount Pleasant and the 19th Congressional District. In 1994, he narrowly lost a seven-way Republican primary to Mrs. Kelly, then a first-time candidate, and lost again to her in the general election, where he ran on the Conservative and Right to Life lines.
"Why do I run?" Mr. DioGuardi said. "Obviously, the fire has to be in your belly to always campaign. Campaigning is not easy, and I have the energy for it, thank God. But I'm running because people are telling me something is wrong."
What is wrong, he maintained, is that the district has in Mrs. Kelly someone who is a "radical left-of-center liberal" on social issues, including abortion rights and gay rights.
Earlier this month, Mr. DioGuardi, who radiates confidence, was designated the party's Congressional candidate by the leaders of the four-county district, itself split, and he already had the Right to Life party backing. Under his scenario, Republicans with conservative leanings will dominate the primary, give him a victory in September and an easy victory in November over the Democratic candidate, Richard Klein, a Chappaqua doctor.
Mrs. Kelly, in contrast, said of Mr. DioGuardi's candidacy: "I don't think it's particularly a big threat. Every threat is a serious threat, but I intend to win because I know I represent the district. The people in the district talk to me. I've been there and lived in the district for more than 36 years. Joe has not. How can he say he knows what they need?"
She added: "I'm a Republican. Republicans believe in letting local people make their own laws. I believe strongly in personal freedom. Every time I've checked, the district is pro choice." Mrs. Kelly is also running on the Freedom Party line.
Supporting Mrs. Kelly in her bid for a second term is the leadership of the House of Representatives, including Speaker Newt Gingrich and the majority leader, Dick Armey of Texas, who are both against abortion. They and other leaders sent Mr. DioGuardi a letter in June urging him to withdraw from the race. "Should it become necessary, the House Republican Leadership is prepared to commit time and extensive resources to Sue Kelly's re-election efforts," the leaders wrote.
But Mr. DioGuardi refused to be intimidated by the letter, saying the leadership support was part of a policy of supporting Republican incumbents, not a commentary on his own credentials. Referring to the changes the Republican-led Congress has been pushing, he said: "Newt is still a friend. We started this revolution together."
Indeed, some of the most conservative, anti-abortion members of Congress have defied the Republican leadership to support Mr. DioGuardi. Representative Bob Dorman of California and Representative Christopher H. Smith of New Jersey participated in a DioGuardi fund-raising event.
Nonetheless, both Representative Kelly and Mr. DioGuardi agreed that this election would not be decided by Washington insiders but by the people of the district who will vote on the issues and the perceived integrity of the candidates.
While differing on some social issues like abortion, each is claiming to be fiscally conservative. Mr. DioGuardi said of Mrs. Kelly: "It's true she voted mainly with the Contract for America, but that's mainly a fig leaf for the problems of this country. And we still don't have term limits and a balanced-budget amendment. And in Sue Kelly's case, she did something very damaging to herself and the country. She didn't support the Health and Human Services appropriation bill that would have implemented the welfare-reform bill."
Mrs. Kelly's campaign countered by saying that during his last term in office Mr. DioGuardi voted with the Democratic leadership 40 percent of the time while Mrs. Kelly has voted with the Republican leadership 80 percent of the time. "We have reversed the spending habits of the Government," she said.
Both candidates see the economy and jobs as important issues. Mr. DioGuardi, calling Mrs. Kelly "ineffective," faulted her for failing to prevent General Motors from closing its plant in North Tarrytown. Mrs. Kelly countered by saying that the closing was announced during Mr. DioGuardi's tenure in office and that early action from him might have prevented the closing.
Mrs. Kelly said she was also hoping to get mileage out of a political scandal that has haunted Mr. DioGuardi since 1988 when Joseph Crabtree, a DioGuardi supporter, illegally reimbursed employees of his automobile dealership for contributions they had given to Mr. DioGuardi's campaign. Mr. DioGuardi was never charged with any election law violation and said he has been fully vindicated.
The Kelly campaign, however, is not reticent about alluding to the Crabtree matter and recent questions raised in the press about whether the DioGuardi Family Charitable Fund Inc., a tax-exempt foundation that Mr. DioGuardi oversees, violated Federal tax laws by its reported political involvement.
"I think Joe has abused those people who gave to his foundation and the taxpayers," Mrs. Kelly said. "We no longer in this nation can afford to have individuals in Congress who are not of the highest ethical and moral character."
Mr. DioGuardi countered by saying that the Kelly campaign was "recycling old things," trying to "create an aura that there is a problem when there is not." He said his foundation is a good-government organization that fully complies with the law. "There are several things that epitomize Joe DioGuardi," he said. "Joe DioGuardi is energy, perseverance and integrity."
Mr. DioGuardi said: "Whoever wins on Sept. 10, you can bank on it, is your Congressperson," that a Democrat does not have a chance in the November general election.
Mrs. Kelly disagreed, saying, "If he wins, this will be a Democratic seat."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Reviving Those Vacant Department Stores

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
OLD department stores vacated by bankruptcies or corporate restructurings in the late 80's and early 90's are making a comeback. The evidence is in a crop of conversions under way or planned across the state.
Many stores are being carved up and put back together as retail centers for multiple tenants on the lower floors with offices above. 
 A few are being converted to other uses, one as a medically oriented mall.
The key to the appeal of the vacant stores is location. Many occupy prime spots in downtowns or as part of highway malls. Other factors are the state's stable, if not robust, retail climate (the statewide vacancy rate remains flat at 6 percent) and economics.
Generally, it still costs far less to renovate an existing building than to construct a new one, industry analysts say.
Downtowns, which suffered during the regional mall movement in the 60's and 70's, are once again finding favor among shoppers and, in turn, among retailers, said William A. Farber, chief operating officer of Levin Management Corporation in North Plainfield.
The company manages 5 million square feet of retail space in the state.
Such conversions are not without challenges. For one thing many sites have inadequate, and often no, on-site parking -- a prerequisite for success. There is also the problem of what to do with floors above the second level.
"In the suburbs there is no real acceptance of vertical malls," Mr. Farber said. "The solution is that a project has to work on the ground and first levels."
That is the approach being taken by the developer doing the $6 million conversion of the Lord & Taylor store on Millburn Avenue in affluent Millburn, which closed in 1988. Irwin Ackerman, a Woodbridge-based developer, bought the building in 1992 because "locations like these in towns with strong demographics do not exist anymore," he said, noting that the store also had parking for 500 cars.
He has since divided the 120,000-square-foot store, now called Gateway Center, into a home for three retailers on two of its three levels.
They are Fresh Fields, a natural food market, with 30,000 square feet; Home Place, a home-furnishings outlet with 50,000 square feet, and a 10,000-square-foot Revco drugstore.
"You have to find the right mix of tenants," Mr. Ackerman said. But even with that, he added, "it's hard to move people to the third level."
It is also hard to get retailers to move there, so Mr. Ackerman said he was turning 15,000 square feet on the third level into professional offices.
THE same is true for the former B. Altman's in the Fashion Center Mall on Route 17 in Paramus. The 180,000-square-foot three-story building now houses Bed Bath & Beyond and TJ Maxx, each on a full 60,000-square-foot floor.
"We are working on a deal with service users for the top floor," said Richard Steinberg, executive vice president at At Mall Properties in Manhattan.
A group of developers, including principals of At Mall Properties, took over six B. Altman stores when the retailer went bankrupt in 1990 and have repositioned, sold or leased all of them.
The logical re-use for the Route 17 store was retail, said Mr. Steinberg. "We would have liked to find a single user and didn't want to create an interior minimall with lots of smaller stores, which was too dangerous," he said. "Having multiple large tenants works and is less risky."
Big-box retailers with their large appetite for space, said Mr. Farber, the management executive, are the "engine driving the market."
Such retailers want to be in strong downtowns, said Thomas Welsh, a Morristown-based real estate consultant. He is representing the Elblum Holding Company of Morristown, the owner of the former Macy's branch at the corner of Speedwell Avenue and Park Place. The Morris County seat's population of 17,000 swells to 50,000 during the day.
The three-and-a-half-story, 125,000-square-foot store, vacant since 1993, is involved in "active discussions" with single users and developers who want to divide it into several stores, said Mr. Welsh, adding that negotiations for a long-term lease on the property were under way.
Among the developers eying the site is The Applied Companies of Hoboken. If it acquires the store Applied will turn the space, at a cost of about $25 a square foot, into a home-furnishing market with one or two 20,000- to 30,000-square foot anchors, 10 smaller users and perhaps a restaurant, said Michael I. Barry, a company vice president.
"It is a retailing segment not found in the nearby malls," said Mr. Barry. He said in the short term the store's top level would probably be leased as offices.
Stores in urban settings are also being recycled. One is the 1.2-million-square-foot, 16-story former Macy's -- originally built at the turn of the century as the flagship of the Bamberger's department-store chain , which occupies an entire block in downtown Newark.
A Manhattan-based partnership, comprising Samuel Jemal and his brothers, Joseph and David, and Edward Friedman, are under contract to buy the building, where the bottom retail floors have been closed since 1991.
Until recently, the top floors were used by Macy's for its computer operation.
The plan, said Samuel Jemal, is to subdivide the two lower 80,000-square-foot floors into retail space for one or two 30,000-square-foot users and 15 to 20 smaller ones, from fast-food chains to apparel stores, needing an average of 3,000 square feet each.
The basement will be turned into 400 parking spaces, which he said would be an attraction and "key to the project's overall success."
The 240,000-square-foot, $6 million first phase, he said, will create the "cash flow" necessary to redevelop the upper floors as below market-rate office and warehouse space.
Mr. Jemal said the partners had bought the store at an attractive price and considered Newark's downtown retail climate "vibrant."
Construction on the first phase is to begin in September and occupancy is expected by next spring, he said. Rents have not yet been set.
THERE are also plans for 609 Broad Street, the four-story, 421,800-square-foot landmark former Hahne's store that was built in 1901 and closed in 1986. Its basement will become a garage for 160 cars, and the first floor will be carved into 75,000 square feet of shops and perhaps a restaurant and a nightclub.
The second and third levels will become offices, said Miles Berger. He, his brother, Bruce, and his cousin Solomon are redeveloping the store in anticipation of the completion of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center.
It is taking shape just across Broad Street and is to open next year.
Mr. Berger said the more than $2 million retail conversion would begin once the city approved his application for a tax abatement.
He said the hope was to have the stores open by next May. Rents are to start at $18 a square foot net, he said.
Some stores, like the former 110,00 square foot Hahne's in downtown Montclair, vacant since 1989, are being recycled to different uses. A group of New York and New Jersey investors plan to turn the two-and-a-half-story store, at the corner of Church and South Park Street, into a mall-like medical center.
The $15 million project, Healthcare Center at Montclair, will have 40 percent of the space devoted to anchor tenants, affiliated with hospitals, and the rest to medical and health-related services and retail uses. A parking lot across Church Street, which is part of the property, will become a 315-car garage.
"The building's downtown location fit the future model for healthcare," said James G. Wurm, project manager for York Hunter, a construction management concern with offices in Newark and Manhattan that will renovate the store and erect the garage. The store's large floors also lent themselves to the new use and enough could be salvaged to be cost effective, said Mr. Wurm, whose firm has offices in Newark and Manhattan.
There are signed commitments for 20 percent of the space. "Half the building must be preleased to trigger financing and start construction," said Mr. Wurm. "It is not out of the question that work can start by year's end."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
Score Another for the Woodsy Corporate Culture

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

DATELINE: ARMONK

 BODY:
IN a search that lasted two years and pitted New York State against Connecticut, Swiss Re America finally decided to build its new North American headquarters in this countrified corporate community, best known as the home of I.B.M.
"It was a battle right to the end," said John A. Lombardi, the Supervisor of the Town of North Castle, of which Armonk is a part. "They made us work very hard, right to the bone. Every day I thought we were going to lose them." 
 In the last few months, after looking at properties in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, Swiss Re America narrowed its choice to two sites. One, a pristine plot of wooded property on King Street in Armonk, overlooks the Kensico Reservoir. The other, in sharp contrast, is an urban property at Tresser Boulevard and Greyrock Place in Stamford, near the site where the Swiss Bank Corporation is building its headquarters.
"People wondered at the choice between two sites that are so different," said Heidi E. Hutter, chief executive of Swiss Re America, a subsidiary of the huge reinsurer Swiss Re, which protects insurers against catastrophic losses. "Stamford had the attraction of being in a community of other reinsurance companies in an urban setting.
"But it came down not to what the company needed at this point in time, but looking through a 50- to 100-year horizon. And we decided we wanted to be in a campus-like setting and establish our own identity apart from other companies."
The esthetics and pristine state of the Armonk property were also in its favor, Ms. Hutter said. "Once we decided to go with the campus setting, this was by far the most beautiful site," she said.
Earlier in its search, Swiss Re America looked at existing buildings but could find none to its liking. "To be candid," she said, "I was initially in horror about the prospect of constructing a new building, but we found we had to in order to get what we wanted."
Swiss Re America occupies 330,000 square feet in five buildings in midtown Manhattan. Its head offices are at 237 Park Avenue. "The move to Armonk will enable the company to consolidate its operations," said Stephen B. Siegel, president of the Edward S. Gordon Company, which brokered the deal. "But it plans to keep its Financial Services Group in midtown. I'm now looking for a 180,000-square-foot space for it."
IN Armonk, the company plans to build a 300,000-square-foot building with rights for an additional 60,000 square feet. The project is expected to cost $100 million.
The site has already been approved for up to 720,000 square feet, built in two phases, Mr. Lombardi, the town supervisor, said. "It was done for another project in 1988, which never materialized when the real estate market declined."
The proposed design will include several wings "like long fingers," branching off a central core, said Sara Fox, senior vice president at Swiss Re America. It fits into the corporate culture established by the parent company, based in Zurich. "In Europe, there are strict regulations about building design and employee access to air and light," she said.
"In our new building, there will be floor-to-ceiling glass and no employee will sit more than 35 to 40 feet from a window," Ms. Fox said. "It might not be the most efficient design, like in speculative buildings designed for maximum efficiency with massive floor plates where people have to sit in cubicles. But we want all our employees to have access to the beautiful site."
Swiss Re America's decision to move to Westchester, which was announced on June 27, is expected to bring 650 new employees into the market. "It's very exciting," said Martin Berger, co-founder of the Robert Martin Company of Elmsford, the county's largest owner of commercial office space. "It will have positive residual effects in all areas, not just the office market. Our printing and advertising companies will benefit, as will housing and shopping centers."
When a major company leaves Manhattan, Mr. Berger said, "it usually keeps its umbilical cord attached there for a while until it realizes that using local companies is just fine."
"After about a five-year period," he added, "one will more easily see all the economic benefits that will be derived."
The deal does not, however, alleviate the office market's most pressing problem, which is vacant space. "But it's bound to have a positive impact on the county's image as a headquarters location," Mr. Siegel said. "This is also a growth company and its success at its new location will benefit the entire region."
Mr. Berger said he thought more companies might relocate to Westchester to build their own headquarters. "Manhattan is really tightening," he said. "We'll start to see more companies looking to the suburbs to expand."
One of the most immediate benefits will be the addition to North Castle's tax base. "Swiss Re will become the town's third largest taxpayer." Mr. Lombardi said. New York City, whose water system is in the region, is first and I.B.M. is second.
TO get the company, the town had to offer assurances of a speedy approval process. "That was absolutely critical," Ms. Fox said. "Now that we've made our decision, we want everything to happen tomorrow."
Ms. Fox is hoping for all approvals to be in place by early 1997. "We intend to start construction in the spring," she said.
The state contributed incentives, including a $500,000 interest subsidy grant, $400,000 in construction loans and grants and a promise of $50,000 to $60,000 in job-training funds.
The state Department of Transportation also promised to expedite a scheduled improvement of King Street, or Route 120. A 2.7-mile section will be realigned and widened from two lanes to four, including the improvement of two intersections, one at Route 22 and one at the Old Post Road. And exits 2 and 4 on Interstate 684 will be redesigned to handle more traffic.
"Without the road work, we couldn't have made the decision to move 650 employees to Armonk," Ms. Fox said.
The design work on the project has already begun, Mr. Lombardi said. "The various agencies are now meeting with the State Department of Environmental Conservation to prepare the impact statement."
Landing Swiss Re America required the effort of several government agencies "all working together to convince the company that Westchester would be a friendly business environment," said Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, a state agency designed to attract business to New York.
Gov. George E. Pataki got personally involved by placing several calls to Ms. Hutter. "He wanted to assure her that her company was wanted and we'd be willing to assist in their New York search in any way possible," Mr. Gargano said. "We're not in a position to throw money around. But we try to help where we can."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sara Fox of Swiss Re America at Armonk site of the reinsurer's new national headquarters. A model of the complex is above. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)
(Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CHATTER;
On Teaching and Coaching

 BODY:
Chatter recently asked for opinions on year-round schools and for advice to Coach Dan Reeves of the Giants. Here are some replies.
 
Entering the 21st Century
There should be year-round schools not only for economic reasons but also because today's students need every advantage they can get to survive in a fast-changing, highly technical world. 
 Teachers need to be paid according to their ability and time, but they too must move into the 21st century. Half-days and in-service days and administrative days and conference days are all dinosaurs from the past and need to be put behind us as quickly as possible and do what's right for my grandchildren and then some.
 
BARBARA BENNETT
Neptune
 
Old History, New Math
With Japan and Germany already implementing 240-day school years, what is America waiting for?
Schools used to close in the summer because many teachers as well as students went back to the farms to plant for the fall harvest. Hardly a reason in 1996 to give an active mind three months to do nothing!
The biggest obstruction to extending the school year are the powerful teachers' unions, which have figured out how to make 12 months' salary on 10 months of work!
 
NICK ANTONICELLO
North Arlington
 
Pre-Season Quarterbacking
1. Find a quarterback.
2. Hire all Joe Paterno's assistants from Penn State.
3. Release all players who had a 3.5 average in school and replace with 2.5-average students who can run, block and tackle and generally play football.
 
PETER MARSH
Brick
 
Is Dallas for Sale?
Dan Reeves should make superhuman efforts to bring together Donald Trump, Steve Wynn and Governor Whitman to purchase the Dallas Cowboys and bring them here. The Donald and Wynn can come up with the money and the Governor can oil the way with offers that no one can refuse.
 
JOHN NICHOLS
Fair Lawn
 
Keep Your Eye on the Ball
SUNY Albany is a great place for the Giants to train. I work there. If they keep focused on practice and not the diversions (bars, etc.), they might actually come out looking good!
 
CAROL VAN DENBURGH
Kinderhook, N.Y.
 
A New Training Film
Coach Reeves should make his players watch the movie "Little Giants" for inspiration.
 
KEVIN D'ANTONIO, age 8
VINCENT D'ANTONIO JR., age 5
North Bergen

HEADLINE: Community Interests Vs. Property Rights

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
A SWEET summer breeze sends shallow waves rippling through the blue canvas awning on the terrace at the Bonnie Briar Country Club in Mamaroneck. Diners gaze over 150 acres of rolling landscape, a verdant palette of a dozen hues, from the deep emerald of the fir trees to the pale jade of the willows.
On the course, accompanied by bird songs and hovering squadrons of dragonflies, golfing parties (who are these people who get to play on weekdays, anyway?) make their way back and forth over the west branch of the Sheldrake River, which doubles as a water hazard for the 13th, 14th, 16th and 17th holes. 
 It doesn't appear as if anything is missing from Bonnie Briar.
But something very important has been taken away, say the owners of the acreage: their right -- their Constitutional right -- to develop the property. The owners, Bonnie Briar Syndicate Inc., had planned 71 homes along a curving, roughly A-shaped roadway, realigning the golf course around the perimeter of the residential cluster.
When new zoning frustrated their plans, the syndicate took the Town of Mamaroneck to court. In doing so, they joined a host of "takings" cases that have proliferated nationwide in recent years. Property owners, encouraged by several Supreme Court rulings, are turning more frequently to the Fifth Amendment -- "nor shall private property be taken for public use without just compensation" -- to escape what they see as burdensome land-use regulations. Wetlands and endangered-species laws are prime targets of the property-rights movement, but zoning provisions have also been challenged.
Until two years ago, Bonnie Briar was zoned to allow single-family dwellings on minimum lots of either 15,000 or 30,000 square feet. But in 1994, the Town Board rezoned the property, in the interest of preserving open space and recreational resources, reducing the potential for flooding hazards and maintaining the "suburban quality of the community as a whole." The new zoning limited uses chiefly to private recreation facilities (in other words, what was there already) and prohibited residential development altogether.
Bonnie Briar Syndicate, which leases the land to the Bonnie Briar Country Club, sued the Town Board. The syndicate asserted that its property had effectively been taken by the government, in violation of the Fifth Amendment. Earlier this month, the rezoning was upheld by Judge Peter M. Leavitt of State Supreme Court in Westchester County. But a lawyer for the owners said an appeal would be sought, so the fight over Bonnie Briar is not over.
Nor is it the only significant "takings" case in New York. Another Westchester town, Cortlandt, is being challenged by the owners of a 128-acre former emery mine. The property was bought by Briarcliff Associates, a subsidiary of the Thalle Construction Company, a major road and utility contractor, with a view toward using it as a quarry.
The town rezoned the area for housing but the owners said residential development would be impossible, since there was not adequate septic capacity, an assertion the town disputes. Claiming that they had been denied all economically viable use of their property, the owners sued. The case is now before Judge Francis A. Nicolai of State Supreme Court for a decision.
Courthouses are not the only places where "takings" battles are being fought. An Omnibus Property Rights Act, introduced last year by Bob Dole, is pending in the United States Senate. It would require compensation to owners if a governmental action diminished the fair market value of their property by 33 percent or more. A similar measure was passed last year by the House of Representatives. President Clinton has already said he would veto the property-rights act or any other compensation-entitlement bill if it reached his desk.
Compensation laws have been enacted in Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi and Texas, according to Nancie G. Marzulla, president and chief legal counsel of a national group called Defenders of Property Rights, based in Washington. The compensation threshold in these laws varies from a 20- to a 40-percent loss of value, she said.
In the New York State Assembly, Robert A. Straniere, Republican of Staten Island, introduced a bill that would entitle owners to compensation if a government regulation, except one that prevented noxious uses or protected public health and safety, reduced the value of their property by more than 50 percent. It had not emerged from committee by the end of the session and would have to be reintroduced.
"We're not talking about speculators," Mr. Straniere said. "We're talking about people who bought property in good faith -- maybe to build a home for themselves or a few units -- in an area that wasn't obviously environmentally sensitive, who find out they can't use their property. The Supreme Court has identified this as an area for legitimate redress."
What the United States Supreme Court has done is to expand the concept of regulatory "takings." The underlying premise is that land-use controls can effectively deprive owners of the use their property every bit as much as outright seizure, leaving owners to pick up the tab for common benefits -- like waterfront access or undeveloped open space -- that should be borne by the public at large.
As a general proposition, a regulation must substantially advance a legitimate government interest and not deprive a property of all of its economic value. It was long ago established by the Supreme Court that if a regulation went "too far," it would be recognized as a taking. But for most of this century, the Court was largely silent on the subject.
"It used to be that when you talked about the Fifth Amendment, people thought you were talking about self-incrimination," said Roger J. Marzulla, who heads the environmental law section at the influential Washington firm of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld. (He is also Nancie's husband.) "As few as five years ago, when you talked about the just-compensation clause, people had no idea what you were talking about."
He said the new cases "indicated that the Supreme Court is serious about property rights, that compensation is indeed due and that government at all levels must take into account the extent of private property rights."
But Jerold S. Kayden, associate professor of urban planning at the Harvard Graduate School of Design, said that recent legislative action "reflects a recognition by property-rights advocates that they have not yet achieved the victory they wanted in the judicial branch."
"We're still left scratching our heads about what happens when a regulation has a severe impact but the property value isn't diminished to zero," Mr. Kayden said. "The fact that millions of dollars may be foregone by the impact of regulation doesn't automatically trigger a constitutional finding of a taking. But between the cup and the lip is a large area for further exploration."
On everyone's lips these days are the words "rough proportionality," the latest addition to the Fifth Amendment lexicon, introduced by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, writing for the majority in a 1994 case known as Dolan v. City of Tigard.
"It has put a new arrow in the quiver of those who are challenging takings," said James M. Altman of Robinson Silverman Pearce Aronsohn & Berman in Manhattan, lawyers for the Town of Mamaroneck in the Bonnie Briar case.
Tigard is a suburb of Portland, Ore., in which the Dolan family has a plumbing and electric supply store. The Dolans applied for a permit to double the size of the store and pave a parking lot. The city granted the permit on the condition that they dedicate part of the property along the flood plain of a creek for a storm-drainage system and public greenway and that they dedicate a 15-foot strip as a pedestrian-bicycle pathway. The requirement involved about 10 percent of the property.
The Dolans appealed the decision on the ground that the requirements were not related to the proposed development and amounted to a taking. The Oregon Land Use Board of Appeals upheld the city, noting that the paved lot would add runoff into the creek and that the new store would generate more traffic.
Chief Justice Rehnquist said that the city had not adequately quantified how the pathway would offset traffic demand and that it was difficult to see how recreational visitors "trampling" along the greenway was sufficiently related to the city's interest in reducing flooding problems.
"We think a term such as 'rough proportionality' best encapsulates what we hold to be the requirement of the Fifth Amendment," the Chief Justice wrote. "No precise mathematical calculation is required, but the city must make some sort of individualized determination that the required dedication is related both in nature and extent to the impact of the proposed development."
Three months ago, the Tigard City Council revised the permit conditions, calling for easements through the property, rather than the dedication of property to public use. Liz Newton, assistant to the city administrator, said the Dolans could have reapplied for a building permit.
Dan Dolan, one of the plaintiffs, said the basic conditions had not changed. "It's just an easement instead of an outright taking," he said. "What's the difference?" He said the family suffered at least a "temporary taking" over the four years that it took to pursue their case. They are seeking damages from the city in a case that is to go to trial next month.
Mr. Marzulla believes the Dolan case will ultimately limit the "unreasonable demands" of local and county governments for the dedication of property as part of the approval process. "Everybody sits there and says, 'That would make a great park, we'd love to have a greenway or a riverwalk,' " he said. "That's the kind of deal-making cities do. The only way you can justify that now is to show that it's an even-steven trade, so that the property owner is not being required to hand over more than his fair share."
But Peter Byrne, a professor of law at the Georgetown University Law Center, said the influence of Dolan and related cases had been "quite slight" and that state courts "have not been particularly impressed by the rhetorical invitation in those cases to be much more vigorous for property rights."
A lawyer for the Town of Mamaroneck, Judith M. Gallent, noted that the Dolan case did not apply to all regulations but rather to exactions of property. Her colleague, Robert S. Davis, agreed that Dolan was not "earth-shaking," but said it was "important because it provides a new way of asserting the claim."
Indeed, Dolan's "rough proportionality" line was one of the arguments advanced on behalf of the Bonnie Briar Syndicate by its lawyer, Stuart R. Shamberg, of Shamberg Marwell Hocherman Davis & Hollis in Mount Kisco, as was the "nexus" between impact and exaction that the Supreme Court called for in Nollan v. California Coastal Commission.
"There is no close nexus between the deprivation of my client's right to construct residential housing on the property and the municipal goal of preserving open space," Mr. Shamberg said. "It was our position -- and it still is -- that it's unconstitutional to take away our right to develop the property if our plan would have preserved the open space."
"The remedy was disproportionate to the municipal goal," he said.
In his decision, however, Judge Leavitt said the invocation of catch-phrases like nexus and proportionality was "out of context and entirely inefficacious for the analysis required herein."
Judge Leavitt said that while Bonnie Briar had been zoned residentially for more than 70 years, no development proposal was submitted until December 1993, when the enactment of the new zoning was all but inevitable. "Such circumstances are hardly indicative that the use which had been preferred in the past is no longer 'economically viable' simply because another use, to which the property had never been put, is no longer permitted," he wrote.
In Mamaroneck, the owners protested losing the right to residential development. In Cortlandt, the owners, Briarcliff Associates, protested gaining the right to residential development -- since, they argued, such development is impossible on the 128-acre site, known as Salt Hill.
"They have unconstitutionally taken all of our economic benefit from that land," said Mr. Shamberg, who represents Briarcliff Associates as well as the Bonnie Briar Syndicate. "You cannot use that property for any residential uses. It is a mountain of rock. The highest and best use of that property is clearly as an aggregate mine."
Briarcliff Associates is suing the Town of Cortlandt for the value of the mine, which it estimates at more than $9 million, plus interest compunded back to the day of the rezoning. Mr. Shamberg said there was "no question" that Briarcliff would have received a permit from the state to operate a mine at Salt Hill.
A lawyer for the town, Daniel Riesel of Sive, Paget & Riesel in Manhattan, said Cortlandt taxpayers should not be required to pay Briarcliff Associates "as a reward for their efforts to circumvent state and local law in their attempt to convert a small innocuous emery mine into a massive crushed-stone facility."
"Nor can plaintiffs credibly argue that Salt Hill had a fair market value of over $9 million," Mr. Riesel said, "just two and a half years after they paid $400,000 and it remained an unpermitted, undeveloped and abandoned property."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Gina S. Kim, Ira A. Apfel

 BODY:
Gina Soon Kim, a daughter of Drs. In-Soon and Young Wook Kim of Yardley, Pa., was married last evening in Bryn Mawr, Pa., to Ira Aaron Apfel, a son of Fanchon and Jerome B. Apfel of Gladwyne, Pa. Rabbi Julie Greenberg performed the ceremony in Thomas Great Hall at Bryn Mawr College. The Rev. Poong W. Kim, a Presbyterian minister, took part in the ceremony.
The bride, 26, is a candidate for a combined M.S. and Ph.D. degree in labor economics at Cornell University. She graduated cum laude from Bryn Mawr. Her father is an anesthesiologist at Lower Bucks Hospital in Bristol, Pa. Her mother is a pediatrician in Morrisville, Pa. 
 The bridegroom, 28, is a freelance writer in Ithaca, N.Y. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. His father is of counsel to Blank, Rome, Comiskey & McCauley, a Philadelphia law firm.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
You're Stung by Stocks. Are Bonds the Balm?

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
AS the stock market seesaws, investors may be tempted by the security of the bond market. But in recent years bonds have quietly shed their image as safe investments for a much racier one. Moreover, their newfound volatility seems to be here to stay.
The overriding question, however, is whether now is a good time for people who have been battered by stocks to turn to bonds. 
 Unfortunately, there is no simple answer. Domestic bond performance typically is tied to the United States economy; the more sluggish the economy, the better bonds perform. But today, top fixed-income analysts paint vastly different pictures for the economy, and they come to starkly opposite conclusions.
Yes, buy bonds, says William H. Gross, fixed-income manager at Pacific Investment Management in Newport Beach, Calif., money managers and advisers to the Pimco mutual funds. The current advantages of bonds are clear: you lock up a yield of close to 7 percent and pick up some price appreciation if interest rates fall. And he predicts they will, with the 30-year Treasury bond rate falling to 6.5 percent by the end of the year as the economy weakens.
"The two biggest spark plugs for the first half of the year are not with us for the second half," Mr. Gross argued: Consumers have lost their enthusiasm for spending as the stock market has given up a chunk of its gains for the year, and mortgage refinancing has all but evaporated as interest rates have crept higher.
Higher consumer debt levels will also help brake economic growth in the next 6 to 12 months, said Laird Landmann, a fixed-income portfolio manager with Hotchkis & Wiley, money managers in Los Angeles.
He has started buying already. "No one is smart enough to call interest rate turns, so we try to be disciplined," he said. He views the 4 percent real long-bond rate -- the difference between interest rates and the inflation rate -- as a signal. Then, he said, "we begin to move the duration and maturity of our portfolios slightly higher."
He pushed the duration of the Hotchkis & Wiley Low Duration fund up to 2 years from 1.5, and the Total Return fund to 5.5 years from 5. The longer maturity is expected to bring a bigger return.
A slowing economy gives bondholders confidence that inflation will remain under control and, if so, bond prices can rise and yields fall.
The biggest question mark is on the wage front. The latest employment report showed a sharp jump in wages, but on average they rose only 3.4 percent in the last 12 months, Mr. Gross said, "and that's relatively low for the sixth year of an economic recovery."
In Congressional testimony on Thursday, the Federal Reserve Chairman, Alan Greenspan, helped ease wage-inflation fears, Mr. Gross said. "He suggested wages are controlled by global trade, accelerating technology and other secular forces, and didn't foresee any slackening off of those forces." Holding wages down would mitigate the need for the Fed to raise rates, Mr. Gross said.
H. Bradlee Perry, former president of David L. Babson & Company, investment counselors in Cambridge, Mass., finds that bonds offer good value based on their poor showing so far this year. The Lehman Brothers Aggregate Bond Index lost 1.2 percent in the first six months, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 10.1 percent.
Why didn't bonds rally more when stocks tumbled this month, since the stock decline was at least partly because of worries about the economy?
Bonds' failure to surge "suggests that there's concern about inflation floating around the market," said Chip Norton, managing editor of IBC's Bond Fund and Money Fund Report in Ashland, Mass.
Mr. Norton takes a middle view. He is not recommending bonds now because of market uncertainty over short-term Fed policy. But he says short-term Treasury issues and money markets are good places to park money at the moment because top-performing money funds are yielding only about 1.25 percentage points less than 30-year bonds.
A contrarian position is held by Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley in New York. Don't buy bonds, he said.
"Since the beginning of the year, investors have harbored the notions that the economy is weak, inflation is dead and the Federal Reserve has nothing to do," he said. But the economy has improved every month, he said, and now it is strong enough that inflation poses a threat in 1997.
The Fed must shape policy based on what it believes will happen a year out, and "I think they will conclude interest rates are too low, even relative to today's inflation rate," Mr. Roach said.
Bonds would rate a buy if the economy weakened appreciably in the next six months, but that won't happen, he argued, because "the economy is well supported by fundamental income growth, still-competitive currency, the need for business to boost productivity and the dynamics of the inventory cycle."
Referring to Mr. Greenspan's comments, Mr. Roach said, "I saw the Fed laying the framework for eventual monetary tightening." Bond rallies, like the one after the Greenspan testimony, he said, should be seen as opportunities to sell.
Even people willing to take the plunge into bonds best beware, Mr. Perry said. The image of bonds as tranquil investments with predictable returns began to fray when inflation accelerated in the mid-1960s, and was destroyed when inflation and interest rates jumped to double digits from 1979 to 1982.
More recently, most investors expected bond prices to resume their placid nature once inflation eased. But while inflation has been a steady 2.6 to 3 percent during the last four years, long-term bond prices have fluctuated as much as 20 percent since late 1993.
A variety of factors have caused this basic change, which is likely to persist indefinitely, Mr. Perry said. They include the increased speculation in more complex bonds and derivative securities, the growing amount of government debt worldwide and the globalization of financial markets, which has limited the Fed's influence. The growth of bond mutual funds, from $300 billion in 1985 to $800 billion just before the bond market slump in 1994, has not helped either.
At least for now, bonds will remain volatile, Mr. Perry concluded. What can investors do? He recommends intermediate-term bonds, which have about half the price volatility of longer-term issues over time. Most important, he said, an investor can no longer be sanguine about bonds and should be careful about their maturities and quality.

HEADLINE: Who's Hanging Together? Club Owners

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL

 BODY:
IT is no secret that New York club life is hurting.
The crackdown on clubs by City Hall, the end of the libertine 1980's and the eclipse of a diverse clientele of artists, celebrities and outrageous personalities by a largely under-21 crowd -- all have led to the demise of dance clubs as hip hangouts. 
 Then there is the indictment in May of Peter Gatien on charges of turning two of his megaclubs, Limelight and the Tunnel, into Ecstasy bazaars.
In an effort to climb out of the sump, about a dozen normally rivalrous club owners agreed to found a trade group last week to fight common woes. The New York City Cabaret Association, as it is likely to be known, arose from a meeting last Monday at the Bottom Line in Greenwich Village.
The get-together was organized by Andrew Rasiej, the owner of Irving Plaza, and David Hershkovits, the editor in chief of Paper magazine. Mr. Hershkovits said that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's vaunted quality-of-life campaign has included an effort to close clubs.
"Anything construed as trendy or hip that will attract too many people or the wrong kind of people has a real problem," Mr. Hershkovits said. "I think there's a cultural bias against people who stay up late."
Bar and club owners complained of harassment by the police and other city departments for noise and traffic violations in neighborhoods that have gentrified after clubs pioneered them. Hilly Kristal, the owner of CBGB in the East Village, said he was fined $2,000 when a band played without his consent on a truck outside his club.
"It seems to me the community boards have a system to stop places from opening up," said Nur Khan, the owner of Wax bar in SoHo.
The meeting also included city officials. "While your bottom line is that you want to make money, my bottom line is I have constituents who want to sleep at night," said Kathryn E. Freed, a City Council member.
Capt. Thomas Lawrence of the 10th Precinct in Chelsea said that on Sunday nights, when the Tunnel holds a hip-hop party that draws as many as 2,000 young people, neighborhood car thefts and robberies rise. "It's not harassment," Captain Lawrence said of the police efforts. "We go to community board meetings and hear we're not doing enough."
Club owners have rarely made common cause. A number are secretly hoping for Mr. Gatien's fall, Mr. Hershkovits said, so that they can carve up his empire. The eye-patched Mr. Gatien, who was present, donated $3,000 to the cabaret association.
Mr. Hershkovits, whose magazine depends in part on nightlife advertising, has been urging the owners for months to unite to promote clubdom as vital to the New York economy.
"The music industry, P.R. people, magazine editors -- they all go to clubs when they're young, and this is how they get into the business," Mr. Hershkovits said.

HEADLINE: NEIHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;
New Hopes, Old Worries Over Big Mall

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
At Triangle Sports on Flatbush and Fifth Avenues, Bill Shapiro keeps a framed photo of his grandmother, Bessie. It was taken in the summer of 1916, when Bessie Shapiro first opened the shop and posed next to a sign advertising Army cots for $3.50.
Today, Mr. Shapiro, 58, fears that his sporting goods and Army surplus store will fade into history, like those $3.50 Army cots. Mr. Shapiro and other small-business owners in the area fear that they will become casualties of the giant Atlantic Center shopping mall under construction at Atlantic and Flatbush Avenues. The 380,000-square-foot shopping center is to open this fall. 
 "The world is going to change," Mr. Shapiro said, surrounded by stacks of sneakers and hiking boots. "We're really an anachronism. Now, with these big stores coming into the city, it's a challenge."
For others, it's a renewal. Although there is grumbling among Flatbush Avenue and Fulton Street merchants, there is also a sense in the surrounding communities that the $85 million mall will revitalize the area. Pathmark will provide the neighborhood with a desperately needed supermarket, some residents say, and retail chain stores will bring a wider variety of goods at lower prices.
William Vinnecomb, the chairman of Community Board 2, which includes the mall area, said that although he is concerned about traffic and the fate of small shopkeepers, he hopes the supermarket and other retailers at the mall will keep dollars in the borough with cheaper prices, better services and greater variety. "We're happy to see the development move forward," he said. "It is continuing the renaissance of downtown Brooklyn."
But residents have some concerns, too. There is anxiety about the traffic that the mall will draw and complaints about the noise and inconvenience that construction has wrought. Several neighborhood groups are pressing the developer, Forest City Ratner Companies, to insure that local residents will be hired for the estimated 1,250 permanent jobs projected at the mall's retail shops.
"We fully support the hiring of local people," the developer's spokeswoman, Joyce Baumgarten, said. "These individual stores do their own hiring. We have nothing to do with it. But most of these retail stores do hire locally. That's what is so wonderful about this development."
Today, residents and shopkeepers are waiting to see what the giant mall will do for their slice of brownstone Brooklyn.
Ron Shiffman, the director of the Pratt Center for Community and Environmental Development and a city planning commissioner, said that the "big-box stores" at Atlantic Center signal a shift in downtown Brooklyn's commercial development, which has been led primarily by local entrepreneurs and a few chain stores. The mall, he contends, threatens the viability of smaller shops and detracts from the urban nature of brownstone Brooklyn.
"It is designed with a suburban mall mentality in an urban area," he said. SOMINI SENGUPTA
