HEADLINE: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;
Slicing the Last of the Regulated Monopolies

BYLINE: By LESTER P. SILVERMAN; Lester P. Silverman is a director of McKinsey & Company, the management consulting firm, in Washington.

 BODY:
MERGERS, restructuring, alliances: We've become used to these headline-making events in the telephone industry. It is still unsettling, however, when such news involves electric utilities.
Well, customers and investors, get ready. The current takeover battle over a utility in Kansas, the recent merger of electric and gas companies in Texas and nontraditional alliances -- like the one including Ameritech and Wisconsin Electric to provide interactive energy information -- are only early indications of the revolutionary changes about to occur in the last remaining regulated monopoly. 
 Since 1978, when a Federal law opened power generation to private companies, the market has become more competitive. Today, marketers -- both utility affiliates and independents -- offer to supply power at about 40 percent below the costs that utilities are passing along to customers. Including the transmission and distribution of the electricity, these prices are still 15 percent lower, on average.
Evidence from other industries, like telecommunications and natural gas, and from other countries shows that customers who gain the right to choose their electricity supplier will exercise that right. Almost half the large customers in Britain, for example, have switched suppliers since they were given this choice five years ago.
In this country, it is not surprising that Federal regulation has accommodated these market forces by providing wholesale customers like municipalities with access to the transmission system. And pilot experiments, allowing consumers to choose their electricity suppliers, much as they do their long-distance telephone companies, are under way. Soon all customers in California will have the option, and Massachusetts and New York are likely to follow suit. Federal legislation introduced this month would provide for customer choice nationally.
The results of all this will be the end of the electric utility industry as we know it. In its place, three distinct, but linked, businesses are emerging: power generation, wires and energy services.
Power generation will be a highly competitive commodity business. Power producers -- utilities as well as independents -- will be fighting it out in regional markets defined primarily by constraints in the transmission network. Price transparency, aided by the proliferation of spot markets and futures contracts like those recently initiated by the New York Mercantile Exchange, will stimulate even more competition.
The transition will be painful for many of today's generators. Costs that customers will no longer cover for expensive plants and contracts -- "stranded costs" in industry jargon -- could require the eventual write-off of about $135 billion, about equal to the equity of American utilities.
Successful generators will have low costs and will be astute in playing regional power markets. Many of today's players won't cut it, and a huge consolidation of generating plants by efficient producers is inevitable.
THE wires business -- the transmission and distribution of electricity -- will remain regulated but will be operated by utilities or third parties, with access to the wires open to all.
Operators of distribution wires will seek regulation that encourages efficiency. Regulators are expected to go along, provided that the savings are shared with customers. Some competitors will seek economies of scale by consolidating assets and activities with neighboring electric and other utilities, including providers of natural gas, water and possibly telephone and cable service. The recent merger of the Texas Utilities Company, a power company, with the Enserch Corporation, a gas utility, and the acquisition of a British water company by its local electric distributor are early moves toward "wires and pipes" companies.
The energy services business, which involves the packaging of different types of energy and other services, is just getting started. The leading edge of this business is the marketing of power -- generated by low-cost providers and moved for a fee across the wires of intervening utilities -- to wholesale customers. Since it was first allowed in 1992, more than 200 companies have entered this business. The early leaders have been natural-gas marketers and financial traders who have had a decade to perfect their game. But the big contest is still ahead.
Consider, for instance, the service businesses born of telecommunications deregulation. Cellular phones, paging, conference calling and a host of other services now account for about 25 percent of telecommunications revenue. Several companies are looking for the energy equivalent of these services by offering packaged natural gas, electricity and related services to grocery, fast-food and hotel chains; residential customers are next.
What will the electric power industry look like in about a decade? There will probably be a small number of national-scale generators -- perhaps a dozen or so --, supplemented by regional and niche players. Many of today's electric utilities will be little more than regulated wires companies, but some will have grown by acquiring neighboring wires and other operations. Many companies -- maybe banks, retailers or other service companies -- will offer electricity, usually bundled with other products and services.
Although electric mergers have become more frequent, the industry's future probably holds more horizontal than vertical consolidation. Companies that aspire to be regional or national generators will seek only generating assets, not the forever-regulated wires attached to today's integrated utilities. Others will shun the competitive generation business but may be interested in acquiring distribution assets to consolidate wires-only or wires-and-pipes businesses.
Tough choices are ahead. Investors, who have seen electric utilities underperform the market in recent years, have the difficult task of picking winners. Policy makers must sort through the competing interests to balance demands for lower rates with the need to establish rules for effective long-term competition. Perhaps the toughest decisions are faced by the utilities as they try to remake themselves. Customers should benefit from lower prices and more options, but how much they do so will depend on how astute their choices are.

HEADLINE: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;
In Search of the Best Market Barometer

BYLINE: By LAURA PEDERSEN 

 BODY:

Q. What is the best stock market indicator to watch?
 ERIN SLEET
 Kansas City, Mo.
 
A. If I knew, I'd be -- as the old song goes -- as rich as Rockefeller. Anyone who even dabbles in stocks knows how hard it is to divine which way they are headed. When J. Pierpont Morgan Sr. was asked what the market was about to do, he snapped, "It will fluctuate," summing up many investors' frustration. 
 But there are a host of indicators, trends and theories -- some, of course, more reliable and economically significant than others -- that traders and analysts use to guide their investing strategies.
The Jewish New Year, Rosh ha-Shanah, celebrates renewal and turning over a new leaf. So how do many investors greet it? By unloading their portfolios. The maxim goes: Sell near Rosh ha-Shanah; buy close to Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, which always falls 10 days later.
Other Wall Streeters invest ahead of the "Santa Claus Rally" -- a rise in stock prices that often occurs between Christmas and New Year's Day. Or they heed the "January effect" -- the almost inevitable rise in stock prices just after New Year's as pension funds invest year-end cash contributions.
"Everyone's looking for that magic bullet," said Yale Hirsch, whose Hirsch Organization in Old Tappan, N.J., publishes "The Stock Trader's Almanac" ($27.75 plus shipping for the 1996 edition). Among his favorite indicators is the advance-decline line -- the ratio of the number of stocks that have advanced to the number that have declined over a certain period. The line is believed to tell the general market direction: bullish if more stocks advance than decline, and bearish if declines outnumber advances. When the line points down, as it has for some time, it usually signalstrouble.
Mr. Hirsch cautioned that the daily advance-decline line had lost some of its appeal since the advent of program trading, which has made the market more volatile. Stick with the weekly number, he said, "because it smooths out much of the volatility."
For a hint of what might be ahead in this election year, check the Presidential cycle, Mr. Hirsch suggested. The indicator holds that stocks decline soon after a President is sworn in, presumably because he takes immediate steps to reduce inflation, Government spending and the deficit. "Which is why the gains in the President's third and fourth years usually tower over those in his first and second years," Mr. Hirsch said.
Should Bill Clinton be re-elected, "think bearish," Mr. Hirsch said. History records a bear market 9 times out of 10 when a sitting President is re-elected. The exception: Ronald Reagan in 1984.
What indicator would a Wall Street pro pick, given just one choice? "The long bond," said Michael Schwartz, an independent floor trader on the American Stock Exchange. He takes his cues from interest rate fluctuations by watching the 30-year Treasury bond, the "long bond" in trader parlance. It normally pays investors the most for their money. "With the long bond yielding above 7 percent and dividends on stocks only 2 percent," Mr. Schwartz said, "stocks are starting to look pretty unattractive." When rates rise, people tend to move out of the market and into fixed-rate investments like Treasuries and bank C.D.'s.
There is a name for this, but it might be confused with a 12-step recovery program. Called the "three step and stumble rule," it is Wall Street's version of "three strikes and you're out." The theory is that stock and bond prices will fall if the Federal Reserve raises the discount rate three times in a row. By raising this key interest rate, the Fed both increases the cost of corporate borrowing and makes alternative investments, like money market funds and C.D.'s, relatively more attractive than stocks and bonds. If you're keeping score, we took Step 1 when the Fed reversed course and raised the discount rate early this year. That means there are two steps to go. The next Fed meeting is on Aug. 20.
A money manager who dismisses most indicators as hocus-pocus is Jim O'Shaughnessy, the president of O'Shaughnessy Capital Management in Greenwich, Conn., and the author of "What Works on Wall Street," to be published in September (McGraw-Hill, $29.95). "Let's face it, if someone had a really great indicator, you wouldn't be able to get on the phone with that guy," he said. "And he'd be so rich he wouldn't want to be on the phone with you."
Mr. O'Shaughnessy, who probably doesn't even read his daily horoscope, is more of an empiricist when it comes to market judgments. His favorite tool can be called the "total market return rate."
When I try to explain this indicator, I'm reminded of Chevy Chase, a.k.a. Gerald Ford, engaged in a mock Presidential debate on an episode of "Saturday Night Live." He complained of being blindsided by economic numbers and argued, "I was told there wouldn't be any math."
Having myself flunked high school algebra (asked to add 2A and 2B, I once answered, "ABBA"), I realize this is dangerous, but here goes:
Start with the earnings yield on the Standard & Poor's 500 (for those unfamiliar with the measure, it's the inverse of the price-earnings ratio of the index). Add that measure (now 5.44 percent) to the S.& P. dividend yield (2.25 percent). Divide the sum by the latest 13-week T-bill rate (5.13 percent). When the final number falls below 1.5, Mr. O'Shaughnessy said, it's a bad omen for stocks because investors are not being compensated enough for the added risks of the stock market, versus the risk-free return in bonds. Right now, the indicator is a sliver below the threshold, at 1.499, though in recent weeks it has darted further into the danger zone with the market's gyrations.
Mr. O'Shaughnessy loves this calculation; he has tested it back to the 1950's, and it has been consistently on target.
The trouble with all sorts of indicators, most of which had been spelling gloom and doom well before the recent market rout, is that they may turn out to be fads -- hot today, gone tomorrow. Remember the odd-lot theory? It held that the odd-lot buyer -- usually the individual investor who trades in lots of less than 100 shares -- is most often a victim of bad timing and that, therefore, money can be made by becoming a contrarian. Its advocates maintained that heavy odd-lot buying in a rising market was a sign of technical weakness and an impending market reversal. They haven't been heard from lately, in large part because small investors made a mad rush to mutual funds.
What accounts for the short shelf life of many indicators? The constant change in the stock market. "It's like fighting a new war with old tools," Mr. Hirsch said.
So what is an investor to do? "Don't try to time the market," Mr. O'Shaughnessywarned individual long-term investors. "More money is lost heeding the indicators than just leaving your portfolio alone."
Had you left all your eggs in the market back in September 1929, you'd still have come out ahead 20 years later.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Is It a Bear, Or the Cub That Roared?

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
EVEN the most complacent investors must have winced over the rumbling of the stock market last week. It gyrated wildly early on, recovered a bit but still ended on a down note.
When all was done, the Dow Jones industrial average had shed 84 points, or 1.5 percent of its value. Was it just some momentary indigestion, common in even the most vigorous of bull markets, or was it instead the first growl of a long-coming bear market? 
 Four professionals, each of whom has a different perspective on the ways of the stock market, was asked to answer two questions: Is this a correction or the beginning of a bear market? And what advice would you give a relative wondering what to do?
Though their answers are conflicting -- as are their interest-rate forecasts and market theories -- the experts describe the forces that will determine whether stocks and mutual funds continue their bull run. REED ABELSON
 
Byron R. Wien
U.S. investment strategist
Morgan Stanley
Well, I think the downturn is bigger than we've seen, and it probably is the beginning of a bear market, but not definitely.
There are reasons for a bear market, including valuation. The market is not undervalued. If interest rates go higher, the market will become overvalued. There were also enormous flows of equity capital into the market at the beginning of the year, but that is diminishing. Volume peaked in March, and that tends to occur five or six months before the market makes a top.
If you have good long-term holdings with big gains, don't sell them. On the other hand, if you have had some profits, you could use the current rally to raise reserves. I think you will get better prices later.
 
Eric Miller
Chief investment officer
Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette
We're treating it as a correction, still within a secular bull market. Corrections can last a few weeks or a few months. We're not convinced this one is over. For the very short term, we've had some relief.
The next five to six weeks is an important time in terms of data and events that could prolong or deepen the correction. There is still the open question of whether the Federal Reserve will move to tighten this summer. Our own view is that there is going to be a visible slowing of economic growth in the second half.
If you do not own stocks at all and have been intending to and have the wherewithal, you should do selective buying. If you have been very aggressively invested, you should probably use rallies to lighten up some positions.
 
Elaine Garzarelli
Chairwoman
Garzarelli Investment Management
My indicators are neutral. On a scale from 0 to 100, they've dropped from 80.5 percent in April to 48.5 percent, which is still neutral. The correction is over now. The market can have a fairly nice move.
I'm very positive on interest rates. The key things I look at are inflation and the budget deficit. If the 3-month Treasury bill goes up a point from here, and the 30-year and 10-year Treasury bonds go up a point from here, I would have a "sell" signal. The market could go up to 6,400 at current interest-rate levels.
If people are nervous about the market, I would tell them to get an index fund. You could sell out easily if the Fed hikes interest rates by a full percentage point.

Alan Blinder
Princeton economics professor
Former Fed vice chairman
The difference between a "correction" and a "bear market" hinges, I suppose, on how long stock prices keep falling. Since the long-run trend of the stock market is decidely up, a bear market is really just a correction that lasts a long time. (Was October 1987 a correction?)
I do not pretend to be able to forecast how long stock prices will fall. But I certainly don't see why current economic conditions -- steady growth at a moderate pace, low inflation, low unemployment and high profits -- should be bad for stocks.
The advice I'd give to my brothers and mother is that stocks are the only place to be for the very long run. Buy a broadly diversified portfolio and measure time in years, not days. And don't try to time the market; you will probably fail.

HEADLINE: The World;
Talk Multilaterally, Hit Allies With Stick

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Clinton Administration came to office three years ago heralding a new age to end the constant economic warfare among the world's trading nations -- an age in which countries could settle their arguments in a host of new international courtrooms.
It started with the North American Free Trade Agreement, which created panels of judges to interpret a treaty so thick that one American diplomat swears she used her copy to clobber a rat to death in her apartment. Then the United States led the way in creating potentially the world's most powerful international court, the World Trade Organization. 
 But these days America's allies unanimously complain that while Washington talks a great game of international consensus, it tosses the rhetoric aside whenever the stakes are truly high. Then it unleashes its economic clout to force other nations to toe the line. This, the allies say, is exactly what the Administration is doing to them as it works to isolate Cuba, the last Communist holdout in the Western hemisphere, and Iran, viewed as a prime sponsor of terror.

 
 
'Bullying'
 President Clinton has joined Congress in threatening to impose huge penalties against foreign companies doing business with either offending nation. Lawyers call this "extraterritorial reach," a practice the State Department used to scream about when Arab states used it against American companies doing business in Israel. Lloyd Axworthy, the Canadian Foreign Minister, has another word for it.
"This is bullying," he said the other day. "But in America, you call it global leadership."
The sting of that leadership was felt the other day by Sherritt International Corporation, a Canadian mining company. Under the Helms-Burton Act, the company's top executives and their families have been prohibited from entering the United States because Sherritt is "trafficking" in property President Fidel Castro seized from American companies in 1959.
Last week, President Clinton tightened the screws another half-notch, under pressure from Cuban-Americans in Florida and, to a lesser extent, New Jersey -- not coincidentally two key states in the coming election. Under the same law -- which the President first opposed, then signed after Cuba shot down two planes piloted by anti-Castro exiles -- Mr. Clinton said he would allow American citizens and companies to sue any foreign concern using their now-decrepit property in Cuba, from old factories to the aging phone system. But in a gesture to Canada, Mexico and Europe, he also suspended that right for six months in hopes that the allies would change their attitude about "engaging" Mr. Castro. The European Union and Canada were unimpressed, and said they would pass laws calling for retaliation against American companies.
Mr. Clinton's aides bristle when they hear what one official called "all this whining" that they are abandoning multilateral solutions to problems. "It's simply an unfair complaint," said Samuel R. Berger, the deputy national security adviser. "This is a Government -- whether the issue is Bosnia, GATT, NATO expansion or relations with the former Soviet Union -- whose instinct has always been to do these things in a collegial way. To extrapolate from a few instances that the U.S. is going unilateral is a bit ridiculous."
To understand why the allies are so upset, imagine a similar law enacted by Canada -- aimed not at the Cuban revolution but the American. After all, thousands of colonists loyal to King George fled north, abandoning their graceful houses in Boston and their factories up and down the Atlantic coast. A Canadian Helms-Burton law would permit their descendants to sue companies now occupying that factory land, and yuppies now living in those old mansions -- a throwback to an era when the Americans built forts on the shores of Lake Champlain.
At least that's the sort of parallel drawn sarcastically by those on the business end of Helms-Burton. But some of those who complain of American bullying speak transparently from self-interest.
When the United States took on Japan on its barriers to selling American autos and parts last year, Tokyo tried to bring the case before the World Trade Organization. It doesn't take an international trade lawyer to figure out why: the conflicting evidence about what constitutes an open or closed market is so complex it would have have required months or years of hearings. And presumably Japan could use its own considerable economic clout to assure that other members of the organization would think twice before rushing to Washington's side.
Wise to the strategy, Washington went head-to-head, threatening sanctions if Japan failed to sign a satisfactory agreement. The result was faster action: The most recent trade figures, released on Thursday, show a big improvement in auto-related sales to Japan. Score one for staying out of court.

 
 
Muscle-Bound
 But over the long term, the United States is not likely to be free to flex its muscles whenever it wants to. "The spread of our companies to every corner of the world, and our inability to call the shots ourselves, will push us to take the multilateral route," said Jeffrey Garten, who was part of the negotiating team in the car talks and is now dean of the Yale School of Management. "We would like to do what we did in the cold war, to go to our allies and decree an outcome. You can't do it any more. Now there is always a huge amount of arm-twisting and tradeoffs."
Sometimes that arm-twisting is easier to explain than at others: the Administration makes the case that Europe's continued investment in Iran has done nothing to curb the country's terroristic tendencies. But Cuba, even some of Mr. Clinton's advisers concede, is a very different case. Without a looming election, it's hard to imagine him risking relations with the nation's biggest trading partners to destabilize a tiny island on the brink of economic disaster. And when Administration officials are asked why the United States hews to a policy of "engagement" with powerful Communists in China while urging isolation of weak ones in Havana, the answer comes right out of Clausewitz: you wage the economic wars you can win.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
A Marathon of Disruption For Corporate Atlanta

BYLINE: By JERRY SCHWARTZ 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
OR most of his working life, Mike Sweeney has donned the corporate uniform of suit and tie and driven to work for an ordinary business day as an administrator in the midtown Atlanta offices of the Nationsbank Corporation.
But for the next two weeks, he will work at the bank only from noon to 5 P.M. He then will slide into a pair of bright red shorts, a golf shirt spangled with red, white and blue and work until midnight as a volunteer at the Summer Olympics, conducting visitors to and from events.. 
 Barbara Petit, a freelance events planner in Atlanta, lives only five minutes by car from the hub of Olympic activity, but she has moved into a downtown hotel, speaking once or twice a day by phone with her husband and daughter.
Ms. Petit expects her average workday during the Olympics to be from 15 to 20 hours.
"I'm hoping there will be a rhythm that develops somewhere along the line," she said. "Right now, it's just wake up, get to work and keep going."
Exhausting days, odd assignments and logistical headaches are expected to be the rule for the 100,000 Atlantans who work in the central business district, now converted into the capital of the sports universe.
Although some Olympic events are being held far from Atlanta -- yachting, for example, is in Savannah, Ga., almost 250 miles away -- these Games are in some ways the most compact in Olympic history. The sites for 16 sporting events and the athletes' Olympic Village are in a three-mile-wide circle in downtown Atlanta, called the Olympic Ring.
As a result, dozens of downtown streets will be closed to all but Olympic traffic. Ordinary business deliveries will be suspended and office workers have been told to be at their desks by 7 A.M. or to forget about coming downtown. Those who are taking the subway or public buses have been warned that their commute could be three times longer than usual.
Some companies have simply urged their workers to take vacations during the Olympics. But people still have to get to work, and many companies, including Suntrust Bank, Georgia-Pacific and Coca-Cola, with their headquarters within walking distance of the Games, have had to develop strategies to get employees to the office.
Several have formed a private, 24-hour bus system to collect workers in suburban areas and bring them downtown. Georgia-Pacific expects to transport about 400 of its 3,000 downtown workers on the private bus system each day.
Some companies have set up early-morning shifts so employees can be home by early afternoon. Others are allowing employees to telecommute, working from home using personal computers and modems.
Several companies have released workers to serve as Olympic volunteers. About 300 Georgia-Pacific employees have volunteered and will receive half their usual pay from the company. About 750 of Coca-Cola's 6,000 Atlanta employees have also volunteered, with their salaries during the period paid by the company.
Most of the rest of Coca-Cola's work force is assigned to various aspects of the company's Olympic Games sponsorship, like the Coca-Cola Olympic City, the company's Olympic theme park. "The Olympics is our business," said Mark Preisinger, a spokesman for the company. "About two-thirds of our employees have Olympic assignments. The other third are running the day-to-day operations."
Suntrust is using cots so essential workers in the company's check processing center can literally sleep on the job, said Hugh Suhr, a spokesman. Interoffice mail for several downtown Suntrust sites will be delivered between midnight and 6 A.M.
THE odd working hours and longer commutes can throw home lives into chaos. Some workers have had to hire nannies or get help from friends and relatives to care for children. "Our employees already have been told by their day-care centers that they can't expect to leave their children in day care for 12 to 14 hours a day," Mr. Suhr said.
That is not the case at the day-care center at the All Saints Episcopal Church, a half-mile from the Olympic Village. The center is extending its hours during the Olympics, opening an hour earlier in the morning, at 6, and closing at 9 P.M., two hours later than usual.
"We're not so concerned about people being able to drop off their children," said Paulette Fair, who works at the center, "but we recognize they may not be able to get back here when they planned."

HEADLINE: The Week of Investing Dangerously

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:
IS it the Big One? That's what Californians ask every time crystal trinkets start to tap-dance on the bookshelves. And that's what investors ask these days every time this space-traveling stock market slips.
That can be a stomach-churning question indeed for investors old enough to recall a certain Monday in October 1987. They know what a market free fall can do to the gut or the nervous system, and now gladly play "Where were you that day?"
 No, last week won't join the disaster pantheon, even though for a time the crystal was audibly skittering on Wall Street. 
 In a sense, though, Tuesday was the Big One -- the busiest day ever on the New York Stock Exchange. And the week had its share of Little Ones, a thrill a minute -- a 161-point drop for the Dow industrials on Monday, a wild seesaw ride on Tuesday, a record rise for the Nasdaq on Wednesday, a sharp Dow rebound on Thursday.
By Friday the capitalist citadel had survived another week intact, but that doesn't mean there was any shortage of nervous stomachs and bitten nails along the way.
 A day-by-day look at the market's impact on some very different people, from experienced investors in glass towers to workers in out-of-the-way coffee shops, gives a sense of Wall Street's vast reach.
 
Monday: Seeing a 'Meltdown'
As the week began, Louis Navellier was upbeat but cautious. Mr. Navellier runs two mutual funds, managing more than $1 billion from his base in Reno, plus writing a newsletter.
In a telephone message for his newsletter clients recorded over the weekend, Mr. Navellier noted, "We had a number of our favorite companies report strong earnings last week." His favorite adjective: "phenomenal," which he used three times in about 30 seconds, as in "a phenomonal report for Ascend Communications."
In the recording, Mr. Navellier expressed optimism about earnings, despite the previous week's market weakness. But he was less rosy about the broader market. "I am not optimistic about the Dow and the S.& P.," he said.
Charles I. Clough was not optimistic at all. Mr. Clough, who as Merrill Lynch's chief investment strategist mainly advises institutional clients, sees his role mainly as giving advice on "whether stocks are a good value or too high." He is partly removed from the fray, living in Concord, Mass., and venturing to New York three days a week. And he was distracted as the week began, his son having been married on Saturday.
Mr. Clough, bearish since February, turned more so in May. Companies have lifted profits by cutting costs, he said, but have done the easy part -- "picking the low-lying fruit." So if the economy slows, he argued, they will find it hard to raise profits.
 And the mutual fund boom, he worried, "has become speculative." Now, "it's not middle-aged people saving for retirement, it's people trying to make a fast buck."
Mr. Clough was in for a busy week.
 But these are the pros. What of the small investor? At a Starbucks Coffee shop in the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia, all the full-time employees are investors -- at least in Starbucks shares. Staff members get a percentage of their salary in stock options.
On Monday, though, news of the Dow's precipitous drop didn't penetrate the bustle of the shop. Coffee and conversation flowed.
Mark Chesney, Starbucks district manager, didn't hear about the plunge until he tuned in National Public Radio on Monday evening -- and after that he followed it through the week. But he was never too concerned. The stock did fall on Monday, to $24, and it "could drop to $15 and I wouldn't worry a bit," he said, "because I know over the next few years it would come back." The whole idea, he said, was to allow the options to build up for retirement, or for a house.
Another investor, Diane Haines, also took the long view. At no time during the market's wild ride did Ms. Haines, who is self-employed, look at her battered portfolio and consider climbing out on the window ledge.
For one thing, the rock ledge at her Clinton, N.J., home is just six inches above a goldfish pond. Also, Ms. Haines joined a local investment club 20 months ago to learn, with a divorce pending, how to manage her own affairs.
A central philosophy of the club is the idea of looking at a plunging market not as a disaster but as an opportunity to snap up quality stocks on the cheap.
Not that she stayed calm through it all. After work on Monday she got a call from a friend who told her about the Dow's dismal day, and a bolt of alarm shot through her. The next morning she called her discount broker's "800" number, punched in her account number, and a computer voice delivered the bad news. "Oh my goodness," she gasped to herself.
Mr. Navellier, the fund manager, felt that same jolt. Monday "was quite shocking," he said. "In fact," he added, referring to the plunge in the technology-heavy Nasdaq market, "we've had a bit of a technology meltdown here."
Still, "I would find it very hard to even think of selling right now," he said.
At Starbucks, Garry Novick, manager of the Chestnut Hill store, was also jolted -- though, busy all day, he did not hear of the drop till evening. Then he started checking the market "two, three, four times a day."
Mr. Clough, adviser to institutions, took it all in stride. In his opinion, the market actually cracked the previous Thursday on news of bad earnings, and hardly recovered on Friday.
As for the sudden plunge on Monday, he said, "I try not to be surprised by the market -- I've seen it come unhinged before."

Tuesday
 
'Oops, Here We Go Again'
Ms. Haines tried to shut the big market story out of her mind and concentrate on her work at the accounting and business service she runs. She was grateful, she said, that she didn't hear of Tuesday's 167-point midday dive until that evening, when, at a meeting, a local banker told her. "My reaction was, 'Oops, here we go again. Back-to-back losses of 160 points.' He didn't bother to mention until later that the market had quickly recovered," she recalled with a mock shudder.
"There were moments when the numbers were down and it took nerve to handle the temptation to sell," she said later with a smile that expressed relief that she had not succumbed to hitting the panic button during the darkest hours. "If I wasn't in an investment club, I know I'd be listening to friends saying it was the end of the world."
On the other hand, she resisted a temptation to pick up the phone and buy stocks that looked cheap. Her busy schedule made it impossible to track sliding stocks, and she wanted Wall Street to settle down before deciding whether to look for bargains. "Usually I keep a little list of stocks to buy if they go down to a certain level, but I haven't been mentally up to keeping one," she explained. On a bedside table lay three unread copies of Barron's.
Mr. Navellier sounded shell-shocked on Tuesday afternoon. "Well, we had a volume reversal, and that is good," he said, "but there was not a lot of news driving the reversal. We've got to get some follow-through before we get a real sign."
Mr. Clough was not surprised to see the market bounce back. It had, he said, dropped too far, too fast. "We had the combination of it being deeply oversold, plus a sigh of relief" about better earnings coming out. Still, he remained cautious: "That can lift it for two days," but not for long.
Certain traders, though, live in an upside-down world -- finding gloom in others' glee, seeing light when others see dark. These are the short-sellers, who make a living betting that stocks will fall. They do this by selling borrowed shares, and if their pessimism proves correct, they can replace them with shares bought later for less.
 In these circles, the market's tumble on Monday should have brought a sigh of relief. Short sellers have, after all, been retrenching since 1991, when the market's long bull run began. For most of them, though, the relief was decidedly short-lived.
"Until the market took off on Tuesday, everyone was fat, dumb and happy," said Benjamin Kopin, who manages $4.5 million in Lynx Partners, a short-selling fund in Chicago. Everyone, that is, who sells short.
Despite efforts to cover his losses, Mr. Kopin said he still "lost a little money" on Tuesday, probably because his fund is weighted toward small-capitalization stocks, which tend to be volatile.
Still, Mr. Kopin seemed to be taking the market's renewal in stride. "There are probably short-sellers who have made 40 to 50 percent over the past 10 days," he said.
For him, Tuesday was "really ridiculous." He found himself trying to buy back 10,000 shares of a particular technology stock he had shorted earlier. Even though the stock had been a recent favorite of investors, Mr. Kopin noticed on Tuesday morning that it had slid to his particular price target, which was $20 a share.
"All of a sudden I was trying to cover 10,000 shares, but there were simply no sellers," he said. "The stock hit bottom at 19 3/4, but when I put in a market order, I was lucky to get it filled at 22 3/8."
 
Wednesday
 
'Losing Money Is Always Scary'
As Wednesday dawned at Starbucks, Wall Street seemed light years away. Customers read newspapers over coffee or talked with friends. Classical music -- not CNN or stock reports -- provided the background noise.
Hermi LeFurge, the assistant manager, detailed the different tastes of Starbucks coffees for a customer new to the shop.
The stock market? "I don't really follow it," Ms. LeFurge said. "Starbucks is such a nice company to work for that even though the stock is going down, I know it will go back up." She admitted, though, that this week's volatility had caught her attention, and while she hasn't tracked Starbucks stock in the past, "I will now."
Mr. Navellier, meanwhile, was uneasy -- even with the market stabilizing. "I didn't like yesterday's reversal," he said, continuing to believe that the market was being driven by the whims of market makers.
Also unnerving him was the continued action in stocks that reported good earnings, like Intel, which after Tuesday's close reported better-than-expected earnings. "Intel was up four points at the opening and now it's kind of fizzled," he said about 10:30. "People like me ride wave after wave of institutional buying pressure. If the buying stops, we just sit there."
Often, an individual's reaction to market swings has much to do with age. It's an investing mantra that while there may be bumps along the way, in the long run stocks will do just fine. That's scant comfort, though, if retirement is around the corner.
 Mr. Novick, the Starbucks manager, is 49, and views his option plan as something that will be used for retirement, so he is able to take a longer look at the market's ride.
Ms. Haines, at 58, is watching from another angle. "Losing money is always scary," she said Wednesday evening. "Being as close to retirement as I am gives one a different perspective."
 
Thursday
 
'The Market Is Certainly Back'
By Thursday, the equity markets were bouncing back, partly because Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said he expected economic growth to moderate. And Ms. Haines was having second thoughts about not joining the buying spree.
"You can talk all you want about taking advantage of a correction, but when it actually happens you don't know which way the market will swing," she said after the Dow jumped 87 points. But she didn't waver from her conviction that the markets should settle down before she waded back in.
"I'm fairly conservative and never could go wild with investing," she added, noting that she has bought only one Nasdaq stock lately. "The only bum stock I bought was from a 'hot tip' I got from a friend."
Mr. Kopin, the short-seller, spent a good chunk of Wednesday trying to cover his losses as technology stocks soared. On Thursday, one bit of luck became apparent when the stock he had bought Tuesday at 22 3/8 rose to 28. Despite his good fortune, Mr. Kopin noted late in the afternoon that the day had been "very hard on shorts" over all.
"If you'd looked at my screen today, you'd think the market had been up a lot more than 87 points," he said after the close. "If we get another day like this tomorrow -- especially another strong move in the morning -- I may start backing out."
Mr. Clough spent much of the week on the Delta Shuttle between Boston and New York, talking to clients, all hungry for advice. When the market goes up, he said, they want new ideas; when it goes down, they want defensive suggestions. "I sense that psychology is as volatile as the market."
By Thursday morning at Starbucks, the "big story" was no longer the market but the explosion of T.W.A. Flight 800 off Long Island. There was talk of little else, though some people did not forget to follow the market. After the sharp rebound, Mr. Novick said, "The confidence I felt earlier in the week followed through to a positive ending. The market is certainly back."
 
Friday
 
'We Don't Want A Dead-Cat Bounce'
On Wall Street, the day was mainly an anti-climax, with many traders -- and much of the rest of the nation -- preoccupied with updates on the T.W.A. crash. The Dow lost 37 -- treading water, by this week's standards.
Mr. Clough got a late start for Cape Cod, and as he drove he spoke of the week's close. Thursday's snapback, he said, had something to do with Mr. Greenspan's comments. Also, "it was so deeply oversold by midday Tuesday that it had to bounce back." But the rally wasn't really convincing, he said. It was "a ragtag kind of affair, just the usual suspects gaining a point or two."
What is important, he said, is "what happens in the next several weeks," since the market has been "acting emotionally." He expects choppiness to continue, though "it may be more like Chinese water torture."
Mr. Navellier shared his skepticism. "I'm increasingly suspicious of this rebound because there has been no news" to fuel it, he said. "What we don't want is a dead-cat bounce" -- when stocks rebound simply because they fell so far so fast.
Mr. Navellier travels 12 to 15 days a month to visit clients, but even on the road he is so focused on his beloved spreadsheets that he may be oblivious to what city he is in. But of one thing he is sure: "This is the most volatile week I can remember."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
If Market's a Yo-Yo, They Hold String

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
WHO makes the rain on Wall Street? In decades past, it was monopolist robber barons, industrial conglomerates, corporate raiders or high-tech program traders.
But these days the fate of the financial markets rests in less gilded hands: those of ordinary individuals, who over the last five years have quadrupled their investments in mutual funds that buy stocks, thus becoming the single largest force behind the stock market's upward climb. 
 In that time, stock prices have rarely taken an extended downward turn. Investors got a scare in the first half of last week, however, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 5 percent below its peak for the first time since 1994. From the beginning of July until Tuesday, the industrial average tumbled more than 500 points, or 9.5 percent. Only the calming influence of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, who spoke before Congress of the Fed's vigilance against inflation, stayed a possible rout.
Now all eyes on Wall Street are turned toward Main Street, to see how average investors will respond to a wildly gyrating stock market. During the great mutual fund boom, the greatest fear among investment professionals has been that people who bought mutual funds thinking that stock prices could only go up will, at the first sign of a downturn, take their money and run, perhaps causing a global market crash.
"The market's rise since 1994 in particular has almost totally been a function of inflows to mutual funds on the part of the public," said Steven C. Leuthold, an investment manager in Minneapolis, who noted that the money comes from both those who passively deposit money in corporate retirement plans and those who actively invest cash they hope to use in a few months. While mutual fund managers make the decision about which stocks to buy, it is the surge of money from individuals that has been the greater source of the market's strength.
Several factors account for the trend, which was a long time in coming. From their start in 1924 through the end of World War II, mutual funds did not attract much attention, "because everyone remained cowed by the markets of the 1920's," said John Bogle, chairman of the Vanguard Group, the country's second-largest mutual fund company. Even after the market's boom in the 1960's, a severe decline in the early 1970's again turned investors away.
 
 
 
The Ideal Vehicle
 But in 1981, the greatest bull market in stock and bonds in history began, as inflation fell and the economy began to expand. And the ideal vehicle for middle-class investment became the mutual fund -- simply, a pool of money contributed by individuals and managed by a professional spreading risk across dozens of investments. Total assets in stock, bond and money market funds grew from $100 million in 1980 to nearly $3 trillion today. Stock funds in particular have grown most rapidly in the last five years.
The mutual fund boom results in part from the fact that more and more companies are scaling back retirement benefit plans, finding it cheaper to hand over cash to employees now and let them invest the money. At the same time, Baby Boomers have begun shifting from a lifestyle of profligate spending and consumption to one of saving and investing. As inflation has declined, people have grown less enamored with owning "stuff" that increases in value with inflation -- artwork, precious metals and real estate, for example -- and more apt to invest in assets that can generate income.
"All of those factors coincided in about 1990," said Abby Joseph Cohen, an investment executive at Goldman Sachs & Company. Looking around for a place to invest, people realized that over the last 70 years, except for short periods when interest rates were abnormally high, stocks provided higher returns than nearly all other investments.
After the market gained more than 36 percent last year, investors poured $140 billion into stock mutual funds in the first six months of 1996 -- more than in any previous full year. Morningstar Inc., a service that monitors more than 7,000 mutual funds, notes that it tracks more stock funds -- 3,221 -- than there are companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange -- 2,755.
Last month, however, as the stock market started to dodge and dip, the amount of money flowing into mutual funds slowed down. And last week, when stock prices fell more sharply, the flow reversed. Investors were reported to have pulled $4 billion out of stock funds in the week ended Wednesday, the most in any week in nearly five years.
Whether that is a temporary blip or the reversal of a pivotal trend will not be known for several months at least. The mutual fund industry's major trade group, the Investment Company Institute, has long maintained that investors do not panic and flee when stock prices drop.
In a study of shareholders' behavior from 1944 to 1995, John Rea, the institute's chief economist, found that even the stock market crash of 1987 failed to trigger "substantial outflows" of more than 5 percent of the industry's assets. "Stock fund shareholders generally are experienced investors, have long-term investment objectives and horizons and have a basic understanding of investment risk," the report concluded.
Not even everyone in the fund industry agrees. "To say that fund investors stay strongly committed through thick and thin is a canard," said Mr. Bogle of the Vanguard Group. He said investors are holding mutual funds for shorter periods of time and are increasingly using them as a means of speculating on the near-term direction of the stock market -- or even small sectors of it.
Fund companies themselves have encouraged such practices. Most offer automated, toll-free phone numbers that allow investors to easily switch between individual stock funds or pull out entirely.
The growth in mutual funds, and the related eagerness of fund investors to chase whatever fund manager or investment trend is hottest at the moment, has affected the stock market in other ways as well. The volume of cash flowing into funds has increased the demand for stocks to buy.
 
 
 
Happy to Oblige
 Wall Street has only been too happy to supply that need. In May more companies "went public" -- selling stock to the investing public for the first time -- than in any single month in the past decade. New companies hungry for expansion cash found that they could skip the traditional route of going to venture-capital firms for seed money.
This speculative fever has helped to finance rapid advances in computers and other technology that in turn fuel consumer spending and economic growth, said Sanford R. Robertson, chairman of Robertson, Stephens & Company, a San Francisco investment bank that specializes in bringing technology companies public. In much the same way that the advent of public stock ownership helped to fuel the Industrial Revolution, mutual fund shareholders have been the driving force behind the technology explosion of the 1990's.
The mutual funds that eagerly bought the shares of many of those nascent companies, however, found that in addition to rising faster than the overall market, they fell more quickly when it dropped. Mutual funds specializing in the stock of small companies, after generating returns of 15 percent in the first six months of this year, have since fallen by an average of 10 percent, and many have fallen into the red for the year.
Up to now, fund investors have typically found themselves better off by investing after dips in the market. But Mr. Leuthold questions how patient they will be -- even those investing for retirement -- if the market goes into a prolonged slump.
He also wonders how many of the investors who flocked to mutual funds in the last five years know that a real market downturn can last years. Investors who bought stocks in 1968, just before the stock market collapse of the 1970's, did not recover their original investment until 1982. "Even on the part of those investors who are buying mutual funds for retirement, I think there is a gross misunderstanding of the dynamics of the stock market," said Mr. Leuthold.

HEADLINE: When Worlds Collide

BYLINE: By Ronald Steel; Ronald Steel, professor of international relations at the University of Southern California, is the author of "Temptations of a Superpower."

DATELINE: NORWICH, Vt.

 BODY:
There is something both normal and frightening about our reaction to the explosion that blew T.W.A. Flight 800 out of the air and killed 230 innocent people. Normal in that the unexplained destruction of any symbol of American power and influence -- a military base, a government building, a corporate headquarters, an American-based airline -- immediately leads us to suspect terrorists. Frightening in that such acts lie beyond the customary rules of innocence and guilt, cause and effect, by which we organize our lives. If this should prove to be an accident rather than a crime, the best that we will be able to say is that it was not terrorism this time.
Terrorism, the means by which the weak frighten and punish the strong, has become part of our lives. We are no longer shocked by it. We have even come to expect it. Sometimes, as in the case of the World Trade Center bombing, it comes bearing foreign accents and perplexing religious dogmas. Other times, as in Oklahoma City, it takes the form of the strangers who are one of us, with their familiar delusions of omnipotent enemies. 
 In truth they are one, the terrorists abroad and those at home: the ones we do not know, and the ones we spawn. They are both products of a world whose rules they do not understand and which they feel does not understand them. They want to return to an earlier time in which they believe that they would have an honored place. They are, to their minds, upholders of a true faith -- a faith that, whatever its tenets, will put them among the winners rather than the losers, the respected rather than the ignored.
Although they are people whom, rightly or wrongly, time has passed by, they are very much creatures of their time. They have taken the technology of the strong and adapted it to their own ends. Technology may be a liberating force, but what it unleashes resists and often defies those who create it. Chain reactions, whether in nuclear furnaces or the caldron of ideas, are constantly in danger of going out of control. Just as a gun is a terrible leveler, erasing status and privilege in an instant, so are the most awesome weapons of a state. The United States may be able to intimidate any other state with the sheer magnitude of its military power, but individual Americans are hopelessly vulnerable to those weapons in the hands of other individuals.
Terrorism eradicates the distinction, so essential in international relations, between the state and the individual. States challenge one another or even go to war. The wars may be terrible. But they are, for the most part, fought by certain clear rules. States rarely try to assassinate one another's leaders. Think how shocked we were by the C.I.A. schemes in the Kennedy Administration to kill Fidel Castro. They do not wantonly make civilians targets without some compelling military justification. Consider the continuing difficulty we have explaining to ourselves the destruction of Dresden and Hiroshima. Responsible states do not torture or kill their prisoners. When they do, we consider them guilty of war crimes.
States generally avoid such acts not because they operate under a higher moral code than do individuals, but because they fear retaliation in kind. Two can play the game of assassination and atrocity. Thus the "rules of war." But terrorists have no interest in such distinctions. They operate outside the contrived world of state-sanctioned violence. This is the source of their weakness, but also of their strength. They know that the kinds of retaliation that states use against one another -- war, economic sanctions, embargoes -- are useless against them. A few individuals may occasionally be caught -- like the bombers at Riyadh, the World Trade Center and Oklahoma City -- but the core group of true believers remains untouched.
Every modern state is highly vulnerable to such terrorism. Indeed, the more modern it is, the more technologically and sociologically complicated its structure, the more vulnerable it is. It takes only a power outage to shut down a great city, or an abandoned truck to instill fear among tens of thousands, as happened last week in Seattle. The U.S. is not alone in being a target or being vulnerable. Ordinary civilians, the more innocent the better, have been targets of I.R.A. and Algerian terrorists. Their objective is to neutralize power by assaulting it at its weakest link: public confidence.
Why the United States? Alas, the proper question is, why not the United States? Just as the American Government is the locus of power within this country (and thus the logical target for right-wing militia members who feel otherwise powerless), so the United States is the locus of power for a "new world order" that would render irrelevant traditional faiths and even whole societies. Americans pride themselves on being in the forefront of the modern, in being the world's leader. But not everyone finds that world as appealing, or even as inevitable, as we do. To many it is deeply threatening.
We proudly declare ourselves to be No. 1, the world's only remaining superpower. Naturally, the discontented of the world hold us responsible for their plight: their poverty, their ignorance, their weakness, their irrelevance. A nation cannot be No. 1 when it suits its convenience and be "Who, little me?" when it doesn't. In status begin responsibilities. We so much take for granted not only our status but our standards that it hardly occurs to us that others may look upon them with alarm. We extol such principles as democracy, individualism, consumerism and the marketplace of ideas as though they were uncontested virtues. We are sincerely puzzled when others find these notions threatening. We assume they must be either misinformed or obtuse. Like the Victorian traveler confronted by uncomprehending "natives," we start talking louder.
It was never the Soviet Union, but the United States itself that is the true revolutionary power. We believe that our institutions must confine all others to the "ash heap of history." We lead an economic system that has effectively buried every other form of production and distribution -- leaving great wealth and sometimes great ruin in its wake. We purvey a culture based on mass entertainment and mass gratification: one that extols hedonism and accumulation even as it describes them as individualism and abundance. The cultural messages we transmit through Hollywood and McDonald's go out across the world to capture, and also to undermine, other societies.
Unlike more traditional conquerors, we are not content merely to subdue others: We insist that they be like us. And of course for their own good. We are the world's most relentless proselytizers. The world must be democratic. It must be capitalistic. It must be tied into the subversive messages of the World Wide Web. No wonder many feel threatened by what we represent. We are the apostles of globalization, the enemies of tradition and hierarchy. A chasm runs through the center of the globe. On one side are the modernizers, with their absolute belief in science, rationality, individualism and progress. On the other are the defenders of the faith and moral certainty.
The war between modernizers and traditionalists will continue for a long time to come. Two worlds are in collision, and all of us are in the front lines.

HEADLINE: Pay for Play: Jordan vs. Old-Timers

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
In a way, Michael Jordan is cheap at the price.
It was reported last weekend that for a mere $25 million, the Chicago Bulls, and the world, will get another year of what you can bet will be inspired performance from Mr. Jordan, whose day job is being the world's most expensive pitchman. 
 The largest one-year contract in the history of team sports may seem excessive, but not since Babe Ruth sold baseball and the joys of consumer appetite as a globe-traveling ambassador of Yankee power (true, the chant soon became "Yankee, go home!") has a single athlete so dominated his sport and embodied his time. And Jordan can command more from a sports economy now vastly inflated by television money, a global audience, athletes rights' to control their contracts and 50 years of middle-class leisure. (So can Shaquille O'Neal, who last week jumped to the Los Angeles Lakers for more than $17 million a year.)
The Babe was beloved in the transitional '20's for simplifying life, evoking the myth of our arcadian past and providing a role model for immigrant and other throwaway children. Jordan, similarly, is used as a role model, though often at a disservice to minority youth. To many, he also represents cultural imperialism and avarice (the $25 million will probably represent less than half of his total annual income). Still, his intense dedication to perfection and his brand of romanticism (remember his minor league field of dreams?) make it hard to begrudge him anything.
Well, almost. There is a nagging thought: Does being Mike entail any responsibilities beyond doing your best on court?
Let's ask Inge Hanson, who runs Harlem RBI, a youth baseball and mentoring program. She was mugged earlier this year by a 14-year-old and his 10-year-old henchboys. After they knocked her down and took about $60, a mugger kicked her in the face. The next day, the bruise that had welled up on her left cheek bore the imprint of a Nike swoosh. It lasted for three weeks and she felt sad thinking she was probably robbed to finance a fancier pair of Nikes.
"But I can't honestly answer your question," she said. "How could Michael Jordan possibly know that by endorsing sneakers -- sneakers! -- he was involved in a crime? And yet, one does wonder if he has any responsibility to his audience beyond just saying, 'Just Do It!' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Jordan, the $25-million man. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "To Be Like Mike"
 Michael Jordan will be paid a reported $25 million to play for the Chicago Bulls next season.
 Is this an outrageous sum? Perhaps. For statistical fun, let's compare notable sports compensations over the past century or so by accounting for inflation between then and now.
 Hmmm. Jordan and his sports-superstar contemporaries still are doing pretty well by comparison -- though for perspective we must also consider the $20 million that Sylvester Stallone gets for a movie like "Judge Dredd."
 American values -- go figure.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By DAVID RAMPE 

 BODY:

CONTRACTS
In Another League
As President Clinton continues his contract negotiations with the American public, it's clear he's far more interested in job security than in landing any kind of raise, even a cost-of-living adjustment. That's just as well, given how salaries of elected officials have lost ground to those of sports stars over the years. In 1930, as Babe Ruth was trying to negotiate an $80,000 contract, reporters asked him if he wasn't embarrassed to be seeking more than the $75,000 that President Hoover earned. "I had a better year," the Babe answered. Well, Shaquille O'Neal just signed a $17 million-a-year contract with the Los Angeles Lakers, meaning he'll make every five days what Mr. Clinton makes annually. But did he have a better year?
 
CURRENCIES
A Strong Dollar Leaves
U.S. Manufacturers Moaning
With the dollar buying nearly 40 percent more yen than it did a year ago, Japanese manufacturers have a huge competitive advantage in the United States. The relatively weak yen gives them a choice of cutting prices to build market share, holding prices and increasing profits or mixing the two strategies. It probably spells good news for consumers, as most price wars do. But the Big Three auto makers and companies that make machine tools and earth-moving equipment are unhappy, indeed. But the Clinton Administration has consistently come down in support of a strong dollar, saying American companies were competitive and healthy enough to be just fine.
 
TURNAROUNDS
A Quick $490 Million
Sunbeam, that lagging appliance maker, is reaching for the stars. It brought in the noted turnaround player, Albert Dunlap, to increase the company's value, just as he did rather famously at Scott Paper. In just 18 months there, he aggressively, if not ruthlessly, cut one-third of its workers, 11,000 of them, and sold $2 billion of assets before selling the company to Kimberly-Clark for $9 billion. Now Sunbeam management is apparently hoping for a dose of the same medicine. The company named Mr. Dunlap chairman and chief executive late Thursday and Sunbeam's stock rose $6 on Friday. That immediately lifted the company's value by about $490 million. And that was before Mr. Dunlap even got a chance to sit in his new chair.
 
LABOR
Money Makes Relevance
Heavy spending on political advertising by unions has the Republican Party counterpunching and complaining about heavy-handed union bosses. "We're telling the truth," said John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. One analyst of Congressional races, Charles Cook, said, "It's the first time labor's been truly relevant politically in at least a decade."
 
FASHION
Drama in the Lanes
The fate of couture, the most exclusive and elitist of fashion's arts, seems to be up to a French businessman. Bernard Arnault, the chairman of LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, has supplied the only drama couture has had in the last year. He installed John Galliano at Givenchy and is now looking for a designer to replace Gianfranco Ferre at Christian Dior. His search was the buzz at the recent Paris shows, and he caused waves by declining to stand for an ovation for Mr. Ferre's last couture collection for Christian Dior. His departure marked the end of an era at Dior.

EARNINGS
Intel Saves the Day
 
When the going gets tough, the tough report record earnings. Say thank you to Intel, the computer chip maker, which after the close of a tumultuous day of stock trading on Tuesday calmed Wall Street by reporting surprising second-quarter earnings. Its effect was like a rainbow appearing after a storm. Traders who only hours before had seen gloom in the technology sector, were suddenly upbeat not only about high-tech stocks, but for the stock market in general. The numbers were so good that they helped lift the Dow industrials 18 points on Wednesday and by that time the cavalry had arrived: strong earnings from General Electric, Ford and Apple Computer. Despite disappointing results from AT&T on Thursday, the Dow climbed another 87 points, helped by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, who cautioned that the economy's growth should moderate later this year, which reduces the likelihood that the Fed will have to raise interest rates soon. This week the market will be watching for earnings from Microsoft, RJR Nabisco and I.B.M.
 
TRADING
U.S. Settlement on Nasdaq
After a two-year investigation by the Justice Department, the Government and 24 securities firms reached an agreement on pricing practices that provides for closer Government oversight. Attorney General Janet Reno said the agreement, which is subject to approval by a Federal judge, would "deter future price-fixing on Nasdaq." The firms, which did not acknowledge any wrongdoing, still face a class-action suit in Federal District Court in New York.
 
MERGERS
Let's Make a Deal
The Federal Trade Commission has finally cleared the way for the $6.3 billion merger of Turner Broadcasting System and Time Warner. Sure folks, go ahead and do your deal, the F.T.C said, but do this for us, will you: carry a second news channel to compete against CNN, which is Turner's flagship news network. It is the first time the Federal Government has ever ordered that a cable channel carry a particular type of programming on such a scale. No big gulps were heard from the companies, and the deal seems sure to be approved by the agency in about three weeks.
 
AIRLINES
Crash Puts Pressure on T.W.A.
T.W.A. faces an agonizing sorting-out after a deadly crash that raised eerie associations to Pan Am Flight 103. The crash of T.W.A. Flight 800, on route from New York's Kennedy International to Paris, causing the loss of 230 lives, came as T.W.A. was on much stronger financial ground that it had been in years. Fliers may shy away from the airline for a while, but then come back in the months to come as pricing and scheduling conveniences wipe out the memory, travel agents predict. Still, T.W.A. has an aging fleet, and if security or maintenance lapses are found to have contributed to the crash, all bets on the airline's recovery are off.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
The G.O.P.'s Problem With Women

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHAT does a Republican woman want?
Republican men would like to know. At a critical moment, they seem a bit clueless. 
 Women in the Republican Party have always been a political minority, outnumbered not just by Republican men but by Democratic women. Now some in the party fear that its base of female support could shrink further, a bare 15 weeks before a national election that already looks perilous.
The instant reason is abortion: a furious battle between a mostly male Republican leadership that appears deeply and rigidly opposed to it, and a wing of moderate, pro-choice women leaders who want the party to be more flexible.
 
 
 
A Party Staple
 An NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll released last week suggested that the debate could force a staple of Republican politics, the affluent professional woman, to leave the party altogether -- or, perhaps, to begin waging a fight to retake it from social conservatives. And it implied that the furor could be affecting Republican women's support for the party's Presidential nominee-in-waiting, Bob Dole.
But abortion is the touchstone for broader, more subtle differences between moderate women and the party that some analysts and Republican politicians say may be ripe for exploitation.
Put one way, "Republican women show less of an ideological tendency than do Republican men," said Joe Cammarano, an assistant professor at Syracuse University who has studied Republican voting trends. "Republican men tend to be more ideologically consistent with the Republican Party platform."
Put another way, the most radical Congress in decades has unsettled even some of the women who elected it. "They're pretty concerned about the changes they see and those that are contemplated," said Representative Connie Morella, a Maryland Republican who has made a career of moderation. "They're very uneasy about the direction their party is taking."
The Republicans cannot afford to lose many more women from the centrist ranges; in the 1994 Congressional races, 54 percent of women voted for Democrats, and the gender gap was obvious in the primaries this spring.
Among those who identify themselves as Republicans, the differences between men and women are small. On Government spending and economic policy, on the military and foreign policy, on family and social standards and even on abortion the two sexes take sides in roughly the same proportion.
But on questions about the social compact -- on welfare, health care, unemployment and jobs, on affirmative action -- Republican women part ways with men. The men have moved dramatically since 1994 to limit or abolish bureaucratic safety nets and bootstraps. The women see a continued Government role in keeping unfortunates afloat.
In short, they are like Republican men, just less so. This has not escaped President Clinton as he has sought to rebuild his political constituency in the last year. And it may explain why Ms. Morella and others say the potential for defections is so high.
"The reason the gender gap became a gulch this year is that the Republican Congress wanted to affect the safety net," William Schneider, a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute and a television analyst of the elections, said in an interview last week. "It's not just children or compassion. It's that women only began to achieve economic independence in the last 25 years, and they still feel vulnerable in the marketplace. They want the Government to be there to protect them should the net fall through."
 
 
 
Better Marks
 The NBC/Wall Street Journal survey found that Republican women tended to rate Mr. Clinton's ability to handle such issues somewhat higher than men did, and rated Mr. Dole's ability lower than did the men.
Whether that queasiness translates into votes is an unanswered question. The gender gap has swelled and ebbed over the years for many reasons, and while many pollsters say it is growing this year, others aren't so sure.
The Republican pollster Richard Wirthlin reports that the share of women who say they usually think of themselves as Republicans has dropped from the high 30-percent range in late 1994 to the very low 30's now, some 20 months later. Responses to a similar question asked regularly in the New York Times/CBS News Poll suggest that, on average, the share of women who say they consider themselves Republican has bumped along at 28 or 29 percent for the last six years, and now stands at about 28 percent.
One reason the disaffection of moderate women has looked like such a sore thumb this summer, experts say, is that the moderates make up a disproportionate share of the party's highly visible elite. Many were activists who built the party before forces on the right took it over in the 1980's. Most are better educated than average Republicans, and higher levels of education tend to go hand in hand with more flexible stances on issues like abortion.
They descend from an older strain of Republicanism that was fiscally conservative but more socially progressive, taking a hands-off position on Government intervention in personal matters. They were Eisenhower and Nixon voters, and they actually outnumbered Republican men for a while. Within the party, they have been displaced by the women of the religious right who may share their fiscal conservatism but are hardly libertarian on social standards.
 
 
 
'Just Blown Away'
 "For moderate Republican women," Mr. Cammarano said, "abortion is more than simply a symbolic issue. It really goes to the heart of their differences with their political party. The women who are involved in this fight really felt the Republican Party was the party of low taxes, fiscal austerity and progressive social policy without much intrusion. And that's just been blown away."
Mr. Schneider says the shift ultimately may bring more women into Republican ranks. Women generally are more religious than men, he notes, and the party's embrace of religion has struck a chord with many.
But in the short run, with the abortion debate still raging, the party and Mr. Dole have a problem. Mr. Dole, who takes a strongly anti-abortion position, made a peace offering to the moderates last week by awarding the keynote speech at the party convention next month to an abortion-rights supporter, Representative Susan Molinari of New York.
That only served to enrage Republican anti-abortion forces and their base of fundamentalists, a group Mr. Dole needs as much, if not more. And it is not at all clear what he can do that would make both of them happy.
"People think of the gender gap as symbolic -- throw a woman onto the ticket, and get rid of it," Mr. Schneider said. "Uh-uh." As the abortion debate shows, nothing about men, women and politics is that simple.
