HEADLINE: Madagascar in Crisis;
The Land of Endangered Species in Danger

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: ANTANANARIVO, Madagascar

 BODY:
MADAGASCAR'S newish Prime Minister gave his State of the Nation address last month, and nobody came.
That is, more than 100 of the 130 members of Parliament refused to take in their seats and listen, expressing their displeasure at his new Cabinet. He's a respected former chief justice and one of the chief authors of the new constitution, and they had hoped he wouldn't retain the same old presidential cronies that have left this country in such a mess. They were disappointed. 
 Why care? No special reason. That's part of Madagascar's problem. Few people except the French think about Madagascar at all unless they like lemurs and vanilla.

 
 
Ylang-Ylang and All That
 The French, of course, have a soft spot for their former colonies. And Madagascar, an island just east of South Africa, is a remarkably romantic place: It is a blend of Indonesian, Arab and African cultures, a place where people disinter their dead relatives and dance with them, where the perfume of ylang-ylang trees sometimes masks that of the open sewers, where betting on chameleon fights is a national boys' sport.
Chameleon fighting, come to think of it, is not a bad metaphor for Malagasy politics. Madagascar, the world's fourth largest island, is one of the world's basket cases. It is one of its 10 poorest countries, with an average annual income of about $200. Whole neighborhoods are filled with people eking out livings by selling trash -- nails they've restraightened, scavenged bolts they've found nuts to.
But why such poverty? Unlike Angola, Mozambique and Somalia, Madagascar has had no civil war. Unlike Rwanda and Burundi, its tribes don't hate each other to death. Unlike Malawi or Benin, it isn't tiny and overshadowed by big neighbors. It's the size of France.
It has lots of tourism potential -- strange animal species, long beaches and, for wealthy visitors, great French food -- and yet fewer than 100,000 people a year visit. Some are scientists, who don't spend much money, and some, far worse, are animal and reptile thieves.
Being an island near Africa is part of the problem. Having a population (nearly 13.9 million a year ago) that grows faster than the economy can create jobs hurts too. So do falling prices for its chief exports, including vanilla, coffee and cloves. When Americans skip dessert, Malagasy farmers suffer.
But the chief damage to the country has been political. Malagasy politicians have made a stunning array of bad choices.
Under the rule of a military tribunal headed by Didier Ratsiraka from 1975 to 1990, Madasgascar chose as it closest ally North Korea. It also nationalized its banks, mines, insurers, oil companies and export houses. And then Madagascar suppressed the French language, causing 50,000 of the 70,000 French who openly ran the economy and quietly ran many of the government ministries to depart. Even after Mr. Ratsiraka admitted in 1982 that his brand of socialism had failed and asked the West for money his government lacked the political will to undertake the austerity measures demanded by Western bankers.
Eventually, the Malagasy franc plummeted, halving public officials' salaries and forcing many of them to charge "fees" for doing their jobs, which encouraged widespread corruption. But the government didn't respond by cutting its own payroll. Nor did it reprivatize banks or give Esso back its piece of the national oil company. Instead, Madagascar tried to borrow money elsewhere -- even from princes in Lichtenstein.
"They ended up with money launderers and crooks," said Herizo J. Razafimahaleo, a leading opposition politician. "They got taken, and we lost our financial credibility." Madagascar's external debt is $4.25 billion, and it can't pay.

 
 
And Cyclones Too
 Since 1990, everything from cyclones to general strikes has hit, and the country has gotten steadily poorer.
Now the West, frustrated with the mess, won't cooperate. Esso, for instance, doesn't want its shares in the national oil company as repayment. It wants $25 million, in cash, from a government whose hard currency reserves are probably less than $2 million. Under a law sponsored by Jesse Helms, if the case isn't well on the way to settlement by Aug. 27, all new American loans and aid, even that for vaccinations and schoolbooks, can be cut off.
For now, American interests here are almost entirely ecological. Madagascar's ecology is fascinatingly weird -- about 80 percent of its plants and animals are found nowhere else. But even that national resource may be endangered. As the ever-growing population cuts trees for fuel, grazing land and rice paddies, Madagascar's biological niches are slowly vanishing.

New at Democracy
For Prime Minister Norbert Ratsirhaonama the trick now is finding a way to please the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, so the country can get its credit restored. Other banks follow the I.M.F.'s lead, and France has said its foreign aid will depend on cooperation. And the demands of the lenders can get quite specific -- early last year, they forced the dismissal of the governor of Madagascar's central bank. In that sense, the World Bank and the I.M.F. are "governing" Madagascar just as Wall Street and New York State "governed" New York City in the late 1970's.
Elements in Parliament, including Mr. Razafimahaleo's business-oriented party, Leader/Fanilo, seem eager to toe the I.M.F. line, believing that this is the way to push Madagascar toward recovery. But it won't be easy. "Remember, they've only been at this democracy thing for three years," said one diplomat. "This is definitely government as a work in progress."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 758 words

HEADLINE: Olympic Fever in New York

 BODY:
The Olympics got under way in Atlanta this weekend with a spectacular display of international spirit and distinctly Southern heart. From Gladys Knight's "Georgia on My Mind," to the tribute to the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., to the touching moment when an ailing Muhammad Ali grasped the Olympic torch, the ceremonies were a reminder of why a city reborn as a place of tolerance and fair competition is an appropriate place for these international Games.
Yet even before the torch was lit Friday night, New York City, proud of its own international heritage, had begun thinking about trying to hold the Games in 12 years. The idea, which has won Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's tentative endorsement, raises exciting possibilities. 
 Like Los Angeles and Atlanta, New York could gain from the billions of dollars in spending, not to mention the good will and the sports facilities left to the city afterward. Even more important for the region's long-term development, the Games could spur private and public spending on infrastructure projects the city needs but has not undertaken.
But playing host to the Olympics also carries costs and risks. New Yorkers need to take a hard look at what benefits, financial and otherwise, would accrue from the Games and what public resources would have to be mobilized.
The Olympic Games can bring intangible benefits by stirring pride and civic feelings for the host city. They also bring money.
This year's Games may pump $5 billion into Atlanta. By the year 2008, with revenues rising rapidly, the Games could generate twice that amount in the New York City area. A new all-purpose Olympic stadium and other sports facilities, financed from revenues raised by the sponsoring committee, would serve as a permanent legacy for use by all New Yorkers and could help revive some of the city's rundown neighborhoods. On the other hand, economists at the Federal Reserve Bank in Atlanta and elsewhere in Georgia say the gains there will be limited and temporary.
What excites many business leaders is the prospect of spurring the construction of needed infrastructure. Taxpayers would have to foot much of this bill, however. In Atlanta, nearly $600 million in city and state government funds have gone to renovate sewers, repair roads, fix up the airport and help provide security. It is not clear that the increased tax revenues generated by the Games will pay for these expenditures. The Federal Government has helped with an additional $225 million over the last five years in Atlanta, but Federal spending may be tighter in the future.
Even if a New York organizing committee raises $3 billion from television rights, corporate sponsorships, merchandising, tickets and other sources, that money must then be spent to put on the Games themselves. Olympic rules say it cannot be spent for road or airport improvement, only for facilities directly needed for the Games. New Yorkers will need to look closely at whether they want to put scarce tax dollars into transportation projects to support the Games, or whether they would prefer a crash program to rebuild crumbling schools.
Another question is whether the money available for the Games would be enough to pay for all the facilities needed. The athletes could presumably use the New Jersey Meadowlands stadium, Madison Square Garden and even the Javits Convention Center, but probably not facilities on Long Island or Connecticut because they are too far away.
For that reason, organizers think the city would need to build a huge new stadium for track and field events, several smaller facilities and an Olympic village for 15,000 athletes and others. That sounds like too long a list for the money, though the village could conceivably be sold off and the stadium could be used later for other sports.
The main stadium, in fact, could be converted for the Yankees, as Mayor Giuliani suggests, or for the Mets, who want a new stadium in Queens. Some think it might make sense to build the other facilities nearby on the West Side or at Flushing Meadows, especially since Olympic events are supposed to take place in reasonable proximity to each other. Others have suggested the Harlem riverfront, the Brooklyn waterfront or even Governors Island in New York Harbor.
The Olympics would be a thrilling event for New Yorkers. The New York City Partnership, a leading business group, is to be commended for starting to raise private money for a feasibility study. All New Yorkers will eagerly await the answers to these difficult questions.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Beijing Bullets

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It's all Nafta's fault.
I have season tickets to the N.B.A.'s Washington Bullets and last week I heard the giant sucking sound of jobs moving south. Actually, it was only one job, but it was enough to make the front-page of The Washington Post. Bullets star forward Juwan Howard, the centerpiece of his team and a role model in this city, headed south after being offered $98 million over seven years by the Miami Heat. 
 Where is Ross Perot when you need him? I mean, none of this would have happened without Nafta, GATT, the W.T.O., APEC, the E.U., not to mention the N.B.A.
It's true. What you see with Juwan and other N.B.A. free agents, argues political scientist and disgruntled Bullets ticketholder Norman Ornstein, is how the integration and deregulation of global markets gives us more freedom of movement and more opportunity to profit from larger and larger markets, "at the same time that it severs the bonds of loyalty workers or employers might feel to any particular place." It is precisely because basketball (much more than baseball or football) has become a global sport, with a global TV audience and a global pool of loyal consumers for N.B.A.-endorsed products, that it can offer megasalaries that break any player's loyalty to team or community.
I was just in Moscow. The hottestselling matryoshka doll there -- those little wooden dolls with one inside another inside another -- is of the Chicago Bulls. Outside the Kremlin you can buy Scottie Pippen inside Dennis Rodman inside Toni Kukoc inside Michael Jordan. And if you aren't a Bulls fan, Moscow vendors offer matryoshka dolls of every N.B.A. team.
Juwan Howard's good fortune is that the improvement in his jump shot coincided with revolutions in global market integration and communications, which enable fans from Moscow to Mexico to help pay his salary -- by buying N.B.A. souvenirs or viewing rights. The N.B.A. already talks of expanding teams to Europe and Latin America. (Coming soon: "The Cali Cartels." The team logo is the poppy. The owners pay everybody in cash.) And just wait until China's workers get hooked on the N.B.A. and can afford to buy the high-tech sneakers they now make for the global market. Juwan Howard will make $980 million and his next contract will be with "the Beijing Bullets."
Just as the hometown player is becoming extinct, so too will the hometown owner. The net worth of Washington Bullets owner Abe Pollin was reported to be $100 million, derived originally from local Washington real estate. He was being asked to spend his entire net worth to keep one player. No wonder teams are now owned by I.T.T. or CNN's Ted Turner or Microsoft's Paul Allen. In a global economy only an owner with a global-size income can pay global-like salaries.
USA Today noted that Juwan Howard's $98 million contract would pay the average salary of an elementary school teacher ($30,000 a year) for 3,267 years. Michael Jordan's $25 million salary works out to $105 per second of playing time, or $315 for every three-second violation.
Juwan and Michael's fans may not begrudge them their salaries, as long as they win. But the widening gulf between winners and losers in the global economy that these sports salaries reflect will have social repercussions, argues Harvard University political theorist Michael Sandel: Rich and poor will increasingly live separate existences, sending their children to different schools, living in different neighborhoods and shopping in different stores.
And now, also rooting for the home team differently. It used to be that going to the game pulled a community together. But it will be able to do that less and less because to pay these huge salaries ticket prices are put out of reach to all but the rich, or stadiums are segmented with high-priced corporate boxes where only the wealthy sit. To pay for Shaquille O'Neal's $121 million salary, the Los Angeles Lakers had to raise their cheapest seats from $9.50 a game to $21, and most expensive from $500 to $600 per game.
"In the past," noted Mr. Sandel, "some sat in bleachers and some in box seats, but everyone ate the same hot dogs, drank the same beer and got rained on by the same storm. But now the wealthy can dine on lobsters in air-conditioned corporate boxes while the rest eat peanuts in the grandstands -- if they can afford to go at all. So even the ballpark is no longer the kind of shared public space that brings together people from different walks of life."

HEADLINE: In Peacetime, Vietnam's Army Turns to Business Ventures

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam

 BODY:
In a recently refurbished army museum here, an exhibit on the war against the Americans has shrunk slightly to make room for a new display showing the military's role in the civilian economy, building dikes and electrification projects.
Since its founding in 1945, the People's Army of Vietnam has defeated the French and the Americans, held the northern border against a Chinese incursion and tamed neighboring Cambodia. But the army, while continuing to play a vital role in Vietnam, is now in transition, without a war to fight for the first time since its creation. 
 It is shifting its targets from foreign invaders to internal security threats and its energies from the battlefield to the marketplace.
At the recent Communist Party Congress, it strengthened its political clout and focused on a new mission, guarding against the "hostile forces" of Western influence unleashed by the country's newly liberalized economy.
"Without the military, disorder may occur," said Do Muoi, the Party's General Secretary. In a time of fundamental change, Vietnam is counting on its military and security forces to maintain party control and to insure that the West, defeated in war, does not win over the country through economic and social change.
The Congress increased the representation of military and internal security forces on the 18-member Politburo to 6 from 4 and gave them 3 out of 5 positions on a new standing committee that is to run day-to-day affairs. One of these men, Gen. Le Kha Phieu, 64, heads the army's political department and is viewed by foreign diplomats as a possible successor to Mr. Muoi, who is 79.
The increased political power of the armed forces reflects a desire to protect the country's political and social structure rather than any retrenchment of economic liberalization, foreign military analysts said. The army has already committed itself to the marketplace, they said.
Like the People's Liberation Army in China, which has become a major economic power there, Vietnam's military has quickly seized new opportunities and now owns 300 major state enterprises. But unlike the Chinese military, the Vietnamese military is viewed as largely free of the country's widespread corruption.
"At the moment, the army is one of the more popular institutions in Vietnam because of its relative image of not being corrupt," said Carlyle A. Thayer, who heads the School of Politics at the Australian Defense Force Academy and is an expert on the Vietnamese military.
Vietnam's military now has only half the estimated 1.2 million servicemen that it fielded less than a decade ago. According to one Western diplomat in Hanoi, it now includes an army of about 550,000 soldiers, a navy of 40,000, an air force of 15,000 and a paramilitary force of 15,000.
Even as it has shrunk, its budget has risen every year since 1992, to $890 million last year, and it has been buying foreign aircraft, ships and antiaircraft weapons, Mr. Thayer said.
As the military has grown smaller, it has also sought ways to turn a profit from its assets.
It has turned some of its vast rural and urban holdings into real estate enterprises and converted agricultural land that supported troops into agribusinesses including rubber, tobacco and coffee plantations.
And in some cases, demobilized units have remained essentially intact, with engineering battalions reinventing themselves as engineering companies and signal corps reemerging as electronics communications companies.
"What was formerly a military unit is now a construction company, and the officers of the unit have become directors of the company," said Chuck Searcy, who represents the Vietnam Veterans of America Foundation in Hanoi.
In Vietnam's newly vibrant civilian economy, the military seems to be everywhere, managing hotels, a laundry service and a travel agency; mining coal; running a bank; chartering helicopters, and manufacturing electric fans, raincoats, transformers and bicycle parts.
Combined revenues last year in military-run enterprises were $360 million, up 25 percent from the year before, the official Vietnam News Agency said in February.
It reported that the military had entered into 49 joint ventures worth $445 million with foreign companies, mostly in mechanical engineering, construction, and ship and plane repair. Western businessmen here say these joint ventures include contracts with a Japanese candy company and with the South Korean conglomerate Daewoo, which plans to assemble automobiles here.
Thus for the military, as for the country at large, there seems to be no turning back. The difficult questions are how to move ahead into economic and social terrain they know far less well than they did the jungles of the Ho Chi Minh Trail.
"I don't think the military is a constituency for going back to old-style Communism," said a Western trade official who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The issues have to do with power and control, and they have to do with rents and profits.
"They paid the price," he said. "Now they are saying, 'We want to make something out of this.' They want to send their kids to good schools, and they want to make money."
Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, 83, the military mastermind behind Vietnam's defeat of both the French and the Americans, supported the political and economic policies of the Congress, telling reporters: "Vietnam must at the same time be bold and cautious. We are Communists; we are pragmatists. We are very optimistic, but at the same time we see difficulties."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Vietnamese Army now controls 300 major state businesses. On Thursday, soldiers passed a reviewing stand in the city of Hue. (Lois Raimondo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Weighs Lifting Curb on Arms Sales to Latin America

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, July 20

 BODY:
At the urging of Defense Secretary William J. Perry, the Clinton Administration is considering easing a decades-old ban on sales of high-technology weapons like advanced fighter jets to Latin America, raising fears of a new arms race in a region that has been relatively calm after years of military conflict and dictatorship.
Mr. Perry and major weapons makers contend that the blanket restrictions, imposed in the 1970's, are no longer warranted because democracy has spread to every country in the region except Cuba. 
 These advocates maintain that the arms ban is costing the United States jobs by allowing foreign competitors to gain in the Latin American arms market.
But critics of lifting the ban, in the region and in the United States, say feuds between Latin American countries are still too volatile to justify access to state-of-the-art weapons, which they say will only add fuel to smoldering fires, perhaps inflaming minor border disputes into regional wars.
The debate is being closely watched in the region. Many people are asking why, if there is stability in Latin America, the United States should sell highly advanced weapons to countries that neither need them nor can afford them.
Argentina is adamantly opposed to a relaxing of the ban. Argentine officials say they have told the Clinton Administration that they do not want to enter an arms race with Brazil and Chile, particularly when Argentina has drastically scaled back its military spending.
The Argentines also maintain that Chile and Brazil, which have expressed an interest in acquiring advanced fighter planes like the F-16, still do not have full civilian control over their armed forces and thus are ill equipped to regulate the new military technology.
"Putting these weapons in the hands of countries that don't have complete civilian control over their militaries could have major consequences for the region," said Enrique J. de la Torre, a director of international security for Argentina's Foreign Ministry. "We believe the United States should use a stick-and-carrot approach and make these weapons available only as progress is made toward consolidating democracy."
The Clinton Administration began a review of the arms ban -- which was imposed by President Carter in reaction to military abuses of human rights during the 1970's -- at the request of Defense Secretary Perry.
Mr. Perry has said the United States should treat Latin America as it does Africa, Europe and Asia and approve arms sales case by case.
Meanwhile, Congressional leaders and weapons contractors in the United States are strongly lobbying the Administration to end the weapons restrictions.
In a recent letter to Secretary of State Warren Christopher, several senators said that "thousands of hard-working Americans depend on legitimate overseas defense sales" and that "the Administration should do everything possible to make sure it is American working people who are producing the hardware purchased by our friends in Latin America."
The senators noted that France had sold about 200 fighter aircraft to seven Latin American countries in recent years and that the sale of 200 American-made fighters would represent more than $4 billion in exports and provide 40,000 jobs.
Frank Simpson, vice president for Latin America of the Lockheed Martin Corporation, which makes the F-16, said the United States did a disservice to Latin American countries by forcing them to buy from Europe and Asia. "The armed forces in these countries are mismanaging their limited funds by not being able to buy the best and most compatible systems," he said.
While the market for weapons in Latin America is relatively small, about $2 billion in sales last year, industry analysts and executives said they expected sales to increase as countries sought to replace outdated equipment and as new military conflicts arose.
Chile is one country that wants to buy advanced fighters. But Gen. Fernando Rojas, commander of the Chilean Air Force, said that he had stopped meeting with American aircraft manufacturers and that Chile was considering buying fighter planes from countries that had no such restrictions.
"I rather like the North American planes, and I know the sales brochures inside out," General Rojas said in an interview. "But until they get permission from the Government to sell them, I invite the contractors to stop talking about planes and start taking tours in Chile."
In the last decade, as military dictatorships proved to be social and economic disasters in Latin America, most countries have made the transition to relatively stable democracies. The new governments have greatly reduced military spending and liberalized their economies.
Except for Chile, Brazil and Argentina, few countries in Latin America are building up their military resources or have the money to buy the sophisticated weapons at issue. The weapons mentioned most often are F-16 fighter-bombers, advanced helicopters and electronics and radar systems.
Many Latin American experts say the likelihood of military conflict has been greatly reduced by economic integration. They cite a rise in investments between countries and recent trade pacts like Mercosur, which includes South America's largest trading partners: Brazil, Argentina, Chile, Paraguay and Uruguay.
But critics of the proposed change in United States policy note that the Chilean military is still headed by Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who led the 1973 coup that toppled the leftist Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens.
Under the Chilean Constitution, which was written by General Pinochet, the civilian Government cannot cut military spending, and the armed forces receive 10 percent of Chile's copper sales, or up to $400 million yearly.
Military analysts said the sale of F-16's would change the air power balance in favor of Chile, which would have technology far superior to Argentina's, unless the Argentines also came up with the money to buy F-16's.
Defense Minister Oscar Camilion of Argentina said in a recent interview that military spending by his country had declined 75 percent in the last 10 years, and that it could not afford to buy new F-16's.
"We think it would premature to sell F-16's in Latin America at this time," he said. "We believe it would be very unstabilizing."
Chile's purchase of the advanced fighter planes would have little impact on Brazil, which is more than 10 times Chile's size.
Although Brazil has said it cannot afford to buy F-16's because of budget cuts, Ivan Frota, a retired top general who often comments on his country's military policy, said Brazil would probably find the money to buy F-16's, but only if they were fully equipped with the latest technology.
Some United States Congressmen who oppose removing the ban said its withdrawal would prompt Latin American countries to plow scarce resources into a costly arms race that would take money away from much-needed social reforms.
But Chile says it needs the F-16's to maintain a level of competence and to defend itself against historic enemies.
There is a persistent distrust in Chile of its three neighbors -- Argentina, Peru and Bolivia -- which all have had major conflicts with Chile. This sentiment is partly promoted by the armed forces in an effort to maintain support for a strong military.
"We are not threatened by our neighbors," General Rojas said. "On the contrary, we have excellent relations with them. But these countries sometimes have goals that are counter to our interest. At any given time it can come to a crisis."
Those opposed to changing United States policy cite several events they say illustrate the fragility of peace in Latin America: last year's border war between Peru and Ecuador, which left 78 soldiers dead and hundreds wounded; a standoff in Chile last year between the Government and the armed forces over the imprisonment of convicted military officers, and an attempted military coup in Paraguay in April.

HEADLINE: ATLANTA: DAY 2;
The South's Struggle to Define Itself

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 20

 BODY:
The images from the opening ceremony Friday of bubbly cheerleaders, chrome pickup trucks or Gladys Knight singing "Georgia on My Mind" were so bright and vibrant, it was possible to think the South's transformation from America's pariah region to sparkling center of its population and economic growth was complete.
But by focusing more international attention on the South than anything that has happened since the civil rights movement, the Olympics in Atlanta are also adding fuel to a furious tug-of-war over the symbols and realities that define the contemporary South. 
 Atlanta won the Games in large part because it sold itself as a model of interracial harmony that had transcended its racially tragic past. But, as controversies over Civil War re-enactments, the Georgia flag and even the Olympic mascot are showing, the Games come at a time when the traditional images that once defined the South are the subject of bitter disputes as never before.
And the Games pose the question about just which image is closer to the real South: the exuberant show of interracial regional harmony and shared Southern culture that 3.5 billion viewers across the world saw Friday night, or the escalating controversies over the Confederate battle flag and antebellum history that increasingly divide white and black Southerners?
Almost since Atlanta unveiled Izzy, its neutered, slug-like mascot to widespread derision four years ago, critics here and throughout the South have worried that Atlanta was likely to sidestep all the tortuous racial issues in the South's past and present by putting on a bland corporate extravaganza devoid of regional identity. Organizers have vehemently denied they would do so, and the evocative regional images from the opening ceremony and the numerous Southern-themed art shows, concerts, museum exhibitions and displays surrounding the Games would seem to support that claim.
"It will be a celebration of the South, but not a celebration of Southern stereotypes," said Andrew Young, co-chairman of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games and civil rights leader, former Congressman and former Mayor of Atlanta. "The one thing I'm very determined to do is not to sanitize the South, but not to run from it either. What percentage of the South was ever antebellum mansions? We'll be celebrating the people of the South, and I think we'll be redefining the South as well."
To be sure, there is something incongruous about battling over the Civil War and 19th-century images in this Olympics, whose main symbols are the Xerox, Coca-Cola, Swatch and Kodak logos of the international commercial culture.
And the Games, from the biracial team that brought them to Atlanta, to the way Atlanta's business and civic culture is based upon an unusual measure of black and white cooperation, reflects the flawed, but remarkable progress in the South toward Martin Luther King Jr.'s dream, also featured Friday night.
But, as the South has prospered economically and its politics have become increasingly biracial -- black-dominated in cities such as Atlanta -- disputes over Old South imagery, as exemplified by long-running bickering over flying the Confederate battle flag in Georgia, Alabama and South Carolina, have become increasingly common.
Groups promoting traditional, largely white, Southern heritage say that Olympic organizers and corporate sponsors have become so skittish about the racial connotations of Southern heritage that they are trying to blot most of it out.
Members of the Sons of Confederate Veterans, made up of the descendants of Confederate soldiers, were prevented from marching in a parade in suburban Roswell, Ga., coinciding with the Games. They finally went to court and were allowed to participate but not until the word, antebellum, was removed from the event's name and a sign showing where nearby slave quarters had been was removed. A number of Civil War battle re-enactors were denied permission to take place in various events, and some blacks burned the Georgia flag Friday.
Members of groups like the Sons of Confederate Veterans, which is now growing at a faster rate than it has in decades, say they are the victim of a new form of cultural censorship in which the South's old symbols have suddenly become verboten. Many members of such groups these days take pains to decry the Ku Klux Klan and racist groups who use the Confederate battle flag, but they maintain it stands for Southern heritage, not racist hate.
"There's no doubt these are a p.c. Olympics," said David Thrasher, a spokesman for the Georgia Division of the Sons of Confederate Veterans, referring to political correctness. "There's a two-sided agenda at work. One side is to portray Atlanta as a city further advanced in race relations than the rest of the U.S., which we all know is not true.
"A second part is what we consider hate from some African-American groups directed at changing our symbols, masked by political correctness."
He added that, political feelings aside, there is no question that visitors from throughout the world cannot get enough of antebellum Southern culture.
To many blacks, almost any imagery from the Civil War, and particularly anything including the Confederate flag, are bitter reminders of slavery, and they have no place as public symbols. A group seeking to change the Georgia state flag said in a statement this week, "Only the hooded uniform of the Ku Klux Klan and the burning cross do more than the Confederate battle emblem to remind us of the evil side of our Southern heritage."
Dr. Moses Norman, an Atlanta civic leader, who is black, said divisive symbols like the flag have their place in private observances, but need not be part of a public spectacle like the Olympics.
"The question is how do they contribute to what we have evolved to as a multiple, pluralistic culture?" he said. "To the extent symbols add nothing positive but create walls that separate individuals then we say, 'O.K., keep that close to heart, but let's not advance it in such a way as it becomes divisive to what we're really trying to do.' "
John Shelton Reed, author, sociologist and University of North Carolina professor, said the disputes reflect real fault lines in the South.
"There was a consensus developed between white Northerners and Southerners in the decades after the war that basically said, 'We're going to allow Confederates their honor and respect in exchange for them agreeing to respect and preserve the Union.' The trouble is blacks were not consulted, and now that consensus is coming apart."
Reed, a fan of an earthier view of the South than that usually associated with the go-go booster world of Atlanta, said he had mixed feelings about the Hollywood-style portrayal of the South in the opening ceremony. But he said they did acknowledge Southern culture in a way he feared the Games might not.
"Especially after Izzy, I thought it would be all Greece and sports and nothing Southern about it, so I shouldn't complain," said Reed, who with his wife, Dale Reed, is the author of the recently published "1,001 Things Everyone Should Know About the South" (Doubleday, 1996). "New Orleans would have had more fun, Charleston would have had more class and Nashville would have had better music, but it wasn't bad for Atlanta."

Weiner for The New York Times); Protesters outside the state capitol Friday setting fire to the Georgia flag and its reminders of the Confederacy. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Man's $11 Million Gift to a College Marks a Rare Friendship

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
As Harvey Wexler lay dying from cancer last year, some of his friends were concerned that he might not have enough money to pay his medical bills.
But last month, after Mr. Wexler's estate was settled, Bryn Mawr College received more than $11 million, its largest gift ever, from the unassuming man who lived in a modest one-bedroom apartment in northwest Washington, D.C. 
 "It's a very big gift for a private college," said Donna L. Wiley, director of resources and secretary of Bryn Mawr, a women's school near Philadelphia.
Mr. Wexler's fascination with Bryn Mawr sprang from his 30-year friendship with Joan Coward, a government economist who graduated in 1945. Miss Wiley called it one of the most romantic gifts she had ever seen. "Clearly, he adored her," she said.
Neither Mr. Wexler, who was 67 when he died, nor Ms. Coward ever married.
He was a deeply private man; not only did his best friends not know of his wealth, but some of them did not know of his relationship with Ms. Coward, either. But a picture of his life and his decision to make the gift emerge from letters that he wrote and from interviews with friends and business acquaintances.
Mr. Wexler met Ms. Coward in Washington in 1960, when both their careers focused on the airline industry. He worked for the Air Transport Association of America, a trade association, and later became a senior vice president and lobbyist for Continental Airlines. She was an economic analyst for the Civil Aeronautics Board. She moved to an apartment in his building, and they spent much time together. She told friends that she was not the marrying kind, drawing parallels between her idol, Katharine Hepburn, who was a Bryn Mawr graduate, and herself.
Although not an active Bryn Mawr alumna, Ms. Coward treasured her education there. Mr. Wexler recalled in a letter to Ms. Coward's sister, Nancy Urban, that on their first date in 1960, Ms. Coward had told him how they had used original documents rather than textbooks at the college. "I even tested her on one matter and she knew more than I," he wrote.
Ms. Coward grew up in Bryn Mawr and attended a local private school. After graduating from Bryn Mawr, she worked for Eastern Airlines as an economic analyst before moving to Washington in the mid-1950's.
After Ms. Coward died of cancer in 1990 at the age of 67, Mr. Wexler wanted to create a memorial, perhaps a scholarship fund. The more he talked with Bryn Mawr officials, the more enamored he became with the college, college officials said, and the bigger the gift grew.
He also struck up a running conversation with a Bryn Mawr economics professor, Richard Du Boff, who will hold the first chair in economic history. It will be named after Mr. Wexler's parents.
Another chair will be endowed in Ms. Coward's name for political economy, and two more chairs in Mr. Wexler's name for professors in economics, history, philosophy or political science.
Mr. Wexler's views on money, education and philanthropy owed much to the influence of his father, Samuel. In a letter to friends shortly before his death, Mr. Wexler recalled how, as a 5-year-old during the bank panic of 1933, he watched tellers at a bank that his father owned give depositors their money when other banks remained closed. The next day, people lined up to deposit more money.
Mr. Wexler made steady investments in blue chip stocks. But otherwise, his friends say that they have few clues to how he accumulated the money he left to Bryn Mawr.

HEADLINE: Strawberry Warning Costs Growers Millions

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 20

 BODY:
California strawberry growers are still trying to recover from a wave of negative publicity and more than $20 million in losses that began when health officials in Texas blamed the fruit last month for outbreaks of intestinal illness.
Federal health officials said this week that contaminated raspberries from Guatemala were the likely source of the cyclospora microbe that has sickened about 1,000 people in 13 states, the District of Columbia and Canada since early May. 
 Earlier investigations had suggested that strawberries, either domestic or imported, might be the source of the outbreak. Although Federal health officials never confirmed strawberries as the source, the Texas Department of Health issued an advisory on June 8 against eating fresh strawberries after 26 Houston residents became sick. Other health departments issued advisories urging consumers to wash the fruit thoroughly.
Because California produces 80 percent of the nation's strawberries, growers in that state were hurt the most by the Texas warning, which was lifted on June 23. Since the advisory was issued, California growers, who last year had sales of $608 million, have lost more than $20 million, according to the California Strawberry Commission.
"The Texas advisory hurt us a lot," Teresa Thorne, a spokeswoman for the group, said, adding that widespread coverage in the news media exacerbated the effect. "In a single day, consumer confidence was taken away, and we're still having a problem with it despite being given a clean bill of health."
Most troubling to California health officials and those within the produce industry is that Texas officials issued the advisory without testing strawberries from California or other locations. They instead based the advisory on interviews with people who had contracted the illness.
"We're very concerned about the public's health, but we feel Texas officials made accusations without backup information," said Sandra R. Smoley, California's Secretary of Health and Welfare.
But Doug McBride, a spokesman for the Texas Department of Health, said that his department was only watching out for the public's health and safety. "Had we not taken the action we did," he said, "it's conceivable that we could be answering another question from the public right now: 'Why didn't you tell us?' "
Strawberry shipments were down 15 percent nationwide last month compared with June of last year, when more than 1.4 billion pint baskets were sold. With four more months left in the strawberry harvesting season, Ms. Thorne said, "I expect total losses in the tens of millions of dollars."
In the New York area, the largest United States market for California strawberries, sales have dropped as much as 90 percent, said Alvin Nathel of Wishnatzki & Nathel, a New York produce company.
"A flat of strawberries is selling in the New York market for $3 to $4," he said. "That barely covers the cost of growing and shipping."
Cyclospora, a parasite that attaches itself to the small intestine, causes diarrhea, stomach cramps, vomiting, weight loss, fever and fatigue. Identifying the source of the outbreak has been difficult, particularly because it takes a week or more for a person to become sick and even more time before cases are reported.

HEADLINE: Harriett Heywood Patton, 85, Founder of Recording for Blind

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Harriett Heywood Patton, a founder of Recording for the Blind and a managing director of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, died on Wednesday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. She was 85 and lived in Bronxville.
She suffered a brief illness, her husband, Arch Patton, said. 
 Mrs. Patton is credited with contributing significantly to the growth of Recording for the Blind, which she served as president in 1954, and of the Opera Guild. She was managing director of the guild from 1959 to 1968.
She was born in Indianapolis and graduated from Wheelock College in Boston. During and after World War II, she worked for United China Relief and the Friends of France and played a pivotal role on the Committee for Economic Development, a national organization.
The committee brought together top corporate executives to plan for the postwar era; Mrs. Patton was recruited as deputy director.
Acting as a welcoming party of one, she kept track of the members' comings and goings and saw to it that they were fed, chauffeured and otherwise cared for.
In 1948, she was a founder of Recording for the Blind, and she helped build it from a local group in New York for the benefit of blind war veterans into a national organization. She crusaded across the country to get concerned people to band together in local chapters and open recording studios for volunteers to do the readings.
Eleanor R. Belmont, founder of the Opera Guild and a friend, persuaded Mrs. Patton to turn her attention in that direction and become managing director. During her tenure of nearly 10 years, the guild's membership and donations quickly increased, both in the United States and abroad.
Mrs. Patton, who had served as a director, was familiar with the operation and earned a reputation for running a trim ship. Annual gifts to the guild, $90,000 in Mrs. Patton's first year as chief executive, rose nearly fourfold, to $355,000.
She grew up in Portland, Me., and acted in summer stock for three years as a young woman.
Besides her husband, Mrs. Patton left no immediate family. An earlier marriage to Roswell L. Gilpatric ended in divorce.

HEADLINE: Bosnia Gears Up for Election, With 25,000 Candidates

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, July 20

 BODY:
Sejfudin Tokic, 35, a former pharmacist, went today from a seminar on running a political campaign to a meeting in the suburbs with campaign workers, then back to his office, with its broken windows and stained carpets, for another meeting.
It was opening day of the campaign for the Bosnian elections scheduled for Sept. 14, a campaign almost scuttled by a quarrel among outside powers over whether the field was ready, and then delayed by a scrimmage to wrest the Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic from office, something accomplished only Friday. 
 No one would suggest that the Bosnian elections, a crucial element of the Dayton peace accord, are going to be a paradigm of democracy. The phones often do not even work, noted Mr. Tokic, leader of the Union of Bosnian Social Democrats, so how can he coordinate with party officials in other cities?
People question how democratic an election can be when citizens are not free to return to their homes and vote, and the media are controlled by different governing entities in various parts of this fractured country.
"But we have to have elections, to make a step toward pluralization and democracy," said Mr. Tokic, who wants to move away from ethnic-based politics.
If participation is the standard, this is an incipient Athenian democracy. So far, 25,000 people have registered -- to be candidates.
Voters will be electing a three-member national presidency of one Bosnian Muslim, one Bosnian Croat and one Bosnian Serb.
They will also vote for a 42-member House of Representatives, with 14 members coming from the Bosnian Serbs and 28 from the Muslim-Croat Federation.
The House members will choose 15 delegates -- 5 from each ethnic group -- to a House of People.
In addition, the Bosnian Serbs and the Federation will each choose an own assembly, and local councils will be elected throughout the country.
This will be no two-party election. Indeed, 47 parties have qualified -- some of them run by warlords -- including the Green Party, the Pure Party of Rights and the Party of Economic Prosperity.
The lurking issue is whether the elections will be another step toward the partition of Bosnia -- with Serbs and Croats joining their respective neighbor countries -- or a tentative step toward a unified democracy.
In trying to gauge the future, foreign and Bosnian analysts are looking at the municipal elections last month in Mostar, a Bosnian city divided between Croats and Muslims. Voter turnout was high, and for the first time in three years people crossed the confrontation line in large numbers.
"The election served as a great pretext for interaction," and showed that people can "interact peacefully, indeed warmly," says a report by the Sarajevo office of the International Crisis Group, a Washington-based research organization.
But the people voted along ethnic lines. A moderate multi-ethnic coalition of Muslims, Croats and Serbs, led by a popular former Mayor, received only 1,900 votes out of 58,000 cast. Given the anger and fear, so raw after years of war and propaganda, a similar outcome is possible on the national level.
Some Bosnian Serbs are already taking advantage of the election rules to move toward splitting from Bosnia.
In pursuit of the ideal of a multi-ethnic state, the Dayton peace agreement provides that people are to vote where they lived in 1991, before the war and the "ethnic cleansing." But refugees can apply for permission to vote where they are now living.
At least half of the potential voters are refugees, having been forced from their homes by the war.
In the Republika Srpska, to date an astonishing 125,000 Bosnian Serb refugees have applied to change their voting residence, according to statistics from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which is supervising the election.
This decision has not exactly been voluntary, officials say. The Bosnian Serb authorities have been forcing refugees to register to change their voting residence to be eligible for international relief assistance, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said here on Friday, calling the situation "scandalous."
Even though there are several hundred thousand Muslim refugees in the Federation territory, only 7,000 have asked to change their voting residence.
As for what the people will be voting for, "it's complex," Mr. Tokic, the former pharmacist, said with a laugh.
The contests most closely watched will be for the national presidency and Parliament, and in the Republika Srpska. There, the opposition to the governing Serb Democratic Party, which Dr. Karadzic headed until he resigned on Friday, is based in the northern city of Banja Luka.
The opposition, which has split into two coalitions, is usually described as "moderate," compared with Dr. Karadzic and his colleagues.
The party regarded as having the best chance to make some inroads on Dr. Karadzic's party is the Socialist Party of the Republika Srpska, a branch of the Socialist Party in neighboring Serbia, which is run by the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic.
In the Muslim-Croat Federation, the strongest challenge to the governing Party of Democratic Action, a Muslim-led party headed by Bosnia's President, Alija Izetbegovic, will be from Haris Silajdzic.
Mr. Silajdzic, 50, a former history professor, resigned as Prime Minister earlier this year and is generally viewed as more inclined toward a democratic, nonsectarian state than the Democratic Action Party wants.
Public opinion polls show Mr. Silajdzic as the country's most popular politician. If Mr. Silajdzic and Mr. Izetbegovic split the Muslim vote, Momcilo Krajisnik, a nationalistic Serbian hard-liner who has replaced Dr. Karadzic as a candidate, could emerge as the top vote-getter and thus be the first president of the three-member presidency.
Against all of these parties is Mr. Tokic's United List coalition, which has in its leadership a former Bosnian Serb commander and a former commander of the Muslim-led Bosnian Army.
At the seminar, as the party leaders worked on their campaign themes, one that emerged was "togetherness and unity."
Mr. Tokic said his coalition would be pleased with 10 percent of the vote.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A shop window in Pale displayed a poster of Radovan Karadzic, who has agreed to step down as chairman of the Serb Democratic Party, a condition for its participation in the Sept. 14 elections. Some fear that the elections -- for a three-member presidency and legislators -- will harden ethnic divisions. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: The Dream, Deferred

BYLINE: By Jeremy Waldron; Jeremy Waldron is Laurance S. Rockefeller University Professor of Politics at Princeton University.

 BODY:

GOSPEL CHOIRS
Psalms of Survival for an Alien Land Called Home.
By Derrick Bell.
228 pp. New York:
Basic Books. $23.
This is the third of Derrick Bell's Geneva Crenshaw series. Like "And We Are Not Saved" and "Faces at the Bottom of the Well," "Gospel Choirs" is a collection of parables, dreams and dialogues about the present and the possible futures of race relations in America, gently threaded together by the author's own voice -- that of a black law professor and activist -- and that of his fictional friend and muse, Geneva Crenshaw. 
 Geneva is a civil rights lawyer who was injured, perhaps killed, in a car wreck after facing down some good ol' boys who were chasing her on a Mississippi road in the 1960's. Whether she died or not, she certainly has supernatural powers and -- what is even better -- preternatural insight. In the earlier books she was a source of inspiration and occasional reproach for the professor in his meditations on the prospects and politics of the African-American community. In "Gospel Choirs" she is more than that. Her presence and that of another character, Gwynn Gant, a lesbian attorney, are a reminder that African-Americans as much as anyone have to come to terms with issues of sexuality and sexism.
The book's distinctive stand on these issues emerges in a dialogue with another familiar character -- the professor's limousine driver, Jesse B. Semple. Jesse is inclined to wonder whether even the good Lord Himself could change the nature of men in their relations with women. "It's not a question of nature," the professor replies. "It's one of mind, of will." Jesse reads to the professor from a James Baldwin book that he often dips into while waiting for his passengers: black sexism, he says, is an understandable response to the hostility and humiliation that young men face every time they go out their door. The professor acknowledges the point, but insists again that political will must overcome even the most "natural" tendencies: "I'm not talking about blame, Jesse. I'm talking about . . . the best chance to survive our future dealings with white America." Black women have proved time and again that they have the strength and resolve to stand up for themselves and their people. African-Americans, Mr. Bell argues, must build on that as a source of strength, and proceed on a basis of equal respect.
Mr. Bell's position on sexism needs to be understood in the context of a broader argument about American race relations. The subtitle of "Faces at the Bottom of the Well" was "The Permanence of Racism," and the thesis is that the goal of racial equality -- the "dream" of Dr. King, the mythical color-blind society -- will not be achieved in the United States in the foreseeable future. If anything, Mr. Bell expects matters to get much worse. "Gospel Choirs" is prefaced by a grim review of the cynical policies of corporate America, whose effects are insecurity and rising unemployment in all communities, and a particular burden of poverty and misery for blacks compounded by "the rage of many whites who, fearful for their own jobs and future well-being, are all too easily convinced that the threat to both is our black presence rather than the real villain -- corporate greed." Since submission or surrender to racism, however it is caused, is not an option, the prime strategy must be the strengthening of black community to be "better able to fend off the myriad manifestations of hostility we will most certainly face during the transformation and possible destruction of our economy."
At the same time, the permanence of racism does not mean an end to the fight against discrimination and inequality: on the contrary, it means clear and dignified struggle against these things on the simple ground that they are wrong and unjust, a struggle that will not be muddied by the compromises that might be necessary or appropriate if victory were actually at hand. We no longer have any illusions, Mr. Bell seems to be saying, but still -- if the cause is lost and we are crushed, it must not be through our choices.
Besides the issue of sexism, what distinguishes "Gospel Choirs" from its predecessors is the presence of a soundtrack. Each chapter is prefaced by lines from gospel songs: "We've come this far by faith," "I'm comin' up -- on the rough side -- of the mountain," "Nobody told me the road would be easy." The music is woven into the text as well, sometimes quoted or sung by the characters, sometimes discussed as a topic in its own right -- how black churches had to find their way back to gospel music from forms of worship "a la Mozart" that had been thought more polite and acceptable in a white world. The author regards gospel as a well-spring of faith and cheer, and his use of gospel is one of the most attractive features of the work.
Derrick Bell was dismissed from Harvard Law School after he prolonged a leave of absence to protest the school's failure to hire minority women. He is currently a visiting professor at New York University Law School. Some of his academic colleagues will sneer at the style of this book. It is not a social-science study of American racism nor is it a jurisprudential treatise. In fact, it's not really a book about law at all: the Supreme Court hardly appears in Mr. Bell's stories, and then as a rather sad and impotent institution.
Many chapters are presented in dialogue form, which I guess has something in common with the Socratic method used in law schools, except that it is more conversational and respectful of the participants' perspectives. Certainly it's a more interesting back-and-forth than Plato's dialogues, where the interlocutor usually contributes something like "You're perfectly right, Socrates." Other chapters use fantasy, pastiche and dreams, even science fiction. These are not always successful: I wish, for example, that the professor's interview with the talk-show host Biff Rightwing had gone through a few more drafts. But when they do work they are magical: the power of the allegory "Equality's Child," toward the end of the book, approaches that of the Grand Inquisitor story in "The Brothers Karamazov."
I suppose there would be a problem if everyone wrote about race in the Derrick Bell style. We need analysis and we need social science as much as dream, dialogue and narrative. But we would certainly be the poorer if no one wrote like this; for even to be disconcerted by Mr. Bell's technique is to open oneself to the challenge of his thesis and the soaring power of the music that sustains it.

HEADLINE: Still Waters

BYLINE: By Hal Espen; Hal Espen, a former senior editor at The New Yorker, is a writer living in Oregon.

 BODY:

A RIVER LOST
The Life and Death of the Columbia.
By Blaine Harden.
Illustrated. 271 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $25.
The Columbia River was once famous as the farthest reach of the Western frontier, a primordial salmon-choked torrent that had taken Lewis and Clark for a wild ride on the final leg of their cross-country journey. More recently, from the depths of the Great Depression to victory in World War II and the economic triumph that followed, the Columbia became a shining symbol of national power and virtue. In a providential feat of luck and good timing, the New Deal-financed Bonneville and Grand Coulee dams came on line just before the United States entered the war, delivering millions of kilowatts to the aluminum smelters, airplane factories and shipyards of the Pacific Northwest, as well as electricity to the Manhattan Project's secret plutonium factory along the banks of the Columbia at Hanford, Wash. After the war, the dams on the river made it possible for farmers to irrigate vast tracts of desert land and allowed the region to use twice as much electricity per capita as the rest of the country, at rates that were half the national average. The river even inspired a Northwest anthem of sorts in Woody Guthrie's "Roll On, Columbia." "Your power is turning our darkness to dawn," the 1941 song, which was commissioned by the Federal Bureau of Reclamation, went. "So roll on, Columbia, roll on." 
 These days, however, things seem to have gone terribly wrong. The heroic era of dam building is over; the time when monumental concrete bulwarks and colossal turbines filled every Westerner with patriotic pride is past. The system of dams along the Columbia and its main tributary, the Snake, produces more than a billion dollars of hydroelectric power a year, but the dams have transformed most of the great river into a series of sluggish slack-water lakes, suitable for barge traffic and windsurfers but not much else. The irrigation subsidies that the Federal Columbia Basin Irrigation Project provides to farmers turn out to have been spectacularly uneconomical, and taxpayers are footing the bill. The river is becoming more polluted every year. And now it seems that while Americans were celebrating the harnessing of the Columbia, they failed to notice that the treaty rights of the Indians who had lived along its banks for thousands of years were being trampled on, and that the dams were hastening the wild salmon of the Northwest toward extinction.
All this sounds like one more example of the kind of bleak story that the revisionist historians of the West have been offering lately -- another tale of disaster, exploitation and environmental depredation. Alternately, this situation could provide the occasion for a grieving, elegiac book by one of the neo-environmentalists who have contributed to the lyrical nature-writing boom of recent years. Sometimes, however, nothing serves like an industrious journalist, and Blaine Harden, who covered Africa and the Balkan war for The Washington Post, has written a hard-nosed, clear-eyed, tough-minded dispatch on the sort of contentious subject that is almost always distorted by ideology or obscured by a fog of sentiment. The result is a scathing indictment of technocratic hubris, and of those who play what Mr. Harden calls "the river game" for shortsighted economic gain.
"A River Lost" would be less heart-rending if its author's stake in the story were not personal. Mr. Harden's father helped build the Grand Coulee Dam, and he raised his family in a central Washington farming town that owed its existence and its prosperity to Columbia River irrigation. After college, Mr. Harden lived on the East Coast and abroad for nearly two decades; when he returned to the Columbia basin in 1993, he found that the peaceful home he remembered from his youth was now "a natural-resource war zone." Moreover, most people no longer worked in agriculture or similar industries; the majority of the population lived in the cities and suburbs west of the Cascades, where Microsoft and other high-tech companies were thriving. The affluent residents of the wet, arboreal West Side were willing to make moderate sacrifices to save the salmon and otherwise preserve "the giant civic park that the Pacific Northwest had become." They tended to view the pro-irrigation, pro-slack-water residents of the dry East Side as troglodytes and ecological criminals. Without letting the plugged-in, high-consuming West Siders off the hook, Mr. Harden ends up agreeing with them.
But he lets the facts, and his former neighbors along the Columbia River, speak for themselves. As a good reporter should, Mr. Harden takes a close look at the thing itself: he begins with an account of the days he spent descending the Snake and the Columbia on tugboats shepherding gigantic barges that carry everything from grain and computer chips to milk cartons and decommissioned nuclear submarine reactors. The tugboat crews and the barge companies believe, with some justice, that their livelihood is jeopardized by proposals to "draw down" the river -- that is, to lower its level and spill its flow over the dams, in order to assist the juvenile salmon that must now traverse warm, slow-moving pools and brave the often deadly turbines. The drawdown would also halt barge traffic for several months each year. The pilots and deckhands tell Mr. Harden, in no uncertain terms, what they think of salmon and Indians and yuppies in Seattle and Portland who are threatening their way of life.
Mr. Harden is equally adept at eliciting the rationalizations of other East Side denizens whom history has turned into presumptive villains: retired dam builders, heavily subsidized farmers, nuclear engineers and utility company lobbyists. Along the way, he encounters a shocking incidence of casual racism directed against Indians; he repeatedly hears the preposterous allegation that Indians themselves, through overfishing, are responsible for the dwindling stocks of wild salmon. In rebuttal, Mr. Harden presents the dismal record of fraud and callousness by the Federal Government, and makes it clear that a vast environmental and cultural tragedy could have been prevented if earlier generations had paid heed to the wisdom of the Indians' veneration of the salmon.
"A River Lost" is a far from perfect book. The prose is not always elegant; some of the material has already been effectively reported in other recent books; and some parts of the story, like the increasing role of Hispanic farm workers and other immigrants in the Columbia basin, are virtually ignored. But this is a precise and brave book. It must not have been easy for Blaine Harden to find himself turning his journalistic weapons against his own heritage, but he has done the conscience of his homeland a large service.
