HEADLINE: Doors Shut to Poor Seeking Homes

SERIES: AN AMERICAN PLACE: Scaling Back Section 8

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ohio, July 19

 BODY:
For two decades, the Federal Government's Section 8 housing subsidy program has helped poor working people like Wanda Schott get off welfare. After spending two years on a waiting list, Ms. Schott, a divorced mother of two boys, became eligible for one of those precious Section 8 vouchers and, in 1994, used it to rent a trailer in this suburb of Canton.
Not long after, she got off welfare, taking a 25-hour-a-week job in the bakery at the I.G.A. supermarket in the Buckeye Village shopping center. A few afternoons a week she works a second job, for a lawn care service. 
 Then, in April, the county housing authority determined that the trailer no longer met Federal housing standards. Ms. Schott had 90 days to find another apartment that would accept her Section 8 voucher.
She was not able to, though she searched frantically, visiting 20 apartments a month. "I looked everywhere," Ms. Schott said. "I can prove it with my tiredness."
Recent Federal budget cuts have lowered the payments to landlords, causing apartment owners here and across the country to withdraw from Section 8, threatening the nation's biggest housing program for the poor.
For now, she has moved her two boys in with her mother, but there is no room for her. So Ms. Schott sleeps in her '72 Ford truck, which she keeps parked in her mother's driveway, filled with pillows and cushions and a windup alarm clock to wake her for work. "At night I climb in and throw the cushions over me," she said, "I put up this here curtain so I have privacy."
Even in a time of relative prosperity and in a community like Stark County with a strong tradition of volunteerism, a place where the Republican Mayor of Canton, Richard Watkins, has opened a free medical clinic for people without health insurance, there is evidence that the Government's safety net for the poor is unraveling.
The county's 300 homeless-shelter beds are full year round.
Federal transportation cuts have meant that the public bus system, which serves mainly the elderly, the working poor and the handicapped, has had to reduce service on most routes to once an hour, shut down after 6:30 P.M. and may close altogether next year.
Recent Federal cuts for the Legal Services Corporation, the primary program providing legal aid for the poor in civil matters, have reduced the local office from eight lawyers to five. Next month the poor will no longer be able to get a legal aid lawyer to represent them on certain child custody matters. Because of cuts in Federal Emergency Management Agency money for the homeless, a Canton soup kitchen at the J.R. Coleman Outreach Center had to close this month.
None of these developments has become a political issue in this place that mirrors national politics -- not even among Democratic politicians. "It's not a question that is being talked about," said Carol Duncan, an advocate for the homeless. "It just doesn't appear."
When President Clinton speaks like a Republican, calling for a two-year limit on welfare, he is playing to conservative communities like Stark County, where the sentiment against taxes and welfare is strong, even among Democrats. In the 1980's, many Democrats here deserted their party's Presidential candidates for being too liberal, returning in 1992 to help Mr. Clinton carry Stark.
At a time when the national political agenda has been set by the Republicans, conservative talk is not going to cost Mr. Clinton many votes here. Liberals like Ms. Duncan have no one else to turn to. "He does the best he can with the Republican Congress totally opposed to what he wants to do," she said.
In the case of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development -- which many conservative Republicans would like to abolish outright -- doing the best he can has meant watching the agency's annual budget shrink from $25.2 billion to $19.5 billion during his Administration. (For 1996 Mr. Clinton requested $21 billion; the Republican Congress appropriated $19.5 billion.)
Several cuts last fall have had a particularly harsh impact on Section 8, a program, begun in the Nixon Administration, that provides housing assistance for 3.6 million poor Americans. "Across the country landlords are being driven away," says Julio Barreto, director of legislative affairs for the National Association of Housing and Redevelopment Officials. "We'll be left with landlords who don't have the housing you want people to have."
The Section 8 program provides a certificate or voucher, which the renter can present to any landlord who is willing to take part. Tenants pay 30 percent of their monthly income toward the rent and the Federal Government makes up the rest.
In return, the landlord agrees to follow Section 8 rent guidelines. In Canton that means charging no more than $359 a month (plus utility costs) for a two-bedroom apartment. In time, as a tenant like Ms. Schott, 30, earns more money, she pays a larger share of the rent and the Federal subsidy decreases.
Tenants appreciate being able to use the voucher anywhere, blending anonymously into a neighborhood rather than living together in a public housing project. There are 150,000 on the waiting list for Section 8 in New York City, 47,000 in Chicago and 40,000 in Los Angeles, where officials have closed the list until 2001.
The program has political appeal because it relies on private landlords in an era when privatization is so popular.
But three recent changes enacted as Federal budget-cutting measures are driving landlords away.
First, the maximum allowable rent a landlord can collect through Section 8 was reduced last fall. In Canton that amounted to about $10 less per month. The cut comes at a time when the economy here is strong and rental prices on the open market are climbing, giving landlords little incentive to take part in Section 8.
When Ralph Swonger Jr., a Canton landlord who used to do a lot of Section 8, advertised two available house rentals recently he had 143 calls, 43 from people with Section 8 certificates. He did not bother with the Section 8 people. "You can't get as high rents now," he said. "Hey, I'm in this for business."
Second, the compensation to a landlord for damage by a Section 8 tenant vacating an apartment has been drastically reduced. Landlords used to be able to collect nearly three months worth of rent from the Federal program for damages; now they can collect just one month's.
This has discouraged Rudy Kulisek of Niebel Property Management from most Section 8 rentals. In his dozen years in the program, he says 95 percent of these renters have been good, but the other 5 percent can cause significant damage. Until this year he could collect as much as $1,200 for damages to a typical rental, saving him the time and cost of going to court to recoup the damages. Under the new guidelines, he can collect only one month's rent and winds up paying $250 for a lawyer to get a court judgment against a poor tenant who usually has no assets.
The third budget factor is stricter lead paint inspection standards that took effect for Section 8 landlords last October, without Federal money to pay for cleanup costs. In the early 1990's two Democrats, Senator Alan Cranston, of California and Representative Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas, sponsored the legislation created to protect children.
But the effect, says Rhonda Webster of the Stark County housing authority, has been to set a higher, costlier standard for landlords willing to accept Section 8 tenants than for all other landlords, who do not have to be inspected. "These inspections can cost the Section 8 landlord thousands of dollars and then thousands more if there's a problem," says Ms. Webster. "Most of these landlords are mom and pop operations, they can't afford this. Our landlord list keeps getting smaller."
Among those dramatically reducing their role, she says, is Royal Estate Management Corporation, the largest local rental agency.
And so, people who have waited two years for a certificate, are now turning back those certificates, unused. "One of my staff was playing back her messages the other day," said Ms. Webster, "and I heard a woman's voice: 'What am I going to do? I'm looking every day, I can't find anything.' "
It is Ms. Schott's question too. Right now, the three-bedroom brick house owned by her mother, Shirley Salmen, a widow, is full.
Besides Ms. Schott's sons, aged 8 and 10, there is her brother and his daughter, plus Ms. Schott's furniture from the trailer.
The other afternoon, Ms. Schott and her mother, who works a midnight shift as a nurse's aide, sat in the backyard discussing what to do.
Ms. Schott started listing all the places she had looked for an apartment.
"I know what you mean, sweets," said the mother. "You went clear over to Malvern looking."
They remembered when she moved into the trailer two years ago.
"There was an old smelly mattress, animal poop under the sink," said the daughter. "I hauled trash to Mom's and I paid for extra pick up. We painted it ourselves."
"We're a team," said the mother.
The trailer's interior had been dark blue, even the ceilings. "We painted everything white," said the daugther.
"Snow white," said the mother. "Kitchen took three coats."
One reason the trailer's owner flunked the housing authority's inspection last spring was problems with the water. "One day she had water," said the mother, "then two or three days, no water. She'd come over my house and bring a couple of gallons of water home."
'When she moved out of the trailer in early July her brother asked if she would be going back on welfare. "I can't," said Ms. Schott, who makes $4.90 an hour at the bakery. "Everyone says 'welfare' like you're low scum and I'm not."
"You're not," said the mother, "I know you're not."
But she can't spend the winter in the truck, either. For now she has no set plan, she is just thankful for the summer heat.
Living midway between Democratic Cleveland and Republican Columbus, the citizens of Canton, Ohio, and surrounding Stark County have a history of voting for the winning Presidiential candidate. As the November election approaches, this is the 18th article in a yearlong series that seeks to explore the forces shaping the political debate at the grass roots. (Previous articles are available to computer users on The New York Times on the Web, at http:// www.nytimes/specials/canton.)

"You can't get as high rents now," he said. (Photographs by Scott Heckel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Tribe Is Now Wanted as a Resource

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: JOSEPH, Ore.

 BODY:
They saved Lewis and Clark from starvation, helped many an Oregon Trail straggler find the way west, and outfoxed the United States Army in battles that are studied by military historians to this day.
Yet for all their standing in the history books, the Nez Perce Indians have never been able to regain a foothold in the land they were forced from in 1877 -- an exile that led to one of the last major Indian wars in North America. 
But now, in a turn of history and uncommon fate, the people who live in the mountain valley that was taken from the Nez Perce want the Indians to return and are even assembling the financing to buy a large patch of real estate for them. They regard the return of the Nez Perce as a way to help replace the dying logging and ranching economy that was created as a justification for removing the Indians in the first place.
"They're opening the door for the trail home -- I never thought I'd see the day," said Earl (Taz) Conner, one of about 4,000 Nez Perce in North America. Mr. Conner is a direct descendant of Old Chief Joseph, for whom this town is named and whose burial site is a prime tourist attraction here in the Wallowa Valley, in northeastern Oregon. "It is really ironic, asking us Indians to return after booting us out of there in 1877."
These days, the people in the valley see the tribe as a potent economic resource. They hope to set aside land for an interpretive center they believe will be a tourist magnet, as well as a year-round cultural and camping site for the Nez Perce.
A remote, mountainous area, four hours of hard driving from the nearest city of any size, Wallowa County has suffered economically in the last decade as timber mills have shut down and cattle prices have plunged.
The Nez Perce have long since disappeared, leaving behind only a little cemetery at the foot of Wallowa Lake. Also known as the Sahaptin, they were given the name Nez Perce (meaning pierced nose) by the French because some of the Indians wore nose pendants.
Tourists from all over the world come to see the cemetery and the heart-stopping scenery. In Germany, where the fascination with American Indians knows few bounds, the Wallowa Valley may be as well known as Cooperstown is to American baseball fans.
Until now, among the ranchers and cowboys here, there has been ambivalence about the Indians who were driven out.
"I wouldn't call it guilt, but now that some of the old-timers here have fallen on hard times, they can appreciate a little better what happened to the Nez Perce," said Paul Henderson, the National Park Service coordinator for the Oregon end of the 1,100-mile Nez Perce National Historic Trail, which commemorates the 1877 war.
What has happened here has happened in other Western counties where Indian cultural events have become a big attraction. About 10 years ago, some Nez Perce Indians started to return for the annual rodeo here, setting up a powwow on nearby grounds. Before long, the powwows were attracting more people than the rodeo, which was named Chief Joseph Days.
In all the sorry history of American Indians, the Nez Perce story stands as a singular tale. This year, in Stephen E. Ambrose's best-selling book about Lewis and Clark -- "Undaunted Courage: Meriwether Lewis, Thomas Jefferson, and the Opening of the American West" (Simon & Schuster) -- a new generation of Americans is learning about the tribe that saved the expedition known as the Corps of Discovery from starvation in 1805 and 1806.
For months, the explorers lived among the Nez Perce, marveling at their elaborate economy, their horse-breeding skills, their athleticism, their ability to prosper in the vast reaches of the Columbia River Plateau.
In part because of their longstanding good relations with the Federal Government dating to that expedition, in 1855 the Nez Perce were given official recognition of the land they lived on, about 13 million acres covering parts of what are now Oregon, Washington and Idaho. Included in that original treaty was the Wallowa Valley, where the Joseph band of the tribe had lived for centuries.
But trespassers inevitably came, as part of the gold rushes in the 1860's and 1870's; the treaty was broken; and by the 1870's, the Army ordered the Nez Perce out of the Wallowa region and onto a much smaller reservation in Idaho. Rather than be rounded up, the Wallowa band fled, led by Young Chief Joseph -- son of the older chief.
Their 1,600-mile march, with the military in pursuit, over several months was page-one news around the world -- with the Indians winning most of the battles.
"On our part, the war was in its origin and motive nothing short of a gigantic blunder and a crime," The New York Times wrote in 1877.
Finally, just short of the Canadian border in what is now Montana, where the tribe had hoped to be taken in by other Indians, the starving, freezing band of Nez Perce surrendered.
Some 250 Nez Perce warriors, joined by 500 women, children and old people, had fought with about 2,000 Army soldiers in 20 battles and skirmishes. Later, the Army estimated that a total of 151 Indians had been killed. It was, Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman said, "the most extraordinary of Indian wars."
Afterward, the Government scattered the Nez Perce all across the continent, from Canada to Oklahoma, but never allowed them to return to this valley. Young Joseph was buried in 1904 in the chalky volcanic soil of eastern Washington. He died, it was said, of a broken heart.
Though the Nez Perce made numerous appeals to the Government, and through the courts, to get their Wallowa Valley land back, they were rebuffed. The Government pointed to a revised treaty -- signed by some Nez Perce leaders in Idaho, but never signed by Joseph or his band -- as the legal basis for keeping the tribe out of Oregon.
Mr. Conner, whose great-grandfather Ollokot fought in the war, noticed a change in attitude a few years ago, as the Wallowa economy went into tailspin.
"I was working for the Forest Service, the only Indian walking around there, and I was approached by this economic development guy from the city of Wallowa," Mr. Conner recalled. "He said he thought the Indians could save this county. I had to laugh at that."
These days, tourists by the busload cannot get enough of the vanquished Joseph band, said Mr. Henderson, the Park Service coordinator.
"Joseph has become one of those transcendent figures in American history," he said. "There is just this huge interest. They come here, to the end of the road, and they see what Joseph was fighting for."
Down the road from Joseph, in the town of Wallowa, community leaders say the aura of the Nez Perce may be the No. 1 draw. Their visitor brochures now proclaim Wallowa as "Gateway to the Land of Chief Joseph," and the Nez Perce Powwow -- which is separate from the gathering in Joseph -- is now in its sixth year.
Seeing a chance for economic revitalization, the valley's community leaders have joined with the Indians to develop a big Nez Perce cultural and interpretive center. They obtained a $250,000 grant from an Oregon historical group, and plan to use the money to buy 160 acres atop a bluff not far from the river where the Nez Perce used to fish for salmon, just outside the town of Wallowa. They intend to begin a major fund-raising effort for the rest of the money, an amount yet to be determined, to build the center.
The Nez Perce, it turns out, have been something of a lost gem in this valley. "We're just a bunch of white folks -- we didn't have a clue at first," said Terry Crenshaw, one of the leaders behind the effort to build a cultural and interpretive center.
But the recent developments have a different meaning for Nez Perce like Soy Redthunder, a descendant of Joseph who lives on the Colville Indian Reservation in Washington State, where Young Joseph is buried.
"The whites may look at it as an economic plus, but we look at it as homecoming," Mr. Redthunder said.
He said the tribe would have to be very careful, given that anti-Indian sentiment still lingers in the valley. "I don't think we want to rush in there and take over the county," he said. "But I see a serious effort to return the Nez Perce people to the Wallowa Valley."
Until a few years ago, Mr. Red thunder said, he had always felt shunned here. "At their cowboy festival, they were highly indifferent to native people -- they considered us drunken Indians," he said.
Up in another part of this county, the Nez Perce are about to take possession of 10,000 acres along a creek where Young Joseph was born. This land is being bought by the Bonneville Power Administration, which sells electricity from the string of Federal dams along the Columbia and Snake Rivers. Having destroyed the salmon runs on which the Indians used to depend, the dam operators are required by law to offer something in return.
In this case, they are buying Wallowa County land and turning it over to the Indians for management. No Indians will live there, but they will get hunting, fishing and management rights. It would be controlled by the band of Nez Perce living on the reservation in Idaho -- a group that has been separate from the Joseph band since 1860.
Standing near the Wallowa River, where generations of Nez Perce have long fished for the big chinook salmon and steelhead trout that make their way into the Oregon interior, Mr. Conner could scarcely believe the changes that are under way.
A Navy veteran, he has always felt that people in other parts of the world appreciated the Nez Perce more than people in his home in the Pacific Northwest.
"I was in Spain once," Mr. Conner recalled, "and this guy said to me, 'You're Indian, right? What are you, Sioux?' I told him I was Nez Perce, and his face lit up. He said, 'Nez Perce! Chief Joseph.' "
The return of the Nez Perce here, "would be a tremendous happening for our people," Mr. Conner said, adding, "We're pretty close to being home."

HEADLINE: Spanish Journalist Didn't Merit Post

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Chill in Spain" (editorial, July 15) presents only one side of the story of the dismissal of Spanish Television's New York bureau chief, Jose Martinez-Soler. 
 Mr. Martinez-Soler received his post during the previous Socialist government for no apparent professional merit. Before this he was director of a fledgling daily newspaper that failed. He was then given a program on Spanish state television that also failed. It was only after his predecessor in New York was dismissed that he was given that post.
Mr. Martinez-Soler lost all credibility among his peers long before the events to which you refer. His continued success under the Socialist government, despite repeated failure, earned him the nickname "rug of the regime."
You also repeat a suggestion too common in the United States news media, of Franco-era "anti-democratic practices" in Spain's political life. Franco died more than 20 years ago. Since then there have been peaceful, democratic elections for the national government.
The Franco legacy long ago gave way to Spain's more pressing concerns, like European Union membership, fiscal responsibility, education and double-digit unemployment.
 
NURIA HERNANDEZ -MORA
MATTHEW KINEEN
Madison, Wis., July 18, 1996

HEADLINE: Olympics Stung By Technology's False Starts

BYLINE: By JERRY SCHWARTZ 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 21

 BODY:
Atlanta's Olympic organizers, who had promised the most technologically sophisticated Games ever, were scrambling today to repair their most basic information systems.
Two days into competition, the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games was still unable to feed competition results to its own Internet site or to news agencies, preventing newspapers, radio and television from publishing and broadcasting up-to-date results. 
 The committee's much-promoted internal information system, "Info 96," was missing large blocks of data, including any warnings about the continuing troubles in the Olympic transportation systems.
Though they did not specify the problems, officials said most of the trouble occurred in computer networks developed by I.B.M., which had invested $80 million to be a worldwide Olympic sponsor and the lead "technology integrator" of this year's Games. I.B.M. also has agreements with the International Olympic Committee to be the lead technology sponsor for the 1998 Winter Games in Nagano, Japan, and the 2000 Summer Games in Sydney, Australia.
"These are start-up problems," Jeff Cross, a spokesman for I.B.M., said. "This is the largest sporting event in the world -- equivalent to a NASA space shot or two Super Bowls a day for 17 days. There are some legitimate start-up problems that people are working 24 hours a day to address."
Most of the technology problems seemed to be computer-related, but perhaps the most public failure was a 12-minute blackout at the Georgia Dome during Saturday night's first appearance by the American basketball "Dream Team." The Olympic committee said the problem was caused by a technician who pulled the wrong switch.
Olympic visitors also reported problems with telephone lines and cellular phones. Customers said that phone lines promised at Olympic venues were not always installed on time. Cellular service was spotty.
Robert R. Neal, director of technology for the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, said the committee's principal difficulty was getting results from the 29 competition venues to I.B.M. mainframe computers. "We are looking at why the distribution is not 100 percent accurate," Mr. Neal said.
Even some results that were reported turned out to be inaccurate. One water polo score was reported in the Info 96 system as 12 to 7, but the individual goals listed in the same system added up to a score of 11 to 8.
Analysts said the computer difficulties could be a blow to I.B.M.'s plan to position itself as a major integrator of technology systems.
"It's an amazingly ambitious goal to provide all of this information in real time to the whole world," said Roger B. McNamee, principal of Integral Capital Partners, a technology management and investment firm in Menlo Park, Calif. "That said, dropping your shorts in front of the entire world is significantly more embarassing than doing it privately."
Andrew B. Whinston, professor of economics and computer science at the University of Texas, said the failure might complicate I.B.M.'s efforts to sell its Lotus Notes software, the backbone of the Atlanta results system, as an Internet tool and internal corporate data-base system.
"It's an extreme disaster for I.B.M. because they've been touting Lotus Notes as a solution for system integration and integration with the World Wide Web," he said. "They spent $20 million to $30 million in advertising and it has kind of exploded in their face. They've completely undone their arguments about Lotus Notes' abilities to interface with the outside world."
Late today, Olympic technology officials were organizing a manual results system that the ancient Greeks could appreciate. Results are to be transmitted by facsimile machines from outlying venues to a central office and distributed by runners.
American and international news agencies, which had been promised a sophisticated electronic results system fed directly from Olympic computers, said the system had failed. The agencies said they were forced to assign employees to watch the competitions on television and then type results into their systems.
"It is disappointing to know that what was billed as a state-of-the-art results service can't even produce bare scores in some cases," said Terry Taylor, the sports editor for The Associated Press.
The failure in the results system also led to a failure of the Olympic Internet site and a domino-effect failure of other Olympic World Wide Web pages dependent on the Atlanta committee for official results.
Olympic visitors also reported some problems with telephone lines and cellular phones. Customers said that phone lines promised at Olympic venues were not always installed on time. Cellular service was spotty.
The BellSouth Corporation, another Olympic sponsor, had said it would build a cellular phone system capable of handling all Olympic traffic. Still, some spectators at the opening ceremonies said they were not able to make or receive calls.
"The system is capable of handling 800 percent of normal capacity," a BellSouth spokeswoman said. "So far, we are only running at 200 percent of normal. If several hundred customers are near one cell site, it will be busy."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 24, 1996, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Monday about technical difficulties at the Olympic Games misstated the nature of the computer-related problems in reporting results of the competitions. They did not involve I.B.M.'s Lotus Notes software. The company says it is investigating the cause of the problems.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Invitation To Murder

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Six months after Pan Am 103 and all aboard were blown up over Scotland in 1988, a commission appointed by President Reagan came to a specific central conclusion about defeating international terrorism and presented it in the first paragraph of its report:
"National will and the moral courage to exercise it are the ultimate means for defeating terrorism. The President's Commission on Aviation Security and Terrorism recommends a more vigorous U.S. policy that not only pursues and punishes terrorists but also makes state sponsors of terrorism pay a price for their actions." 
 Now we watch or brood, mourning, knowing that we or those we love could have been on that sickeningly brief flight of T.W.A. 800, and died over Long Island -- if we were lucky enough to be dead before we hit the water. We do not know whether the 230 aboard went down murdered, as intelligence agencies tell the White House they believe, or through unprecedented accident. But we do know that whatever the truth, we ourselves will continue to be prey, meat for predators killing in the sky, a skyscraper in downtown New York, a community center in Buenos Aires or U.S. military housing in Saudi Arabia.
So this should be the moment to remember not only what the commission said, but that its point has never been fulfilled by the U.S. or its allies in the eight years and two Presidencies since then.
Nobody has been arrested for the slaughter of Pan Am 103, though the U.S. claims to know the names and addresses of Libyans it says planted the bomb.
The nasty fop who runs Libya still turns up at meetings of Arab leaders and still builds the world's biggest underground chemical weapons plant. Syria, the country that has the world's greatest collection of known terrorist camps, is honored by a visit of President Clinton. The only price its dictator has had to pay is to listen to hours of diplomatic wheedling from the American Secretary of State. We know the countries where the bombers of the World Trade Center were trained and financed, but not one has felt American retaliation.
And when we turn to our allies for help in containing Iran, terrorism's bank and quartermaster, they tell us we are interfering with their commercial interests.
For its sponsors and hosts, terrorism is the cheapest effective method of warfare. It can make a political giant out of an economic dwarf, force major countries to shift policies or to buckle and promote a local dictator into a world figure. But the "national will and moral courage" to fight it does not come cheap. In case there was any doubt, the commission, headed by Ann McLaughlin, spelled out what it would mean.
"While a law enforcement approach must always be a part of our response to terrorism, this commission finds unacceptable the idea of holding ourselves in all cases to a criminal standard of proof before we act. The U.S. must be ready to view some terrorist attacks as a matter of national security and indeed in some cases should be prepared to treat the act for what it is, an act of aggression against the U.S. A swift response could be directed against the terrorist group responsible and/or its state sponsor.
"The Commission recommends planning, training and equipping for direct pre-emptive or retaliatory action against known terrorist hideouts in countries that sanction them."
Since Pan Am, some improvements in airport security have been made but not the most important -- shifting responsibility to the government from the airlines who have to feed safety into profit-and-loss calculations. In any case, airport security without retaliation and punishment for terrorists and the countries that give them help and safe haven is like a criminal justice system without police, courts or jails -- an invitation to murder.
Every time there is a terrorist slaughter the West acts as if it was something new, or unrelated to those that came before or will follow. No price list exists for terrorists and sponsors, no action plan -- and none will come out of yet another "antiterrorism" conference of chickens and foxes.
Some day the democracies that defeated Communism and Fascism may have the national will and courage to confront terrorism where it is planted and nurtured. Until then we will remain prey, marching obediently to our assigned seat and role.

HEADLINE: Dole's California Hurdle

BYLINE: By Dan Schnur; Dan Schnur, a visiting instructor in politics at the University of California at Berkeley, served as communications director for Gov. Pete Wilson of California from 1991 through 1994.

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
At the outset of the 1988 Presidential campaign, the Republican strategist Lee Atwater regularly pointed to California as his party's trump card. He knew George Bush could win a national election without the state's truckload of electoral votes, but recognized that for the Democrats it would be almost impossible. "They need it," he said. "So I want it."
Today, Lee Atwater is gone, and Bob Dole's troubles have his advisers pointing fingers and his allies heading for the tall grass. He is 27 points behind President Clinton in California, according to the latest Los Angeles Times poll. 
 To Republican operatives trapped inside the Beltway, the cultural distance from California may seem insurmountable. They see the millions of dollars needed to win this prize as a resource that could be better deployed in other battleground states. But such thinking represents the parochialism and risk aversion that cost the Republicans the White House in 1992. The Bush campaign folded its tent in California months before the election, effectively deserting Republican candidates across the state.
Californians' first prolonged exposure to Mr. Dole's campaign will come next month, at the Republican National Convention in San Diego. While the national television networks have substantially reduced their planned coverage, their California affiliates will go all out. Mr. Dole will likely be more visible in California that week than at any other point through the fall.
California's economy has just finished replacing the half-million jobs it lost in the recession of the early 1990's, and the memories of that experience remain fresh. Bill Clinton has done his best to feel California's pain. As President, he has visited the state 25 times, more often than Ronald Reagan did in his first term.
For Mr. Dole to compete effectively here, he must ignore the myth that candidates score points by bonding with the earring-and-Armani crowd in the Democratic enclaves of West Los Angeles and San Francisco. The voters he should speak to are farming in the Central Valley and struggling to meet house payments in Riverside and San Bernardino. They run small businesses in the high-tech environs of Silicon Valley and San Diego and raise families in the conservative bastions of Orange County and the North Coast.
Bob Dole doesn't need to turn up on "Melrose Place" to reach these voters. He needs to convince them that he understands the hardships they've endured and that he has an agenda to help make their lives better.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines on Concerns About Rates and Stock Prices

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Falling stock prices in the United States and speculation that Japanese interest rates were headed higher pushed the dollar down against the Japanese yen and the German mark yesterday, currency traders said.
The dollar received a brief bit of encouragement overnight on remarks by the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer. He told the business daily Handelsblatt that he saw no reason the dollar should not return to its recent strength. The dollar was as high as $1.5488 marks in May. 
 Mr. Tietmeyer encouraged speculation on lower German interest rates by saying the Bundesbank would continue to check regularly whether monetary conditions would allow it to lower interest rates "a little."
News that the growth rate of the German money supply had fallen below 10 percent also encouraged talk that monetary policy might be eased at the Bundesbank's meeting on Thursday, the last before a monthlong summer recess.
But the dollar later reversed gains as stock market jitters reappeared in New York. The Dow Jones industrial ended the day with a loss of 35.88 points.
"People are looking at the stock market today and saying 'I can't buy dollars,' " said Gabriel Grippo, chief dealer at Credit Agricole.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.4850 German marks, down from 1.4865 marks on Friday. The dollar was also quoted at 107.44 Japanese yen, down from 107.95 yen. The British pound rose to $1.5505 from $1.5455.
Against the yen, the dollar gave ground on expectations that Japanese interest rates were headed higher and on bearishness linked to last week's news of a 13.2 percent widening in the United States trade gap for May.
Analysts expect that further deterioration in the trade deficit in the second half of 1996 will release a torrent of excess dollars into the currency market as Americans' demand for imports outstrips demand for American exports abroad.
"You have a turning trade picture," said Robert Fullem, assistant vice president at NatWest Bank P.L.C. "One that was looking very rosy is now looking fairly bleak."
Trading today is likely to be influenced by the release of the Bank of Japan's quarterly economic outlook.

HEADLINE: Courtship of U.S. Talent for Export

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE C. R. WHITE 

 BODY:
Even at its most virulent, the presumption that American culture -- with its movies, McDonald's and military might -- would dominate the rest of the world never pointed an accusatory finger at fashion. It has been the lot of American designers to be considered also-rans behind the chic French, the intellectual Japanese and those great apparel industrialists, the Italians.
It is Americans, however, who have now found themselves the favored consorts in a lusty international courtship for talent. Some of America's most gifted players, identified in the mid-1980's as its fashion heirs apparent, have entered contracts with European or Asian manufacturers to assist in the development of collections. 
 This demand, along with the difficulties that designers now face in securing investors to finance their businesses, has given rise to a new breed of American designers: those who are sculpturing careers from consultancies.
European designers have a long and lofty history of consulting. Gianni Versace, Giorgio Armani, Claude Montana and Romeo Gigli have all been consultants.
Until the late 1980's, designers like Anna Sui, Michael Kors, Todd Oldham, Marc Jacobs, Randolph Duke and Rebecca Moses were content to turn out one central collection under his or her own name. But the economic downturns of the last decade and changing buying patterns have slowed the speed with which high-end companies can expand. Designers are now more willing to strike alliances with large concerns eager for input from the outside.
Interest in doing business this way rather than in investing millions of dollars in a designer's company is coming from manufacturers as well as retailers, both here and abroad.
Forced into the consultancy arena, designers are finding they rather like it. Selling a piece of one's business to an investor is one thing, but finding an investor who is compatible with one's vision and temperament is another.
"The whole concept of a cash cow, a backer, is obsolete," said Mr. Oldham, who is in the midst of a three-year consulting deal with Escada, the giant German company. "You would have better luck finding a dodo bird. It is and was a struggle, but every time I met with a potential backer, I could feel my allergies coming up."
When Onward Kashiyama, a Japanese company that in the last two decades has developed several licenses with European designers, wanted its own global brand, ICB, it turned to an American, Mr. Kors. He is the consulting designer for the collection, introduced in 1993.
"Worldwide, there's never been the interest in American fashion that there is today," Mr. Kors said. "The feeling 10 years ago was that the idea of a fast-paced life style was strictly an American problem."
In varied forms, sportswear dressing, an American invention, has recently infiltrated the style sensibility of countries as diverse as Japan, France and Nigeria. American sportswear ranges from Ralph Lauren's classic conservatism to hip-hop's on-the-edge street look.
"Because of CNN, MTV and the distribution of films, television and so on, different countries don't necessarily have distinct looks," said Ms. Sui, who consults on Cento X Cento, produced by Gilmar Spa, an Italian company. Gilmar also retained Mr. Jacobs as a consultant, for its Iceberg collection.
Three years ago, American designers, including well-known names like Calvin Klein, Donna Karan and Mr. Lauren, began staging runway collections in tents in Bryant Park, helping to raise the country's fashion profile around the world. Since then, hundreds of journalists and retailers have converged on the tents twice a year. The tents have also shone a spotlight on a new generation of designers -- in their 30's or early 40's.
When manufacturers look to American designers, they are invariably eyeing New York. All of these designers, though hailing from around the nation, were trained in New York, and New York is where they shaped their sensibility and -- with the exception of Ms. Moses, who now lives in Italy -- have their base.
"Living in a melting pot, it's very easy for me to go to Europe," Mr. Oldham said. "Certainly no place in the planet is like New York City. For total cross-culturalization and multi ethnicity, this is it."
The United States' predisposition to marketing has perhaps unwittingly aided the increased popularity of American designers.
"We have a very different approach to product," said Ms. Moses, who consults for Genny. "We don't make product just to exist, and this translates well. People now want an international appeal to their businesses. The style we were raised with is what's happening. I get calls all the time from people looking for English or American designers."
In choosing Ms. Sui and Mr. Jacobs as consultants for his collections, Paolo Gerani, a vice president of Gilmar, which is owned by the Gerani family, said that their American orientation was a decisive factor in their selection.
"The American designer right now is making a good interpretation of fashion today," he said. "Even Europe in many ways is looking to New York City as the center of energy."
Mr. Gerani has gone further in indicating his faith in American creativity, having introduced two licensed collections: Sui by Anna Sui and Marc Jacobs Look. But even though Mr. Gerani has said he is open to investing in these designers' companies in the future, he has stopped short of doing so.
In the 1980's, private investment money flowed into the coffers of companies like those owned by Ms. Moses and Mr. Duke, but the last 10 years have been joltingly difficult.
"The falloff of interest from backers tracks the retail situation," said Michael Mermey, a lawyer and business consultant specializing in fashion. "The young designers' only hope for survival is to create a critical mass of design projects so as to increase their visibility and to have positive cash flow."
Ms. Sui is following that path. In addition to her deal with Gilmar, she is developing a new beach-wear collection for spring 1997 for Domani, another Italian company. Capital can come in the form of cold cash or other resources like machinery and fabrics, she pointed out.
Robert Duffy, Mr. Jacobs's business partner, says consulting has been a life raft. Their company is also a consultant to Renown, which markets a collection in Asia designed by Mr. Jacobs, called Two: C.
It was through their consultations, encouraged by Mr. Versace, that Mr. Duffy and Mr. Jacobs were able to develop the Marc Jacobs Look line, which is produced by Gilmar and distributed in some Asian countries by Renown. "I know we could not have done it without consulting," Mr. Duffy said.
Barry Bryant, a senior director for equity research at Rodman & Renshaw, an investment firm, says that if sales continue to pick up, it will likely lead investors -- albeit more cautious ones -- back into the fashion business.
But indications are that designers themselves may prefer investors whom they have come to know through consulting. Mr. Oldham says he has had several casual conversations with Wolfgang Ley, the chairman of Escada, about investing in an Oldham franchise.
Designer-consultants could even give rise to a new breed of fashion broker, the designer's agent, Mr. Duke speculated.
Mr. Duke, who earlier this year became the design and creative director for Henri Bendel three days a week, has also done a collection for QVC and consults for Authentic Fitness and OAS, swimwear companies, after having ended an exclusive agreement with Anne Cole swimwear this spring.
"The emerging designers like me came along at a tenuous time," Mr. Duke said. "Little did we know we wouldn't be able to do it the way the mega-designers like Halston, Donna, Calvin and Ralph did in the 70's and 80's. There are changes at fashion's doorstep, and if designers are going to continue to evolve, we have to face them."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices End Day Lower

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Treasury market ended lower yesterday as investors worried that the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, might take a hawkish stance on inflation at his appearance today before Congress.
After Mr. Greenspan's appearance before a Senate committee on Thursday, Treasury prices rallied. The market seized on his comments that he expected economic growth to slow this year, which would forestall the need for higher interest rates. But Mr. Greenspan also indicated that the Fed might have to raise rates anyway, and it was this view that held sway in the market on Friday and yesterday. 
 "There's concern that Greenspan might change the tone of his Humphrey-Hawkins testimony to make it more clear that the Fed is willing to tighten if the economy does not slow soon -- with 'soon' meaning by Aug. 20," said Michael Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc.
Kevin Flanagan, first vice president and economist at Dean Witter Reynolds, said, "There's been talk that Greenspan was not happy with the market perception of his testimony and there's fear he might take a more hawkish stance."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 11/32, to 87 13/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 7 percent from 6.98 percent.
"Today's action was really a set-up for Greenspan's testimony on Tuesday at 2 o'clock," said Waldo Best, senior economist at BZW Government Securities Inc.
Mr. Greenspan heads to the House Banking subcommittee on banking and international monetary affairs for the second leg of his semiannual Humphrey-Hawkins testimony..
The Fed chairman's testimony comes as the market prepares to absorb a wave of new securities.
The Treasury will sell $18.75 billion in two-year notes today and plans to sell $12.5 billion in five-year notes tomorrow.
Mr. Greenspan's testimony comes at a delicate time, said Patrick Dimick, senior Treasury analyst with the CS First Boston Corporation.
"Do you think people will want to buy two-year notes when Greenspan will talk an hour after they are awarded?" Mr. Dimick said. "It's kind of a vulnerable position to be in."
At its regular weekly bill auction yesterday, The Treasury sold $27.0 billion in three- and six-month bills.
The bond market strengthened in morning trade on Monday but the bond market rally was capped when the stock market was able to contain its losses.
"Bonds started to turn lower when it became evident that the stock market wasn't going much lower today," Mr. Dimick said.
Dollar weakness also pressured the bond market, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Home Ownership At 15-Year High

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Home ownership in the United States has reached a 15-year-high of 65.4 percent as buyers take advantage of good times and relatively low mortage rates, the Clinton Administration said today.
The ownership rate rose three-tenths of a percent in the second quarter, reflecting about 700,000 new homeowners in that period. 
 The Administration said that the improvement followed successful efforts to reduce the United States deficit, which has helped to keep interest at relatively low levels recently.
President Clinton's economic adviser, Laura Tyson, said, "Lower deficits, lower mortgage rates and higher job growth are a good recipe for higher homeownership rates."
The highest ownership rate was 65.8 percent, in 1980.

HEADLINE: ATLANTA: DAY 4;
It's Business as Usual, And Nobody Is Happy

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, JULY 22

 BODY:
For a lot of Atlanta businesses, the Olympics coming to town held out the promise of hordes of customers and tons of new business. But from the downtown Underground entertainment complex to nearby restaurants and malls, it isn't turning out to be Christmas in July.
Instead, business during the first few days of the Games has been slow to spotty. Among the few to cash in so far have been the city's taxi drivers, who had expected to be idled by the offer of free public transportation and shuttle buses, but have seen business pick up because of glitches and overcrowding on the city's public transportation system. 
 It has been an especially rude awakening for the operators of Underground, who decided early on to charge a $5 admission fee to the crowds of people they thought would be visiting its shops and restaurants. The fee, they said, would help not only to provide them an extra buck or so of profit, but also help pay for security.
But when people stayed away in droves on Friday, they lowered the admission price to $3 on Saturday. And when there were still so few people coming that Barbara Anderson, an Underground vendor, said "you could fire cannon down the main corridor without hitting anyone," Underground management dropped the admission on Sunday.
"We thought we were a value-added location with free entertainment and everything, but it turns out that that's not a big deal because other places, like the Centennial Olympic Park, are value-added too with entertainment and they are free of charge," said Martin D. Fortes, the vice president and general manager of the complex.
Anderson, who owns three pushcarts among the hundreds that line the cool brick corridors of the Underground complex, calls the original decision to charge admission "a bad management move." Since it was lifted, she said her business has picked up to what it normally is during July. But that is a far cry from what she and others had expected from the Games.
Rafih Benjelloun, who is a volunteer envoy for the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, as well as chairman of the Atlanta Restaurant Marketing Association, is disappointed to the point of anger.
With business at his Imperial Fez Restaurant a quarter of what it usually is this time of year, Benjelloun says a lot of the city's restaurants are suffering because large corporations are relying on caterers to put on sumptuous receptions in tented pavilions, rather than booking local restaurants. But he also suspects that the attendance at the games has fallen way below the anticipated 3 million spectators.
"Right now we have more advanced reservations for Christmas and New Year's than we do for the Olympics," Benjelloun said, "and that's the case with most of the members of the association who had been expecting a lot of business."
He said the International Olympic Committee and the Atlanta committee ought "to tell people 'Please feel free to explore the town.' "
To be sure, Benjelloun and others worried that the experience of Los Angeles, Lillehammer and Barcelona suggested that they Olympics might not be quite the bonanza many envisioned, but the current situation was worse than they feared.
In some ways the city has been victimized by its own public relations, suggested Sam Massell, president of the Buckhead Coalition, a local business group.
During the months leading to the Games, business leaders and others were admonishing residents about the expected crowds, discouraging driving in town and encouraging people to take vacations and even leave town during the Games, making many apprehensive.
Last weekend Massell spent time on local radio trying to undo some of this.
A member of the Atlanta committee, Massell conceded that some of this was probably exaggerated by "design," as part of "a marketing strategy" to boost the Games.
One of the few groups showing some signs of optimism are the city's cab drivers who, in the buildup to the games, felt left out of the transportation mix with all the emphasis on pedestrian malls, closed streets, limited numbers of taxi stands, shuttle buses and free public transportation.
With problems on the public transportation network, Chukwura Chambers, a driver stationed outside of the Westin Hotel sidled up to a party of five, who were debating whether to take mass transit.
He reminded them of the reports of crowding and delays, gave them an estimate of the cost of the trip -- and won a fare.
"He's a good salesman," said one of the party, Edwin Uchtman of St. Louis, explaining why he decided to take the cab.
Such adjustments are coming hard to many here who thought that everything would pretty much sell itself in Atlanta this summer. After weak attendance over the weekend, promoters of concerts at the downtown Rialto Center for the Performing Arts today started previewing acts in free street performances, and handing out advertising fliers in a downtown office plaza.
"There are so many messages out there, so many options," said Don Payne, the promoter for a concert by the South African band Inthsholo, "that we had to turn salesman and bring it to the street.
"There was this expectation that the streets would be shoulder-to-shoulder people, and it hasn't worked out that way."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Business at Atlanta's Underground entertainment complex, and elsewhere in the city, hasn't been as brisk as expected during the Olympics. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Potential Running Mates: Down to About a Dozen

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Bob Dole has narrowed his list of potential running mates to about a dozen names, a group dominated by governors, officials familiar with the process said today.
The officials, speaking on the condition that they not be identified, emphasized that Mr. Dole was far along in the selection process and that every person on the list is a serious contender. Each of these candidates has now received detailed questionnaires -- seeking information on medical, financial and biographical background -- and at least two have already been interviewed by Roderick DeArment, a lawyer on the search team. 
 Govs. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin and Jim Edgar of Illinois were interviewed late last week by Mr. DeArment, the officials said. Two other Midwest Governors, John Engler of Michigan and George V. Voinovich of Ohio, were also being interviewed, the officials said, adding that those sessions were delayed because of Mr. Dole's visits to Ohio and Michigan late last week and back to Michigan and Kansas today.
Three others who have been sent questionnaires by Mr. Dole's search team are Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania; former Gov. Carroll Campbell of South Carolina and Dan Lungren, the California Attorney General.
"The people being interviewed are serious candidates," said one of the officials. "The universe has been circled. Now it's a question of being winnowed down."
Mr. Edgar and Mr. Ridge stand out from the other governors mentioned because of their support for abortion rights. But Mr. Dole said earlier this month that he could accept a running mate who backed abortion rights. The officials said the remainder of the list included some governors, but would not say whether Gov. Christie Todd Whitman of New Jersey was among them. One official said that "they are people you would know" and no particular surprises.
Dole campaign officials said that the plan now -- assuming that the name of the candidate does not leak out sooner -- is for Mr. Dole to announce his choice on the Friday before the party's national convention, which opens in San Diego on Aug. 12. One campaign official said Mr. Dole is considering announcing his choice of running mate in his hometown of Russell, Kan.
Mr. Dole returned to Russell today, as he often does on his special occasions, to celebrate his 73d birthday. It was a day of celebration that started here in the capital, where Mr. Dole brought gifts to a "reverse birthday party" at a community center for senior citizens before flying to Michigan and on to Kansas.
Campaign officials said Mr. Dole was leaving this stage of the search for a running mate to his staff, and that the candidate himself would probably only interview his final three choices.
The officials said it was not beyond the realm of possibility that, at the last minute, Mr. Dole would add a name or two to the list, including Colin L. Powell, although they say they are virtually certain that the retired general would not accept an offer.
But those familiar with the process also cited once talked-about candidates who are not on the list. They include Gov. Pete Wilson of California; James A. Baker 3d, a former Secretary of State; and Dick Cheney, a former Defense Secretary. Officials said Mr. Cheney was disqualified because of his history of heart problems.
As campaign officials ground through the details of the search process, Mr. Dole and his wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole, who turns 60 next Monday, arrived at the community center with three dozen gifts, including toaster ovens, blenders and a lamp, all of which had been requested by the recipients, many of whom the Doles have known during their decade-long association with the center, Sarah's Circle.
Mr. Dole, who retired, last month after 35 years in Congress to devote himself full time to running for President, also presented Sarah's Circle, which provides housing and community programs to low-income senior citizens, with his first month's pension check -- for $6,650. The former Senator could receive a pension as high as $107,000 a year and has said he would donate it to different charities. This was his first presentation.
Mr. Dole said that his wife had given him a CD player that played seven disks "so I can listen to my Johnny Mathis records."
Asked how it felt to be 73, Mr. Dole told reporters at Sarah's Circle, "You always feel a little older in the morning. By noon I'll feel about 55."
Mr. and Mrs. Dole have been involved with Sarah's Circle, located in an ethnically mixed neighborhood close to downtown Washington, since they hosted a Thanksgiving dinner there in 1986. Today, Mr. Dole's daughter, Robin, accompanied them and they brought their dog, Leader, as well.
With Mr. Dole's age a potential liability to his candidacy -- he would be the oldest person elected to a first term as President -- the Dole campaign confronted the inevitable head on.
"I don't think age is a negative for us," said Nelson Warfield, Mr. Dole's press secretary, explaining the backdrop of senior citizens and noting that Mr. Dole's doctors say he is in excellent health. "Health answers age, and Bob Dole has been completely forthcoming with his medical records," Mr. Warfield said. "Bob Dole has released his comprehensive medical history going back to the 1940's, while Bill Clinton has released only summaries."
The couple continued their birthday celebration throughout the day, flying on a campaign plane strewn with blue, red and yellow streamers, party hats and noisemakers.
They left Washington for Dearborn, Mich., where Mr. Dole participated in an economic forum with Govs. Engler, Voinovich and Thompson, each of whom boasted of what they had done for their local economies, as if auditioning for Mr. Dole.
The Doles then continued their celebration in Russell, where they joined in an old-fashioned ice cream social, complete with pony rides.
Arriving in Russell this evening, Mr. Dole told a crowd of about 300 people in a local park: "My first call this morning was from Senator Strom Thurmond. He's 94. He thinks I'm a little young to be running for President, and he wants to be my running mate."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bob Dole turned 73 yesterday, and he attended a celebration in Russell, Kan. At left is Russell T. Townsley, Mr. Dole's longtime friend. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Stocks Continue Their Decline, Heightening Investor Concern

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
The relief investors felt last week was short-lived as stocks declined yesterday for the second consecutive trading session, heightening concerns that the worst may not be over.
The latest losses, among big and small stocks alike, continued to erase many of the gains that took place toward the end of last week and suggested no end in sight to the market's recent volatility. 
 Stocks of small companies, especially in technology, were hardest hit. The Nasdaq composite index, which consists of many of these companies, tumbled 16.29 points, or 1.5 percent. While the index closed at 1,081.39, well above its lows of last week, it remains down almost 14 percent from its high in early June.
The selling also spread to blue chip stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average, for example, shed 35.88 points, or about seven-tenths of a percent, to 5,390.94. The index fell by more than 50 points twice during the day.
Investors seemed particularly concerned about the possibility that individuals, who have been one of the primary forces behind the surge in stock prices over the last five years, had lost their enormous appetite for mutual funds.
"If you look at how the market has behaved this year, especially small-cap or aggressive growth stocks, it's been very much of a liquidity-driven bull market," said William B. Keithler, a portfolio manager for Berger Associates in Denver. The recent fall-off in the amount of money individuals have been pouring into stock funds "has people spooked," he said.
Without the rush of money into stock funds like aggressive growth funds, which have tended to be big buyers of technology and small-company stocks, investors are paying more attention to earnings and stock prices and are not finding much to like. They continue to be anxious over the outlook for corporate profits, especially in technology, which is suffering from a combination of summer doldrums and a recent spate of disappointing announcements by leading technology companies like Hewlett-Packard and Motorola. While stock prices have fallen, many stocks continue to trade at expensive levels.
"Nasdaq is under a lot of pressure," said David Shulman, chief equity strategist for Salomon Brothers. "Most folks are not done selling."
While many market analysts contend it is too early to tell whether individuals are abandoning the market in any meaningful way, recent reports suggesting the clamoring for stocks is dying have increased the fear that good times may be over. Liquidity Trim Tabs, a newsletter in Santa Rosa, Calif., is estimating that investors pulled out about $2 billion in stock funds from Tuesday through Thursday last week.
Anecdotal evidence from some of the major fund companies, however, suggests that many investors, encouraged by the short rally last week, were putting money into mutual funds by the end of the week. The Montgomery Funds in San Francisco, for example, said there were more purchases than redemptions by Friday. At T. Rowe Price in Baltimore, investors began to put money into funds Thursday and Friday, and the complex ended the week with a "very modest net outflow," according to Steven E. Norwitz, a spokesman. The Vanguard Group ended the week with positive net inflows.
And some analysts argued there was little evidence individuals were bailing out. "I think it is very premature and presumptuous to assume that individuals have stopped their love affair with stocks," said Alfred Goldman, chief strategist for A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. "Despite the stealth bear market in 1994, individuals continued to be buyers."
Mr. Shulman of Salomon agreed. "One week does not make a trend," he said. While mutual fund flows will slow in the second half of the year, compared to a strong first quarter, he predicted they would still represent the best second half in history.
But even if individuals are eager to put their money into mutual funds, investors are still likely to have a hang-dog expression for the remainder of the summer. Any slowdown in the economy is likely to crimp earnings, said Arthur A. Micheletti, the chief investment strategist for Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser in San Mateo, Calif.
Investors are also concerned that the Federal Reserve will eventually raise interest rates, despite their initial enthusiasm last week over the remarks of Alan Greenspan, the chairman. "I think we'll go through this for the next several months: will they or won't they?" said Mr. Micheletti, who predicted continuing volatility.
The forecast for the technology sector, which had led much of the rally earlier in the year, is not much sunnier. Market analysts say it is likely to remain in its slump until well after Labor Day.
"I think we're seeing the summer correction that we have not seen for two years," said Michael Carmen, the manager of the Montgomery Small Cap Opportunities Fund, who noted that the traditional seasonal slowdown seemed even worse this year compared with last year because of the introduction of Windows 95, which helped technology stocks during last year's dog days.
And some managers have been reluctant to start buying just yet. "It hasn't been as easy to pick off bargains as you might think or might like," Mr. Keithler of Berger Associates said. Unable to find stocks at good valuations, he has allowed cash in his fund to rise, he said.
Even Mr. Carmen, who described himself as a "net buyer of good stocks," agreed that some stocks continued to be too expensive for his tastes. But while he said he thought that the correction in small stocks was not yet over, he has been finding some stocks to buy. "It lets you coil the spring for the bounce back," he said.
The market decline hurt a broad variety of stocks, including those in companies reporting strong earnings. Declining stocks outnumbered advancing stocks by 1,770 to 649 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Sears, Roebuck, which had exceeded analysts' earnings estimates when it reported its results last Thursday, fell 1 5/8 yesterday to 42 1/2. Mobil, which announced higher earnings yesterday, also fell 3/8, to 114 3/4.
Among the technology stocks battered yesterday was Microsoft, despite talk on Wall Street that the software giant would announce solid profits. The stock fell 1 1/4 to close at 119 3/4 before the company reported earnings of 87 cents a share, exceeding Wall Street estimates. Other technology stocks that suffered were Iomega, one of the year's technology high fliers, which fell 2 5/8 to close at 19 7/8, and Cisco Systems, which fell 1 3/8, to 50 5/8.

HEADLINE: Bankers Trust to Pay $210 Million for Wolfensohn

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
The Bankers Trust New York Corporation disclosed today that it would pay about $210 million in cash and stock to acquire Wolfensohn & Company. The price was higher than analysts had speculated.
Bankers Trust announced the acquisition of the New York-based investment bank in May, hoping to strengthen the bank's investment banking business and profit from Wolfensohn's ties to some of the best known companies in the world. The purchase price was not disclosed then, and analysts estimated Bankers Trust would pay roughly $150 million. 
 The higher-than-expected purchase price shows how much the bank was willing to pay for contacts in the world of corporate mergers developed by Wolfensohn's partners, who include the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, Paul A. Volcker.
Bankers Trust is buying a firm with 10 partners and 55 bankers that worked on $37.4 billion in acquisitions last year.
Bankers Trust is giving Wolfensohn's partners a powerful voice in the entire bank, making Mr. Volcker a director and putting three other partners on its operating committee.
All but $7 million of the purchase price consists of 2.88 million shares of Bankers Trust common stock, valued at $202.89 million, which will go to the firm's partners, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The firm's partners include Mr. Volcker, Raymond Golden, Glen Lewy and James Wolfensohn, who left the firm last year to become president of the World Bank.
Bankers Trust also said in a separate statement that the acquisition had won Federal Reserve approval.

HEADLINE: Suburbia Can't Kick the Nozzle;
As Gas Guzzling Becomes a Way of Life, Oil Imports Soar

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

DATELINE: CLIFTON PARK, N.Y.

 BODY:
Like most residents of this fast-growing bedroom community 20 miles north of Albany, Janet Mulvey cannot do anything away from home without first hopping into one of the cars in her driveway.
To deliver her son to preschool, to buy new window shades or pick up the dry cleaning -- not to mention doing her job as a roving children's speech therapist for adjacent Schenectady County -- Ms. Mulvey has to slide behind the wheel of her 1991 Toyota Landcruiser and negotiate the winding roads out of her housing development past all the other four- and five-bedroom homes. And her husband, Martin, who sells extended warranty programs to car dealers, burns up even more miles in his 1994 Toyota Camry. Both carry cellular phones and laptop computers wherever they go, turning their vehicles into instant mobile offices. 
 "There's no way to do anything about it," Ms. Mulvey said of the 1,200-plus miles a week the couple often put in behind the wheel. A car is, simply, "independence," she said, and maneuvering her huge, four-wheel-drive vehicle from mall to mall and drive-through window to drive-through window is "my village."
This is America, two decades after the oil crises of the 1970's that left a suburbanized nation shell-shocked at its utter dependence on imported petroleum. According to figures released this month, the United States is more reliant on oil imports than at any time since 1977 -- and it is hard to find many people who seem to care.
Briefly this spring, a spike in gasoline prices reminded Americans of the potential costs of their suburban life style. And the bombing of a housing complex for American, British and French troops in Saudi Arabia last month brought home the vulnerability of the United States' foreign supplies.
But as the Mulveys and their neighbors in Clifton Park show, day-to-day worry about foreign oil supplies, and accompanying acts of conservation, have slid out of most Americans' consciousness, while the need for that oil is embedded even more deeply into their lives.
"The availability and the price of gasoline are no longer even on people's radar screens," said Cheryl Trench, executive vice present of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in Manhattan. "What people want is comfort, safety and the convenience of being able to cart the entire football team around town."
In 1973, the year of the Arab oil embargo that led to long lines at the pumps, the United States imported nearly 35 percent of its oil. It dropped that figure to 28 percent in 1982. But today, with the economy booming and shortages a fading memory, the country has reverted to its old ways. Daily oil consumption in the first half of this year has risen above 18 million barrels for the first time since 1979, and imports have surged to 8.3 million barrels, or 46.3 percent of the total, a near record.
Even so, with gasoline cheaper than it was in the 1950's after adjusting for inflation, Americans are embracing gas-guzzling vans, pickup trucks and utility vehicles with a vengeance.
And if the Mulveys are any indication of the national mood, it will take nothing short of another oil crisis to jog Americans out of their complacency.
"My job depends on travel to meetings," declared Mr. Mulvey, the general agent for Upstate New York for Automotive Professionals Inc., a company that supplies new-car dealers with vehicle-service agreements underwritten by the Travelers Insurance Companies. "It's not negotiable," he added matter-of-factly. "I have to be there." Mr. Mulvey calculated that he drove an average of 150 miles a day, and sometimes covered 500 miles.
Janet Mulvey is no less dogmatic. "I have to drive, no matter what it costs," she said in an interview in the office she has set up in the couple's huge four-bedroom house in the Olde Dater Farm Development that was carved a few years ago out of the countryside.
When she is on the job, Ms. Mulvey says, she always eats and drinks in her car. She buys gasoline only at Mobil stations because they have a wide assortment of snacks -- and clean restrooms. "There are no restrooms on this job; I rely on gas stations and fast-food restaurants," she says somewhat ruefully.
She says she drives about 40 miles a day when she is working; last week, she took maternity leave from her job to prepare for the birth of her second child next month.
Mrs. Mulvey said that even modest attempts to form school car pools broke down in her neighborhood over people's unwillingness to bend to the schedules of others. Asked if public transportation is available in her town, she replies, "Not that I know of." (In fact, there are commuter buses to Albany, but there is no local service within Clifton Park.)
But the people who live here did not come for the public transportation; they came for the housing. Where else could they afford such big houses, situated on half-acre and one-acre lots and crammed with all the energy-driven conveniences and comforts that the 1990's have to offer?
The Niagara Mohawk Power Company says that a growing number of new homes in the area it serves, including Clifton Park, have central air-conditioning and features like outdoor lighting, saunas, and Jacuzzis and swimming pools. Indeed, Clifton Park epitomizes the life style that America began embracing four decades ago, as interstate highways spread across the farm and woodlands that were carved into the suburbs and the more distant exurbs of the modern metropolis.
So no matter where they are going, the residents of Clifton Park have to drive. Many of the main streets lack sidewalks, and walking or biking along them them is a dangerous proposition with traffic zooming along at 50 or 60 miles an hour. As a result, parents must drive their children everywhere -- and often buy them cars as soon as they reach 16, the age at which they can take driving lessons.
"All my friends have cars," said Claire F. Tosti, 17, as she sat sipping cappuccino with her friend Brianne Kellog, also 17, at Persnickety's in the Village Shopping Center. "You can't even ride a bike to from one development to another." Ms. Tosti had picked up Ms. Kellog at her home in her Dodge Omni and driven to another mall for a movie before coming here. Driving, Miss Kellog added, "is the only way to see your friends.
With gasoline costing less than $1.50 a gallon in much of the country, fuel efficiency is usually low on the list of car shoppers' concerns. As they closed a deal at Clifton Park Dodgeworld recently to buy a Dodge Ram 1500 Laramie SLT Club Cab, a hulking pickup truck whose interior has the look and feel of a luxury car, Vern Huestis and his wife, Michele, were thinking mostly about power and carrying capacity, not energy independence. The sticker announced that the vehicle would get 11 miles a gallon in the city and 15 miles on the open highway, but the low ratings did not bother Mr. Huestis.
"I'm not worried about gas being shut off," he said, explaining that comfort and the ability to haul heavy gear for his job as a field-training leader for the Army National Guard, were his main considerations.
Likewise, his wife chose her Plymouth Voyager mini-van because it has the room to hold the dispensing machines and boxes of chewing gum that she hauls around as a service representative for the Ford Gum Machine Company.
"I'm self-employed," said Mrs. Huestis, who drives 200 to 300 miles a day, three days a week, sometimes going as far as Worcester, Mass., to call on her customers. "I have no choice but to drive something that has the space I need."
Such attitudes are music to the ears of David Reali, the general sales manager at Clifton Park Dodgeworld. "Today's customers pick their vehicles more for life style and work, rather than just for transportation," Mr. Reali said. "They need tremendous flexibility to carry computer equipment, golf balls, kids and adults. Mini-vans are my largest sellers."
But whereas Americans in the early 1980's pursued a course of almost fanatical energy conservation, in the 1990's even the experts tend to take a relaxed view of things. Ms. Trench of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, for example, says that the current situation "is certainly not a cause for alarm."
After all, Ms. Trench says, the oil industry, using a "panoply of new technologies," has shown how "stunningly responsive" it can be to shortages as they develop. "We don't need to fear dependence on imports," she says flatly. "It really is a different period, and a different market."
Similarly, Martin P. Meyers, associate director specializing in refined products at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Massachusetts, saw little need for worry about America's energy-consuming habits. Gasoline use is up less than 1 percent so far this year, he notes, even while the economy is humming along, and demographic trends -- more older people driving few miles -- suggest it will not increase sharply anytime soon.
And, he adds, "while there are more mini-vans on the road, even mini-vans are getting better mileage than they used to."
