HEADLINE: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- WEIGHT LIFTING;
The Adventures of Hercules Continue

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 22

 BODY:
Naim Suleymanoglu became the first weight lifter in history to win three gold medals, and he also set a world record, in the 141-pound competition today at the Summer Games.
Suleymanoglu, known to the world as Pocket Hercules, won in one of the most dramatic confrontations possible as he and his closest rival, Valerios Leonidis of Greece, traded three straight world-record lifts. 
 Not quite 5 feet tall, Suleymanoglu snatched 324 1/2 pounds and then raised 413 3/4 in the clean-and-jerk for a total of 738 1/4. Leonidis failed in his final attempt for the gold medal, but did set his own world record in the clean-and-jerk in his next-to-last lift.
When Suleymanoglu was in New York three months ago, he was asked who his biggest competition would be. He said, in two of the few words he used in English, "the Greek."
He was right about that. Leonidis matched him right up to the final attempt today in a competition that had the joint rocking.
The championship was held in the cavernous basement of the Georgia World Congress Center, an exhibition hall hard by the Georgia Dome. It had three distinct advantages -- it was air-conditioned, there was excellent rock music blasted over the sound system and it was underground, with no exposure to the tacky tents and trailers and the offensive food smells just outside near Centennial Park.
The two Greek weight lifters had a large cheering section, and they played to the crowd, particularly Yorgos Tzelilis, who alternately pounded his chest and waved his palms toward the heavens, asking for more cheers.
The first half of the competition was the snatch, in which the bar is raised from the floor to the overhead position in one motion. The lower-rated lifters risked hernias and falling bars first, and then the favorites took over.
Leonidis went first and lifted 308 pounds. At 4:45 P.M., Suleymanoglu strode to the floor and lifted 319 pounds. At 4:50 P.M., Leonidis came back and lifted 319. At 4:56 P.M., Suleymanoglu came back and tried 324 1/2 pounds but never got it above his waist and dropped it, almost daintily.
At 4:59 P.M., Leonidis could not raise 324 1/2 pounds but he was still ahead of Suleymanoglu because of his lower body weight, nearly a pound and a half less.
At 5 P.M., Suleymanoglu raised 324 1/2 pounds, held it and then dropped the bar before raising his two fists nearly shoulder high, an extravagant gesture for him. He had the lead halfway through.
The second half was the clean-and-jerk, which involves two motions, one to the shoulders and then overhead. Again, the bottom half of the draw went first.
At 5:45 P.M., Suleymanoglu, with little emotion or extra motion, lifted 396 pounds. At 5:48 P.M., Leonidis equaled him.
Then two announcements were made: Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, was present, and Suleymanoglu would try to raise 407 pounds, which would be a world record.
Suleymanoglu came out and promptly set the world record, then pointed to himself and made an economic wave to his Turkish followers, waving their flags on the the left side.
Leonidis came back and lifted 413 3/4 pounds for another world-record lift -- temporarily. Then Suleymanoglu tried the same weight. He faltered once, then locked the weight above his head. He dropped the weight, threw two punches in the air with chalk flying and strode off the floor. He was ahead again, but Leonidis still had the world record in the clean-and-jerk because of his lower weight.
Now Leonidis had one more try for the gold medal and the overall world record. At 5:58 P.M. he went for 418 pounds. He raised the weight no farther than his waist, but quickly let it drop. With one wave, he walked down the step and disappeared down the runway. "At the moment, I feel the most worthy person won," Leonidis said later.
Suleymanoglu said he believed the gold medal would depend "on the most numbers of misses. He missed twice and I missed once."
This is the third time the world has turned on the television and discovered Naim Suleymanoglu. He was born into the huge Turkish community in Bulgaria and came up through the Bulgarian youth programs. He was not allowed to participate in the 1984 Summer Games in Los Angeles because of the Soviet Union's reprisal boycott, and then the Bulgarians began a repressive drive against the Turks.
He resisted the impulse to defect until 1985, when he was forced to accept a Bulgarian name, Naum Shalamanov.
He won a few championships under his new name, but in December 1986 he slipped out the back during a meet in Melbourne, Australia. He and his family were reunited in Turkey, where he was almost immediately a celebrity.
Turkey paid $1 million to Bulgaria to facilitate Suleymanoglu's changing citizenship in 1988 in time for him to be eligible for the Summer Games. He beat all the Soviet bloc lifters, which he did in 1988 at Seoul, lifting 755 pounds, while two of Bulgaria's lifters were disqualified after testing positive for diuretics.
Suleymanoglu became a national hero in Turkey. He retired for a while, but came back with no political fury, and lifted 705 pounds for another gold medal at the Barcelona Games.
Now he has accumulated 46 world records and 232 gold medals, including three Olympic championships.
"This is a hobby of mine, and I love it," he said. "But it is also true that the people of Turkey want me to win, so I do it for them."
Today he was asked if he was the greatest lifter in history, and he said people would have to make that judgment for themselves.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. WILL DELAY MONEY TO RUSSIA OVER TAX PROBLEM

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Citing the Yeltsin Government's problems with tax collection, the International Monetary Fund said today that it would delay its $330 million payment to Russia this month for the first time.
When Russia was granted a $10.2 billion three-year loan in February, the Fund set particularly stringent conditions, including monthly reviews of Russia's economic status. 
 The problem came to light several days after Russian officials said they would ask for an easing of some terms of the loan. It emerged less than three weeks after President Boris N. Yeltsin won re-election over a resurgent Communist Party. His victory was attributed in part to his widespread spending promises during the campaign that seemed to undermine his commitment to bring the nation's budget deficit and inflation under control.
American and I.M.F. officials said Russian expenditures had remained more or less on target despite Mr. Yeltsin's spending promises, and the auditors agreed to the monthly disbursements throughout the presidential race this spring.
But they said cash receipts from taxes were running well below projections, in part because some companies had refused to pay taxes until they were sure the Communists would not win the election.
Officials said that they were still struggling to get a clear sense of the scale of the problem, and that they were working with the Russians on plans to improve collection and possibly to levy new taxes to raise revenues quickly.
Withholding the loan disbursement should not have any direct impact on Russia's economy. But if the problem is not resolved next month, when a more intensive review of Russia's performance is scheduled, it could hamper the program of support for Russia's bumpy transition to capitalism. Even this one-month delay could unnerve foreign investors, who had earlier been scared off by the prospect of a Communist victory.
The officials said that they expected Russia to act swiftly to rectify the problem, and that the disbursement could be made within weeks.
"What we will most likely have is a delay, then a catch-up," said Stanley Fischer, the I.M.F.'s deputy managing director, who met with Russian officials in Moscow last week. "We don't think we will miss a disbursement if things go according to plan."
Officials of the United States and of the fund said that the tax difficulties should not be a harbinger of any broader troubles, and that despite the delay in the disbursement, there had been progress by Mr. Yeltsin's Government in stabilizing the economy.
"They've brought inflation down more than we expected," Mr. Fischer said. "They've kept the ruble stable despite the election. If they've done all that while not quite meeting all our numbers, our numbers might have been a little tougher than they needed to be."
Russia has prided itself on meeting all of the fund's strict requirements, both for the current loan and for a $6.4 billion loan that was disbursed starting in the spring of 1995.
But the review for July, which was conducted in Moscow over the last week, ended with the fund's team saying it could not complete its work because it could not get all the information it needed. Without a completed review, the monthly payment cannot be released.
The Interfax news agency reported today that tax revenues in the first half of the year were 12 percent below expectations. It was unclear whether the figure included tax "offsets" by which some companies are receiving credit for paying bills owed by the Government to other companies in the form of products and materials. Offsets have accounted for a substantial part of the tax revenues, but because they cannot be spent, they do not have as much value as cash receipts.
Although American and fund officials gave a hopeful interpretation today to the need for a delay, some of the same officials have acknowledged being concerned in recent months as Mr. Yeltsin has stretched his economic resources seemingly to their limit. Last month Mr. Yeltsin ordered the Central Bank to transfer $1 billion to the federal budget to help pay for his campaign pledges, although the Central Bank later tightened credit to offset the inflationary consequences of the move.
The Yeltsin Government, having won re-election, has also begun trying to woo back foreign investors. Today Moscow agreed to give foreign investors wider access to the market for government bonds.
The tax system in Russia has always been one of the nation's biggest problems. Not only are there problems with collection, but also frequent changes in the tax code and the often arbitrary way it is enforced have discouraged many foreign companies from establishing operations in Russia.

HEADLINE: 3 Top Pataki Aides Were Paid by Inaugural Fund

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 22

 BODY:
Three top advisers to Gov. George E. Pataki said today that they had each received payments of at least $20,000 from a fund created from private donations to finance Mr. Pataki's inauguration and transition.
The advisers are Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's director of communications; Michael C. Finnegan, the Governor's counsel, and John O'Mara, the chairman of the State Public Service Commission. They said the money was for the work they did helping Mr. Pataki set up a new administration immediately after he defeated Mario M. Cuomo in November 1994. 
 Today's disclosures were among the clearest accountings yet of how the secret inaugural fund, which has been the subject of an Assembly investigation and a court battle, spent its money. Democrats have estimated that the fund raised $1.4 million, but Mr. Pataki's aides say the figure is closer to $1 million.
Ms. Mucha said she received between $20,000 and $30,000. Mr. O'Mara said he received $25,000 and Mr. Finnegan said he got about $45,000.
Financial disclosure forms filed with the State Ethics Commission also showed that at least six other members of the Pataki administration had been paid salaries or reimbursed for personal expenses by the transition and inaugural fund, though it was unclear how much they had received.
Democrats and government watchdog groups questioned the payments today, saying that the state's top policy makers should not have taken money from a fund financed largely by corporations and individuals who are regulated by state agencies or have state contracts.
"You don't want people holding important government positions to be paid by people who are then going to depend on the favors and decision-making of these recipients," said Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Manhattan Democrat. "It represents a real conflict."
But Ms. Mucha said that none of the people who received money from the fund knew who had contributed to it, and therefore could not have been influenced.
"People were doing a job," she said. "They were working 24 hours a day, seven days a week, trying to put a transition together, trying to organize an inauguration, putting together a government. No one was interested in who was contributing, no one had access to the names of contributors. And for people to make something out of nothing is preposterous."
Soon after the fund was created in late 1994, the Pataki administration promised to release detailed information about the names of contributors, the size of their donations and how the money was used.
But despite those pledges, the Governor's allies who controlled the fund refused to release the financial records last November, saying they did not want the Governor to know who had contributed to it, for ethical reasons -- even though Mr. Pataki had met many of the contributors at a $1,000-a-plate fund-raiser in Manhattan and many of the donors' names were printed on programs distributed at the inauguration.
After that refusal, the Democratic leadership of the Assembly launched an investigation, issuing subpoenas for the financial records from the two private corporations that controlled the fund. Mr. Pataki's supporters challenged those subpoenas in court, but lost in a decision released last week. Lawyers for the fund said today that they expected to release some of the financial records this week.
Ms. Mucha said she was paid between $20,000 and $30,000 -- she said she could not recall the exact amount -- for working full-time for the transition between the election on Nov. 7, 1994, and Jan. 1, 1995, when Mr. Pataki took office. She said the payments also compensated her for having lost five weeks in vacation time she had accumulated while working for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato before joining Mr. Pataki's campaign.
"I was compensated for my work and for what they felt I would be losing by not going back to the Senate," she said.
Mr. Finnegan said his $45,000 payment was for his work directing Mr. Pataki's transition team, a job he said consumed all his time for seven weeks. Mr. Finnegan's former law partner, Stephen J. Mignano, also was paid about $25,000 from the fund for "professional services," said H. Neal Conolly, a lawyer for the fund. Mr. Finnegan said he did not know what that payment was for, and Mr. Mignano did not return phone calls.
Though a spokesman, Mr. O'Mara, who is the state's chief regulator of the electric and natural gas industry, said that his $25,000 payment compensated him for quitting his law job and working full time on Mr. Pataki's transition between November 1994 and mid-February 1995.
Robert E. Boyle, who was the fund's treasurer before being appointed by Mr. Pataki as president of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, received at least $10,000 from the fund in 1995, Mr. Conolly said.
Several other top Pataki advisers have reported receiving payments of at least $1,000 from the fund in their annual ethics reports to the state. Those officials included Health Commissioner Barbara A. DeBuono; Bradford J. Race, Jr., Mr. Pataki's chief of staff, and three top officials at the state Department of Economic Development, Caroline Quartararo, Robert Ryan and Carolyn Bachan. The ethics reports did not require the officials to list exactly how much money they were paid.

An article yesterday about payments from Gov. George E. Pataki's transition and inaugural fund to members of his administration misstated a response from his director of communications, Zenia Mucha. She said that she had received payments to help compensate her for having lost five months in accumulated vacation time from the Federal Government; she did not say five weeks.

HEADLINE: Bad Neuenahr Journal;
To Tighten Germany's Belt, Take a Look at the Spa

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BAD NEUENAHR, Germany, July 19

 BODY:
For the last 20 minutes or so, Gerd Ruhs, still as a pharaoh's mummy, happy as a hippo, has been encased in a coating of volcanic mud whose temperatures run to 120 degrees.
Contrary to appearances, he says -- moving ever so slightly, sweating ever so much -- there is a "taste of luxury" to this and to the massages and other treatments associated with being a patient at the spa here. 
 Outside the clinic where Mr. Ruhs, a 55-year-old technician in a food factory, is about to be unpeeled and hosed down by Theresia Doppelgatz, the nurse who wrapped him in the mud known as fango, Hedwig Wilming is taking a smoking break from her therapy, and she seems to agree.
"Mornings it's fango, evenings tango," said Mrs. Wilming, a 50-year-old nurse, getting a laugh from other people who, like her, wear bathrobes and track suits to undertake the travails of a four-week, state-financed spa treatment, known as a "health cure," that has come to stand in microcosm for one of the most ferocious debates in Germany as it gropes toward unfamiliar austerity.
The question, in essence, is this: can Germany's welfare state continue to afford not just routine health care but also a system whereby, on a doctor's prescription, Germans like Mr. Ruhs and Mrs. Wilming may take a free four-week spa treatment every three years?
In Bonn, just north of here, the Government's answer is no. And, among measures supposed to save some $33 billion in public spending, it has proposed that spa entitlements be reduced to three weeks every four years. The German Government reckons that by trimming spa care and some other smaller benefits, it will save about $5 billion a year.
At present, the state-subsidized spa guests pay roughly $8 a day for their treatment. Bonn wants to double that. The market value of a spa retreat, by contrast, is much more -- up to $250 a day, said Rainer Mertel, the director of Bad Neuenahr's privately run Spa Administration.
To outsiders -- particularly those not raised on the Central and Southern European culture of bathing in often noisome thermal springs and wallowing in volcanic, mineral-rich mud -- Germany's spa system may seem a parable of excess.
"In America you don't have this," Mr. Mertel said. "So you can smile about the crazy Germans."
But along the leafy banks of the River Ahr here, where fat trout loll under bridges and people toss bread to them to watch them rise, there are many different arguments.
Each year 1.5 million Germans take state-financed treatment at some of 1,200 clinics in 320 places officially recognized as curative centers or spas, said Rudolf Forcher, chairman of the Association of German Spas in the southern state of Baden-Wurttemberg.
On top of that, he reckoned, 7.6 million Germans -- 40 percent of the German vacationers whose travels appear on Government statistics -- pay for annual spa vacations that combine Mrs. Wilming's fango and tango with thermal baths, bracing walks, jolly exercise, oxygen baths, massage, fine food and much else. Older workers are more likely than younger ones to be prescribed a stay in a spa by a doctor.
But many Germans ask themselves: are Germany's state-financed spas no more than the ultimate boondoggle, a four-week break on top of the annual six weeks' vacation that has bred a multibillion-dollar industry?
"Of course, you can't filter out the freeloaders," Mr. Ruhs said with a sigh as the clock ticked toward his release from heat. "But all I can say is that if I hadn't had my four cures, I'd have had to be operated on and that would have cost a lot more."
Reinhardt Buchhorn, a 45-year-old municipal worker from Hanover, said: "You are here for your health, not fun. If you're sick, you're sick."
And, besides, said another patient, Manfred Schmidt, 44, from southern Germany, it's not exactly free, either, since German employees pay 13 or 14 percent of their gross salaries in health care contributions, an amount matched by their employers.
"This word 'cure,' it's very controversial," said Dieter Hamann, the director of the Klinik Kurkoln, one of four clinics operated by the privately run spa company that dominates Bad Neuenahr's thermal baths and spa industry. "There's a lot of hostility. People call it a holiday with therapy. But it's not. Our patients are busy from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M."
Indeed, people like Mr. Ruhs and Mrs. Wilming, all clutch personal timetables setting out busy schedules to be treated for ailments of the spinal column and other orthopedic afflictions that they say are eased here. Apart from those maladies, Bad Neuenahr and other spas offer a range of treatments for rheumatism, diabetes, post-operative rehabilitation, circulatory problems, stress and exhaustion.
The spa system is based on what Alexander Gorbing, Bad Neuenahr's marketing director, described as a twofold philosophy. State pension funds, he said, finance treatment for people who are still working to keep them well enough to work until retirement age. And state health care funds finance retirees' treatment to keep older people in good health so that they do not clamor for more expensive health care.
"This German system is unique in the world," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 1, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on July 23 about health care in Germany misstated health insurance costs there. German health insurance premiums average 13 percent of gross salary, shared equally between employer and employee.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Prices Head Higher In Unexpected Summer Rally

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Copper prices rallied in New York yesterday as a decline in stockpiles was taken as a sign of unexpectedly strong demand.
On other markets, natural gas prices rose while wheat fell. 
 The London Metal Exchange said its copper inventories had fallen by 4,625 metric tons, to 224,100 metric tons, from Friday through Monday. That was the ninth consecutive drop posted in the twice-weekly report. In the last two months, stockpiles have fallen 29 percent, to their lowest level since Dec. 5.
"Demand for copper is still very, very good in the U.S.," said John Gross, publisher of The Copper Journal. "It's consistent with the strength in the economy."
The inventory drop comes even as many factories are slowing operations or shutting down entirely for seasonal retooling and summer maintenance. Copper demand is typically lowest in July, traders said.
"For the middle of the summer, demand is really not that bad," said Michael Frawley, a copper trader with Dean Witter in New York.
Copper for September delivery rose 2.55 cents, to 91.95 cents a pound, at the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, the highest since June 20.
In the natural gas market, prices rose for the first time in a week on concern that inventories remain uncomfortably low.
Inventories have been rising, aided by relatively mild weather recently that reduced air-conditioning demand, and the shortfall has narrowed to 28 percent below the level a year ago, according to the American Gas Association. Earlier this year, the gap had been 60 percent.
Nonetheless, August natural gas for delivery at the Henry Hub in Louisiana surged 20.9 cents, to $2.39 for a thousand cubic feet, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Wheat fell to its lowest price in almost 11 months after China canceled plans to buy 725,687 metric tons in a continuing dispute with the United States over fungus contamination in some shipments. Soft red winter wheat for September delivery on the Chicago Board of Trade fell 6.75 cents, to $4.5375 a bushel.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Dole at Ease In Preparing A Film View Of the Man

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: RUSSELL, Kan., July 23

 BODY:
Bob Dole spent his day today making memories to share with the country next month at the Republican convention in San Diego.
With a film crew in tow and small-town America as his backdrop, Mr. Dole ambled around his hometown, chatting with friends, reminiscing with his sisters, narrating a tour through the house where he grew up and examining the artifacts of his life. 
 Under the guidance of Don Sipple, Mr. Dole's chief media strategist, cameras whirred at every move, starting with an ice-cream social in a local park Monday night and concluding with a chocolate milkshake at the Dairy Queen this afternoon.
All the hours of film are to be boiled down to a 10-minute movie that will help introduce Mr. Dole to the nation in August when he gives his speech accepting the nomination to be the Republican candidate for President.
"What a lot of Bob Dole is about is rooted in Russell," Mr. Sipple said at the modest Dole homestead here on Maple Street, during a break in a five-hour shoot.
"The values are strong, the people are strong and life is not so complicated as it is in a lot of other places," Mr. Sipple said. "That's the essence of Russell -- hard work, perseverance, respect for others. That's what we're finding out, and that's what's reflected in him."
As part of the film project, Mary Ellen Mark, a photojournalist, has joined the entourage.
The film crew was unobtrusively standing by and waiting for useful visuals to unfold, unscripted. Aides said the crew was looking for "genuine moments."
Several occurred on Monday night in the park as many well-wishers greeted Mr. Dole and squads of children sought his autograph. He chatted at length with one of the few black families there, whom campaign aides had spotted and escorted to a table near Mr. Dole and who, it turned out, were all Democrats.
He also spent several minutes with two boys in wheelchairs, kneeling before one of them, Jimmy Rodriguez, and talking quietly. The boys need electric wheelchairs, which cost more than $11,000, and Mr. Dole said he would see what he could do, taking their addresses and phone numbers.
Mr. Dole, who has lived in Washington for the last 35 years, has used Russell as a touchstone for big moments in his previous bids for national office. He plans to use it again this summer as the staging ground before he heads to the convention, with a stop first at the Eisenhower Library down the road in Abilene. Then he plans to announce his Vice-Presidential choice from here and "spend a day or two to get our batteries recharged," as he put it, before heading to the Republican convention in San Diego.
The reporters and camera crews who travel with Mr. Dole's campaign have been kept at arm's length during the filming because the campaign does not want a stray reporter to wander into the frame and disrupt the authenticity of the shot.
But this morning in Mr. Dole's sister's backyard, a small group of reporters was allowed in for a brief picture-taking session while Mr. Dole ate breakfast. In a newly disciplined mode, the candidate is resisting talking with reporters, so when he was asked when he might present his long-awaited economic plan, he replied, "It's a secret."
He confirmed that he planned to visit former President George Bush on Friday in Kennebunkport, Me., in part to mark the sixth anniversary of the signing of the Americans With Disabilities Act, which Mr. Dole was instrumental in enacting.
"He's been very helpful," Mr. Dole said of his former rival. "I talk to him now and then."
Eyeing a boom microphone over his head, Mr. Dole advised his companions -- his daughter, his sister Gloria and his sister's husband -- to keep mum. "They can pick up a flea scratching," he said.
Inside his former home, Mr. Dole submitted to what Mr. Sipple described as an "extensive interview" as he pored over mementos. These included the sound scriber he used to tape his law school classes in the 1940's. The machine was necessary because he had been severely injured in World War II and could not write. Standing before a cabinet, Mr. Dole pointed out several little knick-knacks he had sent home to his family.
"No one lives here, except when I'm home," he noted.
As he left the house, Mr. Dole was asked how the filming had gone.
"I was on my best behavior," he replied.
Mr. Sipple was asked how much of the project was scripted, and he said almost none.
"You mean you don't tell him what to say?" a reporter asked.
"No," Mr. Sipple said.
Then, aware that everyone listening was familiar with Mr. Dole's legendary resistance to being told what to do, he added with a laugh, "Absolutely not."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bob Dole visited yesterday with friends in Russell, Kan., his hometown, where his campaign was making a film for the Republican convention next month. Mary Ellen Mark, the photographer, joined the expedition. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Up On Soft Retail Indicators

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rebounded from early lows yesterday to close higher on a combination of factors, including a weak stock market, neutral remarks by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and softness in retail-industry indicators.
Investor nervousness about supply and the testimony by Mr. Greenspan before the House banking subcommittee applied downward pressure on market prices going into the afternoon. While the weekly Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi/Schroder Wertheim index of chain store sales showed a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent for the week ended July 20, it was the 1 percent decline in the Johnson Redbook survey of retail sales that gave the market support in the afternoon -- rallying on rumors first -- that it would show a decline, squeezing short positions along the way. 
 The 30-year bond rose 13/32 , to a price of 8729/32 ; the yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, slipped to 6.97 percent, from 7 percent on Monday.
News reports that Elaine Garzarelli, a highly regarded stock market analyst, had told some clients that the Dow Jones industrial average would slip 15 percent to 25 percent from its highs set this spring, prompted weakness in stocks that some in the bond market saw as a buying opportunity in short-maturity Treasury securities.
The figuring was that money flowing out of stocks would likely find its way there.
Mr. Greenspan's testimony in the afternoon produced no fireworks, except for some relief buying. The Fed chairman said he saw growth slowing, though the timing of that slowdown remained uncertain.
Yesterday's Treasury sale of $18.75 billion in new two-year notes was in fact aided by the late rally in the Treasury market brought on by a slide in the stock market.
Larry M. Berman, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said the two-year note auction "actually came in better than expected."
He added: "All in all, it was an average auction. However, all interest in the auction was muted because the bond market was waiting to see if the Fed would pull the trigger and raise rates, though it appears that they will not raise rates before Aug. 20. But if the economic data at the end of this month is stronger than expected, there is no reason to wait."
The high yield at auction was slightly lower than expected at 6.288 percent, with the noncompetitive bidding above average, but the bid-to-cover ratio -- the total amount bid at auction for all prices against the size of the auction -- was weak. So far this year, the average bid-to-cover ratio has been 2.33 to 1; yesterday it was 2.16 to 1.
Mr. Greenspan said little that was sensitive to the market ahead of the futures close, traders said. The gains came mainly on the weak Redbook retail sales figure and the slip in the Dow on the prediction of a 15 percent to 25 percent correction.
"Technically, last week, we saw the reaction off of Fed chairman Greenspan's Senate testimony, which produced headlines that appeared bearish, and rightly so, the market traded down," Mr. Berman said. "The market has been light in volume and the dealers have been looking at the large leverage hedge funds and their biases, and going with them.
"Given the risk that Mr. Greenspan could say something today, there is no great rush to jump into the market at this moment. There was some relief buying on the auction's results and the buildup of shorts during the day's selling were squeezed out at the end. Nothing new has been given to the market to develop a new trend. Still, 6.90 percent to 7.10 percent will likely be the range in front of the end- of-the-month data."
Following are the results of today's Treasury auction of new two-year notes:

HEADLINE: Casino County

BYLINE: By James Thomas Snyder; James Thomas Snyder writes for The Daily News in Memphis.

DATELINE: MEMPHIS

 BODY:
Congress has passed legislation to create a commission to examine the rapidly expanding gambling industry, and President Clinton has said he will sign it. All this comes not a day too soon. It's too bad, in fact, that the commission wasn't in place before the casinos came to Tunica County.
The small cotton county in northwest Mississippi where 10 casinos have opened since 1992 offers a lot for the panel to look at. It also demonstrates why we need such a forum for debate and a clearinghouse for information as many poor communities look to gambling to generate development, growth and revenue.
Growth was what the county's residents were after when they voted to allow casinos on the banks of the Mississippi south of Memphis.
By almost any standard, Tunica was once the nation's poorest county. Per capita income in 1989 was $6,449. In 1991, more than half of the residents received food stamps, and more than a fifth received welfare. In 1985, after touring a poor community there, Jesse Jackson labeled Tunica County "America's Ethiopia."
What happened in Tunica defies exact judgments about gambling as a good or bad influence. Take the unemployment rate. It hovered around 13 percent in 1990, fell to 8.7 percent in 1993, then climbed to 12.9 percent in 1995. More residents are employed now than ever before. But more are unemployed, too, since so many who had stopped looking for jobs have rejoined the labor market, lining up for the easy work and quick money the casinos were supposed to offer, only to find there weren't enough opportunities to go around.
By 1995, three years after the casinos opened, food stamp use fell from 54 percent to 35 percent of the population and welfare dependency from 22 percent to 10 percent. But the population has not changed, and, except for a boom in hotel construction, development is nonexistent. Moreover, some gaming halls have shut or moved 15 miles north to the other end of the county, nearer Memphis, which hurts in a rural area where distance affects whether workers can keep jobs.
A Federal commission would be a clearinghouse for these kinds of considerations. It would do what regulatory agencies do: set objective standards to evaluate information. As it stands, we have to sort through endless propaganda.
Take, for example, a brochure published by the American Gaming Association, the industry's lobbying group, written to dispel "myths" about the evils of gambling. The association cites Tunica County's huge spurt in retail sales -- nearly 600 percent in three years -- to counter the argument that gambling nabs customers who would otherwise patronize small local businesses. What the association fails to mention is that there is little evidence that small businesses are profiting. The retail sales are mostly at the casinos, which sell souvenirs.
Also, to rebut claims that casinos put addictive gamblers on the road to financial ruin, the brochure cites declining bankruptcy rates in southern Mississippi, where the state's other gambling center is located.
The gaming lobby isn't telling the whole story. The brochure boasted that bankruptcies in southern Mississippi dropped from 1992 through 1994. But in that time bankruptcy rates were also declining nationwide. In 1995, they started to climb again, both in southern Mississippi and nationally.
The most absurd claim -- made in the brochure and by the association's president, Frank Fahrenkopf, in a television interview last week -- is that casinos don't cause crime.
Explain that to the court workers in Tunica County, who have faced at least a tenfold increase in their caseload -- 1,200 filings to 12,000 -- since the casinos opened. Though Federal crime statistics are not yet available, felony indictments for the county increased from 13 in 1992 to 172 in 1995.
In coming years, we'll be sure to hear more arguments about whether gambling is a pernicious influence or a clean and rich source of economic growth.
A Federal commission would help us wade through the slosh of information, misinformation and disinformation to provide a clear, accurate reflection of what gambling does to communities that turn to it as a savior of last resort.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Salomon Inc. Earnings Are Stronger Than Expectations

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Salomon Inc. yesterday reported surprisingly strong earnings for the second quarter, as revenue from bond trading and investment banking surged.
Salomon, the parent company of the securities firm Salomon Brothers Inc., earned $291 million, or $2.58 a share, compared with a loss of $60 million, or 73 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. The results exceeded Wall Street expectations of $1.48 a share, according to a survey of five analysts by IBES International Inc. 
 "Both trading and investment banking did well and contributed to the results," said Raphael Soifer, an analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman & Company who follows Wall Street. "It's another quarter on the road to turnaround," though it remains to be seen how the company will fare when financial markets decline, he said.
Pretax earnings at Salomon Brothers, the second-largest American securities firm in terms of capital, jumped more than ninefold, to $525 million during the second quarter from $56 million a year earlier. The unit lost almost $1 billion before taxes in 1994.
Salomon Brothers' revenue, net of interest and interest expense, more than doubled to $1.2 billion, from $552 million in the second quarter of 1995. Bond trading paced the increase. Salomon is the world's biggest bond trader, and its balance sheet averaged $193 billion in the second quarter.
Revenue from fixed-income sales and trading rose to $706 million, from $93 million in the quarter a year ago, while investment banking revenue jumped 63 percent, to a record $251 million. Salomon was the No. 2 underwriter of American stocks and bonds and the seventh-ranked adviser in mergers for the first half of the year, according to the Securities Data Company.
Salomon's better-than-expected results are in line with the rest of Wall Street's earnings, which swelled as mergers soared to record levels, the stock market hovered near all-time highs and interest rates remained relatively low during the quarter.
Salomon's Phibro unit, which trades commodities, lost $17 million before taxes in the second quarter. The loss narrowed from $162 million a year earlier. Basis Petroleum, the company's oil and refining business, lost $13 million before taxes. In the quarter a year ago, the unit earned $1 million before taxes.
Last week, Salomon announced plans to combine Basis Petroleum's crude oil gathering, marketing and trading operations with the Howell Corporation's gathering marketing and pipeline assets in a master limited partnership.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;
G.O.P. Leaders Seeks Tax Cuts Wide in Scope

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
With Presidential politics and Congressional races both clearly in mind, the Republican leadership on Capitol Hill called today for a program of broad tax cuts, raising the pressure on Bob Dole to follow suit as he formulates his own economic platform.
Speaker Newt Gingrich, the majority leaders of the Senate and the House, and the chairmen of the tax-writing committees all generally endorsed short-term tax cuts followed by a sweeping overhaul of the tax code as the key to improving the nation's growth rate and giving Republicans a powerful campaign issue. 
 Mr. Gingrich said he would like to see a rollback of the 1993 tax increases and possibly an across-the-board reduction in income tax rates during the first month or so of a Dole administration.
"I would love to see us jump-start with President Dole, in the first 30 or 40 days of his administration, an immediate tax package with immediate pro-growth consequences and immediate tax relief before the April 15 deadline next year," Mr. Gingrich said. "Then, in a more orderly way, over a five- or six-month period, have the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee really dramatically get the Internal Revenue Service out of the lives of working Americans."
Mr. Dole is widely expected to make a tax cut the centerpiece of his economic strategy; he said in a television interview this month that a "tax cut will be a part of it" and that he thought that tax rates should be "flatter and fairer." But he has not offered any details or said how he would pay for such a cut. Campaign aides say they expect his plan to be announced in the next several weeks.
Mr. Dole, who has long argued that bringing down the Federal budget deficit is the nation's most important economic task, has been searching for a formula that would permit a politically popular tax cut without undermining his credibility as a deficit-fighter.
But his slow pace in developing an economic plan and his apparent qualms about embracing a big tax cut have worried Republicans in Congress, who fear that he is undermining their own political standing and depriving them of what they see as a red-meat issue: the tax increases enacted at President Clinton's behest by a Democratic-controlled Congress in 1993.
The Republican Congressional leaders spoke today at a forum on Capitol Hill that was organized largely at the initiative of Jack F. Kemp, the former Congressman and Housing Secretary, who in the last several years has been the most visible Republican proponent of big tax cuts.
Mr. Kemp has long occupied the end of the Republican economic policy spectrum opposite Mr. Dole, and has had a strained relationship with the Dole campaign since endorsing Steve Forbes, a strong advocate of a tax overhaul, late in the Republican Presidential primary season. But the Dole campaign sent its top policy adviser, Donald Rumsfeld, to speak at the meeting today, and other Dole aides said they did not feel that Mr. Kemp was pressuring the candidate to adopt policies he was not comfortable with.
"Republicans in Congress want a more concrete plan to run on," one aide to Mr. Dole said. "There is absolutely no divergence between the needs of the Dole campaign and the needs of Republican politicians who must draw distinctions in their campaigns, the clearest of which is Republicans' cutting taxes versus Democrats' raising taxes."
The forum served as something of a campaign kickoff for the emerging Republican theme that Mr. Clinton's fiscal policies have condemned the nation to disappointing growth in jobs and income.
"We've had three and a half years of Clinton economics now, and we know what that feels like," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader. "We also know what the economy will look like with Bob Dole in the White House working with a Republican majority in Congress: Tax cuts and tax reform will stimulate growth; more jobs and higher take-home pay."
The White House repeated that it would portray any large tax-cut proposal from Mr. Dole as a blow to bipartisan deficit-reduction efforts that have already yielded economic benefits like lower interest rates.
"It's a step back for balancing the budget if Bob Dole allows Newt Gingrich to talk him into a major across-the-board give-away that relies on sham financing and the very supply-side magical assumptions that Bob Dole spent the 1980's criticizing," said Gene Sperling, an economic adviser to the President.
The Republican leaders at the forum today gave no indication of how they would pay for any tax cuts. But they appeared to edge closer to accepting the much-debated theory that tax cutting pays in part for itself, by promoting economic growth, and that tax cuts therefore do not necessarily lead to an increase in the budget deficit. Mr. Dole long derided that supply-side theory.
"I believe we can cut taxes and balance the budget," the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said in a statement issued at the forum. "Some people let themselves be drawn into the belief that the two are mutually exclusive. To the contrary, cutting taxes will provide just the boost this economy needs."
And Mr. Rumsfeld suggested that Mr. Dole, or at least his advisers, were more open to supply-side theory than he was in the past.
Mr. Rumsfeld said that he agreed with critics of so-called static revenue analysis, which holds that reducing tax rates leads to lower tax revenue, and that he accepted its supply-side counterpart, dynamic revenue analysis, which holds that reducing tax rates spurs people to try to earn more money, thereby generating more revenue.
"There is no question but that there is a flowback or feedback that occurs," Mr. Rumsfeld said. "There are people who would argue about the extent, but I think most people who've looked at it carefully agree that it's there, and it's not trivial."
But Mr. Dole also received a veiled warning from one of his closest colleagues from his years in the Senate, Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee and one of the fiercest Republican advocates of deficit reduction.
Mr. Domenici said he fully supported a broad-based program including a tax overhaul. But he said any such program must be credible, which in his view means it must include a credible budget-balancing proposal. "A growth plan that is not credible," he said, "is worse than not having one."

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
Alcoa Vacating Its Downtown Pittsburgh Landmark

BYLINE: By CHRISS SWANEY 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
A corporate restructuring at the Aluminum Company of America has brought with it a decision to relinquish the company's 31-story aluminum headquarters building in downtown Pittsburgh, a landmark on the city's skyline since its construction in 1952.
To replace it as the corporate headquarters, Alcoa is putting up a $40 million building on the riverfront on the city's North Side, about a 15-minute walk from downtown. But the new building is designed for only 450 employees; the existing building has been home to about 1,500 of Alcoa's 1,700 employees in the Pittsburgh area. At one time 2,000 Alcoa employees worked there. The company has 10,000 salaried workers in the United States. 
 Alcoa's intention is to sell the building and the expectation is that the buyer will be a development company that will try to find new corporate tenants and will rehabilitate space for them. The addition of Alcoa's 442,500 square feet of rentable space to the leasing market means that the office market will have an estimated 3.7 million square feet of space available, for a vacancy rate of 16.5 percent, said Peter Sukernek, general manager of Hanna Commercial Real Estate Services, a commercial arm of the Howard Hanna Company, a real estate company based in Pittsburgh.
"This will be the best new space that has become available since the 80's," Mr. Sukernek said, a reflection of the fact that there has been no new construction downtown since Renaissance II, a series of office buildings produced as a public-private partnership at the junction of the Monongahela and Allegheny rivers in the heart of downtown in the 1980's. He said it was doubtful that a single tenant would take the space, and that leasing would take some time.
Alcoa's new six-story glass-and-aluminum headquarters building will have 236,200 square feet of space and be situated on two acres at Isabella Street between the Seventh and Ninth Street bridges. It has been in construction since May, with occupancy expected in the spring of 1998.
It will have two levels of underground parking for 375 cars, with valet parking available. A 22,500-square-foot park facing the Allegheny River and a 2.5-mile jogging trail will also be accessible for Alcoa employees.
The project architect is the Design Alliance of Pittsburgh and the general contractor is Turner Construction of Pittsburgh.
"Our new building allocates space to employees based on need, not title," said Paul H. O'Neill, chairman of Alcoa, "and creates an open architecture to encourage conversation and teamwork." All office space will be enclosed in floor-to-ceiling glass and no work station will be farther than 45 feet from the windows. Only about 60 percent of the space will be for offices or work space, with the other 40 percent for meetings or collaborative work.
"It is a design driven by function, not status," said Martin Powell, principal architect with Design Alliance. "People will be more visible and more accessible." The main entrance will open on an atrium where escalators will go to other floors. Elevators will be used mainly for freight or the handicapped.
The Alcoa project is one of several waterfront developments on the city's North Side. They include a 30,000-square-foot general-purpose office building and a 94-apartment $20 million town house complex.
Another project in construction is a $22 million community of 232 apartments on six acres adjacent to the new Alcoa building. Called Lincoln at North Shore, it will provide 160 one-bedroom apartments renting for $650 to $815 a month, and 72 two-bedroom apartments at $990 to $1,300 a month.
The Pittsburgh-based Mascaro Inc. is the general contractor for the city's newest residential community. Kaufman/Meeks of Houston is the project architect while the Lincoln Property Company of Dallas is the project developer. Lincoln Property, one of the nation's largest private development companies, owns and manages 100,000 apartments. The project is scheduled for completion in summer 1997.
There is also a possibility that a $140 million baseball stadium will be built for the Pittsburgh Pirates on land four blocks south of the Alcoa building. Owners of the team began negotiating with city officials three months ago on a new-stadium site.
The North Side represents about a third of the Pittsburgh waterfront, once home of many steel mills and warehouses. More than $100 million of public and private funds have been pumped into half a dozen projects to give the waterfront a contemporary function.
Still, there is concern that continued job contraction by large employers in Pittsburgh could hurt an already sluggish economy. A combination of bank mergers and corporate downsizing in the last decade has brought about a loss of more than 2,700 white-collar jobs in Pittsburgh over the last three years.

HEADLINE: European Beachhead For Korean Ambition

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
Oceans away from his home base, in a dark cavernous factory here covered with decades of grime left by Communist neglect, the South Korean magnate and chairman of the Daewoo Group, Kim Woo Choong, sees the future. He walks the aisles of antiquated metal pressing machines, unruffled by the thunderous noise or the disheveled Polish auto workers peering at their new boss.
"I can see a change in attitude already," said the silver-haired Mr. Kim, who is betting big on his ability to transform easygoing Polish job habits into crisp Korean style.
More than a dozen auto makers, including the General Motors Corporation, came to Poland to bargain over the country's state-run car and component manufacturer, a 20,000-employee behemoth with a record of producing inferior cars. 
 Without much ado, Mr. Kim, who heads Korea's fourth-largest industrial conglomerate, won the bidding, taking control of Fabryka Samochodow Osobowych, or F.S.O., for $1.1 billion -- part of a plan aimed at becoming one of the 10 biggest auto makers in the world by 2000.
The key to the plan is Central Europe, a region where manufacturing costs are still low -- auto wages are one-fifth the level in South Korea -- yet the appetite of consumers for cars and other products is growing. Car sales in Poland and the Czech Republic, for example, soared 30 percent in the first five months of this year. By the end of the year, Poles are expected to have bought 300,000 new cars, making the country the 10th-largest car market in Europe.
Central Europe will also serve as the production base for bigger markets in Western Europe and to the east. If Poland achieves European Union membership early in the next century, trade barriers would fall just as the new Daewoo ventures reach peak production. By that stage, Daewoo plans to have two completely new "world cars" -- the T car and the J car, both designed with Italian engineers -- rolling out of its Central European plants.
"It's a very bright market," said Mr. Kim, who may, however, see more brightness than others.
Financial analysts in Seoul note that as the South Korean market becomes more problematic because of mounting costs, all the major conglomerates there are hunting abroad for new markets.
But though many Korean and other foreign manufacturers are flocking to this region, none are putting more on the line than Daewoo, which is committing a total of $5 billion to projects in the area.
And few are facing more formidable obstacles. For openers, Mr. Kim must sharply upgrade Daewoo's lackluster engineering skills even as he overcomes cultural gaps in the workplace. How Daewoo, a debt-laden company, plans to finance the rapid expansion is not exactly clear. Nor is it certain that the appetite exists for so many Daewoo cars.
South Korean cars in general are hardly known as premier vehicles, and Daewoo, after an unhappy 14-year joint venture with General Motors that ended in 1992, has been dogged with a poor reputation. (During part of the joint venture, Daewoo produced Pontiac Le Mans cars for sale in the United States.)
But Mr. Kim insists that the group's auto company, Daewoo Motor, will fix the quality gap, even as it raises last year's production level of 520,000 cars, all made in South Korea, to 2 million worldwide by the end of the decade. Economies of scale, he argues, will improve quality and performance. One million cars, he says, will be manufactured in South Korea, and one million at plants in countries from Uzbekistan and India to Poland and Romania.
To accomplish his mission, which some believe is partly motivated by his determination to show G.M. what stuff he is made of, Mr. Kim has gone on a huge shopping spree.
Aside from F.S.O., over the last two years Daewoo bought a truck factory in southern Poland for $700 million, a car plant in Romania for $300 million and a Czech truck manufacturer for $200 million. As well, Daewoo recently bought 51 percent of a Romanian shipyard, is constructing a washing-machine and circuit-board factory in Warsaw and is planning a 30-story office tower here.
Financial analysts, competing car companies and stunned but happy local politicians have looked on with a mixture of awe and skepticism at the voracity of Daewoo's appetite.
The established car titans are approaching more cautiously. General Motors, for example, is planning to build a $340 million plant in southern Poland, to open in 1999 with initial production of 78,000 cars.
"If I was with G.M., I would be doing what they are doing," Mr. Kim said in his modern but Spartan Warsaw office. "We are a latecomer, so we take more risks than them."
Mr. Kim, who has legal problems back home, has been spending much of his time here and in Vienna, nurturing the new businesses. He is one of a group of high-level Korean executives indicted last year on charges of giving bribes to former President Roh Tae Woo in exchange for lucrative contracts. Mr. Kim is due to stand trial later this year, but is not expected to face any jail time if convicted.
As for financing all the new ventures, "it is not an easy task," said Cho Dung Sung, a professor of business administration at Seoul National University who closely follows Daewoo. Mr. Cho, who wrote a Harvard Business School case study on Daewoo in 1984, is writing a sequel but said that he did not yet have an "exact picture" of how Mr. Kim would raise the money.
Last year, the parent Daewoo Group had a net profit of about $530 million on revenues of $51.2 billion, from making ships, consumer electronics and computers, in addition to cars. The company also controls a construction business and has other activities. Daewoo Motor, which netted just $13.7 million on sales of $4.5 billion, had nearly $3.2 billion in debt last year, about 4.4 times equity. Most Daewoo companies trail their competitors at home, with Daewoo Motor in third place behind Hyundai Motor and Kia Motors.
Mr. Kim said he expected to borrow 60 percent of the cost of the new ventures from international banks. The rest would come from new equity issues, European bonds convertible into shares of Daewoo's profitable Korean companies, plus profits from the new acquisitions.
What is clearer than the financial picture is the hectic pace at which Daewoo managers -- more than 100 are in Warsaw -- are trying to turn around the newly acquired plants.
They are finding alienated workers, soured by decades of poor treatment at the hands of Communist managers. One of the first tasks was to clean the grease-soaked blackened floor of the factory that has the stamping presses. Polish workers scrubbed it with hand scrapers.
"With the Koreans, it's clean, clean, clean, then quality, quality, quality," said Tadeusz Papis, the deputy leader of the independent trade union, which is the second largest at F.S.O. "We have to get used to the Koreans. But they have to get used to us or nothing will happen."
But the Koreans, according to Mr. Papis, are solicitous. For example, workers were surveyed about possible quality-of-life improvements in the workplace. The first request was renovation of the squalid bathrooms. Soon, workers were asked about tile colors, and all bathrooms were brought up to Western standards.
Part of the challenge for Daewoo is to get more out of its new workers. The company started by sending 900 Romanian employees to South Korea for three months' work experience. The Romanians got a shock.
"They work very, very hard, over the normal," said Dan Ceausu, a body shop supervisor. "When we went there, everything ached -- not only our arms, but our backs, our legs."
In Poland, about 1,500 workers are destined for six-month stints in South Korea. An advance team of about 50 workers in quality control went for two weeks during the spring. They found the experience at times inspiring, at times exhausting.
"We got to know the quality control system there and we have to implement it here as fast as possible," said Wojciech Michalik, a supervisor. "The Koreans say: 'Eliminate all these failures; there's too much noise in the chassis; set up a team.' Sometimes it's too much perfection; sometimes it's too fast. I'm here every day 6:30 A.M. to 9 P.M. That's new."
Perhaps more than anything, the Koreans taught a sense of the competition in the marketplace. "They know and now we know," Mr. Michalik said, "that the difference between us and our competition -- Fiat and General Motors -- is big."
Kim Kwon Tae, the new chief of production and engineering at Daewoo-F.S.O., as the new venture is officially called, suggested that the productivity and quality control tasks were daunting but doable.
As he walked the assembly line recently, the production chief was upset to see workers smoking at their stations. Personal lockers where workers kept toolboxes -- and where stolen parts were often stashed away -- would soon be abolished, he said. "It was the same in Korea 20 years ago -- we were very poor, and people stole," he said.
More important, he intends to double the engineering team at the plant, mostly by hiring recent and eager graduates from Polish universities. He has inherited 817 engineers, but about 60 percent are more than 40 years old. "Under Communism, their duty was to just get older," he said. "They had no chance to be creative."
As Daewoo's Central European ventures get under way, the company has already given a segment of the West European market a small taste of how adventurous it can be.
Because of an agreement relating to its breakup with General Motors, Daewoo was allowed to start selling in Western Europe only last year. (It is planning to sell cars in the United States for the first time under its own name starting late next year or early in 1998.)
The company chose Britain as a launching pad. With its Nexia model, imported from South Korea, Daewoo recorded the fastest growth of any newcomer to the market, a feat that took competitors by surprise. In the first 12 months, it sold 18,000 Nexias -- many through the novel marketing technique of using outlets in the Savacenter superstores of Sainsbury, a supermarket chain.
Such a venture, however, is only a tiny step compared with Mr. Kim's overall plans.
While Professor Cho is taking a wait-and-see attitude, he cautions that Mr. Kim -- a manager who sold cheap textiles to Sears, Roebuck in the 1970's -- is not to be underestimated.
"He is a master in selling products abroad," Professor Cho said. "He's not timid in creating the challenge -- that's the mark of a visionary."

HEADLINE: District of Columbia's Budget Wins Senate Panel's Approval

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
The Senate Appropriations Committee today unanimously approved the District of Columbia's $5.1 billion budget for the 1997 fiscal year, the second sign this week that Congress is satisfied with the city's progress toward solving its financial crisis.
On Monday, the House approved the District's budget by a vote of 332 to 68, attaching only two conservative social proposals, compared with the half-dozen that House members added last year. 
 The full Senate is expected to vote on the District budget next week and differences remain to be worked out by a House and Senate conference committee after the summer recess. But the votes this week are the latest sign that Federal lawmakers approve of the steps District officials are taking to reach a balanced budget by 1999, as required by a 1995 law that created a control board to oversee District finances.
"This shows our transformation plan is working," said Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., referring to a four-year strategy to redesign the city government and bring spending under control. "It means we have more credibility now; our plan for the future has been accepted by Congress and the control board. And it demonstrates the rightness of my policies."
The House approved a $4.99 billion budget for the District and provisions that the District could not spend Federal or local money for abortions and could not provide health-care benefits for unmarried domestic partners of city employees.
The House version also included a limit of $40 million for the 1997 budget deficit, which is projected to reach $99 million without more spending cuts. That stipulation came largely at the behest of Representative James T. Walsh of New York, chairman of the District subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee, who has been pushing the District hard to make deeper cuts. He also insisted that an additional $59 million in cuts be implemented.
The control board and the Senate Appropriations Committee approved a $5.1 billion budget for the year. The Senate version did not include the restrictions on spending for abortions and domestic-partner benefits.
"I felt it was important to reward them," Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on the District, said after the vote, referring to the city. "I believe there are some areas where the priorities demand more spending."
For Mr. Barry, a Democrat who returned to office in 1994 to confront a deficit that was projected to reach $722 million in his first year, the votes this week were a major political victory in that a Republican-led Congress was validating his approach to solving the city's worst financial crisis.
Although Mr. Barry battled with the control board to save jobs and programs for the 1997 fiscal year, which begins on Oct. 1, he and the board reached agreement on a budget that brings the deficit down from $116 million for the current fiscal year. The district is required to balance the budget by 1999 and keep it balanced for another four years before the control board would disband.
But when the House subcommittee considered the consensus budget, Mr. Walsh insisted that another $59 million in spending be eliminated. Mr. Barry and Andrew F. Brimmer, chairman of the control board, argued strongly that cuts of that size would decimate vital programs for city residents.
"There's no rationale for his cuts," Mr. Barry said today. "I'm hopeful that the Senate will stand firm and Mr. Walsh will relent."

HEADLINE: SENATE APPROVES SWEEPING CHANGE IN WELFARE POLICY;
BIG ROLE TO STATES

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
The Senate approved a comprehensive welfare bill today that would end the longstanding Federal guarantee of cash assistance for the nation's poorest children and give states vast new power to run their own welfare and work programs with lump sums of Federal money.
The vote was 74 to 24. Democrats split, with 23 voting for the bill and 23 opposed. Fifty-one of the 52 Republicans voted for the measure, which calls for the most sweeping welfare changes since the New Deal and is similar to the House bill passed last week. [Roll-call, page A22.] 
 The Senate approved only two of the four amendments most ardently sought by President Clinton, who said he would insist on further "improvements" as a condition of signing the legislation. One would guarantee Medicaid coverage for people who might lose such health insurance because of new restrictions on welfare eligibility. The other would retain the Federal guarantee of food stamps for the poor, denying states the opportunity to set eligibility and benefit standards for food aid financed by the Federal Government.
Campaigning in California, Mr. Clinton welcomed changes by the Senate but said more were needed.
"You can put wings on a pig, but you don't make it an eagle," the President said. "We want real welfare reform.
"Today the Senate took some major steps to improve the bill going through Congress. If we can keep this progress up, if we can make it bipartisan, then we can have a real welfare reform bill that honors work and protects children."
Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, said: "History will praise this day. A system that has failed in every aspect will now be thrown away. We'll start over with a new system that has a chance of giving people an opportunity instead of a handout."
But Senator Carol Moseley-Braun, Democrat of Illinois, said: "I believe that the Senate will rue the day that we passed this legislation. This day, in the name of reform, the Senate will do actual violence to poor children, putting millions of them into poverty who were not in poverty before."
"This bill is election-year politics and rhetoric raised to the level of policy," Ms. Moseley-Braun added.
The Senate measure, like the House bill, would impose a five-year lifetime limit on cash assistance payments to any family, and states would be allowed to set stricter time limits.
Democratic support for the bill eroded today as the Senate rejected several Democratic amendments, generally on party lines. The Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, voted against the bill after hinting last week that he might vote for it. Only one Republican, Senator Lauch Faircloth of North Carolina, opposed the bill; he said it was not tough enough.
In a surprise today, the Senate narrowly rejected one of the four amendments sought by Mr. Clinton, a proposal that would have allowed states to provide vouchers or other forms of non-cash assistance to families denied cash benefits because of the time limits. The vouchers could have been used to obtain diapers, cribs, clothing, medicine or school supplies for children.
The House version of the bill does not allow the use of Federal money for such vouchers, and Republicans twisted arms in full view on the Senate floor today to make sure that vouchers would not be permitted under the Senate measure, either.
Democrats also failed to win approval for an amendments that would have allowed public assistance and social services for legal immigrants, who are denied aid under the Republican bill.
Moments before the final vote, the Senate Republican leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said: "If you really want welfare reform, this is it. This may be the last opportunity."
Welfare has become a major issue in this year's elections. Mr. Clinton has said repeatedly that he wants to sign a welfare bill, but he has sent mixed signals on the latest version.
Mr. Lott said Republicans would win, regardless of whether Mr. Clinton accepted the measure. "If he signs it, the country will be the beneficiary," Mr. Lott said today. "If he doesn't, he'll have to explain why."
One Democrat backing the bill, Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, said: "This bill is not perfect, but it is a major step in the right direction."
Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, summarized the case for the bill this way: "Welfare was never meant to be a way of life. It was meant as a temporary helping hand, a safety net to be used for a few months."
But Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a New York Democrat who is a longtime student of social welfare policy and who led opposition to the bill, said, "Senators such as I cannot conceive that the party of Social Security and of civil rights could support this legislation, which commences to repeal, to undermine, both." Mr. Moynihan and five colleagues said Mr. Clinton should veto the bill.
In September, the Senate passed a somewhat similar welfare bill, 87 to 12. Mr. Clinton signaled support for that measure but later vetoed the final version, saying it would impoverish more than one million children.
The new bill now goes to a conference committee of negotiators from the House and the Senate, who will try to resolve differences between the chambers. Republicans said they wanted to complete work on the bill by the end of next week so they could send it to Mr. Clinton.
Several Democrats who voted for the bill said they had done so mainly to move it to the next stage of the legislative process, and they said they might change their votes if protections for children were dropped in negotiations with the House. They said Mr. Clinton should not hesitate to veto the bill if it moved sharply to the right in the bargaining.
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House Republican leader, said the more conservative House would prevail on many issues where the chambers disagree. That would please some Administration officials, who call the bill as a potentially devastating blow to children.
"I hope Armey can push this bill to the right in conference" so it will become unacceptable to the President, one Administration official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said tonight. But Mr. Clinton's political advisers said they hoped he would get a bill he could sign.
These were the major actions today:
*By a vote of 51 to 48, the Senate refused to let states use Federal money to provide vouchers to families who reach the five-year limit on cash assistance.
*On a voice vote, the Senate agreed to guarantee Medicaid for people cut from the welfare rolls. The House bill has a similar provision, but it provides slightly less protection for poor people.
*By a vote of 53 to 45, the Senate eliminated part of the bill that would have allowed states to receive their food stamp money as a lump sum, or block grant. The House bill permits such block grants. The President strongly opposes this option, saying it would cripple the Government's ability to meet the increased demand for food assistance in the face of recessions or natural disasters.
*By a vote of 52 to 46, the Senate upheld provisions of the bill that would ban food stamps and many other forms of public assistance for legal immigrants who have not become citizens. The Senate rejected a Democratic proposal to continue such benefits for legal immigrants already in the United States.
Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, said the Medicaid amendment told states, in effect: "Go ahead if you wish, reduce eligibility levels for welfare. But Medicaid eligibility levels should remain as they are today."
The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the bill would save $60 billion over six years, mostly by cutting food stamps and benefits to legal immigrants. Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, said her state alone would lose $17 billion over six years.
Ms. Feinstein said the bill would affect more than one million Californians.
"They are aged," she said. "They are blind. They are disabled. They are children. This bill would immediately throw them off whatever assistance they have with no other recourse."
But Senator Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania, said: "People who come to this country sign a document that says they will not become wards of the state, and what's happening? Millions of people are coming to this country. They're bringing moms and dads over. Mom and dad qualify for Supplemental Security Income benefits. You and the taxpayers of this country are picking up the tab as we become the retirement home for the rest of the world."
The amendment to preserve the Federal guarantee of food stamps for the poor was offered by Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota. It won support from six moderate Republican Senators.
The Senate also approved an amendment offered by Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, that would deny welfare and Medicaid benefits to people convicted of drug crimes. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, criticized the proposal, saying it would prevent Medicaid from paying for drug treatment and prenatal health care in many cases.
Senator Roth denounced Mr. Clinton's proposal for vouchers, saying they "would seriously undermine the five-year time limit." Under the bill, Mr. Roth said, poor families could still receive food stamps, Medicaid, housing assistance and other aid after reaching the five-year limit on cash benefits.
"Over five years," Mr. Roth said, "a typical welfare family receives more than $50,000 in tax-free benefits. Five years is enough time to finish a high school degree or learn a skill through vocational training."
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, invoked Franklin D. Roosevelt as his authority for saying: "If people stay on welfare for prolonged periods of time, it administers a narcotic to the spirit. This dependence on welfare undermines their humanity and makes them wards of the state."
 
HIGHLIGHTS
Welfare Changes
 
Following are major provisions of the Senate welfare bill, which is similar to the House welfare bill:
 
* The Federal guarantee of cash assistance for poor children would end. Each state would get a lump sum of money to run its own welfare and work programs.
 
* The head of every family on welfare would be required to work within two years, or the family would lose benefits.
 
* Lifetime welfare benefits would be limited to five years. (States may set stricter time limits.) Twenty percent of families may be exempted because of hardship.
 
* States could stop payments to unmarried teen-age parents. Payments may be made only if a mother under the age of 18 stays in school and lives with an adult.
 
* States that reduce births to unmarried women would be rewarded with additional cash grants.
 
* About 300,000 disabled children from low-income families would lose cash benefits because of stricter eligibility standards in the Supplemental Security Income program. (Source: Senate Finance Committee, Congressional Budget Office.)
