HEADLINE: Officials Offer Expanded Plans to Rebuild Columbus Circle

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
New York City and state officials yesterday outlined their most comprehensive approach yet to rebuilding Columbus Circle, home to some of the city's most valuable real estate and some of its most reviled architecture.
Besides seeking developers to build a 59-story complex, including street-level stores and two slender towers, on the site of the New York Coliseum, economic development officials said they were also trying to sell 2 Columbus Circle, a 10-story, city-owned architectural curiosity that houses the city's Department of Cultural Affairs and the Convention and Visitors Bureau. 
 The plan was described by the officials as they released a long-awaited request for development proposals for the Coliseum site, at the southwest corner of Central Park.
By enlarging the development plan to include the far smaller site at 2 Columbus Circle, "we can create something entirely new for the entire circle, which is now a cut-up mess," said John S. Dyson, the former Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, who has headed the city's planning effort for the Coliseum site.
The Coliseum plan announced yesterday would resurrect a development scheme that in an earlier, somewhat larger incarnation had provoked New York City's most bitter development conflict of the 1980's.
The earlier plan, by the developer Mortimer B. Zuckerman, was to have included towers rising more than 65 stories. It was scaled back in 1990 amid a torrent of lawsuits and a deep real estate slump, and the deal finally collapsed in July 1994.
But officials hope that the new plan, coming at a time when the city's real estate market is gradually improving, has a better chance of success, in part because of other work already under way around Columbus Circle.
Indeed, the city and state are making available half of the real estate around Columbus Circle at a time when almost all the rest is being upgraded. Other projects around the circle include Donald J. Trump's conversion of the former Gulf and Western office building into an expensive condominium and hotel tower and the renovation of the southwest entrance to Central Park.
The city is also planning to reconfigure traffic patterns around the circle, eliminating lanes that bisect it and creating a relatively simple traffic rotary.
The statue of Christopher Columbus at the center of the traffic circle would be surrounded by a plaza that is larger than the current one, and made accessible to pedestrians by crosswalks.
Although the plan for large new buildings may provoke some of the same neighborhood criticism that erupted in the 1980's, officials said yesterday that it offered a chance to redeem Columbus Circle as a showplace of urban design.
"We are going to the private sector and saying, 'Think up something clever that will replace what has been referred to as the Mussolini architecture of this building,' " Mr. Dyson said, referring to the Coliseum.
Officials from the city, the state and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority -- the owner of the Coliseum -- said they would consider several options for the Coliseum site, including various combinations of housing, offices and stores. In its request for development proposals for 2 Columbus Circle, the city said it would consider the same range of options.
Mr. Dyson said the plan did not depend on finding a single developer to purchase both sites, but that the request for development proposals at 2 Columbus Circle had been timed so a proposal encompassing both sites could be considered. Developers are to be selected by the end of December for the Coliseum site, and by the end of January for 2 Columbus Circle.
Unlike the previous development plan, the new proposal for the Coliseum site restricts the size of any new building to what would be allowed under existing zoning. Mr. Zuckerman had won approval for buildings 20 percent larger than allowed by normal zoning, in exchange for his pledge to upgrade the Columbus Circle subway station.
The new plan does not require a developer to pay for subway station improvements.
Government officials, who have been preparing the new development scheme for more than a year, are known to have been in close touch with architects, environmentalists and community groups who opposed the 1980's plan, and have won widespread, if still qualified, endorsements.
Still, experts said yesterday that the plan could encounter protests and even lawsuits because it was guided, as was its predecessor, by the goal of selling development rights to the highest bidder.
That objective was reiterated yesterday by E. Virgil Conway, chairman of the transit agency, who said that obtaining the highest bid for the Coliseum was a "top priority."
Neither he nor other officials were willing to speculate on what the price would be, but there seems little chance of a bid even close to the $435 million that Mr. Zuckerman was willing to pay during the real estate boom of the 1980's.
The transit agency, meanwhile, has included $200 million in its five-year capital plan in anticipation of the Coliseum sale.
"My big concern is that price is going to drive the project," said H. Claude Shostal, president of the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit research group that fought to block the earlier Coliseum plan.
"We are clearly at a much better starting point," he said, praising the restrictions on the size of the project and efforts to coordinate any new buildings with other improvements in the area.
"But nobody has indicated how much weight they will give to urban design considerations versus the selling price," Mr. Shostal said. "The proof will be in the review and reward process."
Real estate executives said there was intense interest among developers, at least in the Coliseum site. Mr. Trump, Arthur Zeckendorf, Edward J. Minskoff and Stephen Ross -- all large-scale Manhattan developers -- are known to be preparing proposals for the site.
"It is clearly one of the great sites in Manhattan," said Martin Turchin, vice chairman of Edward S. Gordon Inc., a real estate brokerage. He said he expected bids and development proposals for the Coliseum from at least 10 Manhattan developers, and offering prices that may exceed the $200 million sought by the transit agency.
The city's offer to sell 2 Columbus Circle appeared yesterday to catch the real estate industry somewhat off guard. The building, originally erected as an art museum, has been repeatedly ridiculed by architecture critics -- the Manhattan guidebook of the American Institute of Architects calls it a "white marble confection" -- sits on a lot that is far smaller and less valuable than the Coliseum site.
Nonetheless, some executives said the idea of building on both locations presented intriguing new options.
"I haven't taken a serious look at 2 Columbus Circle, but I intend to," Mr. Trump said.

HEADLINE: A Polite Warning to Mr. Yeltsin

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund delivered an appropriately gentle wake-up call to the Russian Government this week. It delayed a $330 million disbursement in loans pending Moscow's action to raise tax collections toward previously agreed levels.
The delay was entirely warranted. The I.M.F. had agreed to lend the Government of President Boris Yeltsin about $10 billion over three years on condition that it adopt tight fiscal and monetary targets. The fund could not have let the budget shortfall go unchallenged if it hoped to maintain the credibility of its agreements to lend money to governments that promise to undertake fiscally prudent economic reforms. 
 Russia's tax shortfall reflects a fundamental, though solvable, problem. The Russian tax system is riddled with corruption, loopholes and atrocious administration. It has left Government coffers half-empty. The Government is simply collecting too little money to pay for infrastructure, education and research programs that the public needs. Federal taxes in the United States -- a relatively low-tax country -- equal about 20 percent of aggregate income. In Russia, they are only about half as high.
The Russian budget is unsustainable. It needs more revenue to beef up public sending. It needs more revenue just to pay for the shrunken Government programs that Mr. Yeltsin has kept in place. It is running deficits modestly above levels that he negotiated with the monetary fund.
Yet for all these serious problems, the fund wisely downplayed its decision to withhold loan disbursements pending a review next month. It issued no heavy-handed threats or criticism. None are warranted. Mr. Yeltsin has permitted finances to drift off track, in part by spending money to assure his re-election. But he has not allowed the deficit to soar out of sight of I.M.F. targets.
Indeed, the economic picture is much better than most observers in the West expected from a beleaguered President who started out hopelessly behind his Communist challenger in the polls. Mr. Yeltsin did promise to jack up wages and pensions of Government employees. Tax revenues plummeted -- falling, as a percentage of total income, by about half. The danger, during a campaign, was that Mr. Yeltsin would outspend his revenues by any amount to assure victory -- in effect by printing money that would eventually drive the economy over the precipice of hyperinflation.
Mr. Yeltsin did not go that far. The deficit rose, but he offset much of the impact of lower tax collections by cutting many Government programs. Indeed, Western observers fear that the spending cuts went overboard, jeopardizing important education and infrastructure programs. The budget-cutting has brought inflation down from about 4 percent a month to 1 percent. The value of the ruble is stable. In short, there are real problems -- real enough to require I.M.F. action -- but no imminent financial catastrophe.
The precise reasons for the tax falloff are unclear. Mr. Yeltsin created some of the problem by eliminating a tax on "excessive" wages -- a wise decision because the tax was shackling fast-growing enterprises. But he did not put another tax in its place. Also, some companies stopped paying taxes, waiting to see if the Communists would win the election.
In any case, Mr. Yeltsin will have to summon the political muscle to go after the handful of enterprises, estimated at about 20, that account for fully half the unpaid tax bills. He will also have to address the tax system as a whole and reform its inept administration. By some estimates, Moscow collects only about half the money its tax rates should generate. Besides starving the treasury, the system imposes a ruinous burden on some companies that do pay according to the law.
Because Mr. Yeltsin did not let Government finances get out of control during the campaign, the corrections he must now make are possible. He also has a new political mandate to proceed. The I.M.F., to preserve its authority, needed to deliver a nudge. It was wise not to deliver a shove.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Congress Passes Sanctions
Against Iran and Libya Trade
Setting up another conflict with America's trading partners, Congress approved legislation that would require the President to impose sanctions on foreign companies that invest heavily in Iran and Libya.
Despite threats of retaliation by European nations that do business in those countries, the House without dissent approved a tougher Senate version of the bill; President Clinton has said he will sign it. The new conflict follows a dispute over trade with Cuba that has put the United States at odds with Canada, Mexico and the European Union. [Page A1.]
 
G.O.P. Calls for Tax Cuts
The Republican leadership on Capitol Hill called for a program of sweeping tax cuts to be followed by basic change in tax law, raising the pressure on Bob Dole to follow suit as he formulates his economic platform. [A1.]
 
New Meat Scare
For Europe?
The European Union announced preliminary scientific findings that may result in banning as food parts of sheep, goats and venison because of a possible link to mad cow disease, or bovine spongiform encephalopathy, which has ravaged Britain's beef industry. [A10.]
 
House Passes Food-Pesticide Bill
The House of Representatives approved an overhaul of laws regulating pesticide residues in food. The bill eliminates a law that bars even trace amounts of pesticides in processed foods and would create a standard allowing only those levels that with reasonable certainty would cause no harm. [A18.]

Saks Holdings and the Isetan Company of Japan said they were assembling a plan to take Barney's Inc., the parent of Barneys New York, out of bankruptcy. But other suitors have also expressed interest. [D2.]

Andrew Ludwick, the president and chief executive of Bay Networks, said he would step down and that a succession plan was in place. But he declined to identify the successor or specify a time frame for the move. [D2.]

American Home Products, Schering-Plough and SmithKline Beecham all reported higher second-quarter profits, as rising sales of their flagship and newer medicines were only partly offset by declines in older products. [D4.]

HEADLINE: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: LEGAL IMPLICATIONS;
Families and Lawyers Are Warned That Airline's Liability May Be Limited

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
Although many bodies from the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 last week have yet to be found, some lawyers have already found clients to sue the carrier. The frenzy is on: lawyers have sent out press releases praising their expertise, and inquiries to members of the small coterie of aviation-law specialists are pouring in. A handful of families have already signed on.
But the District Attorneys of Suffolk and Queens counties, and the bar associations from Pennsylvania, Florida, and Texas as well as New York, have been warning lawyers that direct solicitation of clients is a crime. City and state bar officials are assembling a team of lawyers who will give free legal advice to relatives while refusing to accept any cases themselves, starting possibly as soon as today. 
 From all the ruckus, one would assume that out of a great tragedy, millions can be made. But legal experts say compensation from T.W.A. for this crash could be as low as $75,000 for each passenger.
"This is a very difficult case and the amount you can recover is very, very limited," said Kenneth P. Nolan, whose New York firm has been called by representatives of a half-dozen T.W.A. families.
Hans Ephraimson-Abt, whose 23-year-old daughter, Alice, died when a Soviet missile shot down Korean Air Lines Flight 007 in 1983, said families of the T.W.A. victims should be wary of lawyers hawking their services with promises of big cash awards.
"Clients should never even listen to any promises of money by lawyers because none of the promises are realistic," said Mr. Ephraimson-Abt, who has yet to see any money from the death of his daughter.
In fact lawsuits against T.W.A. could run into the same twofold problem that has slowed cases against Korean Air Lines: Flight 800 was an international route and it crashed in international waters.
Under the Warsaw Convention, a 1929 pact governing the liability of airlines, they do not have to pay more than $75,000 to families of passengers who died on an international flight. By contrast, a domestic aviation disaster would be subject to standard American law, in which plaintiffs have to prove only that the carrier was negligent to win their case. Awards are typically far more substantial, sometimes running into the millions of dollars.
In 1992, Japanese airlines announced that in some circumstances they might be willing to pay more than the $75,000 limit. American Airlines has also waived the limit in two recent crashes.
Some 40 American and international airlines have agreed to waive the limit, but this will not take effect until the agreement is filed with the Department of Transportation. T.W.A. is not yet part of that group, said Kent Martin, a T.W.A. spokesman. Such an agreement would not retroactively cover crashes.
There is another way for the $75,000 limit to be waived: if plaintiffs can show that the airline committed "willful misconduct" -- for example, that it knowingly ignored or violated standard safety measures. Then, new trials or settlements for more money can be sought.
Willful misconduct is difficult and expensive to prove. Lawyers have successfully overcome it in about 10 cases since the Warsaw Convention was signed. They did so in the Korean Air Lines downing, in which they proved that the pilot had strayed into Soviet air space; and in the 1988 bombing of Pan American Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, by proving that Pan Am did not match baggage with its passenger list.
But many awards in those two cases have still not been made. A ruling by the United States Supreme Court in January on the K.A.L. 007 case underlines the second potential problem in the T.W.A. case. If the Warsaw Convention limits are set aside by a showing of willful misconduct, another set of laws must be applied to determine damages.
To the chagrin of the Flight 007 families who had not settled their cases, the Supreme Court said that if a flight crashes in international waters and the plaintiffs are suing in an American court, damage awards will be based on a Federal law called the Death on the High Seas Act.
That act says survivors are not entitled to jury trials and that damages are confined only to the economic worth of the passenger to survivors. So the life of a middle-aged head of a family would be valued at far more than that of a retired person, a homemaker or a young child.
Teen-agers and college students like the members of the Montoursville, Pa., French club fall into a gray area: lawyers must show that the young person would have become a wage-earner and would have been able to give money to their parents out of their salaries.
Possibly anticipating such a situation, T.W.A.'s insurance agents have already asked families of Flight 800 passengers to fill out forms, stating whether the relative smoked cigarettes, said M. Victoria Cummock, whose husband died in the Lockerbie crash and who is advising T.W.A. families. While the medical examiner's office said it needed the forms to help identify the victims, Ms. Cummock said information in them could be used against families in settlement negotiations when the question of life expectancy and economic worth would be raised.
"I know that there were insurance forms and insurance agents who were there very, very early on," Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani remarked yesterday.
Calls to United States Aviation Underwriters Inc., T.W.A.'s insurance agency, were not returned.
The Death on the High Seas Act is invoked when a crash occurs more than a "marine league," or roughly three miles, offshore; the T.W.A. flight seems to have hit the water about 10 miles off Long Island.
The Warsaw Convention and the Death on the High Seas Act apply only to ticketed passengers. The T.W.A. crew and, possibly, off-duty staff traveling on the jet can claim even less than either the $75,000 or the economic loss: they can seek only worker's compensation.
But as Lee S. Kreindler, a lawyer for the Lockerbie plaintiffs, noted, if a problem with a security system or a mechanical malfunction is found that is not under the control of the carrier, all plaintiffs, including families of T.W.A. employees, may be able to seek much greater awards from other defendants. Those could include makers of the aircraft, like Boeing, or firms that oversee some aspect of security enforcement.

HEADLINE: Politics: Political Memo;
Clinton's Use of Incumbency: The Little Plans Loom Large

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 23

 BODY:
As President Clinton barnstorms the country these days -- ahead in the polls but running like an underdog -- his campaign proposals do not so much constitute a platform as a portable, flag-decked front porch planked with row after row of small but worthy ideas.
In the last few months, the President has come out in support of curfews for teen-agers, uniforms in schools, a national registry of sex offenders and a crackdown on deadbeat dads. He has come out against truancy, violence on television, teen-age smoking and teen-age sex. He hardly ever proposes spending Federal money or passing a new law or imposing an ironclad new rule. 
 Instead, Mr. Clinton asks cities, states and the private sector to join him, making it sound like an irresistible crusade, to "go raring into the 21st century united and strong," as he put it in an address to high school students outside Los Angeles on Monday. And in doing so, even his opponents concede, this President has refined the time-tested technique of taking credit for the sunrise into a high political art.
"They may be small, but they do something for somebody and in that sense, they're real news," Marlin Fitzwater, who was press secretary for both Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, said of Mr. Clinton's patchwork of proposals. "Under normal circumstances, you'd just let a Cabinet officer take credit for things like this. Some people will scoff at it, but nevertheless it's effective. I think it's working; he's doing a good job."
Today, Mr. Clinton's topic was domestic violence and, as the son of an abused mother, he's against it. But speaking at a women's crisis center here, he floated a fresh idea to help combat the problem: freeing up the chronically overburdened 911 operators so they can handle more serious calls, like those concerning domestic abuse, by establishing a new, nationwide telephone number for nonemergency calls. "We need a new, national community policing number that's just as simple and easy to remember as 911, so that if you have a tip for the police, if you see a suspicious activity, if a car alarm is going off, you will still be able to call a community policing number," Mr. Clinton said. "But if you have a real emergency, like domestic violence, you can call 911, and this time, your call will go through."
Mr. Clinton did not suggest what he thought such a number should be, or that he would require one to be created. He simply asked the Attorney General to work with the Federal Communications Commission, law enforcement leaders and the telecommunications industry to "develop" one, by an unspecified future date.
To be sure, in every speech, Mr. Clinton dutifully cites his legislative agenda and its more substantial items -- like raising the minimum wage, expanding health insurance coverage and passing new tax credits for college tuition -- most of which is stalled in the Republican-controlled Congress. But he seems to come most alive when he turns to the less sweeping topics.
The President's strategy, developed in collaboration with his adviser Dick Morris, was born of necessity after the Republican Congressional sweep in the 1994 elections tied his hands legislatively. But it has borne fruit beyond the fondest imaginings of most White House aides.
It has the added advantage of letting Mr. Clinton seem upbeat and forward looking, without simply bragging about an overall record of good economic news that he often acknowledges has yet to hit home with the public.
Or as Mr. Clinton put it in his speech to students at Monrovia High School, outside Los Angeles, on Monday, "We know that big statistics don't matter in individual lives unless good things are happening in individual lives -- in families, on blocks, in communities."
In traveling around the country making such proposals, Mr. Clinton has gone the traditional incumbent's strategy one better. Instead of just basking in the Rose Garden, looking Presidential, he is a figure of constant motion, combining a sitting President's majesty with a challenger's energy.
White House aides were quick to note that the original 911 number grew out of the recommendation of President Lyndon B. Johnson's Commission on Law Enforcement in 1967. The Justice Department has been quietly working on the idea of a nonemergency alternative to 911 and is planning a pilot project with the City of Baltimore.
George Stephanopoulos, senior adviser to the President, said Cabinet members and agencies were conditioned to provide regular recommendations of such programs for Presidential attention.
The proposals fit several patterns: those that cost Government nothing (requiring school uniforms), those that are paid for by the private sector (the 50,000 cellular telephones to be donated by the cellular phone industry to neighborhood watch groups) and those that cost little and are paid for by reallocating money already appropriated (the $10 million from the Education Department to help school districts devise anti-truancy programs). Mr. Clinton has even gone so far as to simply re-announce programs already under way (the effort by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms to track guns used by teen-agers).
Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Clinton, campaigning as a retooled moderate with an abiding belief in the power of Government to do good, has an advantage over his Republican rival, Bob Dole, in touting such programs.
"It's tougher for a conservative who's running on a deficit reduction platform, plus a possible tax cut," Mr. Fitzwater said. "I think this puts a big onus on Senator Dole to come up with his tax cut plan, so he can argue that people could take economic advantage of that to help themselves, open their business, hire two more people and so on."
The White House spokesman Michael D. McCurry said he had no worry that the profusion of such pronouncements risked making the President seem small.
"Is this a Presidential-level announcement?" he asked of the the 911 idea. "You bet. Let's work inch by inch to change people's lives positively."
 
BILL CLINTON
 
Speaking at the Women Escaping a Violent Environment Counseling Center in Sacramento, Calif.
 
"We cannot do what we need to do on the issue of domestic violence unless we do something about the stunning fact that the 911 emergency number system today is completely overburdened. Today, it is groaning under the weight of hundreds of thousands of calls a year. Victims of domestic abuse, victims of all violent crime, are having a harder and harder time getting through. Sometimes they have to wait up to 30 minutes for the phone to be answered. That can be way too long. Sometimes they never get through at all. . . .
The reason for the problem is simple and straightforward. Today most calls to 911 are important and serious, but they're not emergencies. They should be handled elsewhere. In some areas, 90 percent of all the calls to 911 are not emergencies. Callers may have a legitimate reason to reach the police, but their calls don't involve crimes in progress or life-threatening situations that need immediate action through 911. It just is the only number they know and so they call it.
So I have asked the Attorney General to work with the Federal Communications Commission, our nation's law-enforcement leaders and the telecommunications industry to relieve the burden on 911 by establishing a new number like 911 for nonemergency telephone calls to the police."

HEADLINE: Sweatshops Contribute to Global Wage Gap

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your July 18 front-page article that says that many workers see their employment in Honduran sweatshops as "the surest road to a better life" points up the complexity of the debate. But that debate should be centered not on whether the apparel assembly plants are good for a country's development but on the responsibility of corporations doing business in these markets to children.
These companies sell their products mostly in Western markets while producing them in areas with the lowest labor costs. Because of these corporations' access to the West, which recognizes basic notions of human rights and decency, it is also incumbent on them to carry out basic notions of human rights and decency in the markets that produce their products. These corporations often are the only ones with the economic power to adopt human rights in the emerging markets. 
 An illustration is Charles Veillon, a Geneva textile importer that implemented an ethical code of conduct for its suppliers in Pakistan and provided financial assistance for education, training and medical care for children there who were being exploited. Charles Veillon was able to make this investment because it reduced the number of its suppliers and entered into longer relationships with them. The suppliers agreed to random audits of their shop floors to assure that they complied with the new code of conduct.
For these achievements, Charles Veillon was awarded the first International Business Conscience Award by the New York-based Council on Economic Priorities last month.
 
ALBINA DU BOISROUVRAY
Geneva, July 17, 1996
 
The writer is the founder of Association Francois Xavier Bagnoud, a Swiss foundation seeking reform of international child labor practices.

HEADLINE: Land Clearing Starts for Brooklyn Hotel

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
After years of setbacks and with little fanfare, bulldozers began uprooting dozens of trees in a scruffy Brooklyn park last weekend to make way for a major development that will give Brooklyn its first large hotel since the 1930's and is widely considered a key to downtown renewal.
The razing of the park signals the end of 13 years of struggles to secure financing and prospective tenants for the $230 million hotel and office complex known as Renaissance Plaza, a 32-story tower that is to include a 384-room Marriott Hotel. 
 In a borough that has struggled somewhat self-consciously under the long shadows from across the East River, the development has been envisioned as the final validation of downtown Brooklyn's emergence as a business and commercial center.
The development, one of several major construction projects in Brooklyn that are reshaping the aging skyline, will add more than 2,100 new jobs. Developers and city officials hope the complex will give a renewed sense of vibrancy to the downtown district.
"It's a key element of the total revitalization of downtown Brooklyn," said Joshua L. Muss, the Queens developer of the project. "It's going to further prime the pump to start another wave of development."
Planned for a city-owned site bounded by Jay and Adams Streets, the 810,000-square-foot Renaissance Plaza is seen as the centerpiece that will link the area around Court Street, the courthouses and municipal buildings to newer developments nearby, like Metrotech, a $1 billion commercial and academic complex, and Atlantic Center, a $530 million retail and housing complex.
After years of delays, the project moved forward in the last two weeks after the final financial piece fell into place with the signing of an agreement between the developer and the Leucadia National Corporation, which is based in Manhattan. One of Leucadia's subsidiaries, the Empire Insurance Group, will be a principal tenant, renting nine floors.
The other principal tenant will be the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, which will lease 14 floors and consolidate its scattered operations under one roof. Marriott has signed to occupy the first seven floors as a hotel. The hotel is to include a business center, a health club, an indoor swimming pool, a major ballroom and more than 30,000 square feet of convention and meeting space.
Mr. Muss, the developer, and Geary Campbell, a spokeswoman for Marriott Lodging in Bethesda, Md., said extensive market surveys show that the hotel will attract business travelers and out-of-towners visiting friends and relatives in Brooklyn.
Greg Brooks, executive assistant to Borough President Howard Golden, said, "If you ask the Brooklyn business community what is the one thing they are really lacking, most would tell you it's a new hotel."
Small hotels and motels have been built along major thoroughfares in Brooklyn, but no large hotel has been constructed since the era of the great hotels in the 1920's, when the Granada and Towers hotels were built, and the St. George Hotel underwent an extensive renovation in 1930.
Since the latest project was conceived, it has been mired in discussions over financing, possible tenants and companies to manage a hotel. And with back rent due on the land and no firm plan to finance a hotel last year, the city had threatened to take back the property.
Partners in the development are Mr. Muss; Leucadia, a holding company, and the Carlyle Group, a merchant bank in Washington that specializes in mergers and acquisitions.
The financing for the project included the sale of $135 million in bonds backed by the leases and underwritten by Paine Webber. The city is to contribute up to $20.5 million to the project, including the construction of the underground parking garage, and up to $27 million for tenant improvements Mr. Muss said. The Borough President has allocated $3.9 million in capital budget grants for the project, with a portion of it for tree replacement, Mr. Brooks said.
The Renaissance Plaza is expected to generate $306 million in economic activity each year and as much as $9.9 million annually in tax revenues. The project is expected to be completed within two years.
Although final deals were worked out nearly two weeks ago, Lonnie Soury, a spokesman for the developer, said yesterday that there has been nervousness about making a public announcement because of the project's troubled past.
The project has suffered so many setbacks that many residents and office workers were stunned to learn that it was actually taking shape.
"I had my doubts," said Marcel Sager, a civil lawyer in Midwood who graduated from Brooklyn Law School in 1986 and knew of the project when he was a student. "Brooklyn has had its ups and downs. They've been talking about this for such a long time."
John Breza, a contractor who lives in the neighborhood, has organized a citizens' group to investigate how the park came to be razed without notice and without regard for trees that date back half a century. "They really didn't expose this too well or try to look for alternatives and try to save open space," he said. "We believe city parks should not be touched."

The development is expected to add more than 2,100 new jobs. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times); Renaissance Plaza is to include a seven-floor Marriott Hotel. (Rubenstein Associates)

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Acquittal in Odd Drug Case

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: SOMERVILLE

 BODY:
When Matthew Jack of Plainfield got into a minor auto accident in Montgomery Township in February 1995, the police found something in his wallet that looked like a bouillon cube and contained the hallucinogen bufotenine. Mr. Jack, 31, an unemployed metal worker from Guyana, was charged with drug possession, but he claimed that the cube was "Black Stone," an over-the-counter product that is used to delay ejaculation. 
 Rejecting a plea bargain, Mr. Jack chose to risk five years in prison by going to trial. A state police chemist testified that since 1995, bufotenine has become increasingly popular, said Erin Smith, a Somerset County special deputy attorney general. But yesterday, a jury acquitted Mr. Jack.

HEADLINE: With Karadzic Out, 'Moderate' Serbs Are Hopeful

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: BANJA LUKA, Bosnia and Herzegovina, July 23

 BODY:
As they try to carry out the Dayton peace accord and its vision of a unified, multi-ethnic Bosnia, American and European officials have spoken hopefully about the emergence of "moderate" Bosnian Serbs.
Their hope is that the moderates could counter the power of Radovan Karadzic, the political leader accused of genocide and other war crimes. 
 Once Dr. Karadzic's tight grip on his people is loosened, the theory goes, a less hard-line opposition, willing to work with the Muslims and Croats in a single nation, might gain power, perhaps even in the elections scheduled for Sept. 14.
These hopes have centered on Banja Luka, the only city worth the name in the half of the country held by the Bosnian Serbs, a leafy city of sidewalk cafes and stately buildings with a cosmopolitan air that contrasts sharply with the peasant village of Pale, where Dr. Karadzic's government has its headquarters.
Opposition parties are indeed sprouting here, but moderate is a relative term, and how much the emerging leaders differ from the Pale crowd in their attitudes about Bosnia, and living in harmony with a Muslim majority, is not clear.
Groups emerging to challenge the Serbian Democratic Party, headed until last week by Dr. Karadzic and still controlled by his allies, range from monarchists and a party headed by the notorious warlord Arkan to extreme nationalists to Communists.
But the only opposition groups given any chance of doing well against the dominant party of Dr. Karadzic and his followers are both here in Banja Luka. They are strong because much of Bosnia's Serbian population is in the Banja Luka area and because their leaders enjoy popularity there and have established political organizations.
One is the Socialist Party of the Serbian Republic, headed by a former factory manager and former Mayor of Banja Luka, Zhivko Radisic, 58. This party is effectively the Bosnian branch of the Socialist Party of Radovan Milosevic in Belgrade -- the Serbian President whose drive for a "greater Serbia" is seen by many as a main cause of the four-year Bosnian war.
The other party is the Democratic Patriotic Bloc, led by Predrag Radic, 55, the current Mayor of Banja Luka. He watched as most Muslims and Croats were violently expelled from his city and all its mosques were burned down. But he is said by Western officials to be more a pragmatist than an ideologue, and he disclaims responsibility for war excesses.
The clash between the opposition and the ruling party here seems to be more about power than drastic differences in philosophy. It reflects a historic feud between Banja Luka and the rest of the Serbian-controlled parts of Bosnia.
The Banja Luka leaders also complain that Mr. Karadzic excluded them from his inner circle, and they say that a Pale clique has grown rich from war profiteering.
Ideologically, the differences between the opposition and the party in power are narrow. Mr. Radisic and Mr. Radic each said, for example, that he would not surrender Dr. Karadzic to the international war crimes tribunal. And each said the West had no business forcing Dr. Karadzic to resign.
Moreover, they said, his forced departure from office, if not behind-the-scenes power, last week, engineered by Washington and Belgrade, only gave Dr. Karadzic's party an electoral boost. More than ever, they said, he can be portrayed among Serbs as a hero felled by the West.
In interviews, Mr. Radisic and Mr. Radic avoided direct answers to a question central to the future of Bosnia and the Dayton accord: will the the Bosnian Serbs be part of Bosnia or unite with the Serbian motherland?
In this labyrinth of elections, each man is running for President of the Republika Srpska, as the Bosnian Serb political entity is known. Reflecting how little difference there is between their two coalitions, their parties share the same candidate for the Serbian spot on the three-member federal presidency of Bosnia.
"I'm very pessimistic," said Spasoje Perovic, 59, a Banja Luka journalist who calls himself an independent. "I don't think these elections will bring major change."
Mr. Radisic is a former Communist who was Banja Luka's Mayor in the 1970's when Yugoslavia was still united under Tito. In the 1980's he worked in the Defense Ministry in Belgrade. His two sons fought with the Bosnian Serb army during the 1992-95 war.
Mr. Radic has been criticized by Western human rights organizations because he was Mayor here during the war, when every mosque in this city was destroyed -- along with many Catholic churches -- and most Muslims were forced from the city, along with other non-Serbian ethnic groups.
Mr. Radic blamed the violence on mobs he could not control -- Serbs from other parts of the country who were taking revenge for the destruction of their houses, churches and cemeteries.
Among the opposition, the only democrat and believer in a multi-ethnic state, Western officials and local journalists say, is Miograd Zivanovic, 45, a philosophy professor at the University of Banja Luka, who is the head of the Liberal Party.
"I think that our future is with Bosnia and Herzegovina," Mr. Zivanovic said in an interview. Mr. Zivanovic has made several trips to Sarajevo since the Dayton accord was signed last November. Neither Mr. Radisic nor Mr. Radic has yet ventured to the Bosnian capital.
With that attitude, and a fledgling party, Mr. Zivanovic considered his chances of success in the elections so slim that he joined the Union for Peace and Progress, a coalition headed by Mr. Radisic's Socialist Party.
"Defeating the S.D.S., that is the most important thing," Mr. Zivanovic said, using the Serbian initials of Dr. Karadzic's party, in explaining why he joined in a coalition that includes an array of Communist organizations.
It will not be easy. The ruling party controls all of the radio and television in the Bosnian part of Serbia, and most jobs in a state-run economy.
But Mr. Radisic has a powerful benefactor in Belgrade -- President Milosevic. The Socialist Party of the Republika Srpska is effectively a branch of the Yugoslavia Socialist Party, which means, among other things, money.
"Choose your poison," said one Western analyst, noting the choice in an election that comes down to Milosevic Socialists, who have shown little inclination to democracy or a market economy in Yugoslavia, or the Serbian Democratic Party, still led by men and women who are strong Serbian nationalists and disavow Dayton.
"If you have to choose between two evils, better to choose socialists than nationalists," said Radmila Karas, 33, a Banja Luka journalist, explaining why she would vote for Mr. Radisic's alliance.
Mr. Radisic and Mayor Radic indicated that their preference was for a Bosnian Serb republic closely integrated with Yugoslavia, though how close, they avoided saying exactly.
Whatever the future, it should happen peacefully, like the separation between the Czech Republic and Slovakia, Mr. Radisic said.
"War for nobody, for nobody," he said, with deep emotion.
To that extent, they may offer a change from the past.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Bounces Back on News From Germany and Japan

BYLINE: Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar shrugged off a drop in Wall Street stocks yesterday, as currency traders took heart from growing prospects of lower interest rates in Germany and receding fears of higher rates in Japan.
 
 In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 107.86 yen from 107.44 on Monday. The dollar traded at 1.4890 marks from 1.4850. The British pound rose to $1,5526 from $1.5505.
 The dollar briefly dropped to a two-month low of 106.95 yen over-night in Asia on lingering worries over a possible rate increase in Japan. The dollar moved back above 107 yen, however, as traders awaited the Bank of Japan's quarterly economic outlook for clues on the direction of Japanese interest rates.
 Some traders expected the central bank's survey to point to a credit tightening, but the surprisingly bleak tone of the report halted speculation of higher interest rates, helping lift the dollar toward 108.00 yen. The Japanese central bank said the economy was moving toward and self-sustained recovery but at a slow temp.
 "People were expecting a rate hike and disappointment was reflected in the market, with the dollar rising close to 108 yen," said Jeffrey Yu, senior dealer at Sanwa Bank.
 The dollar advanced against the mark in Europe on expectations of a 25-basis-point cut in German interest rates when the Bundesbank's policy-setting committee meets tomorrow. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
 Expectations of lower German rates were encouraged by comments by Ernst Welteke, a member of the Bundesbank's policy-setting committee meets tomorrow. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
 Expectations of lower German rates were encouraged by comments by Ernst Welteke, a member fo the Bundesbank council, who said the central bank would seriously discuss a change in short-term rates if economic data allowed.
 "The impression that the Japanese are not going to raise rates and the possibility the Germans will lower rates is a counter to the general negative sentiment on the dollar," said Peter Wadkins, vice president at Standard Chartered Bank.
 Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin also helped the dollar when he told reporters in Washington that he saw no signs of inflation heating up and predicted the continuation of solid economic growth with low inflation.
 Marginally higher stock prices helped lift confidence in the dollar in early New York trading. But stocks later tumbled.

HEADLINE: Art and Sobriety, One Day at a Time

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL 

DATELINE: TROY, N.Y.

 BODY:
THE asphalt-shingled house in Troy looks like thousands of others that were built for laborers in the late 1800's, when work abounded. Such houses faded, like the ambitions of those who inhabited them, when opportunity moved elsewhere.
But 437 Sixth Avenue shelters neither dwindling expectations nor broken dreams. It is the headquarters of the Hermitage des Artistes, a collective of five artisans, all recovering alcoholics, who have whittled together a renaissance of tramp art and reclaimed their own lives in the process. 
 In the last five years, Michael Lavery, Andrew Stutter, Paul Cunningham, Ira Rogoff and Jim Kennedy have ferreted out discarded fruit crates, the preferred medium for contemporary tramp art, shaped the wood slats into decorative objects and carved some whimsy, some beauty, some hope into each piece. Notch by notch. One day at a time.
They have created music boxes and picture frames, patriotic and religious installations and allegorical sculptures in the rococo carving style that was first practiced by itinerant men after the Civil War.
Change the word "hobo" to "homeless," replace "an obsession with riding the rails" with "an addiction to alcohol and drugs," and the Hermitage des Artistes mirrors the cultural confluence that has always bred tramp art: a disenfranchisement that makes idle hands itch for useful work.
On a summer afternoon, electric fans creaked through the warren of carving nooks on the first floor of the house shared by the five Hermitage members. The scent of varnish mixed with the garlicky aroma of a stew simmering in the kitchen. Above the steady chip, chip, chip of knife blade against board, Pat Boone crackled on a battered radio, and Mr. Kennedy had one question for the dealer who called to announce a significant sale.
"Yes, of course, I know they bought it," he said emphatically, squinting through his bifocals like a batter trying to discern a hit from a foul ball. "But did they like it?"
Previous generations of tramps didn't deal in mass marketing. But pieces by the Hermitage des Artistes are now sold in 50 galleries and stores across the United States. The artists' work is displayed at the Smithsonian Institution, in dozens of folk-art museums, even in the Vatican Museum.
Today's tramps see a certain poetry in creating art from what society has discarded. They themselves were discards, they say. Tramp art is their spiritual path, their sobriety.
In the wake of the Civil War, the original tramps had their knives and "they had their pride," Mr. Rogoff said. "They didn't accept something for nothing, they didn't rob, they didn't hurt people, they took what society had thrown away and turned it into something beautiful."
Whittling a statue of Uncle Sam, Mr. Lavery said, "St. Frances told the monks that they could pray and meditate alone all they wanted, but if they didn't work at a craft, they'd never have a spiritual life."
The Hermitage des Artistes is more than a woodworking shop. It is a communal home, open to troubled wanderers, headquarters for lobbying on behalf of the Mohawk Indians, a meeting spot for environmentalists, a tramp-art archive and the spiritual center of a five-man support group of recovering alcoholics.
For each man, every notch he carves puts that much distance between himself and the streets. Or worse. "Eight years ago, I was homeless, I was insane, I was a drunk," Mr. Lavery, 48, said. "Today, I have a spiritual life, I have a craft, I have a home."
Every piece carved at the Hermitage tells the craftsman's story again and again and again. First there was alcoholism, spiritual bankruptcy and destitution. Then there was surrender, a sort of redemption and a covenant that included good works and abiding faith. Next came food, shelter and clothing. And finally diligence, art and serenity.
Like his colleagues, Mr. Lavery sees life in threes. To him, it is no coincidence that the basic cut in tramp art is a three-sided notch, the basic shape a pyramid.
"You need food, shelter and clothing to have belief, work and a spiritual life," he said, "but you need a spiritual life to appreciate food, shelter and clothing."
Hunched over the accumulating layers that will become Uncle Sam, Mr. Lavery is himself a burly pyramid: paint-spattered jeans and denim shirt, thick handlebar mustache, blue eyes piercing through folds of ruddy skin, a navy blue tam-o'-shanter. He has been carving since the winter of 1988.
Homeless, he had been a squatter at 437 Sixth Avenue, an abandoned store with adjoining tenements. His bed was a plank propped on two discarded radiators; he sponge-bathed in a sink that had no running water; he tried to stay warm. And he carved.
"I always carved," he said. Growing up in Rensselaer, N.Y., in the 1950's, restless and poor, he played in the rail yards and learned notch carving from the men who rode the trains. Unlike the other members of the Hermitage, Mr. Lavery dreamed of being an artist.
Mr. Stutter, 40, was formerly a fire-extinguisher repairman; Mr. Cunningham, 43, taught homeless children; Mr. Rogoff, 41, was a health-care worker; Mr. Kennedy, 59, foraged for rare books, which he sold when he could bear to part with them. Among his finds: first editions of Thomas Merton and Freud.
Each was handy and, as their drinking progressed and their careers foundered, each worked sporadically. Mr. Lavery renovated buildings, concentrating on using discards and found objects.
BUT by the winter of 1988, he was unemployable, he said. Huddled in a ratty sleeping bag, he put down the bottle of Gypsy Rose wine and picked up a carving knife again. He worked alone at first, peddling his wares outside the state office buildings in Albany. Through a series of coincidences -- though Mr. Lavery does not believe in coincidence -- he met Mr. Stutter.
Mr. Lavery taught Moose Stutter, the group's strong man, to carve; Moose, who had stopped drinking two years previously, taught Mike Lavery to pray. Then they met Huggy Cunningham, the tree lover, then Stats Kennedy, the brains of the Hermitage. Last fall, Mr. Rogoff, nicknamed Watercooler because he stands around gabbing, joined the group.
"I had to teach other men so that I'd have company, and I had to have company to stay sober," Mr. Lavery said. "We're a male support system, like a family, but better."
He considered the patriotic statue in his hands. "Troy was the home of Uncle Sam, you know," he said. "He was a butcher during the Civil War." In an adjacent cubbyhole, Mr. Stutter tacked layers of wood together to create a music box. In another tiny work area, Mr. Cunningham used cardboard templates to trace and then cut shapes that would become a picture frame.
The Hermitage des Artistes uses about 6,000 fruit crates a year, collected at dawn from supermarkets' Dumpsters. From discarded grape box to carved object, the wood, like the men who transform it, remains within the cramped 500 square feet that is their office, studio and shipping department.
Last year, the Hermitage produced 3,500 decorative objects, which typically sell for $50 to $150. Mr. Lavery also carved a diorama-size version of Noah's ark, populating it with Mohawk Indians fleeing the smallpox plague; a desk shaped like a locomotive; various pieces with a baseball motif, and a life-size statue of Kateri Tekakwitha, a young Mohawk who lived from 1656 to 1680 and is being considered for sainthood by the Roman Catholic Church.
"Kateri wants to be sainted, and we're part of the process," Mr. Lavery said. "We're leaning on the Pope." His statue of her is now in the Vatican collection.
As Mr. Lavery talked, Mr. Rogoff used hoof clippers to dismantle fruit crates, and Mr. Kennedy took telephone orders and scribbled a production plan.
After being discovered last August by Clifford and Gayle Wallach, Manhattan collectors and tramp-art experts who began to promote their work, the Hermitage artists received enough orders to keep them busy well into the next century.
"We're not a factory," Mr. Lavery said. "Every day we have to accept who we are and what we can do. I am working with some prisoners. I mean, you can give these guys all the psychotherapy in the world, but put a knife in their hands and give them some wood, and you'll see real changes."
Mr. Lavery's 15-year-old son, Chris, is showing promise as a carver, and Mr. Rogoff has ambitions for his son as well.
"Most of us were married," Mr. Lavery said. "We all miss our families. We all want to pass our craft, our experience, our strength and our hope along. That's part of the tradition."
Those who have studied tramp art question the romance of the road that the Hermitage des Artistes contends it is maintaining.
"The notion that these pieces were made solely by itinerant men in exchange for food and shelter and only in America is questionable," said Helaine Fendelman, whose book "Tramp Art," a catalogue for an exhibition at the Museum of American Folk Art in 1975, was published by Dutton.
"Notched carving," she said, "is common throughout northern Europe, Scandinavia and Russia, suggesting that immigrant craftsmen may have pioneered its use in this country."
While many small mirrors, frames and boxes were certainly carved by tramps in exchange for food, she said, larger pieces like tables and beds took decades to construct and were carved by settled, professional men.
Gerard Wertkin, the director of the Museum of American Folk Art in Manhattan, said that tramp art emerged initially just after the Civil War, when unemployment was high and industrialization was growing. The form was most common in upstate New York and in Pennsylvania, where cigar factories (hence the proto-American medium, the cigar box) were plentiful, but pieces have been found as far south as Texas and as far west as California. Tramp art faded when economic prosperity returned. The tradition was briefly revitalized in the years preceding the Depression.
As cybertechnology has emerged in the last five years, interest in tramp art has increased, and prices have taken a big jump. "The picture frame I bought for $400 five years ago recently sold for $1,200," said Mr. Wallach, the Manhattan dealer.
Why now? "Nostalgia, the simplicity, the ingenuity and the comfort of something handmade," Mrs. Wallach said. "And it's still affordable."
As Mr. Stutter wrapped the music box he had finished in pages of old sheet music, Mr. Lavery taped together discarded cardboard boxes to create a shipping container for his Uncle Sam.
He will paint the box with a scene from the life of the Hermitage des Artistes. Maybe a painting of the guys on the bus they bought from the Albany County Jail, which they use to tour the country, seeking out the homeless as well as other folk artists. Maybe the scene around the campfire when they stop at the end of the day and forage along the roadside for the makings of a stew. They've used squirrels, raccoons and stray cats, Mr. Lavery said.
Every shipping container bears hand-painted scenes from the men's lives. There is Mike Lavery, playing his banjo. There is Andy Stutter bowling on Friday night. There's Jim Kennedy reading, as usual.
The U.P.S. truck comes every day at 4 P.M. Everybody seemed a little sad to see the boxes stacked on the dolly. Mr. Lavery was pensive as he began to paint a picture of the Statue of Liberty holding a bundle on a stick.
Was he worried about the future?
"Not really," he said, "I've accomplished everything I set out to accomplish. I mean, it's going to be hard to top the Vatican Museum."
Did he have regrets about the past?
He ran his thick, calloused finger through the series of pyramids that formed the Uncle Sam he was about to ship. "I had to have my past to have my present," he said.
He waved his arm in an arc that seemed to bless the cramped workshop. "This," he said, "is as close to doing the Sistine Chapel as you can get."
 
Viewers Or Buyers' Sources Of Supply
 
THE antique tramp art above, all from private collections, dates from 1910 to 1940. Dealers at the Fall Antiques Show, Sept. 26 to 29 at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street, are expected to display about 1,000 pieces of tramp art. These stores in Manhattan carry contemporary tramp art, some by the Hermitage des Artistes: ABC Carpet and Home, 888 Broadway (19th Street); Leo Design, 413 Bleecker Street (West 11th Street), and the Museum of American Folk Art's shop, Columbus Avenue at 65th Street.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
USAir and America West Report Big Earnings Gains

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Two airlines, USAir and America West, reported healthy gains yesterday in second-quarter earnings.
USAir Group Inc. said its earnings increased 77.9 percent, as the airline cut capacity and filled more of the remaining seats with paying passengers. The company's net income rose to $200.8 million, or $2.71 a share, from $112.9 million, or $1.47 a share, in the second quarter last year. 
 Revenue rose 8.4 percent, to $2.15 billion from $1.98 billion.
Wall Street had expected the airline to earn $1.34 a share, based on the average estimate of 11 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. USAir shares rose 75 cents, to $17.625.
"Beneficial economic and industry conditions, coupled with the keen focus of our employees toward making USAir the carrier of choice, produced a record quarter," Stephen Wolf, chairman and chief executive, said in a statement.
The company, based in Arlington, Va., said its load factor, or the percentage of seats filled, rose to 71.1 percent from 67.0 percent.
Traffic for the quarter inched up six-tenths of 1 percent, to 10 billion revenue passenger miles, which represent the number of miles flown by paying customers. Capacity declined to 14 billion available seat-miles from 15 billion.
The company's cost for each available seat-mile rose almost 13 percent in the quarter, to 12.75 cents from 11.30 cents.
Much of that was caused by aviation fuel expenses, which rose 10.9 percent, to $170.6 million. Fuel prices rose 17 percent, to 61.87 cents a gallon from 52.71 cents. USAir's consumption of aviation fuel dropped 5.5 percent, to 276 million gallons.
USAir said it had set aside $41.2 million for its profit-sharing plan during the quarter. It also received $29.5 million from the subleasing of certain aircraft whose value had previously been written down.
The profit-sharing plan covers employees who took pay cuts in 1992 and 1993, when the company had heavy losses. The employees are now entitled to payments because the company is again earning money. About $73.7 million was paid in March as a result of profits for 1995.
Also yesterday, America West Airlines Inc. said an expanded flight schedule helped increase its earnings by 36 percent, even though they were depressed by special charges lingering from its bankruptcy.
America West, which is based in Phoenix, earned $28.4 million, or 58 cents a share, on revenue of $464 million in the second quarter. Last year, it earned $20.8 million, or 46 cents a share, on revenue of $400 million.
The average estimate of 7 analysts surveyed by IBES International Inc. was for earnings of 55 cents a share. The stock of America West slipped 12.5 cents yesterday, to $15.625.
The company's latest quarter included an $8 million noncash charge tied to the more than three years that the company spent under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The airline emerged from bankruptcy in 1994.
For the first half of 1996, America West earned $42 million, or 84 cents a share, up from $26 million, or 58 cents a share a year earlier. Revenue was $877 million, up from $746 million.
Last year, America West announced layoffs of 1,000 employees. The airline said last September that it would increase capacity by 29 percent over the next two years. America West, which has its primary hub in Phoenix, has also begun service to Anchorage, Detroit and San Antonio and has increased its service to 12 other cities. It also plans to start service to Miami and Cleveland.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Municipal bond investors could wind up in an I.R.S. crackdown.

BYLINE: By Sharon R. King 

 BODY:
BUYERS of municipal bonds beware: The Federal Government is cracking down on an illegal price-gouging practice in which bond underwriters overcharge municipal issuers for securities used to set up bond escrow funds. In the process, the I.R.S. may wind up hurting investors who bought the bonds.
This week, the Treasury outlined rule changes aimed at increasing bond issuers' reliance on a special type of Treasury security specifically intended for escrow accounts. By making the securities more attractive, Treasury officials say, they hope to encourage their use and eliminate the opportunities for underwriters to sell issuers Treasury securities at illegally high prices -- a practice known in the municipal bond market as yield burning. 
 Meanwhile, the Internal Revenue Service is setting up a one-year amnesty program to allow issuers who have sold deals tainted by yield burning to pay up.
If the issuers do not comply, the agency's weapon of last resort would be to declare that the tax-free bonds are taxable after all: a step that would, in effect, require investors to foot the bill for the underwriters' illegal behavior.
James Lebenthal, chairman of Lebenthal & Company, the New York City municipal bond retailer, called the I.R.S. strategy "a Kafka-esque nightmare." He added, "The lunacy is putting the issuer on the spot and saying 'Somebody is going to pay -- and I don't care if it is the victim, the perpetrator, the bystander or the bystander's mother-in-law.' "
The Treasury's latest moves are part of a broader effort to address yield burning, a practice that may have cost the agency billions of dollars in lost tax revenues. Here is how the practice works: To refinance their old, expensive debt when interest rates fall, municipalities often sell new bonds and put the proceeds into temporary escrow accounts. By law, those accounts cannot generate a higher rate of interest than the rate on the newly issued bonds; if they do, the excess is considered to be arbitrage profit, and it must be rebated to the Federal Government.
To comply with that law, issuers typically buy a mix of ordinary Treasury securities in the open market or special securities, called slugs, from the Treasury. In yield burning, underwriters sell the issuers Treasury securities at inflated prices, which cuts the yield to levels that appear to meet the escrow requirements but that also generate substantial profits for the underwriters. By some estimates, underwriters may have earned $2 billion to $3 billion of illegal profits from yield burning since the late 1970's.
The I.R.S. will not say how much money it thinks it can collect through this campaign, which could affect more than $270 billion of bonds issued since 1986. The bonds in question are known as advance refundings, which require the establishment of escrow funds and are vulnerable to yield burning.
But the I.R.S. initiative seems to offer little incentive for municipalities to bear the cost of checking the prices they paid for Treasury securities on those long-ago deals. And if issuers do not come forward, the tax agency has to catch them through a formal audit, which is likely to be aimed only at the largest issuers.
It is virtually impossible for nervous investors to determine whether their bonds were subject to yield burning, Mr. Lebenthal said, except perhaps by calling the issuing municipality and asking whether any yield burning occurred in the transaction. A response is unlikely, he added.
Some bond experts say the I.R.S. is likely to strip disputed bonds of their tax exemption only as a last resort. But the agency has taken such steps before. In the late 1980's, the I.R.S. declared taxable five municipal bond deals including two underwritten by the former Matthews & Wright investment bank. In the end, investors were spared the tax consequences only because those involved in the deals paid penalties to settle the dispute.

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton's Duty on Welfare

 BODY:
President Clinton says he might sign welfare legislation if Congressional negotiators improve the House- and Senate-passed bills in a conference committee. He should stop shadow-boxing. The House's bill is odious. The Senate's is only slightly less so. The conferees will produce a compromise somewhere in between. That is not a place a Democratic President should stand.
The conferees will hand the President a bill that, like the bills they will work from, will hurl more than a million children into poverty. It will slice food stamps by an average of $600 for families earning less than $6,300 a year. It will strip legal immigrants, including some elderly, of health insurance. It will, for the first time ever, tell workers who lose their jobs after years of steady work that they cannot collect food stamps for their children. President Clinton will find no honorable reason, in his own promises of welfare reform or the history of his party, to sign such a bill. 
 The President is right that the Senate softened some of the worst provisions of the House bill. The House bill would allow states to take over the food stamp program, thereby wiping out the Federal guarantees and benefit levels. The Senate bill would not. The House bill would set a limit of 90 days for food stamps for workers under the age of 50. That provision would deny food stamps to a worker who collected the stamps for three months in his 20's, worked steadily for the next 25 years and was then laid off. The Senate would limit food stamps to four months in any year. The House bill would strip Medicaid coverage from current and future legal immigrants. The Senate would cover many current immigrants.
Though better, the Senate's bill is offensive in other ways. It imposes a five-year time limit on benefits and some tight limits on food stamps, throwing millions into poverty who run out the string before they can find work. The Senate tells states to put recipients to work, but provides little money -- for job training and day care -- to make that mandate a reality. The Senate makes no effort to provide clothes, medicine or other necessities for children whose parents are cut off welfare. It also allows states to make huge cuts in their welfare spending without penalty. Nor does the Senate bill provide much money to handle swollen welfare rolls during recessions.
To find serious fault with the House and Senate bills is not to deny the need for reform. The welfare system discourages work, encourages dependence and can foster family breakdown. But Congress's arrogance in reshaping 61-year-old institutions is shocking. No one knows how time limits and many other provisions will work out in practice. Critics say they will pummel children and many innocent parents. The G.O.P. says that time limits will force recipients to take responsibility for finding work.
Maybe so. But there is no evidence that time limits will work as promised. If they do not, it is the children who will suffer most. If Congress were serious about reform, and not waging ideological vendettas, then it would watch what happens when states experiment with time limits and other reforms. Wisconsin has asked Washington for permission to impose time limits on welfare benefits and guaranteed work opportunities. Before Congress sets up an untested system nationwide, it might at least see whether such limits work in Wisconsin, which benefits from a flush economy and competent state government.
The Republicans think they have cornered Mr. Clinton. Either he will alienate his liberal constituents by signing their bill, they think, or he will alienate a huge chunk of the middle class by vetoing it. Mr. Clinton vetoed two previous G.O.P. measures, contending that they would hurt children.
With November looming, Mr. Clinton is wavering. He stopped his staff from producing a new estimate of the Congressional proposal's impact on children -- an estimate that would surely have shown that the new legislation is only marginally different from the bills he vetoed. Even without those official estimates, he knows very well what the consequences will be. He should also know he will be harming children and blemishing his record of compassion if he signs the Congressional bill.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKET;
Treasury Prices Post Sharp Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday after demand at an auction of five-year notes was weaker than expected.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond dropped 25/32 , to 874/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.04 percent, from 6.97 percent on Tuesday. 
 The Treasury sold $12.5 billion of new five-year notes, with the high yield at 6.625 percent -- higher than the 6.58 to 6.59 percent dealers had expected.
"Originally expectations were for a 6.58 percent yield, but had to push the yield back to 6.625 percent in order to get the auction done," said Jack Regan, chief market strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross.
The bid-to-cover ratio at the auction -- the total amount bid against the size of the auction -- was an unimpressive 2.16 to 1.
"The low bid-to-cover ratio we had yesterday and today," Mr. Regan, referring also to Tuesday's auction of new two-year bills, "have been the lowest in a long period."
Traders said it was likely that securities dealers ended up holding more of the issue on their shelves than they wanted, noting that there was a lack of interest among investors further along the yield curve.
But Mr. Regan said the poor auction results did not damage the bullish tone of the market, but dented it.
Robert R. Giordano, first vice president and Treasurer of Bank Leumi Trust Company of New York, said the poor outcome of the auction was understandable, especially with so much uncertainty swirling through the market.
"No one was bidding aggressively at this auction," Mr. Giordano said. "There was no real good reason to bid strong, especially with more supply coming in a few weeks and so close to the July employment report next week on Friday, which will have a huge impact on the market. And that number represents the last hope for those who still believe the economy will slow. If there is no sizeable reduction in the number, the Fed will tighten."
The bond prices did receive support from the stock market in early trading, after the Dow Jones industrial average plunged more than 70 points. But as stocks rebounded, bonds gave back those gains.
Still, "bond participants focused more on the bond market's internals today," Mr. Regan said, "and did not necessarily trade against the stock market's volatility."
Next week promises a number of critical economic reports. The data "could be chock full of surprises for both bonds and equities and could be the mental trigger for Fed action, perhaps earlier than the Aug. 20 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee," Mr. Regan said. "With that much apprehension there are few in the market that are willing to take strong positions now."
Mr. Regan says that for the balance of the week it appears the market will be trading in a range of between 6.90 percent and 7.10 percent on the long bond. "We did get to 7.05 percent today and we were at 6.93 percent earlier in the week," he said. "Tomorrow's June durable goods orders and existing-home sales should be market friendly because of the strong data in the prior months. Plus we will have the weekly initial jobless claims, so there will something for everyone."

HEADLINE: Liberties;
President Pothole

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif.

 BODY:
The big story on President Clinton's Western swing this week was that Newsweek sent Anna Deavere Smith as its White House correspondent.
Let's put aside the absurdity of Newsweek assigning the writer and actress, who played a White House press secretary in the movie "The American President" and is now working on a book and a play about political reporters, to cover a news story. 
 The White House was philosophical. "She writes plays and Joe Klein writes novels," said a top Clinton aide, slyly. "Newsweek has a precedent."
And certainly, if Ms. Smith was looking to document the fecklessness of the press, what better evidence than her own instant and bizarre accreditation?
Besides, the news magazine's editors were busy fitting Joe Klein for a hair shirt, wallowing in ethical angst and insisting that the author once known as Anonymous endure a short season in purgatory. The managing editor, Richard Smith, said Mr. Klein had to subject himself to "the full force" of the feelings of his hurt and jealous colleagues, allowing them to vent "individually or in small groups." (A 12-step program for pseudonymous authors.)
The real issue in sending the talented Ms. Smith on the campaign trip is whether it was unfair to give the President such tough competition in performance art.
Bill Clinton, after all, is a metamorphosis artist, performing the roles of New Democrat, Old Democrat, radical liberal and conservative all in his first term. He has gone from being a President with sweeping plans about changing the way government works to a President who wants to change people's lives "inch by inch," as his press secretary put it here on Tuesday.
Instead of the Great Society, Mr. Clinton now brings us the Itsy-Bitsy Society. Instead of a rendezvous with destiny, he has an appointment with detail. From grand, epic-making schemes of social engineering, he has come around to suggestions that we cross a few t's and dot a couple of i's.
What bold new visions will the President come up with next?
Will he ask Health and Human Services to make doctors stop putting really old magazines in their waiting rooms? Will he ask the Department of Transportation to take action on rumble strips?
Bob Dole's campaign is so clueless -- he's 27 points behind in California, a state he still thinks is in play -- that some in the party are faxing each other ideas about how to persuade him to step down.
But at least Republicans can take comfort that their 1994 revolution lives on at the White House, where Dick Morris, the protean consultant for the protean President, churns out teensy-weensy pronouncements on truancy, school uniforms, curfews and deadbeat dads that give Mr. Clinton the aura of principal, if not principle.
In Sacramento, the President took a firm stand against busy signals on 911. He bemoaned "the stunning fact that the 911 emergency number system today is completely overburdened," and said there should be another national number for non-emergency calls.
George Stephanopoulos puts the best gloss on the President's voluntary simplification, saying he's getting small because he's "already taken care of all the big things like the economy and inflation and unemployment."
But maybe the President who rode out of the West, Ronald Reagan, was the end of the era of big themes and big issues, fighting the Commies and getting government off people's backs. Maybe when Bill and Hillary Clinton's big ideas backfired in 1993, and when Newt Gingrich's big ideas backfired in 1995, Americans decided they preferred little stuff that speaks to their real lives, lives shaped by the end of the cold war and yuppie narcissism.
We seem to have decided that if we can't have a straight-talking President who articulates a consistent vision, we'd at least like someone who can get us some cellular phones for our neighborhood crime watch groups.
So it's come down to this: Bill Clinton is running for re-election on the promise that he will make himself useful. If he's not going to be a leader, we want him to be a fixer.
