HEADLINE: Trying to Fix Capital Where 'Everything Is Broken'

SERIES: MONUMENT TO DECAY -- First of three articles.

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES and MICHAEL JANOFSKY; Leslie Wayne also contributed to this article.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24

 BODY:
On any given day here in the capital of the richest nation in the world, nearly a third of the 16 water-pumping firetrucks are kept out of service to save money. Police officers dip into their own pockets to buy tires and put gasoline in squad cars. City clinics periodically stop testing for the AIDS virus because they cannot afford supplies. Local officials are dumping extra chlorine in drinking water to battle elevated levels of bacteria caused by eroding pipes.
The Washington of glittering monuments, world-class museums and graceful, leafy neighborhoods continues to captivate tourists, hordes of them. But in ways big and small, the Washington of cold municipal reality is falling apart. 
 Two decades into Washington's experiment in limited self-rule the city is virtually insolvent. Its bond rating is junk status. Its population, 706,000 just 20 years ago, has fallen to 554,000 -- the lowest since the beginning of the New Deal in the 1930's. While New York and other cities have registered lower crime rates, here crime is on the rise, and arrests are down. City contractors wait months to be paid. Public school employees are facing up to 12 days of furloughs in the coming academic year to help trim the school system's $7.1 million deficit.
And the people elected to run the city, especially Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., lost the trust of Congress, which has the constitutional power to oversee the national capital. Last year, Congress shifted much of the local power to a board of financial overseers, known locally as the financial control board, appointed by the President.
"Everything is broken," said Anthony A. Williams, the city's new chief financial officer. "This isn't just a car that has run out of gas. There is something fundamentally wrong with the car. The gas pedal doesn't work, and neither do the brakes."
Major efforts are now under way to fix things. The control board is pressing local leaders to cut more spending and reduce the size of city government. Mr. Barry has introduced a "transformation plan" to streamline the government. A White House task force has been formed to help city agencies improve services. These efforts were rewarded this month when Wall Street offered to help the city raise $220 million in short-term notes, the first time in 18 months that investors have been willing to lend money to the city.
In Congress, momentum is gaining to pass legislation to create a flat Federal income tax of 15 percent for District residents, a measure some lawmakers say would reverse the population exodus and encourage economic development.
And as a sign that confidence in the city and its efforts for change might be growing, the House on Monday passed the District's 1997 fiscal year budget by 332 to 68, and the Senate Appropriations Committee passed a similar version on Tuesday.
But as Federal and local officials strain to reverse the tumble into financial and physical decay, national lawmakers are beginning to suggest what was unthinkable a few years ago: that Washington's hard-won right to govern itself should be stripped away. After 100 years of being ruled through Congress, the District accepted a limited form of independence that is now under attack.
"The control board is the city's best hope to retain home rule," Speaker Newt Gingrich said recently. "If the politicians stop that control board from succeeding, I think it puts into doubt the whole issue of home rule."
The issue of home rule has special racial and historical poignance here in Washington, a black-majority city that had long been denied political independence by the white Federal establishment.
And while, in many ways, Washington's problems are similar to those of other large and aging American cities -- increasing poverty, rising crime, middle-class flight, Washington is not just any American city. It is the capital, with all the symbolism of great expectation that such a status implies.
"Washington, D.C., is the political center of the universe as we know it, and people could not believe it was bankrupt," said Representative James T. Walsh, the New York Republican who is chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees Washington's budget. "I was doing interviews with German, British, French and Australian TV outlets. They are astounded by it. How could this happen?"
It happened for a complex mix of reasons. But in the end, the prescription for failure was quite simple: In granting Washington home rule, Congress imposed a bad financial and political deal on the city, and local leaders made it considerably worse.
In their zeal to gain even limited independence, city leaders accepted numerous economic and political shackles on the government's ability to function:
*The District's revenue-generating powers are paltry, limited to income, property and business taxes: The only Federal help the District receives to offset its expenses is an annual payment, now $660 million, which even some members of Congress regard as inadequate. And it is barred from taxing the commuters who make up two-thirds of Washington's work force, or the 43 percent of property within its borders that is owned by the Government, diplomatic missions or private nonprofit institutions.
*Its financial burdens are large, and made larger by the city's general decline: It must pay for a variety of social-service programs, including Medicaid, which it splits with the Federal Government. (Most other cities pay nothing for Medicaid.)
*And as the only capital of a major democracy without a vote in the national legislature, Washington has little power to press its case on a national level.
"I think you could bring the smartest person from the Harvard School of Government down here, and he couldn't make this thing work," said Fred Cooke, the city's former chief lawyer.
But Washington has also been failed by its elected leaders, including Mr. Barry, who has been Mayor for 14 of the last 18 years, and Sharon Pratt Kelly, who was Mayor from 1990 to 1994, during which time Mr. Barry served six months in prison on a conviction for drug possession. Both championed a liberal ideology, unchecked by any conservative opposition, in which government provided jobs and services while paying too little attention to the city's budget and physical condition.
Mr. Barry, who describes himself as a child of the civil rights movement, acknowledged in an interview that some of his priorities were misplaced: "My focus was on social services, jobs and education. In retrospect, we should have paid more attention to roads and bridges."
And while that emphasis helped enrich and expand the city's black middle class, the inattention to roads and bridges helped drive them -- and the crucial tax base they represented -- to the suburbs.
But in recent years, the city's problems, and its efforts to address them, have been complicated by the racial and class strains that originated when the city was ruled in a high-handed manner by white-dominated Congressional committees.
That history has often served as a convenient foil for the city's political leadership, particularly Mr. Barry and his supporters, to deflect attention from their own managerial shortcomings, and from corruption in city government: In the 1980's, several of Mr. Barry's close associates went to prison on a variety of charges.
Now, allies of Mr. Barry have criticized the control board, and its chairman, Andrew F. Brimmer, as a vehicle for whites to retake control of the city. They have been especially angered by Mr. Brimmer's threat to dismiss the head of the city's human services agency, a longtime friend of the Mayor, for poor management practices.
"He's doing the white folks' bidding," said Lamont Mitchell, owner of the Imani Cafe in southeast Washington and a close friend of Mr. Barry, referring to Mr. Brimmer, who is black. "They want to get a foothold back in the city," he said. "They lost it through home rule, and they want to get back in charge."
Over the years, that kind of reaction has led whites, and some blacks, to abstain from criticizing the city, even in the face of poor delivery of services.
"There has been a genuine guilt about intervening," said Representative Thomas M. Davis 3d, the freshman Virginia Republican who heads the House subcommittee with general oversight authority for the District. "The difficulty has been every time Congress tried to intervene, people yell home rule or racism."
But as the control board has struggled to halt the city's slide, and as Mr. Barry has challenged its authority, there is a growing sense in some powerful quarters -- and a growing fear in others -- that Washington may need a drastically altered style of government or maybe even a new one.
"The District of Columbia government is a mess," Mr. Gingrich said in a recent television interview. "The fact is, it has to be overhauled."

District Life
From Potholes To Robberies
The problems in Washington never seemed worse than this year, when acts of man and nature combined to deny city residents many of their basic services.
As a stepchild of Congress, the District was virtually shut down along with other Federal agencies during a budget impasse that began last fall and lasted into the spring. With lawmakers unwilling to release money owed the District, the city stopped picking up trash; libraries and health clinics closed, and tourism, the main industry after government, slowed to a trickle.
Then came the blizzard of 1996, exposing the city's inability to perform even simple functions like plowing. While Mr. Barry took to the skies in a helicopter tour of city streets and pronounced most of them passable, residents wondered what city he was inspecting.
Only the Federal shutdown that kept thousands of workers home prevented total chaos along snow-blocked commuter routes. Finally, city officials admitted that the District had too few snow-removal vehicles and salt trucks and that many were inoperable because of insufficient financing to fix them.
The salt, sunshine and warming temperatures that finished clearing the streets only renewed attention on another major problem -- potholes. They were everywhere, growing in size and number, and city officials said it would take months to fill them.
But the disrupting effects of snow and potholes were only annoying examples of a city in free fall. Scarcely a week passes without evidence pointing to deeper, more systemic problems in virtually every city agency. Here are several recent examples:
*Mr. Barry disclosed that the city was paying Medicaid benefits to 20,000 ineligible people. He blamed the oversight on a faulty computer program, which is now fixed, he said, saving the city $15 million a year.
*After a fire at the Department of Treasury, firefighters acknowledged that the closest ladder truck could not respond because it was out of service. They also said that with so few trucks available, other parts of the city were left under covered during the fire.
*Two employees of the city's real estate tax agency were dismissed and four others placed on leave after officials found that they had used improper methods to assess 9,700 residential properties.
*The elevated levels of bacteria recently found in the District's water system violated Federal standards for the fifth time in a year. Carol M. Browner, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said the finding reflected "a pattern of deterioration, neglect and uneven operation."
*Recyclable trash, once picked up weekly, is now collected every other week.
Even major political figures are touched by the problems. Attorney General Janet Reno, the country's top law-enforcement officer, lives in a downtown building where Karin Vaughan owned a beauty salon and spa for years. In April, Ms. Vaughan closed the salon after a string of crimes, including an armed robbery of her customers.
"I wake up in the morning, and I want to cry," said Ms. Vaughan, who lost most of her $250,000 investment in the business. "It feels like a relative has died."

Home Rule
'They Didn't Get A Good Deal'
For 100 years before home rule, Washington had been governed by a Mayor and City Council appointed by the President, and before that a three-member Board of Commissioners. Much of Washington's decline has come as a result of the deal made to allow the city to govern itself.
When police officers, firefighters, teachers and judges moved from the Federal payroll to the District's, Congress did not provide money for their retirement fund. The liability then was $1.9 billion. Today, it has ballooned to $5.1 billion, in part because the District has maintained a generous retirement plan that includes two cost-of-living increases each year. Washington's Medicaid costs have also expanded, to $844 million, from $17 million in 1973.
In addition, the city inherited a set of books so poorly maintained that a $279 million deficit was not discovered for three years.
Without a state government to funnel taxes of non-city residents back to Washington, the estimated $18.5 billion earned in the city by suburbanites is lost to the District. And the Congressional ban against a commuter tax costs Washington $1.25 billion annually in lost revenue, city officials say.
"If you move out of New York to Westchester County, you still pay taxes to the state, which kicks back some to the City of New York in the form of state aid," said James O. Gibson, who was Mr. Barry's planning commissioner during the Mayor's first term. "Here, if you move, it's a 100 percent loss to Washington."
As a result, more than half the money in the District budget comes from local taxes. Other cities receive, on average, 75 percent of their budgets from state and Federal governments. In fact, other national capitals -- like those of the United Kingdom, France, Italy and Japan -- are generously subsidized by their governments.
The District's revenue problems are made worse by the fact that 43 percent of taxable land in Washington, most of it prime downtown real estate, is free of property tax because it belongs to the Federal Government, diplomatic missions or other tax-exempt organizations like the American Red Cross, the World Bank and Georgetown University.
Representative Julian C. Dixon, Democrat of California, and the former chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees Washington's budget, said of home rule: "I don't know if they got a bad deal, but they didn't get a good deal."
Former and current city officials generally agree that the city's negotiators took the deal because local residents thirsting for self-rule felt the prevailing winds of the civil-rights movement, which emphasized black political empowerment. After all, District residents only won the right to vote for President in 1964.
"Those of us who were fighting for home rule were so anxious to get some degree of freedom, we didn't examine what it was," Mr. Barry said. "We inherited a mess."
That "mess" has discouraged many would-be politicians from trying to build a career here. Indeed, working for the city is often perceived as a dead end, leading to no meaningful state or Federal office. In the mid-1980's, before he became chairman of the Democratic National Committee, the late Ronald H. Brown was urged by a group of civic leaders to run for mayor. He turned them down, asking, "Where do you go from there?"

Leadership
Creating Jobs, And Problems
For almost 10 years, the shortcomings of independence were masked by a robust local economy. An office building boom through the early 1980's transformed the downtown skyline and swelled the city treasury with new tax revenue. The city chipped away at its deficit. From 1984 to 1987, the population increased.
The good times paralleled Mr. Barry's early years in office, starting in 1978, and he quickly improved services and controlled finances, winning the support and confidence of the business community. But the boom years hid the underlying flaws of the city's leadership. And ultimately, Mr. Barry's policies made conditions worse.
While new tax revenue flowed in, the Barry administration ignored crumbling roads and bridges, and failed to invest in new computers, telephone systems or training programs for workers. It passed no tax cuts or other measures to attract new businesses.
Instead, the administration spent much of the money hiring more workers, expanding the city's employment rolls to more than 48,700 employees by 1990, from 39,000 in 1982. Those city workers helped create a loyal following for Mr. Barry, who won re-election in 1982 and 1986. They also reduced the city's welfare rolls.
"Marion's view was, 'I can put them on the payroll, pay them and get some tax money from them, or I can put them on welfare and pay them and get nothing from them,' " said a former Barry aide who spoke only on the condition of anonymity. " 'Either way,' he said, 'I'm going to be paying them.' "
But those new middle-class city employees eventually did what thousands of middle-class people have done before: move to the suburbs, in this case, of Maryland and Virginia, taking their tax dollars with them.
In 1988, the District tried to pass a residency requirement for municipal workers, but Congress blocked it. Today, 51 percent of the District government's workers live outside Washington's borders.
Mr. Barry argues that he did not add unnecessarily to the city payroll. He said he had to hire more employees to build up the police department and to run St. Elizabeth's Hospital, a psychiatric institution run by the Federal government that was transferred to the city by Congress in 1985.
"That was a mistake on my part," Mr. Barry said of accepting responsibility for the hospital, which meant adding 3,700 people to the payroll. "We wanted to demonstrate we were able to govern ourselves, able to manage all these big state, county and city functions. We should have said, 'No, thank you.' "
Around the same time, the city expanded programs, offering more social benefits than most municipalities, like full-day kindergarten for 5-year-olds, and half-day nursery school for 4-year-olds. It passed a law guaranteeing every homeless person shelter, and financed a university and law school for residents. By 1995, Washington, with an annual budget of nearly $5 billion, spent more on an annual per capita basis, around $9,500, than any other city in the country.
"The city provided the Cadillac of safety-net systems," said Jack Evans, a veteran member of the city council. "It never saw a model program it didn't fund."
Also in the mid-1980's, the national recession hit Washington, stunting economic growth, and crack cocaine made its first major impact on the city, overwhelming the police department and social agencies. As the exodus of the middle class quickened, Washington by the late 1980's became known as the "Murder Capital" of the United States.
Between 1985 and 1990, the District's population declined by almost 31,000 people, and another 49,000 left by 1995 -- a 12 percent drop in 10 years that included many middle-class taxpayers. Businesses also left.
"We left for economic reasons as well as the degradation of the city," said John Martin, chief financial officer of the Washington Consulting Group, a government contracting firm with 75 employees that left the District last year after 25 years. The company moved just across the city line to the suburb of Bethesda, Md., where Mr. Martin said the firm pays $12 a square foot for office space, compared with $30 a square foot in Washington, and where the office is closer for its employees who also chose to live in the Maryland suburbs rather than the city.
He said the state of Maryland also provided economic incentives, like moving and employee-training costs, benefits Washington was in no position to match.
As the District's economy flagged, evidence emerged that Mr. Barry was beginning his own downward spiral of drug use, alcohol abuse and late-night adventures that ultimately led to his 1990 arrest for smoking crack cocaine. Caught on videotape in a sting operation in a downtown hotel room, his instant response that he was "set up" became a national joke; his conviction and imprisonment became a symbol of corrupt government and an eroding national capital.
But even before his arrest, Mr. Barry's behavior had lost the city critical support on Capitol Hill. As Dwight Cropp, a senior aide to Mr. Barry in the 1980's, said, a common attitude among Federal lawmakers was: "As long as Marion Barry was Mayor of the District of Columbia, the Congress was not going to do anything to assist us."
In November 1990, Mrs. Kelly, a former corporate executive, won election as Mayor with 85 percent of the vote. She vowed to clean out City Hall, not with a broom but with a shovel.

Lost Opportunities
A Bad Situation Gets Even Worse
Before he left office in 1990 after his arrest and conviction, Mr. Barry brought together a group of business, civic, academic and union leaders to study the problems of the city. The $2 million project resulted in an extensive report that warned city leaders to cut spending and increase revenues, or face dire consequences.
While the Kelly administration adopted many of the recommendations, many others were unfulfilled.
"This was a big opportunity missed," said Alice M. Rivlin, the vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, who headed the group. "When Sharon Pratt Kelly came in, she had the window of opportunity and the enormous good will of Congress. There was momentum for D.C. to face up to its problems, reduce the city payroll, restructure the government and come up with long-term solutions."
"Once that opportunity was missed," Ms. Rivlin added, "things went from bad to worse."
Mrs. Kelly declined to be interviewed for this article. But Robert Mallett, her former city administrator, said: "I think many who found her a disappointment may have felt better about her had she had stronger political skills. But nobody could say she didn't tackle every major problem faced by the city."
When Mrs. Kelly took office, Washington was $331 million in debt, the legacy of falling revenues in a bad economy. But unlike Mr. Barry, Mrs. Kelly was embraced by Congress and the financial markets. Wall Street firms raised $336 million for the city. Congress increased its annual payment by $200 million a year to $660 million, and provided a one-time $100 million "emergency" payment.
For the first time in years, the city had a clean financial slate.
But Mrs. Kelly squandered this good fortune and did not make the tough cuts in the city's high expenses, say city officials and Federal lawmakers. Her administration only nibbled at reducing the work force, while tax-exempt organizations like Georgetown University rebuffed her efforts to have them pay anything to the city.
"She didn't have a political base, so she didn't feel she could do the hard things," said Eleanor Holmes Norton, the District's nonvoting Congressional delegate.
On paper, the Kelly administration looked efficient. Each year, the city balanced its budget, occasionally even showing a small surplus. But behind these numbers was a harsher reality. Federal lawmakers said the administration used questionable accounting tactics to mask a widening gap between revenue and expenses. Even the money borrowed on Wall Street to pay off past debts was used for current expenses.
Unknown to most, the city had again begun to roll up massive deficits.
Money earmarked for capital projects was spent for operations in violation of a Congressional ban, and losses at D.C. General Hospital were hidden on the books as loans, according to a 1994 General Accounting Office report. In one year, a "fifth quarter" of tax revenue was added to balance the books.
"It wasn't done in the dark of night," said Mr. Mallett, referring to the accounting strategy. He added that the administration's actions were approved by the city council and by Congress. "We told everybody," he said. "We didn't have any money. We didn't have any cash. We couldn't meet the payroll. You had to do something."
He said Mrs. Kelly felt hemmed in by the conflicting expectations of the two major groups that had supported her: middle-class whites pressing for a smaller government, and middle-class blacks, many of whom worked for the city.
Mr. Mallett said that for many white people who did not work for the city and were paying higher fees and property tax assessments, there were not enough layoffs. "They felt betrayed," he said, adding, "To middle-class blacks, it meant that she was out to get me, that she was doing white folks' work. Clearly that wasn't true. She was just trying to save her city."
And she got virtually no support from President Clinton in trying to ease the restrictions on the city's taxing powers, or to have the Federal Government take over some of the city government's burdens. Indeed, a former Kelly aide says Mr. Clinton virtually ignored Washington and Mrs. Kelly after making one well-publicized walk along a black commercial strip shortly after his election.
"President Clinton never even invited Mrs. Kelly over to the White House," said the former Kelly aide, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity. "Bush at least had her over for a state dinner and had a photo op with her. She didn't have anything like that with President Clinton. My marvelous liberals."
By the end of her term, the city's deficit had ballooned to $335 million, according to a General Accounting Office report.
"She was worse than Barry," said Representative Davis of the oversight subcommittee. "She was in a job over her head. Congress gave the city $1 billion more, and it got no value back."
In 1994, just two years after his release from a six-month prison term, Mr. Barry made one of the most remarkable comebacks in American politics by defeating Mrs. Kelly in the Democratic primary and easily winning in the general election.
Shortly after his inauguration, he announced that the deficit could reach $722 million within a year. Wall Street promptly downgraded the city's bond rating to junk status.
The control board began its work last year by imploring Mr. Barry to cut thousands of the jobs created in the 1980's. Resistant at first, Mr. Barry finally recognized the powers lined against him, especially with Congress ignoring his requests for more money and with Mr. Williams, the new financial officer, accountable only to the control board.
And by last February, Mr. Barry unveiled a plan to eliminate 10,000 city workers, 25 percent of the work force, as part of a four-year plan.
But even now, with major efforts for improvement at work, change is slow. City officials have eliminated a few jobs, and Representative Walsh is insisting that Mr. Barry find more spending cuts in the proposed 1997 budget of $5.1 billion.
"Mr. Barry is a tremendous politician," said Mr. Williams, the city's chief financial officer, who has not always agreed with the Mayor's policies. "But he's a lot like nuclear power. On a good day, he can light the city. On a bad day, he can blow it up."
 
TODAY -- How and why the District of Columbia is falling apart.
 
FRIDAY -- A look at two neighborhoods: Washington's richest and its poorest.
 
SATURDAY -- The flight of the black middle class.

Chronology: "Steps on a Path Of Steady Decline"
 In May 1974, residents of the District of Columbia approved the Home Rule Act in a referendum. Since then, the city has struggled with the constraints placed on its independence by Congress, while grappling with persistent deficits and mismanagement by elected oficials.
 
JAN. 1975
Walter E. Washington, the first mayor elected under home rule, takes office, along with the new City Council.
 
JAN. 1978
Marion S. Barry Jr. is sworn in as the District's second mayor under home rule.
 
JUNE 1980
An audit by the District's financial consultants turns up a $284 million accumulated debt, much of dating back to before home rule, and a $1.4 billion shortfall for city pension funds.
 
JUNE 1981
The General Accounting Office discloses that three banks, seven credit unions and a church, all authorized to dispense food stamps, failed to distribute $2.1 million taken in during the late 1970's; most are out of business, and the city cannot collect.
 
OCT. 1981
Under pressure from religious groups, the House of Representatives kills a District ordinance to decriminalize all forms of sexual relations, the first time Congress has overturned a City Council measure that did not clearly impinge upon Federal prerogatives.
 
AUG. 1985
A Constitutional amendment, passed in 1978, to give the District full voting representation in Congress dies after less than half of the states needed for ratification approve the amendment by the seven-year decline.
 
JAN. 1987
A breakdown in snow removal virtually paralyzes the city and the Federal Government; Mayor Barry is in California at the Super Bowl.
 
OCT. 1990
Mayor Barry is sentenced to six months in prison, after being convicted of one misdemeanor charge of cocaine possession.
 
NOV. 1990
Sharon Pratt Kelly is elected Mayor; during the campaign, she vows to "clean house with a shovel, not a broom."
 
SEP. 1992
Congress votes to force the District to hold a referendum on the death penalty; the vote marks a further deteriotation in relations between Congress and the District.
 
SEPT. 1994
Mr. Barry is reelected Mayor; the budget surpluses under Mayor Kelly are seen as the product of questionable accounting practices.
 
FEB. 1995
Moody's Investors Service downgrades the District's municipal debt to junk status. Standard & Poor's follows suit tow months later.
 
FEB. 1995
The General Accounting Office reports that the District is insolvent and may run out of money by summer.
 
APRIL 1995
President Clinton signs legislation to create a financial control board for the District.
 
Budget data are included from 1981; data before the city's first audit in 1980 are seen as unreliable.
 
(Source: District of Columbia Comprehensive Annual Financial Reports) (pgs. B6 & B7)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Dole Appeals for Businesswomen's Support

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: KING OF PRUSSIA, Pa., July 24

 BODY:
Bob Dole made a big pitch for the women's vote today, highlighting small businesses owned by women and bringing the Republican National Convention's keynote speaker, Representative Susan Molinari of New York, on the campaign trail with him to vouch for his commitment to women's interests.
Women, Mr. Dole said, are starting small businesses at twice the rate of men. And so in two campaign stops in Pennsylvania today, he tried to reassure women that he would be better for small business -- and therefore better for the economy and for them -- than President Clinton had been. 
 Mr. Dole pledged to make various tax and regulatory changes to benefit small business, saying he would announce plans for estate tax relief and a reduction in the capital gains tax as part of the economic program that he will soon unveil.
"I will be on your side, a President who understands what it takes to run a small business," he told about 300 people at the Ace Wire Spring and Form Company, a female-headed factory in McKees Rocks, outside Pittsburgh, that makes oversized paper clips.
"I will stand up for the mom-and-pop store, the new high-tech company and the aspiring woman entrepreneur with a small-business opportunity plan," he said, "and will put government in your corner and not on your back."
Later, at a cookie dough plant in this Philadelphia suburb, he met with Hope Spivak, owner of Hope's Country Fresh Cookies, and said that as President he would hold a White House conference for "women only" to talk about how to create more businesses owned by women. "That's the future of America," he declared. "That's the Dole administration."
Mr. Dole was well received by the audiences at today's events, but he nonetheless arrived in Pennsylvania to bad news. A new poll, conducted by Terry Madonna at Millersville University, found him trailing Mr. Clinton in the state by 24 percentage points. Although he has paid five visits to Pennsylvania since its primary three months ago, he fared worse in this poll than in April, when he trailed the President here by 17 points.
The new poll also showed that even when he was paired with the Governor of Pennsylvania, Tom Ridge, as his hypothetical running mate, the margin remained the same.
Mr. Dole told his McKees Rocks audience that he would win the election anyway, "because people will understand who Bob Dole is, who I am."
"Who is this man who stands up and tells me he wants to be President of the United States?" the candidate continued. "What's he all about? What's he done? Where is he from, and where will he take us as a country?
"These are important questions that will be answered time and time and time again," Mr. Dole promised, although he did not take this opportunity to answer them.
In Pennsylvania as elsewhere, Mr. Dole is laboring under the disadvantage of a yawning "gender gap," in which female voters overwhelmingly prefer Mr. Clinton.
To try to narrow that gap, the Dole campaign invited Ms. Molinari along for her first public outing with the presumed nominee since he named her last week as the Republican convention's keynote speaker. Mr. Dole decided on the flight from Washington to Pittsburgh this morning that she should speak, and the campaign was pleased with her gusto.
She told the group in McKees Rocks that "there is a gender gap that shows up in poll after poll" and that some candidates deserved one. "But not Bob Dole," she asserted.
Like the cheerleader she once was, Ms. Molinari, a 38-year-old Staten Islander, added: "The majority of small businesses that start up in this nation are being started up by -- who? Ladies?"
"Women," the audience answered.
"Women," Ms. Molinari affirmed. "When you say we are going to have government be a partner with small business, who are you helping? Women. And Americans.
"And that's what Bob Dole's record has been all about. When it comes to small business and it comes to women and it comes to helping this nation, there's no finer gentleman."
In his own speech, first in McKees Rocks and then here in King of Prussia, Mr. Dole said the President had been ruinous to small business. He cited not only Mr. Clinton's veto of 1995 budget-balancing legislation and of a bill that would have curbed product liability suits but also the President's 1993 tax increases.
Literature handed out by local Democrats, on the other hand, said that the Small Business Administration had increased its loans to women by 300 percent during the Clinton Presidency and that a record number of small businesses had been created in each year of the Clinton Administration.

HEADLINE: Communists Defeat Yeltsin Plan to Lure Investment

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 24

 BODY:
In a stinging rebuff to President Boris N. Yeltsin, the Communist-dominated Parliament has rejected legislation intended to encourage billions of dollars of foreign investment in the oil and gas industry.
The legislation, which would provide a legal framework for sharing oil production, has been a top priority of Western oil companies eager to develop new fields. It has also been strongly supported by the Yeltsin Government, which is eager to generate badly needed revenue. 
 The Communists' success in blocking the legislation shows that they still have the determination and power to hamper market reforms despite their lopsided defeat by Mr. Yeltsin in the presidential election on July 3.
The Communists are "extremely ideologically charged," said Aleksei Y. Mikhailov, chairman of the Parliamentary Committee on Natural Resources, who supported the legislation. "They think that it is best when the state owns everything."
But the failure to pass the law also reflects Mr. Yeltsin's slow start in getting his new policy team in place, as well as what are seen as heavy-handed efforts by Washington to help American oil companies, Russian officials said.
Parliament voted down the legislation late Friday, setting off a round of recriminations, and this week Yeltsin Administration officials and their parliamentary allies vowed to renew the fight.
Along with the decision by the International Monetary Fund to withhold its monthly loan disbursement because of Russia's tax-collection problems, Parliament's action raises fresh questions about the Government's ability to speed reform.
Even before the election, direct foreign investment in Russia was somewhat anemic, a victim of heavy taxes, a labyrinthine bureaucracy and Western fears that the "new Russia" is politically unstable. "China has attracted 25 times more Western investment than Russia," the Government's analytical center reported in March.
Mr. Yeltsin's re-election brought hope that foreign investors would open their wallets. But for many foreign investors, Mr. Yeltsin's re-election is not enough. Major American oil companies, for example, say they will not invest billions in new projects unless production-sharing laws are enacted.
Under such arrangements, Russia would forgo a multitude of taxes. In return, Russia would get a share of the oil produced by the foreign companies, a royalty based on production and taxes on the companies' profits.
American officials say such an arrangement is attractive because it establishes a ceiling on tax costs. "The project could be unsuccessful, but not because you are overtaxed," an American oil executive said.
But the issue has long been politically charged, with Communists and nationalists saying the West is out to exploit Russia's natural resources.
"Oil and gas are very political," said Alexander M. Knaster, the managing director of the CS First Boston Corporation, financial consultants. "You are not dealing just with the economy. You are dealing with family silver."
As the wrangling has continued, major multi-billion-dollar projects have been put on hold.
One is the Timan Pechora project, in which a consortium of Western companies led by Texaco Inc. plans to drill in the Arctic. Other companies involved include Exxon, Amoco and Norsk Hydro, of Norway.
Other major projects that await new legislation include Amoco's development of the Priobskoye field in Siberia and three projects off Sakhalin Island in the Far East, two by Exxon and one a combined project by the Mobil Corporation and Texaco. Two earlier projects off Sakhalin led by international consortiums were specifically approved by previous legislation and are going forward.
The Ministry of Fuel and Energy has estimated that more than $50 billion in long-term investment could be attracted by production-sharing agreements. Western companies say the shorter-term investment would be far less, but would still be counted in the billions.
The production-sharing issue has been brewing for years. Parliament adopted a basic law on production-sharing in December, but American companies say further amendments are needed to strengthen legal protections. Legislation is also needed to modify the tax code and bring other laws into line with the December legislation.
But when this supplementary legislation came before Parliament late Friday, it was rejected by a vote of 150 to 148. Only 5 of the 147 Communist members of Parliament voted for the measure.
The Yeltsin Government also wants Parliament to authorize 250 locations where Western companies would have the right to produce oil under production-sharing agreements.
But this list has yet to be put to a vote, and supporters now say a list of 20 to 30 locations may be all the traffic will bear in the Communist-dominated Parliament.
The Communists' pervasive suspicion of Western investors was but one factor that led to the defeat.
According to Mr. Mikhailov, the natural resources chairman, recent efforts by Vice President Al Gore on behalf of the legislation backfired, prompting accusations by the ultra-nationalist Vladimir V. Zhirinovksy that the West is pressing Parliament to sell out the motherland.
Mr. Mikhailov said he hopes to revist the issue in several months, by which time he hopes the Yeltsin Government and other supporters will be better organized. He also hopes for support from outlying regions seeking foreign investment, and from Russian oil companies eager to join forces with their wealthier Western counterparts.
But already investors are being cautioned that they may not get everything they want and that the new legislation will take time.
"I expect a resolution in 1997," said Mr. Knaster of First Boston. "The production-sharing law may not be in perfect shape, but I expect we will get to the point where foreign investment starts to flow. It will be a combination of increased courage on the part of the Western companies and increased tolerance by the Russians."

HEADLINE: A Surly New York As Olympic Host?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While "Olympic Fever in New York" (editorial, July 21) fuels New York City's economic imagination, consider the reality. 
 You touch on the problem of transportation, yet New York City can't comprehend a proposal to connect Kennedy International Airport with midtown Manhattan other than its projected $3 billion cost.
Three historical events exemplify what New York can muster: the World's Fairs of 1939 and 1964 and the Bicentennial celebration that included Operation Sail in 1976.
However, those venues were more centralized and monitorable than would be the case in a New York Olympiad. While terrorism as we know it today was virtually nonexistent during the World's Fairs, Op-Sail officials were concerned about it, particularly with all the dignitaries in attendance.
The New York City Partnership, which is raising money for a feasibility study of a New York Olympics, should examine the finances of both fairs and our economy at those times. During Op-Sail, the city wasn't sure it could pay for sanitation services. Yet in the face of bankruptcy, the bicentennial celebration did provide New York an economic boost.
If the city considers playing host to the Olympics, a good dress rehearsal might be another World's Fair in the year 2000. I have proposed such a plan to both Albany and City Hall.
Our citizenry has been so divided and disgruntled that it is conceivable that some New Yorkers might not welcome the Games, taking a not-in-my-backyard attitude.
Simply, these are inhumane times. New York lacks the gentility required to play host to the Olympic Games. We are hostile, not hospitable.
 
DAVID LEE
New York, July 23, 1996
 
The writer is a public relations consultant.

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
Westchester Development Is On Again

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
At Rosecliff, a development of single-family houses overlooking the Hudson River in the Westchester County community of Briarcliff Manor, construction has been stop and go since it began in the building boom of the mid-1980's.
Eleven years and three owners later, the project, which will eventually include 116 single-family homes, is two-thirds complete. And now the project is to begin its latest chapter. Earlier this month, Toll Brothers Inc., among the region's larger developers, bought one model home and 36 building lots for $4.6 million at the 152-acre site. 
 The company, based in Huntingdon Valley, Pa., expects to restart construction at the project by this fall and complete it in three years, said Robert Parahus, a vice president at Toll. The seller was Rosecliff Equities, which bought the unfinished houses in 1995 from the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency that is now disbanded. Resolution Trust took over the undeveloped property when it seized the failed bank that was the financial partner of the first developer, who built and sold most of the 79 homes.
The development, set on a cliff, was once the estate of Edward Walker Harden, who went from being the financial editor of The Chicago Tribune to a millionaire investment banker. It is off Sleepy Hollow Road in the village, which lies in Ossining and Mount Pleasant, 15 minutes from White Plains.
Toll's plan is to build the remaining homes and, contingent upon receiving approvals, modify them to update their interiors. Changes include expanding the kitchens and master bedrooms and baths and making basements, which are not in all the earlier homes, a standard feature. The size and exteriors of the 2,200-to-3,000-square-foot homes, designed in contemporary styles, would not change appreciably.
They, like the existing homes, clustered in groups on the eastern portion of the site, will also have three or four bedrooms (some earlier ones had two bedrooms) and two-car garages. The project is designed as a fee-simple homeowners association, meaning that buyers own the land under and around their homes -- one-eighth- to one-half-acre lots -- but other areas are owned in common and managed by the association. They can also cast off such chores as mowing the lawn and shoveling snow. Seventy acres on the site's western portion have been left undeveloped.
Rosecliff has a clubhouse in the 18,000-square-foot mansion and a pool and two tennis courts. A third tennis court and a paddle tennis court will be added if homeowners want them, Mr. Parahus said, adding that a meeting to discuss such issues is to be set up soon.
The 37 homes are expected to start at $460,000 to $500,000, with some as high as $570,000. The monthly maintenance fee is $475.
Mr. Parahus said Toll saw Rosecliff as "another opportunity in another desirable area" of the county. "The buyers there fit our buyer profile," he added.
The project also underscores Toll's expansion into New York State in general and Westchester County in particular. In the last three years it has started or restarted nine projects, eight of them, with 409 residences, in the county.
Seeing the project move forward is welcomed by homeowners. Mal Nechis, an eight-year resident and vice president of the homeowners association said, "We are hopeful that with an organization like Toll, with a good reputation and a good track record, this is the final chapter, the remaining homes will be built and sold and our values in general will improve." Mr. Nechis said there were still concerns "until we hear what they will do, which will become clear over the next several weeks."
It also pleases Briarcliff Manor, where development activity has rebounded. Several projects that gathered dust during the sluggish economy and others that were started but delayed are moving ahead or to completion. Rosecliff, however, has the longest development history.
Everyone who bought the site has followed the approved plan, which reflects the village's land-use policies for "planned rather than haphazard development," said Lynn M. McCrum, the village manager. If Toll stays with simple changes "it probably will not be a big deal," he added
Rosecliff is being revived at a time when the market in Westchester County is improving. As of the second quarter, 1,879 existing homes of all types were sold, up 23 percent from the same time last year. The median sales price also increased to $245,000, from $236,500 in 1995. For single-family homes the price rose to $292,000 from $283,000, the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service said.
Mr. Parahus said sales at Rosecliff would start in October.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mark Surges and Dollar Falls As Germany Fails to Cut Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The mark surged and the dollar fell yesterday after the Bundesbank surprised currency traders by leaving German interest rates unchanged.
Many traders had been expecting a cut, and the decision by the central bank raised concern that German rates would not move any lower. 
 "We probably have seen the bottom for German interest rates," said Robert Fullem, a currency salesman at National Westminster Bank. With the German economy showing signs of rebounding from a prolonged slowdown, "I would be surprised if they cut the repo rate any further," he said.
The Bundesbank left the discount rate at 2.50 percent and the Lombard rate at 4.50 percent. It kept its chief money market rate, the securities repurchase rate, at 3.30 percent until its next meeting in four weeks.
Lower rates often hurt the mark by making deposits denominated in it less attractive.
"The Bundesbank certainly had an impact," said James Kemp, managing director of foreign exchange at Citibank. "They have surprised the market, as they tend to do."
The dollar dropped as low as 1.4703 marks, its lowest since July 16, when it reached 1.4692 marks. In late trading in New York, the dollar settled at at 1.4775 marks, down from 1.4890 marks on Wednesday. The dollar also traded at 108.31 Japanese yen, down from 108.40 yen. The British pound rose to $1.5575 from $1.5525.
The dollar held up better against the yen amid expectations the Bank of Japan would not soon raise rates.
The Bundesbank last cut the repo rate, a key money market rate, in February, to 3.3 percent. Yesterday's inaction will leave German rates unchanged for at least four weeks, as the Bundesbank council takes a summer break.
The central bank's decision disappointed traders who expected interest-rate differentials to widen in favor of the dollar, with forecasts for a German rate cut and a rate increase in the United States. One- month Eurodollar deposits yield 5.4375 percent, compared with 3.3125 percent for one-month Euromark deposits.
"Everyone felt the Germans would lower rates, and we'd raise them," said James McGroarty, chief currency manager at Potomac Babson Inc., a money manager. "The fact that hasn't happened has led the dollar to fall."

HEADLINE: Moscow Journal;
Secrets of the K.G.B.: A Very Discreet Disrobing

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 25

 BODY:
When the secret police came for Osip Mandelstam in 1938, the one book that this century's greatest Russian poet managed to take with him on his lonely road to Siberian exile and death was Dante's "Inferno."
With the Soviet secret police, Mandelstam knew where he was headed. Who wouldn't? Few organizations in modern history have inspired as much fear, caused more pain or managed to remain shrouded more completely in mystery. Until now. 
 This month, in an attempt to be modern, sophisticated, reasonable and -- above all, it seems -- hip, the K.G.B.'s successor agency, the Federal Security Service, will release six choice hours of its history on CD-ROM, making its long convoluted role as enforcer of evil for Soviet dictators available to anyone with the ability to click on an icon.
"We released this on CD-ROM because that is a modern way to communicate with people," said General Yuri G. Kobaladze, the glib, eloquent spokesman for the security service. "We want to be modern. Even in this sphere we still want to be better than everyone else. Now let the British make a CD-ROM about their intelligence service, and then let the Americans do it. But we will always be first."
They will indeed, although even the slick new agency seems to realize that CD-ROM is not the forum for major new revelations. Partly, that is because the agency's officials are so ambivalent about their role in the new Russia. It is also because most people -- within and without the agency -- would like to make much of the agency's (and Russia's) recent past disappear.
Consequently there are none; the disk, with 60 interviews, is essentially a historian's curiosity, filled with interesting narrative about the importance of the Russian attempt to develop the atomic bomb, for example, as well as evidence of Khrushchev's vacillation during the Cuban missile crisis. But for viewers desperate to divine new meaning from Moscow, the earth is unlikely to move.
That hardly means this CD-ROM is a gimmick, though. Far from it. Five years ago, when people like General Kobaladze starting discussing this project, many in the agency were outraged.
This little disk is a clear landmark on the frequently erratic road to the new, totally post-Soviet Russia, even without revealing the final truth (or any truth) on the wartime activities of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, Americans who were executed for spying for the Soviet Union, or the full story (or any story) about how the C.I.A. official Aldrich Ames turned into Russia's most damaging and valuable agent in the United States.
Only after much agony within the agency, and much debate in Russian society -- where the thought of the agency or the mention of its headquarters building, the Lubyanka, still makes many people actually tremble -- did the security agency decide that to polish its tarnished image it would have to come at least partly clean. Each fact in the production has been cleared by a dubious panel of experts. Nobody can even guess what was rejected.
"This has not been easy for anyone," said General Kobaladze during a recent preview display of the CD-ROM. He served as a London correspondent for a Soviet newspaper in the early 1980's, when most such positions were assumed in the West to be filled by spies.
"This is after all a secret organization and it's hard to convince people that their lives should be revealed this way," he said. "To say here, 'Let's talk about it, let's show people what we do,' is not easy for any intelligence service. It has been particularly hard for us."
The choices were difficult, in part because, the intelligence community is not unanimously excited about President Boris N. Yeltsin and his support of economic and social reforms.
Was the end of the Soviet Union "tragic," as one clip on the CD suggests, or was it simply the natural end of an evil empire?
"We cannot concern ourselves with how to present history, that is not our task," General Kobaladze said. "But I notice that the whole of Russia is struggling with this question. So why can't we in the intelligence services? Part of why we wanted to make this product is to show that we are not so different from the society we serve."
This CD-ROM will be available to anyone with $60, and it comes in an English and a Russian version.
It opens magically with the viewer sitting in a (virtual) black car as it swings through the gates of Yasenevo, the secret base of covert activities just outside Moscow that is to the K.G.B. what Langley, Va., is to the C.I.A. As the music swells (Tchaikovsky, of course) the black sedan swings past buildings that until recently could have been conjured only in the imaginings of John Le Carre.
The faces of Russian spies flash across the screen as the music plays. (Not famous spies of course; the only famous Russian spies are the ones that got away. They don't seem to make much of an appearance in this production.) There are a series of categories the user can click on: chronology (birth of the Soviet state, the "unpleasant" Stalin period, the hot war, the cold war, and perestroika); personality, geography (Cuba, Afghanistan, etc.). Each section is filled with film clips, sound bites, archival material and plenty of good old-fashioned text.
The people who produced this history are not suggesting it will strip the mystique from the spy agency. They are, in fact, hoping it does the opposite.
"In your country the F.B.I. and C.I.A. openly recruit for employees at the best universities," General Kobaladze said. "I want us to be able to do that, too. I want young Russians to be proud to serve, and to consider this agency worthy of service."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A picture of Kim Philby, the most notorious member of the famous British spy ring, was being projected on a screen as a Russian intelligence technician showed off a new CD-ROM that offers highlights of K.G.B. history. (James Hill for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
A Certain Treason

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Day after day now America's allies deliver warnings to its people and government. These democracies, which the U.S. counts as its best friends, warn they will take reprisals against America if it tries to reduce their investments in three dictatorships America counts among its worst enemies -- Iran, Libya, Cuba. Heed our threats, say our friends.
Americans should. These threats are symptoms of the sickness of moral treason in the West -- the delivery of the economic fruits of freedom to help destroy the tree of freedom. 
 American governments, including the present, and most American capitalists have also fallen ill and spread the sickness. But the threats of our allies when Congress dares propose even small medicine should be warning to look into ourselves, see the shame and danger the illness has brought us and try to shake it.
How we laughed in the West when Communist leaders said give capitalists enough rope and they will hang themselves. We have been snickering ever since Communism put its own rope, made of corruption and oppression, around its neck and swung to its death.
The prediction is turning out to be not terribly funny. Western capitalists have not managed to kill capitalism. But year after year they are accessories to the economic strengthening -- essential to the military strengthening -- of dictatorships that would destroy the very system of democratic capitalism under which these Westerners made their profits.
Meantime the dictators occupy themselves by taking the lives of their own citizens through domestic terror and through international terror and war, the lives of citizens of free countries.
British citizens died when Pan Am 103 hit the ground in Scotland, destroyed by Libyan terrorists -- likely with the help of Syrian and Iranian comrades. Frenchmen died in the gulf war that Western investments allowed Saddam Hussein to start. The missile power that Beijing informed us could hit Los Angeles is sustained by American investment in industries run by the Chinese Army. All this -- plus the murder of literally millions of Iraqis, Kurds, Tibetans, Chinese, Iranians and Cubans. Do they count?
But now, without a dissenting vote, Congress has passed legislation to penalize foreign companies that invest more than $40 million in Iranian and Libyan energy development -- essential to those two countries on the U.S. terrorist list.
American companies are already barred from those investments. Foreign companies that ignore the restrictions would not be permitted to export to the U.S. or get American Government loans or high-tech licenses.
Credit for initiating the bill goes to Senator Alfonse D'Amato. Another New York Republican, Benjamin Gilman, led the campaign in the House.
The bill includes a waiver the President can use in the national interest as he sees it. Mr. Clinton has used similar waivers to destroy human rights action against China and delay or kill action against companies that deal in Cuban property expropriated by Fidel Castro from Americans or Cubans who became Americans. But if he uses the waiver on Iran and Libya, Congress will probably pass a no-waiver bill over his head.
Americans opposing the D'Amato bill and the Helms-Burton bill on nationalized U.S. property in Cuba say they would amount to an illegal secondary boycott like the Arab boycott against Israel.
The fact is that the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade does not bar all secondary boycotts. GATT accepted Egypt after it began the world boycott of Israel. Also: American courts have upheld similar sanctions against Communist countries at least four times from Harry Truman's time to Ronald Reagan's.
Enough law book. I guess I do not talk the talk or think the thoughts of those who cannot tell the difference between dictatorships trying to boycott a democracy out of existence -- as in the boycott of Israel -- and the attempt of a democracy to slow the empowerment of dictatorships by capitalists profiting in and by freedom's grace. The difference can be found in law books but more clearly in minds and hearts, or some of them.
The allies have a choice -- trade with America or our mutual enemies. America has one too -- refuse to strengthen tyrannies or continue moral treason against ourselves.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Durable Goods Orders Fell More Than Forecast in June

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
Orders for durable goods declined in June, weighed down by weaker demand for aircraft, cars and business equipment, the Commerce Department reported today.
New orders for durable goods fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in June to a seasonally adjusted $169.07 billion -- slightly weaker than the drop of six-tenths of 1 percent Wall Street economists had anticipated. 
 The June decline, the fourth this year, followed a 4.2 percent jump in May that reflected a surge in commercial aircraft demand, the department said. The only other increase in orders this year was a 1.5 percent gain in March.
"After the strong report in May, some kind of a pullback was to be expected," David Blitzer, chief economist at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said. "There's nothing in this that looks alarming, and there's nothing that would tell me the economy's not real strong."
Further evidence of economic strength came in a report by the Labor Department that applications for first-time unemployment benefits fell last week to the lowest level in six months. In another indicator of economic activity, though, a trade group reported that home resales had declined in June.
Excluding transportation, orders for durables fell in June by six-tenths of 1 percent after a May gain of 1.1 percent gain. Orders for durable goods indicate future prospects of manufacturers, which weighs heavily on the overall economy.
"These are very volatile numbers," Darwin Beck, money market economist at CS First Boston, said. "They were weaker than anticipated, but if you average them over the last two months, they probably continue to show an economy growing at a modest pace."
Orders for transportation equipment, which includes cars, planes, trains and ships, fell 1.3 percent after soaring by 14.9 percent in May, the department said.
Orders for military goods, which experience wide monthly swings, surged 31.6 percent last month after a 5.8 percent gain in May. If the military segment is excluded, overall orders in June fell by 2 percent after rising 4.2 percent in May.
Orders for nonmilitary capital goods, an indication of business investment in new equipment, fell 5.5 percent last month after rising 11.1 percent in May.
Shipments of durable goods, an indication of current demand, fell 1 percent, to $165.7 billion, after a 1.7 percent gain in May. Unfilled orders rose in June for the ninth time in 10 months, gaining seven-tenths of 1 percent, to a backlog valued at $475.89 billion, after gaining six-tenths of 1 percent in May.
In a separate report, the Labor Department said that jobless claims tumbled to 322,000 in the week ended last Saturday from 367,000 in the previous week, partly because of auto industry retooling. The figure was the lowest since the week ended Jan. 13, when blizzard conditions paralyzed much of the East Coast.
Last week's claims were far less than the Wall Street forecasts of 354,000 new applications. The decline also brought the four-week moving average of claims to 352,500, down from a four-week average in the prior week of 360,500.
And the National Association of Realtors said that home resales retreated in June from a record level in May as rising mortgage rates began to affect the market.
Home resales fell 2.3 percent from May to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.18 million units, the association said, lower than Wall Street estimates of 4.20 million units.
The group revised its May figure upward to 4.28 million units -- the highest on record -- from the previous estimate of 4.26 million units.
The association said June sales were up 10 percent from a year earlier, when the resale rate was 3.8 million units.

HEADLINE: Dole Considers Tax-Cut Plan Of as Much as $600 Billion

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
The tax-cut proposals being considered by Bob Dole's Presidential campaign range as high as $600 billion over six years, but Mr. Dole has not made any decision on the size of the reductions or how to pay for them, campaign aides said today.
Campaigning in Pennsylvania, Mr. Dole, the likely Republican Presidential nominee, called again for the size and powers of the Internal Revenue Service to be reined in, saying, "I think we can downsize the I.R.S." 
 He offered no specifics, although his aides are considering a variety of proposals including shifting I.R.S. personnel from auditing to assisting taxpayers in preparing returns.
Mr. Dole has said he plans to make a tax cut the centerpiece of his economic platform. But despite increasing pressure from fellow Republicans to present his plan, Mr. Dole, who has long put deficit reduction ahead of tax cuts, has continued to study options that include an across-the-board reduction in tax rates of 10 or 15 percent, repeal of tax increases enacted by Congress in 1990 and 1993, making Social Security taxes deductible, a reduction in the capital gains tax and incentives for savings and investment.
In a memorandum sent today to Republican political leaders, Mr. Dole's two top policy advisers, Donald Rumsfeld and Vin Weber, and his campaign manager, Scott Reed, wrote that while Mr. Dole "has not reached a final decision on all the details of his growth plan, we can report that it will be a bold, sweeping program to cut taxes, simplify our tax system, address the economic insecurity of working Americans and free our economy to grow at its full potential."
An across-the-board reduction in tax rates of 15 percent could cost $100 billion a year in revenue and would likely be phased in over six years. Advisers to Mr. Dole said some of the cost would be offset by the additional economic growth a tax cut would stimulate. Neither Mr. Dole nor his advisers have specified how the rest of the cost would be offset in spending cuts or new sources of revenue.
The $600 billion tax cut is "under serious consideration," Nelson Warfield, Mr. Dole's spokesman, told reporters traveling with the candidate. "There are a variety of different options, with different price tags associated with them, and that is one of them."
The Washington Post today reported that one economic analysis circulating within the Dole campaign stated that a $600 billion tax cut could be largely offset by the economic growth that the tax cut would bring. The analysis asserted that as much of 40 percent of the revenue lost through a tax cut of that magnitude could be recaptured through the effects of higher growth.
Responding to the newspaper's report, Mr. Dole said "It's not my announcement and it's not my plan."

HEADLINE: INTERNTIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexico Says It Will Repay $7 Billion To the U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
The Mexican Government helped the Clinton Administration neutralize a potentially difficult election-year problem today, announcing that early next month it would pay back $7 billion to the United States.
The early payment will leave only $3.5 billion in outstanding loans from the bailout of Mexico last year, or slightly more than a quarter of the $12.5 billion that the Clinton Administration extended after Mexico came to the brink of national bankruptcy in early 1995. The repayments make it possible for President Clinton to contend that his action, which encountered considerable political resistance, helped prevent a global meltdown of the world's most promising emerging markets -- while creating a profit for the United States Treasury of more than $500 million, because of high interest rates charged to the Mexican Government. 
 Mexican officials said their repayment was motivated by simple economics, not politics. Now that the country has restored its credibility on international markets, it has been able to refinance its borrowings at a lower interest rate -- around 7.6 percent, much lower than the 10 percent the United States was charging -- much the way homeowners refinance mortgages to take advantage of lower rates.
But the political advantages to Mr. Clinton are clear. The repayment makes it difficult for Ross Perot, who is likely to receive the third-party endorsement of his Reform Party, to contend that the Administration spent billions in taxpayer money to prevent a disaster south of the border after the North American Free Trade Agreement, which he railed against in the 1992 campaign, went into effect. And Mr. Clinton's aides are also betting they will succeed at silencing Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who is a major supporter of Bob Dole's candidacy, who argued last year that the loans would never be repaid.
"I would not have thought this possible when we entered this agreement in February, 1995," said Robert E. Rubin, who grappled with the Mexican financial crisis in the first weeks after he was appointed Treasury Secretary in December 1994. Meeting with a group of reporters today in his office, he admitted to periodic doubts himself about whether the bailout -- which he referred to in a far more neutral phrase, "the Mexican support package" -- would succeed in pulling Mexico out of the financial depths.
"I don't wake up in the middle of the night much," he said. "But did I worry about this a lot? Yes, you bet."
Six weeks ago Mexico announced that it would repay $4.7 billion of its outstanding loans, "privatizing" the debt by issuing longer-term bonds to private investors who are now once again willing to lend money to the Government of President Ernesto Zedillo.
To the surprise of American officials, the Mexican refinancing plan was oversubscribed, prompting the Mexican Government to double the amount of debt it had planned to refinance, and to pay back $1 billion to the International Monetary Fund. Several of the fund's major backers, including Japan, had complained that the United States was being paid back first.
Today Mexico's Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, said that the refinancing would save Mexico about $125 million a year -- a politically important point in Mexico City, where the austerity drive after the collapse of the peso touched off mass unemployment and a huge shrinkage of the economy last year.
Mr. Ortiz rejected suggestions that the timing of the early repayment and its size were linked to the Clinton Administration's desire to bury the Mexican bailout as a potential campaign issue.
"No, no, no, it's not that at all," Mr. Ortiz said. "This is obviously a very convenient operation for Mexico."
Mexican officials are also relieved in political terms to be lightening their debt load with Washington. Traditionally Mexico has guarded its sovereignty jealously against political intrusions by its northern neighbor. Many in the Government were mortified that they had to turn to the United States to pull them back from the brink of financial collapse after a mishandled 1994 peso devaluation and that they were forced to pledge Mexican oil revenues as collateral.
"We'd much rather owe to the markets than the U.S. Government," one Mexican official said today.
In the refinancing, in recent weeks Mexico has raised $6 billion by offering a five-year floating-rate bank note in a syndication underwritten by J. P. Morgan and the Swiss Bank Corporation. Because of the intense demand for the note, Mexico was able to lower the initial floating rate it will pay. It will offer a rate that is 200 basis points, or two percentage points, over the three-month London interbank offered rate, which big banks charge each other for international loans.
The offering attracted more than 200 banks and institutional investors from Europe, Asia and the United States. The bidding period closed today. Mexico will pay the United States in early August.
"We are tapping a large group of institutional investors who were not previously buyers of Mexican paper," Mr. Ortiz said.
The return of investor confidence in Mexico is the flip side of the steep price Mexicans have paid for restoring the country to fiscal credibility. Hemmed in by the North American Free Trade Agreement, which prevented Mexico from cutting off imports, Mr. Zedillo agreed to a stringent fiscal and monetary policy whose terms were in some cases dictated in Washington. But after weathering a huge shrinkage in the country's output, Mexico is growing again, by an average of 2 percent in each of the last three quarters. Unemployment is beginning to fall, and private consumption is rising again.
American officials say that exports to Mexico are up 11 percent compared with the beginning months of 1994 -- before the crisis hit. That statistic will likely be cited by Mr. Clinton to answer Mr. Perot's charge four years ago that trade accord would lead to a "giant sucking sound" as American jobs head south. While some jobs certainly did go to Mexico, the crisis there actually discouraged foreign investment in the country, slowing the movement of factories out of the United States.

HEADLINE: Make the New Technology Fit the Worker

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Technology's Edict: Adapt or Lose Out" (Business Day, July 25) rightly points out that workers need to keep up with technological change. But it's not just workers who need to adjust. Machines need to adapt to workers, too. 
 User-friendly technology (technology as a tool to enhance worker skills) is becoming increasingly important as smart companies shift away from the traditional mass-production focus on efficient production at high volume to the new game of increasing worker participation and skill enhancement in what has come to be called high-performance work systems.
Such a shift will require a re-orientation of technology policy. To bolster worker-centered technology development, the White House should create a multidisciplinary initiative to provide coordination across Federal research and development programs, injecting worker-friendly design criteria into Government technology programs from the Defense Department to the national laboratory system.
Some in Washington are talking about a new economic growth plan based on cutting taxes.
Real economic growth will come from a plan that gives workers the skills they need to master the new technologies and the tools and technologies they need to use those skills effectively.
Done right, the dynamic duo of smart workers and smart machines harnessed together in high performance work systems can go a long away toward insuring future economic prosperity.
 
KEN JARBOE
Washington, July 25, 1996
 
The writer is a senior fellow at the Work and Technology Institute.

HEADLINE: Bob Dole, on the Road

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

DATELINE: McKEES ROCKS, Pa.

 BODY:
Bob Dole has found his campaign slogan, and if punctuation is power, this one is a winner.
"The slogan says it all," Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania told an audience at a paper-clip factory. "Bob Dole. A Better Man. For a Better America." A banner behind the podium made it clear that the slogan did indeed have three periods. No one in the campaign knew where they all came from. "Many, many people were involved in creating it," said Mr. Dole's press spokesman. One aide thought it might be a deference to the candidate's staccato speech patterns, but another argued that in Dolese, the slogan would really have read "Bob Dole -- Better Man -- 'merica." 
 The slogan has come a lot easier than the long-awaited tax plan, which may not be released until sometime near the Republican Convention. But that has not stopped Mr. Dole from promising tax cuts. "I'll be announcing my economic package one of these days," he said later in the day. "And when I do, you're going to see a dramatic reduction in [the capital gains] tax.
"Not for the rich!" he added hastily. "But for the people in this audience!"
For an instant, at least, Mr. Dole has solved one of his great vision problems. He has been trying to come up with a tax-cut plan that cannot be attacked as a sop to fat cats, but that still includes longtime Republican betes noires like capital gains and estate taxes. Faced with a dilemma like this in the Senate, he would have split the difference. But a Presidential campaign calls for something starker and sweeter. Something like "a capital gains tax cut only for those of you in this room."
And what about government regulations? "We don't need them!" he cries at a cookie factory near Philadelphia. Earlier in the day at the paper-clip company, Mr. Dole had pretty much left it at that. But the sight of all the raw dough seems to have reminded him that some regulation might be good after all.
"We're gonna keep the health and safety," he amends, standing near flour and sugar sacks. "But a lot of the others are make-work! Make-work!"
Mr. Dole is never going to be a great campaigner, but he seems most uncomfortable when he is trying to push what he knows are wild oversimplifications. If Ronald Reagan had campaigned at that cookie factory, he would have seasoned his talk liberally with anecdotes about struggling families whose road was made smooth by a Republican-sponsored capital gains cut. The stories were sometimes fictional, but Mr. Reagan believed them when he told them, and the audience basked in his sincerity.
Mr. Dole's world view, however, is full of shades of gray. He is happiest making small talk with the audience, telling jokes ("My wife is so smart, Eleanor Roosevelt tried to contact her") and tossing darts at the opposition. When he gets to the red-meat applause lines, he tends to sound either obscure ("I will reform the independent contractor and employee classification rule!") or scary. "Those who commit violent crimes better hope I lose the election!" he said suddenly. "We're gonna stamp it out! We're gonna lock them up!"
He sometimes sounds like a man in an argument with himself, and for good reason. Dole the candidate wants big tax cuts, but the retired legislator still believes they will produce big deficits. There will be no tax plan until one of them wins the fight. GAIL COLLINS
