HEADLINE: ON BASKETBALL;
Russians Just Might Sneak Up on the U.S

BYLINE: By Harvey Araton 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
THERE is little or no doubt which is the most gifted and talented of the women's basketball teams here at the Centennial Olympics, but there will be no equivocation in the following assessment that doubles as a warning to the corporately ballyhooed American protagonists: They do not -- repeat Do Not! -- want to be knee deep in a 1-point game with the ball in the hands of Irina Sumnikova.
As a teen-ager in Minsk, Sumnikova wished to be a gymnast, a dancer or musician. She has wound up as the composite artist, the 31-year-old point guard for the Russian Federation, maestro for a team that has absolutely no right to play as harmoniously as it does. 
 "This is the traditional Russian style," Sumnikova said through an interpreter after the Russians passed and screened and back-doored their way to a 75-70 victory over Italy in the game before the United States' 107-47 drubbing of Zaire yesterday at the Georgia Dome. "There are not a lot of strong individuals but we are strong as a team," Sumnikova added.
How this is possible is indeed a testament to Russia's Princetonian precision, considering this team, with only four returning players from its Barcelona gold-medal winners in 1992, has a new coach and has been together only three months. By comparison, the Americans, touring since last fall in their determined rush for home-soil gold, have the working tenure of the 1960's Boston Celtics.
Someone out there in the shadow of the Kremlin can obviously coach.
Most would ascribe this share-the-ball doctrine to the venerable gent who slipped into a headset yesterday for the Russian telecast, and the man in the headset, Aleksandr Gomelsky, would undoubtedly agree.
"My boys," he still calls the men's team, though he retired from the old Soviet system after winning the gold in 1988 at Seoul. And so as not to allow the women to feel neglected by the father of Russian basketball, he refers to them as -- what else? -- "my girls."
Here in Atlanta, Gomelsky has no calls to make on Russian men, as they failed to qualify for the Olympics at the European championships last summer in Greece. Gomelsky was so distressed that there would be no defense here of the silver medal won at the 1994 world championships and of the proud double-gold Russian heritage itself that he parked himself in the middle of Sergei Belov's losing news conference last summer and demanded to know what his coaching successor was going to do about "this tragedy."
Belov, a former star for Gomelsky, shrugged yesterday and said the new world corporate order has caught the Russians short. "Everything is unstable, politically and economically in Russia," said Belov, who doubles as federation president. A new professional league does not pay enough to keep the best Russian players home, which makes national team commitments more difficult to keep.
The old Soviet days of state-sponsored sports custody are gone, as are the fresh troops supplied by the basketball savvy Baltics, Ukraine and other former republics. A handful of central players from the women's team that won the Barcelona gold under the Unified Team banner have dispersed, leaving Sumnikova as the matriarchal distributor of the ball, of minute-by-minute counsel to less-experienced players.
If need be, they get a kiss on the cheek from their only teammate 30 or older. "It's my responsibility to coordinate the play," she said.
Her blond braid flapping stiffly as she cut a geometric swathe through Italy's defense, Sumnikova went the distance, 40 minutes strong, controlling a game in which she took two shots. Made both. She had nine assists and reminded those of us who witnessed the Unified Team's semifinal dismissal of the United States in Barcelona how the west (of Europe) was won.
One, by not turning the ball over against the deeper and more athletic American defensive pressure. Two, with the kind of superior ball movement and passing the Americans haven't grown up with. Three, by crowding the interior and making the perimeter-suspect Americans convert from outside.
Four years later, the United States is back with more collective purpose and better players.
Sumnikova, who is married and plays professionally in Hungary, has returned with a broken left wrist.
"One of the bones," she said.
Gomelsky's rap on the Russian women concerned their "mentality," or their ability to grind out the strenuous victory. He was dismayed when his brother, Yevgeny, who coached the Unified Team to gold in 1992, was replaced by Vadim Kapranov, and when they lost to Brazil earlier this week. But they did hand Italy its first defeat and several weeks ago, in an exhibition game, lost to the United States by only 1 point. Most of all, the yearlong American hype has created a Dream Team effect, inappropriate in a game played below the rim.
In other words, should they meet in the medal round, all the pressure will be on the United States before 30,000 plus. "So why not?" Sumnikova said when asked if the Russians could win. "Why not?"

HEADLINE: Lambs Among the Bulls and Bears

BYLINE: By Ron Chernow; Ron Chernow, the author of "The House of Morgan" and "The Warburgs," is currently writing a biography of John D. Rockefeller Sr.

 BODY:
As the stock market retreats from its Himalayan heights of early June, investors have started to suspect, with stomach-churning queasiness, that it's not the cozy, inviting place depicted by their brokers. This sudden cooling of middle-class ardor may well slow the small investor's striking evolution from the pariah of the stock market to its motive force, a trend that gathered strength with the mutual fund boom.
A retrospective glance reflects the shift. In the late 19th century, market panics came regularly, at roughly 10-year intervals, shaking out all but hardened speculators. Leery of common stock, magnates like John D. Rockefeller Sr. packed their portfolios with gilt-edged railroad bonds. In those halcyon days, selling a piece of hypothetical future earnings (stocks) rather than guaranteed interest payments (bonds) was regarded as falling just shy of snake-oil salesmanship. The creation of United States Steel and other trusts electrified the public, yet J. Pierpont Morgan couldn't, in good conscience, recommend common stock to small investors. 
 Nevertheless, some Wall Street graybeards of the 1900's were scandalized that the House of Morgan lent its august imprimatur to stock flotations. Individual investors saw Wall Street as the raffish haunt of swindlers and slick city operators, and they either shied away from the market altogether or were the gullible rubes whose late arrival signaled that a rally had crested.
Stocks began to shed their stigma with the Liberty Bond drives of World War I, which broadened the investing public. In the 1920's, Wall Street made its first audacious bid to entice small investors, with banks setting up securities affiliates that promoted stocks with the subtlety of carnival barkers and blurred the distinction between saving and speculating.
Tempted by easy margin requirements and the moonshine rhetoric of unending prosperity, people dabbled in mutual funds called investment trusts, which invested in other trusts, in an endless chain of speculation. For all the razzmatazz, only about 1.5 million Americans played the market. When the 1929 crash predictably arrived, most people applauded it as condign punishment for those urban sophisticates seduced by the speculative mania.
Scarred by the experience, many middle-class investors, like chastened sinners, swore off stocks for a generation, and it took the Dow Jones average more than 20 years to straggle back to its pre-crash highs. In those moribund years, securities regulators banned the more blatant forms of collusion that had been prevalent in the 1920's, making the world safe for the shareholder democracy of the postwar era. By imposing stiff new reporting requirements on companies, New Deal regulators gave a fresh transparency to the stock market and equalized the chances for small investors who had been severely penalized by the insider training of the Jazz Age.
In the early 1950's, the New York Stock Exchange, to woo back investors scared away by the Depression, tried to advance the cause of "people's capitalism" through share ownership, but the investing population reached only about six million. It was the go-go years of the 1960's -- a faddish market awash in crazy conglomerate mergers and the supposed infallibility of growth stocks -- that lured 20 million investors into the market, blotting out cautionary memories of 1929.
The festivities ended abruptly in the early 1970's when the Arab oil embargo and accelerating inflation shattered a still tentative trust in paper assets. Gold, real estate, stamps, Impressionist paintings -- anything hard and tangible to the touch -- became investments of choice.
In August 1982, when the Federal Reserve Board declared victory over inflation and began to ease its Draconian monetary policy, the great middle-class romance with stocks commenced. People felt that in the 1970's they had been pauperized by thrift, with inflation diluting the value of their bank accounts. The ensuing drain of assets from banks persists: the more than $3 trillion now in mutual funds is fast approaching the $4.2 trillion of assets in the American commercial banking system. The bullish surge was further spurred when property values sagged in the late 1980's, refuting the comforting fallacy that real estate was somehow immune to economic laws.
The 1987 crash -- which, under ordinary circumstances, might have dampened faith in common stocks -- became instead a fountain of fresh illusions. Far from being a genuine crash (which are typically followed by bear markets), it was actually a gigantic market correction bearing a misleading message: that crashes are simply short-lived, vaguely unsettling affairs, no more than spectacular bouts of profit-taking forming the prelude to prolonged rebounds.
Buoyed by this belief in the market's eternal resiliency, investors flocked to Wall Street in astounding numbers. Some 51 million Americans now own common stock, either directly or through retirement plans. Wall Street has become wholesome and respectable, suburbanized and gentrified. This vogue has produced the most vibrant capital markets in history, giving American entrepreneurs an edge in world markets.
The public's faith in stocks hasn't been entirely misplaced. Slow but steady growth, subdued inflation, a cornucopia of dazzling new technologies, a widening of world markets with the demise of Communism, a spurt in world trade through lower protectionist barriers -- these are all fantastically bullish developments, the more so in combination.
Yet the present moment may be a fruitful one to contemplate some unforeseen consequences of years of unmitigated hoopla. Until this summer, the stock market had roared ahead for six years without the usual 10 percent correction. While Wall Street fretted that novice investors would dump their mutual funds in a fatally cascading wave of redemptions, the problem has probably been more nearly the reverse -- at least until recently.
Too well-schooled in the gospel of buy and hold, our prematurely wise new investors seemed all but immune to bad news. Never having experienced that ultimate rite of passage, a grim bear market, they evinced a pseudo-sophistication, a virginal innocence. While their long-term outlook is greatly preferable to the alternative, it may have had a perverse systemic effect.
With the market robbed of its customary ebb and flow, dangerous speculative bubbles may have developed. Because the steady cash infusions from 401(k) and other retirement plans feed money automatically into stocks, regardless of adverse developments, they can pump up stocks by liquidity alone.
It may also be an auspicious time to reconsider the market's new status as a sort of souped-up national nest egg. Where retirement funds were once sacrosanct, confined to certifiably dull stuff like investment-grade bonds, they now flow into everything from junk bonds to emerging market funds. The advent of defined contribution plans has shifted the investment burden from professional portfolio managers to often callow individual investors -- with as yet incalculable results.
While it's undoubtedly true that stocks outperform other investments in the long run, what if the baby boom generation reaches retirement amid a sustained bear market? And what will happen to those who retire in the short or intermediate term, before they reap their blessed long-term reward?
Whether the stock market smartly bounces back or resumes its slide, its gyrations are a salutary reminder that it does not proceed in a smooth, linear fashion. It is a volatile world, forever oscillating between extremes of euphoria and disenchantment. A whiff of sin, a potent stench of brimstone, has suddenly revisited the canyons of Wall Street. If we are smart, we will be the wiser for it.

SECTION: Section B; Page 3; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 787 words

HEADLINE: Top Restaurateur Will Buy Stock Back From Japanese

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
The management of Restaurant Associates Corporation, which has blazed a trail in the American restaurant industry and has managed some of Manhattan's most popular restaurants, signed an agreement yesterday to buy back all its stock from its Japanese owner of six years.
The high-profile 1990 purchase of Restaurant Associates by Kyotaru Company drew wide attention as the first major investment by a Japanese company in the American restaurant industry during a frenzied era of trans-Pacific deals. 
 The buyback reflects a continuing about-face by the Japanese on the American business landscape, as their companies have been divesting themselves of major United States investments that have included MCA and Rockefeller Center.
The company is known in New York City for running the popular Sea Grill at Rockefeller Center and Cafe Centro in the Metlife building. But it made its mark first by launching such restaurants as the Four Seasons and the Brasserie.
Because of the deal, average diners are likely to encounter more of the company's themed restaurants in the future, as Restaurant Associates uses its new financial resources to expand rapidly. The agreement has unusual significance in the restaurant world, analysts said, because of the prominence of the company's restaurants and chefs and its roster of blue-chip food-service clients ranging from AT&T to the Harvard Business School.
"Restaurant Associates has always been extremely skillful in establishing their presence and doing things with flair and great design sense," said Malcolm M. Knapp, who heads a restaurant consulting firm in Manhattan that bears his name.
Restaurant Associates, an operating and consulting group, employs 9,000 people and has created restaurants such as La Fonda del Sol, Trattoria and the Forum of the Twelve Caesars in Manhattan. A former executive, Joseph Baum, created the original Windows on the World and refurbished the Rainbow Room.
Restaurant Associates has also rebuilt such national chains as its Acapulco and Charlie Brown's groups. The company owns more than 130 restaurants with 25,000 seats, primarily on the East and West Coasts.
Restaurant Associates also owns 25 Charlie Brown's steakhouses in New Jersey and New York, the 45-unit Acapulco Mexican-restaurant chain in California, and smaller chains in the New York area. The company also provides cafeteria and catering services for such clients as Bertelsmann, Sony Music Entertainment, Morgan Stanley, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the American Museum of Natural History, Lincoln Center, the United Nations Delegates' Dining Room in New York, the Music Center of Los Angeles County and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.
The terms of the Restaurant Associates agreement were not disclosed, but Kyotaru appeared to have taken a loss. Industry executives valued the all-cash buyback of 100 percent of the company at nearly $100 million in a deal that will close in 30 to 45 days. In 1990, trade publications reported that the Japanese company paid $120 million, including the $80 million worth of debt it assumed.
"Finally we are in control of our own destiny," said Nick Valenti, who will remain the company's president and chief executive. The deal was the result of "a yearlong project to persuade the Japanese to sell the company," he said. Kyotaru executives in the United States and Japan did not return telephone calls.
Mr. Valenti has two investment-banking partners in the deal, Bruckmann, Rosser, Sherrill & Company and Furman Selz Investments, and the company will continue to be privately held. Last year revenues of Restaurant Associates, which were not publicly disclosed, were $270 million and its sales grew 11.3 percent, according to Nation's Restaurant News, an industry publication.
In 1988, the senior managers of Restaurant Associates arranged a leveraged buyout, purchasing 54 percent of its stock for $150 million. But the company was crushed by the resulting debt, and the purchase by Kyotaru was expected to infuse cash that would fuel expansion.
Virtually all of the original debt, estimated to be $80 million in 1990, has been assumed by Kyotaru, although Restaurant Associates still has a small debt, according to people with knowledge of the deal.
Yesterday restaurant-industry executives said that the trans-Pacific partnership had never really worked. For the Japanese, who had not been prepared for the American restaurant downturn in the early 1990's, the investment provided minimal opportunities for the distant parent company to intervene in a way that could improve profitability in the volatile and highly competitive American restaurant market.

HEADLINE: Wall Street Bond Rating Firm Faults New York Budget

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 25

 BODY:
Moody's Investors Service, one of the Wall Street firms that rates New York State's bonds, sharply criticized the new state budget today, saying it failed to solve the problem of recurring deficits and virtually insures long and bitter budget fights in the coming years.
The report probably does not mean that Moody's will downgrade the state's bond rating, which is already the second lowest, after Louisiana, among the 40 states the firm reviews. But it almost certainly means that Moody's will not upgrade New York's rating soon. 
 "This pattern of late budgets have not resulted in better budgets," said Robert Kurtter, a vice president of Moody's. "Other states have gotten budgets done on time and have built up surpluses and eliminated deficits. New York has still not addressed these things."
He was referring to the fact that the state's budget was enacted 104 days late this year, he said.
The state's bond rating is important because it determines how much interest the state pays on the billions of dollars in debt it sells each year. A lower bond rating forces the state to pay higher interest rates, which reduces the amount of money the state has to use for other purposes, like education or health care.
"If all the state's outstanding debt were upgraded a notch, the state would save tens of millions of dollars of each year," said Dennis Tompkins, a spokesman for State Comptroller H. Carl McCall.
The Moody's report said that the new budget was too dependent on "one-shot" revenues, so called because they will not recur next year and therefore cannot be counted on to help close the state's accumulated deficit.
This year's budget uses $1.3 billion in one-shots, including $481 million from a fund set aside for doctor's medical malpractice insurance and $150 million from an amnesty on delinquent taxpayers.
The report also criticized the state for doing almost nothing to reduce its accumulated deficit, which is currently near a historic high of about $7.5 billion. The accumulated deficit is not a shortfall in the current year's budget, but represents the gap over many years between what the state has taken in through revenues and what it has spent.
Mr. Kurtter said that the state should have taken advantage of the currently strong economy to close that accumulated deficit and prepare the state for an eventual economic downturn.

HEADLINE: Ousted Head Of Police Admits Fraud

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 25

 BODY:
Only five weeks after being ousted as Newark's Police Director, William R. Celester pleaded guilty today to three charges of fraud as part of the Federal Government's crackdown on government corruption in New Jersey's largest city.
Mr. Celester's lawyer, Anthony J. Pope, said his client had agreed in a plea deal with the Federal authorities to withdraw the not-guilty plea he entered after his indictment on June 20 and to admit wrongdoing to spare his family the travail of a trial. 
 "He's sorry for everything that's happened," Mr. Pope said.
"He pleaded guilty to what he thinks he was responsible for. Whatever he did wrong, he admitted to. He didn't want to put anyone through a trial, especially his family."
Under the plea bargain submitted to Judge Garrett E. Brown Jr. of Federal District Court, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, Faith S. Hochberg, agreed to drop 34 of the indictment's 37 fraud and embezzlement charges in exchange for Mr. Celester's admitting guilt to three counts.
Each dealt with three broad fraud charges: diverting about $29,500 from a "police director's" fund devoted to financing undercover narcotics investigations; keeping nearly $27,000 donated illicitly by police subordinates at a party marking his second anniversary as director, and filing a false 1993 income tax return that failed to list as income $7,750 taken from the narcotics-investigations fund and about $19,600 kept from the anniversary party.
Some of the counts Ms. Hochberg dismissed concerned Mr. Celester's falsifying a mortgage application for a house he and his wife bought in Newark in 1993.
The indictment said Mr. Celester had stated that a relative had given him a $37,000 down payment as a gift when, in fact, the money came from a source that has never been disclosed.
The written terms of the plea agreement submitted to Judge Brown made no reference to the house. Presumably, Mr. Celester and his wife will be allowed to keep it. Ms. Hochberg seemed exuberant about the plea bargain after leaving Judge Brown's courtroom. "It's a 100 percent win for the United States Government and the people of Newark," she said.
As Newark's crime rate grew, she said, "Mr. Celester took that money and put it in his pocket for his own purposes."
Mr. Celester said little outside the court and declined to discuss his plea. "I did the best job that I could," he said. "I think I left the city a lot better."
Ms. Hochberg and Mr. Pope said the agreement did not require any cooperation by Mr. Celester in the Government's continuing investigations into corruption in Newark. "There is no offer of information," Mr. Pope said. "He knows nothing about anyone, as far as I know. He has no further information."
Mr. Celester, who is 53, became Newark's Police Director in mid-1991 after serving in Boston as a deputy police superintendent and a commander in some of Boston's toughest neighborhoods. Newark officials had hoped his tenure would bring fresh crime-fighting ideas and vigorous leadership to a troubled department. But the indictment contended that he had started improperly diverting money from the narcotics-investigation funds a month after he arrived in Newark.
The money went for gifts and flowers for Mr. Celester's wife and a woman friend, trips to Bermuda and Mexico, Christmas gifts for his staff and political contributions to Mayor Sharpe James and unnamed Newark council members, the indictment said. As part of the fraud, he told Newark's business administrator that he had spent $170 at a luncheon and dinner with F.B.I. agents in late June 1994 when in fact the money was a political contribution.
Last November, after Federal agents raided Mr. Celester's home, Mayor James put him on an administrative leave. He was removed from the $95,000-a-year post in June, after his indictment, and is now unemployed, Mr. Pope said.
After Mr. Celester was ousted, critics of the 1,290-member department said he had left it demoralized and in some disarray, with crime increasing and citizens complaining about poor police response.
Mr. Celester is perhaps Newark's most prominent public figure toppled by scandal. Two former city councilmen, Gary S. Harris and Ralph T. Grant, are currently serving 33-month jail terms for taking payoffs from a towing company seeking a city contract. In addition, a top aide of Mayor James, Jackie R. Mattison, was indicted in January on charges of taking bribes from an insurance broker. For months, Ms. Hochberg's staff has been investigating whether money was diverted from a charity set up by Mayor James.
Mr. Celester faces a maximum prison term of 13 years at sentencing, which Judge Brown set for Oct. 7. Ms. Hochberg said her office would seek a lighter term than Federal guidelines provide. But she said that reduction would be a basic one, applied to all defendants who accept responsibility for a crime and spare the Government the costs of a trial.
Under the agreement, he must also repay almost $30,000 and refile four years of tax returns.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Rise as Worries About Earnings Ease
Disappointing earnings reports from technology companies have racked the stocks of late, so the market was happily relieved by I.B.M.'s news that its profits declined less than had been expected. Indeed, the gain in I.B.M. shares accounted for more than half of the Dow industrials' advance of 67.32 points, to 5,422.01.
Renewed optimism about the technology sector spilled over into the Nasdaq market, home of many smaller, high-tech issues. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 20.02 points, or 1.92 percent, to 1,062.39. [D8.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities rose on renewed optimism that inflation would stay in check. The yield on the long bond fell to 7.01 percent, from 7.04 percent on Wednesday. [D15.]
 
Aviation Security Is Tightened
New aviation security measures imposed by the Administration in the aftermath of T.W.A.'s crash will mean long lines, detailed searches and interrogations. Scrutiny will be particularly intense on flights overseas. [B6.]
 
Philips to Cut 6,000 Jobs
Philips Electronics of the Netherlands reported an unexpected quarterly loss as it took a charge of $454 million to pay for 6,000 job cuts in its consumer electronics unit. [D7.]
 
Boeing Earnings Are Robust
Boeing reported unexpectedly strong earnings, which were buoyed by the settlement of some longstanding disputes regarding military contracts with the Government and a pickup in commercial plane orders. [D2.]
 
Bank Acquisition Talks Are Seen
First Nationwide Bank, which is controlled by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, is said to be in talks to acquire California Federal Bancorp in a deal valued at more than $1 billion. [D15.]
 
Disney Earnings Rise 27.7%
The Walt Disney Company reported a 27.7 percent profit gain. Analysts said the broadcast and theme park businesses were strong, but several disappointing live action films hurt the Creative Content unit. [D4.]
 
Restaurant Associates Buyback Set
Restaurant Associates, known for such Manhattan restaurants as the Four Seasons and the Brasserie, agreed to buy back all its stock from Kyotaru, its Japanese owner of six years. [B3.]
 
Editors of Outdoor Life Quit
At Outdoor Life magazine, Stephen W. Byers, the editor in chief, and Will Bourne, the executive editor, resigned in protest after an executive at the parent, Times Mirror, killed a provocative article on bear baiting. [D4.]
 
Durable Goods Orders Slip
Orders for durable goods fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in June, hurt by weaker demand for aircraft, cars and business equipment. [D15.]
 
AT&T and Microsoft in Accord
AT&T and Microsoft said they had formed an alliance to distribute each other's on-line software. The agreement will let users of Windows 95 move onto the AT&T Worldnet service with the click of a mouse. [D8.]
 
Xerox Profits Increase
Xerox reported that its earnings rose 23.1 percent in the second quarter. [D2.]
 
A 'Retro Chic' Drink?
Young consumers may not want to drive their fathers' Oldsmobiles. But icons of their grandfathers' era, like cigars and stiff drinks, are faring better. An unconventional new campaign for Johnnie Walker Red Label Scotch whisky seeks to evoke this "retro chic" image. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Keep the Ban on Latin Weapons

 BODY:
American arms producers, backed by the Pentagon, are lobbying hard to get President Clinton to lift a 20-year-old ban on the export of advanced conventional weapons to Latin America. The defense industry, faced with shrinking military budgets around the world, is eager to open up new markets for its wares. The Pentagon, for its part, likes to keep weapons production lines busy, an activity it refers to as sustaining the defense industrial base. But allowing these arms sales, which the State Department opposes, runs counter to America's best interests.
Opening Latin markets to expensive, high-performance weapons like the F-16 fighter could lessen regional security by spurring local arms races. It could weaken economic development and democracy by diverting scarce resources from civilian needs. It would also run counter to America's declared policy of working to restrain the arms trade worldwide. 
 Defense Secretary William Perry cites the return to civilian government in most of Latin America as a strong argument for lifting the ban. The Carter Administration first imposed the restrictions to discourage destabilizing arms buildups by the military regimes then in power.
Yet some Latin American governments would be more comfortable keeping the ban in place. Argentina, which has cut military spending nearly in half since civilian rule returned in 1983, says it cannot afford F-16's and that introducing them to the region would jeopardize stability. Brazil says it cannot afford the planes either, but analysts there predict that the Government would buy them if they became available. The most visible support for lifting the ban comes from Chile, where the military is still not under full civilian control.
United States weapons exporters argue that lifting the ban would merely shift business from European to American companies. But America already dominates the Latin arms trade. Rather than heat up the competition, Washington should be encouraging other exporting nations to agree to comparable restraints.
Mr. Clinton ought to heed the report by a special Presidential Advisory Board on Arms Proliferation Policy submitted to him late last month. The board concluded that national security and foreign policy concerns should take priority over economic arguments in deciding issues of arms export policy. While the report recognizes the need to maintain sufficient defense production capacity to meet American military needs, it argues strongly that arms exports should not be used for that purpose and recommends converting unneeded weapons plants to civilian purposes.
Those recommendations mark a clear improvement over the arms sales guidelines the Administration announced early last year, which failed to make clear distinctions between economic and foreign policy goals.
The ban on exporting advanced weapons to Latin America has worked well and contributed to the growth of civilian democracy in the region. It would be foolish to jeopardize that success by shifting course now.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Surly New York As Olympic Host?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your July 21 editorial on the possibility of having the Olympics in New York City in 2008 seems balanced. But you overlook the most difficult problems that would accompany our playing host to the Games. 
 Some business people would profit greatly; some construction workers would have temporary work, and minimum-wage workers would be glad to have even these jobs. But we would all endure more air pollution and more strain on our stressed waste-disposal system and water supply.
It is unfortunate that our economy does not factor in the cost on our infrastructure when considering various enterprises. The Olympic Games, over all, might be disastrous for our city.
 
MICHAEL EHRLICH
New York, July 21, 1996

HEADLINE: MONUMBENT TO DECAY;
Toll Is Even Greater In Forgotten Anacostia

BYLINE: By DON TERRY with KAREN DE WITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Markeisha Richardson is a tall, athletic 13-year-old who lives in Valley Green, a public-housing development built in 1961. By the 1980's, it had come to be known as Death Valley, for all the killings in and around its 312 apartments.
Now the development is called Ghost Town, because most of the gunmen are either dead or locked up and because only eight families remain. They huddle together in a pair of two-story buildings, surrounded by dozens of boarded-up buildings as silent as tombstones in a graveyard. 
 "The boys at school say I live in the haunted house projects," Markeisha said. "But I don't care. At least I got a roof over my head. A lot of people don't even have that."
Markeisha lives in the other Washington, the neglected city east of the Anacostia River. The Anacostia has long been the Berlin wall of the capital. Its polluted waters divide the Washington of power and postcards from a city of poverty and broken promises.
West of the Anacostia are the polished monuments to America's might: the White House, the Capitol, the Gap.
On the other side are tarnished testimonials to America's failures: street corners crowded with jobless men; inadequately staffed health clinics; abandoned public housing, and thriving open-air drug markets.
Nowhere is the decline more visible than here, where the police are always busy, the body count from homicides is high and the city's highest rates of infant mortality and poverty eat away at people's spirits. While many problems in the District of Columbia can be found in any big city, they seem more embarrassing here because they are in the nation's capital.
"This is the same city where the President of the United States lives," said Mike Johnson, a community advocate from Ward 8, the city's poorest section, "and we're living in a war zone. How is he going to go overseas and tell other people how to live in peace, and he allows this to go on a few miles from the White House?"
The black middle class has long had a foothold east of the river, where Frederick Douglass, the fiery abolitionist known as the Sage of Anacostia, once lived. But in recent years much of the black middle class here and across the city has fled the District because of its stubborn poverty and deteriorating schools.
To counter this decline, successive Federal administrations have vowed to find new solutions to fight the urban plight.
Jack F. Kemp formed his grand vision for public housing while serving as Secretary for Housing and Urban Development under President George Bush. Speaker Newt Gingrich has talked about using Washington as a laboratory for Republican solutions to welfare, unemployment and crime. Most recently, the First Lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, sat in the White House penning her best seller on community responsibility for raising children. But so far, all the vaunted plans have produced is talk.
And as the financial crisis continues here, lawmakers on Capitol Hill are calling for more cuts in the city's budget. The citizens east of the river, families like Markeisha's, will surely feel the cuts the most.
Her school, in Ward 8, does not have enough books, much less computers. The police in the ward have to fight the highest crime rates in the city with the worst shortages of equipment, and the fear of violence is never far away.
"We had two people shot in my building once," she said. "And the other day, some boys jumped out of a car and started shooting. They looked younger than me. I just don't know why life is so crazy sometimes."
Hope might be battered in Markeisha's Washington, but it is not dead.
A few years ago, Valley Green tenants and the members of a church from Northwest Washington, the wealthy part of the city, turned one of the vacant apartments into a place of prayer and study.
They call the apartment the Jesus House.
In the living room, Bible study for children is held on Tuesday and Wednesday nights. In a back bedroom, six computers have been set up, and tutors from the church, Christ Our Shepard, come every Thursday.
Not long ago, Bible study was canceled because someone was shot to death on nearby Second Street, where some of the children live, and the gunman threatened to shoot anyone else he saw.
Katie French, Markeisha's tutor, is a 23-year-old technical writer who lives in Northwest. Recently Ms. French drove from Valley Green to Second Street to pick up children for the classes. As she drove, she passed a pile of debris along a curb.
"The city would never let this happen in Northwest," she said, pointing to the trash. "Never. Ever."
The next week, the trash was still there.
 
The Politics
Independence Is Threadbare
In the early 1970's, home rule held the promise of a better life for all Washingtonians, whether they lived in Ward 3, the city's richest, or Ward 8. But for black Washingtonians, 65 percent of the city's population, home rule had a meaning beyond the nuts and bolts of who would govern: It was a declaration of independence from the white Federal lawmakers who had been in charge.
In 1975, the funk-rock group Parliament captured the moment in their song "Chocolate City," celebrating Washington's new home rule as black America's "piece of the rock" surrounded by "vanilla suburbs."
"Hey, we didn't get our 40 acres and a mule, but we did get you, Chocolate City," the song goes. "You don't need the bullet when you've got the ballot."
Shortly after Marion S. Barry Jr. was sworn in as Mayor in 1978, the city was booming, especially downtown. Across the Anacostia, however, many people complained that the good times were passing them by.
By the mid-1980's, the national recession arrived, along with crack cocaine. And by the time Mr. Barry was arrested for drug possession in 1990, the District was well on its way to a financial crisis, brought on in part by the limits imposed by home rule and in part by the poor management of the city's leaders.
Nonetheless, the promise of home rule was still strong, even in the poor, black sections east of the Anacostia -- Wards 6 and 7 as well as 8. And these wards supported Mr. Barry in his 1994 political comeback after he served six months in prison.
Mr. Barry's claim of redemption resonated in a place where many people know from bitter man-in-the-mirror experience that hard times and personal demons can bend even the strongest back. Returning him to the mayor's office was as much a nose-thumbing at white Washington power brokers as it was a gesture of belief that Mr. Barry would improve their lot.
Mostly ignored by the rest of the city except in television reports of the drive-by shooting, the abandoned baby, the found body, voters east of the Anacostia went to the polls with a vengeance. Their numbers canceled out the anti-Barry vote of affluent, white areas like Ward 3, which had once avidly supported him.
But the city's fiscal trauma has left Mr. Barry powerless to deliver the jobs and perquisites of his three earlier administrations when he larded the bureaucracy with jobs for his supporters.
Instead, shake-ups, dismissals and furloughs have been the order of the day as the city struggles under the eye of a financial control board, appointed by President Clinton last year to manage the District's budget.
"There's a lack of spirit in the people like I've never seen before," said Rahim Jenkins, the leader of a black men's anti-crime and civic group. "It's almost like God doesn't live in D.C. anymore."
Not even Mr. Barry's presence as a resident has brought any succor to Ward 8 -- except, people say, for the residents of his block. The round-the-clock police detail that guards Mr. Barry must make that block one of the safest in the city, they say.
But even Ward 8's love affair with the Mayor may be waning. When asked about the impact of the city's fiscal crisis on their lives, people east of the river said they were used to being powerless in a city of power.
"He's a politician, right?" Jacqueline Massey, a neighborhood advocate and president of the Valley Green tenants group, said of Mr. Barry. "He came through here years ago and promised to help us, and the next thing we know he's in jail. But he's no different than any other politician. They all make promises on Monday and break them on Tuesday."

The Section
Expanse of Woe At Capitol's Elbow
The rolling hills east of the Anacostia offer some of the best views of Washington, especially at night when the Capitol is lighted up like an unobtainable magic kingdom. But this area is the Washington left off the tourist maps -- where statistics read like those in a developing country; where bad things can happen at any time, and where people start at an early age to talk more about surviving life than enjoying it. The city's spiraling financial decline has only made things worse.
East of the river are 7,000 welfare cases. To the west, in Ward 3, there are 30.
In Ward 8, 26 percent of the households live at the Federal poverty level, compared with 15 percent in the city over all and 6 percent in Ward 3, according to 1992 local statistics. There is only one public library branch and a smaller public community library in Ward 8. But in Ward 3, the home of four universities with their libraries, the city has three public library branches, plus a larger regional library.
Although almost half the births in the city take place east of the river, there are only a few pediatricians there willing to accept Medicaid patients.
There are about 13,000 licensed doctors in Washington, but only a few have private practices in its neediest neighborhoods, said Dr. Mohammad N. Akhter of the city's Department of Human Services.
"In one way, Washington is the capital of the free world," Dr. Akhter said. "But in another way, it is an example of a third world country. Cuba has a better infant mortality rate than Washington."
Historically, said Patricia Hawkins, associate director of the Whitman-Walker AIDS clinic, the neighborhoods east of the Anacostia have never received their fair share of services.
"You'd think, where you have this concentration of problems, you'd have a concentration of services," Dr. Hawkins said. "It has not worked out that way."
Indeed, east of the river is a hard place to feel good about the American Dream. There are only a couple of restaurants where a family can go to sit down and have a meal. In Ward 8, even the McDonald's is closed and boarded up. There is no children's clothing store. There is no movie theater, health club or auto repair shop. And some of the mom-and-pop delis have recently been shut down for selling drugs along with the subs.
But there are plenty of liquor stores.
 
The Crisis
Today's Problems Look the Same
While voters in Ward 3 grumble about potholes, canceled recycling days or fewer garbage collections, in Ward 8 the cutbacks and shortages can be life-threatening.
Inspector Winston Robinson, the commander of the seventh police district, which is responsible for the neighborhood where Markeisha lives, sees the impact of the city's budget crisis in an increase in crime that is matched by a shortage of patrol cars and typewriter ribbon.
A year ago, crime was down in his district, Mr. Robinson said, "but so far this year, we've had an increase."
There have been more than 30 homicides in the seventh district this year; there have been none in Ward 3.
Repairs and replacements to the city's battered fleet of police cars have meant fewer patrols on the street. For the first six months of this year, Mr. Robinson said his district usually had only eight police cars on the streets on any given night, when it is supposed to have 21.
"We couldn't get parts -- tires, batteries, none of the essentials," he said. "You can't provide quality police service if you don't have mobility."
Mr. Robinson said that the district currently had about 16 cars on the street, and that now that Congress had promised to pump millions of dollars into the department even while cutting other areas of the District's government, he expected to get more cars out on patrol.
"But our biggest burden now is restoring the public's trust," he said. "People were feeling pretty good about us last year. The budget problems kind of whacked everything out of order."
On a recent rainy Saturday night, two 20-something police officers, who were afraid to have their names used in the newspaper, patrolled the streets and said they were lucky to have a police car that ran.
They said that there was only one typewriter -- a manual -- at the station, and that it often had no ribbon. "If you want to type your reports," one said, "you have to bring your own."
In two hours, their police radio crackled at least five times with reports of shots fired. The officers said no day passed without a Code 1 call, a top-priority case.
They said their colleagues in the second district patrolling Ward 3 told them that a week could pass without a Code 1.
When people in Ward 8 are asked what impact the city's fiscal problems is having on their shops, schools and hopes for their children, most answer with a weary been-through-it-all-before shrug.
"Sweetheart," said Mrs. Massey, the advocate for public-housing residents in Ward 8, "over here, living through crises is an everyday way of life, and it's been that way for a long, long time. The only reason people are paying any attention now is because the pain we always feel has spread to other parts of town."
At Heart Junior High School, where Markeisha is in the seventh grade, her guidance counselor is Barbara Faison, who also coaches the tennis team. Ms. Faison has to share a computer and a typewriter with three other counselors, each of whom has about 250 students.
There is barely enough money for basic educational supplies, but everyone, Ms. Faison says, knows more budget cuts are coming.
"A cut here feels much deeper than a cut in Ward 3," she said. "There, the cuts might feel like a nick. Over here it feels like someone just cut off your hand."
Markeisha and her friends in Valley Green are wise beyond their years. They have to be to survive. But they are also just ordinary children. And like the grown-ups in their world, they learn early on how to make do with less.
James McCrae, 13, uses the boarded-up buildings in the development to practice his tennis game. Recently, he worked on his backhand, slamming the ball against a wall and a faded "No Trespassing" sign. Sometimes the ball went high and wide and hit a boarded-up window, sending a hollow echo floating over the Valley.
"Ain't nothing to be scared of around here now," James said, wiping his round face. "Ain't nothing left."
Then Markeisha flew by on her green 10-speed as the younger children chased her down the potholed street, calling her name and begging for a turn on the bicycle.
When she slowed down long enough to reveal some of her dreams, Markeisha said she wanted to be a doctor or a hair stylist like her mother. That is, she added, "if something bad doesn't happen to me."
Because of violence in the neighborhood, tutoring sessions and Bible study at the Jesus House had to be canceled at least twice this year. One night, as the tutors pulled onto Second Street to pick up children, several police officers, their guns drawn, were running around after conducting a raid on a drug house.
One of the younger children who did not usually attend the tutoring sessions ran up to the car of Ms. French, the tutor, crying and begging to go along because he was afraid to stay on the block.
"We couldn't bring him," Ms. French said. "We didn't have enough tutors or cars."
Ms. French said that although there were some scary moments for the tutors, they were determined to keep coming. "People live here every day," she said. "Why should we be safer than them?"
That same night, Markeisha told Ms. French that she hoped the tutors would always be there because they were fun to be with and because they took the children on trips out of the city.
"I'm ready to move," Markeisha said, "even though violence is everywhere."
"It's not everywhere," Ms. French said.
"Yes, it is," Markeisha insisted.
"No," Ms. French said, "there are some neighborhoods where you feel safe."
"That's where I want to live," Markeisha said.
 
The Spirit
Fight for Survival Brings New Hope
Most of the monuments east of the Anacostia are flesh and blood, ordinary people trying to grow flowers in a desert. They are people like Willis Thomas, a tennis coach with the Arthur Ashe Foundation, and Hannah M. Hawkins, founder of a social service program, Children of Mine.
The Ashe foundation provides tennis lessons and tutoring to inner-city children.
"If these kids weren't out here playing tennis, they'd probably be running the streets," said Mr. Thomas, who has coached professional players like Zina Garrison-Jackson and Katrina Adams. "Over in Ward 3, people are trying to make the social registry. Over here, they're just trying to survive."
Mrs. Hawkins founded Children of Mine about 11 years ago. It offers after-school meals, tutoring and family counseling. There are days when Mrs. Hawkins, who is 56, is alone with 80 children because she has no money to pay a staff. Everything the program uses, from chairs to toys, is donated. She is not paid.
"We're in worse shape over here than we've ever been," she said. "But through the grace of God, we attempt to do it."
Every other Sunday, the Players Lounge, a restaurant and bar on Martin Luther King Avenue, is turned into a gospel show place. The bottles of gin and whisky are removed from the shelves, and the beer advertisements and cigarette machines are covered with sheets.
"In a matter of minutes," said Philip Pannell, an advocate for the neighborhood, "the Players Lounge becomes the Prayers Lounge. Over here, you learn how to stretch everything you can, including faith and hope."
Arrington Dixon, a businessman and former member of the City Council, returned several years ago to Ward 8, where he had grown up. He is now chairman of a neighborhood civic association. He also runs a telecommunications company from his basement, just down the block from the drug dealers on Martin Luther King Avenue.
Mr. Dixon knows one dealer from their being Boy Scouts together.
"We have a lot of work to do to turn this around," Mr. Dixon said. "To get fair treatment, you have to make noise. The city is doing less here because the political strength is not here. Other parts of the city have more resources and time to make demands. We have people working two jobs just to reach the poverty level. We have to get an infusion of more middle-class people. And we have to organize."

PUB-DATE: July 26, 1996

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2362 words

HEADLINE: Washington's Troubles Hit Island of Affluence

SERIES: MONUMENT TO DECAY -- Second of three articles.

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
The crucial votes had barely been counted in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s resurrection from jailhouse to City Hall two years ago when he offered some hard-eyed advice to those who had voted against him as the personification of this city's breakdown.
"To those white people who have whatever hang-ups they have, get over it," Mr. Barry boldly instructed. "Get over it: I'm the best person for Washington. I know best how to protect their investments, their homes, their businesses." 
 As the city government has since spiraled further downward, Mr. Barry's message has been taken to heart with a vengeance in the District of Columbia's splendid northwestern enclave of affluence, power and white isolation, Ward 3.
"There's been a sea change here among residents," said Jeffrey Itell, the former publisher of The Northwest Side Story, a weekly newspaper, reflecting on the ward's status as one of the nation's handsomest and most influential urban stretches, yet one with its civic grievances. "Even though they remain liberal up here, it's the equivalent of liberals who've been mugged -- who feel mugged by their own government, one they've concluded is totally corrupt and ineffective."
If anything, Mr. Barry's return to power has sealed the separation enforced by the thick barrier of parkland that long has kept the black majority of the city a world apart from the northwest ward. The ward remains a sanctuary of middle- and upper-income privilege, of solid public schools and of higher-priced housing enjoyed by some of the most established powers of American government, commerce and culture, and of world diplomacy as well.
Once avid, even idealistic in their support of home rule and of the first election of Mr. Barry in 1978, the jaded white voters of the Northwest are now vocal in their complaints of abandonment by City Hall. Many say they fear that the fiscal crisis and waves of budget cuts threaten the ward's enviable schools and chill the housing market.
Northwest residents have become so disillusioned with home rule that ward politicians intent on seeming creative are openly asking whether it is time to debate alternatives. Some even support having the District rejoin neighboring Maryland. As a city of that state, Washington would have broader powers than it does today under its restricted independence.
"How exciting it was when home rule came along," recalled Anne Mohnkern Renshaw, a longtime civic volunteer and the elected chairwoman of an advisory commission in the District's Chevy Chase neighborhood, which borders a suburban Maryland counterpart. "I thought: what a great chance for the city, not only as the national capital but as a pilot project for urban areas. Unfortunately, this did not come about. Residents are utterly frustrated with bad government. We'll soon be on our knees."
Older residents recall the period before home rule when President Richard M. Nixon enlarged and modernized the police force. "I was proud to be a homicide detective in those days," said Ronald L. Robertson, chairman of the city's Fraternal Order of Police. "Now, you hear absolutely nothing from Clinton about the city."
 
The Ward
 
Plowing Streets And Other Steps
Despair is hardly as visible a commodity in the Northwest, where Ward 3 is 88 percent white, as it is across town in Ward 8, which is 91 percent black. Three of five adults in Ward 3 have college degrees, while fewer than 1 in 10 in Ward 8 has. The Northwest is distinguished by upper-income shopping strips, glistening food marts and spacious supermarkets. These feed off median incomes 60 percent higher than the city's average, and more than twice the $21,312 median in Ward 8, which has but one full-size supermarket of its own for close to the same number of people.
For all this material edge, people in Ward 3 complain increasingly that home rule, which local voters hailed over 20 years ago, has come to mean a patronage-bloated, ineffective city payroll offering phantom services. More and more residents are so furious at the treadmills of bureaucratic delay that to cite but one routine example, they now simply violate the law: They are building additions onto their homes without permits, rather than wait for action by the city's notorious department that handles the paperwork, said Stephen A. Koczak, a veteran civic leader.
"What we have now is anarchy," said Mr. Koczak, president of the Cleveland Park neighborhood Citizens Association, noting how this sort of building violation conflicted with the civic instincts of the area. "Gradually people come to feel they have to take care of themselves and not worry about the other guy."
Mundane crises abound in the ward: A typewriter shortage at one precinct led to court challenges of handwritten arrest reports as illegible. A bent extension ladder on a Cleveland Park firetruck made third-floor rescues problematical, just as reduced hose crews cut a pumper's effectiveness in half. Well beyond having to plow many snowy streets themselves, residents have invented ways to pay for equipment the city can no longer afford, including bulletproof vests, pencils, office computers, shower heads in firehouses and even a radar gun. Some taxpayers maintain the trees along public walks, pay for private trash hauling or pay teacher aides after the city stops. Sixteen-year-old David Jeffs is given credit for going out this spring to fill in a deepening pothole on MacArthur Boulevard.
New Yorkers and other hardened urbanites might be more amused than empathetic about the problems and the complaints from this well-endowed ward. But residents show a keen sense of the ludicrous, and sarcasm still overflows because the District government was unable to plow the streets last winter, yet blitzed the citizenry with parking tickets for snowbound cars -- and even with tickets for unraked leaves during one brief thaw before the next storm.
"Grit in the sore," Ms. Renshaw said, noting there were but four repair crews for the city's endlessly pocked streets even as dozens of new ticket writers had been hired to claw fresh revenue into the District's cash-starved coffers.
Scott H. Strauss, a member of another of the ward's advisory neighborhood commission, said he was frustrated at trying to help his constituents sway City Hall policy.
"My role is sort of like Nero's: standing around and fiddling while the city burns down in despair," Mr. Strauss said.
 
The District
One Capital, Two Cities
The splendor of the Northwest makes Washington a graphic tale of two cities. Proud ward residents, endlessly active in civic matters, enjoy the most expensive housing in Washington, with 97 percent of the single-family dwellings assessed at more than $200,000, and only 1 percent of the ward's houses being subsidized. In Ward 8, east of the Anacostia River, 23 percent of housing is publicly subsidized.
The Northwest's contrast with the city's most troubled areas could not be more evident than in its minuscule homicide rate, with the ward recording about one killing a year -- in a city where the yearly homicide body count goes beyond 400, earning it the title of the drug era's Murder Capital of the World.
In Ward 3, property crimes are carefully tallied each week over police telephone lines, with regular references to young black perpetrators. Listening can feed the anecdotal conclusion of burghers that "outsiders," not fellow city dwellers, prey on the ward, even as it remains one of the safer upscale urban sanctuaries in the nation.
"If somebody tried to start an open-air drug market in Ward 3, it couldn't happen," said Kathy Smith, a block-watch organizer who is the editor of the Street Smart newsletter. Ms. Smith knows the contrast between the powerful professionals who live in the ward and their crime-ravaged neighbors across town. "Instantly, people here would be up in arms," she said, "and the police would have to respond to hundreds of calls."
Ms. Smith said she sensed that volunteerism was growing stronger in the face of the dwindling services, mismanagement and budget shortfalls that bedevil the city.
"We're not about to dumb ourselves down and make things work inefficiently here just to make somebody else happy," she vowed.
Northwesterners pay a large share of city taxes, and as they receive less service in return, more families are debating the chronic question of affluent urban Americans: whether to move to the nearby suburbs or put their children in one of the dozens of private schools that serve the ward's sizable constituency of government and diplomatic professionals, lawyers, lobbyists and workers in the city's huge news and public-relations industries.
Like other ward residents, Mr. Strauss, of the advisory commission, said he found the Mayor bizarrely self-absorbed in personal retreat and political posturing while the city reeled in crisis. And like others, Mr. Strauss, a Washington lawyer, countered his exasperation with volunteerism.
"The schools have people scared again," said Mr. Strauss, a former New Yorker who views a move to the suburbs as a personal defeat. He has committed his three children to the public schools of North Cleveland Park, but sees mounting anxiety in the ward as budget and personnel cuts add to the pressure on its highly rated schools. They have long waiting lists of applicants eager to join those already commuting from poorer wards.
"But you got a dilemma," Mr. Strauss said, "because home values are dropping, and how much of a hit are you willing to take to get out?"
Schools will have larger classes this fall, closer to the suburban model, because of budget cuts. But a proposed reduction of 240 teachers will affect Ward 3 less than other areas of the city because its schools are already at capacity or beyond and would not be forced to take the cut. At the same time, there is no capital construction budget to speak of, and parents are increasingly being drawn into volunteer efforts to replace boilers and roofs.
Last spring, a noticeable number of parents in Ward 3, worried that the schools might suffer grievously at the hands of the financial control board, appointed last year by President Clinton, put up signs on their lawns: "Control Board, if schools are not your priority, this house is For Sale!"
 
The Issues
Trying to Bring People Together
Beyond anxiety, some residents say common dilemmas are providing an unusual bonding agent for the Northwest enclave and the rest of the city, and might even prove that neighborhood distinctions of race and income can be exaggerated in this class-partitioned capital.
"The basic issues facing people all over the city are crime, schools, financial problems and delivery of services in a timely fashion, without surliness," said Roxane Sismanidis, president of the Woodley Park neighborhood Community Association, who finds estimates of the Ward 3's privileged perch highly overblown.
"I don't think there are black, white or Hispanic views on potholes," Ms. Sismanidis added, speaking as a parent advocate at the Oyster public school, a respected bilingual institution that, as a magnet school, is more integrated than schools in the poorest black wards. "Schools are falling apart all over the city, and it's disgusting all over the city."
The ward is the sort of civics-steeped place where Councilwoman Kathy Patterson, a former newspaper reporter who covered Congress, first became involved in municipal problems when her children entered school.
"My two kids' teachers are two of the most important people in my life," said Ms. Patterson, who was soon organizing parent protest rallies outside City Hall and, ultimately, winning a Council seat.
"Mentally and emotionally, we're very much a part of the city," she said, in denying accusations that the Northwest is a classic case of affluent withdrawal. "My people's economic situation is such that they could live where they please. They live in Washington because they want to. Theirs is a huge commitment."
Even so, the Councilwoman is one of the ranking ward Democrats enthusiastic about looking into merging the city into Maryland, leaving only the city's core Federal buildings as the District. She emphasizes that, unlike past Ward-3-only separatist movements, which were denounced as racist, this one would leave the city with a majority of blacks, but give it the greater power that would come from being part of the bordering state.
Merger with Maryland is being pursued by the Committee for the Capital City, a small private group led by Lawrence H. Mirel. A white lawyer who was general counsel to the City Council 15 years ago, Mr. Mirel lives with his wife, a city schoolteacher, in a predominantly black, affluent part of neighboring Ward 4.
"The black-majority government works fine," Mr. Mirel said. "It just has too much to do and too little resources."
Joining Maryland would retain the city's racial definition and, he said, allow for fairer representation in Congress and more resources to meet Washington's current state-scale responsibilities.
This and other proposals are mere talking points, far from adoption in a city that in the meantime must fight the fiscal crisis with individual enterprise. Melissa M. Kunstadter, a Ward 3 resident, is president of the Federation of Friends of the District of Columbia Public Library. Her group, black and white, rich and poor, has fought citywide to keep all 27 library branches open, although now only one night a week, with a four-day schedule for the summer.
"I wish D.C. could get over this racial nonsense," said Ms. Kunstadter, who has a richer sense of cross-ward relations than many other Ward 3 residents. In contrast to her experience, she finds the city administration's routine emphasis on black pride overshadowing the possibilities of the current crisis.
"There is quite a bit of elbow room to bring people together in this city," she said.
 
Monument to Decay
 
THURSDAY How and why the District of Columbia is falling apart.
TODAY A look at two neighborhoods: Washington's richest and its poorest.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 49; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 377 words

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Has Broad-Based Gain, Aided by Rise in U.S. Stocks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against leading currencies yesterday as stocks rallied in the United States for a second day, easing concern that global investors will flee American assets and shed their dollar holdings.
In other trading, the German mark gained against other European currencies following the Bundesbank's decision on Thursday to hold interest rates steady, upsetting expectations of a rate cut. 
 Declines in the United States stock market had helped drag the dollar down more than 2 percent against the mark and yen last week. But stocks have recovered somewhat in the last two days.
"The market had positioned itself to sell dollars in anticipation of further stock market weakness," said Philip Vasan, head of global foreign exchange at CS First Boston. With stocks rebounding, "we're seeing those positions squeezed out of the market," Mr. Vasan said.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.4822 marks from 1.4775 marks on Thursday. The dollar also traded at 108.37 Japanese yen, up from 108.31 yen. The British pound fell to $1.5545 from $1.5575.
On Thursday, the mark surged after the Bundesbank held interest rates steady at its council meeting. Many analysts had expected a rate reduction, which would have made mark deposits less attractive.
"They absolutely have to cut the repo rate," said Fuad Khadder, executive director of foreign exchange for American Express Bank. "If they don't cut it, they're headed for a real economic slowdown."
The Bundesbank has frozen the repo rate, which it charges German financial institutions for temporary loans in exchange for government securities, at 3.3 percent since February. It last cut rates April 18, when it lowered the discount rate to a record-tying low of 2.5 percent.
It is possible that the Bundesbank "may be at the end of its easing cycle," said Scott Gallopo, chief currency trader at Chase Manhattan Bank. "It's reluctant to cut rates."
Still, the Bundesbank has a reputation for surprising financial markets, and a rate reduction cannot be ruled out when the central bank's council returns from a summer break on Aug. 22, traders said.
"The Bundesbank tends not to conform to the consensus view," Mr. Vasan of CS First Boston said. "Anything is possible."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Move High-Speed Train Idea Away From Coast

 BODY:
To the Editor:
John Henry (letter, July 19) is off the mark in criticizing boat and marina owners' objections to Amtrak's plans to add more and faster trains between New York and Boston and require drawbridges in Connecticut to close for longer periods of time.
Marina owners and boaters are tax-paying citizens and significantly add to the local economy. 
 To suggest that boats are the playthings of the rich and nearly rich is incorrect. The rich and nearly rich are the people who can afford the price of a Federal taxpayer-subsidized Amtrak ticket from Washington or New York to Boston. Few if any of these passengers are Connecticut residents.
Besides, the nearly 100-year-old New Haven railroad bridges are probably in danger of falling down from rust because of years of deferred maintenance.
If Amtrak wants a high-speed rail corridor from New York to Boston, it needs to obtain a right-of-way that is away from the coastline and as straight as possible to permit operating speeds above 150 miles per hour. The cost of such an undertaking would reach into the billions of dollars.
 
EDWARD GOELLER
Poughkeepsie, N.Y., July 20, 1996

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
For the first half of this year, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Milwaukee, Rembert G. Weakland, had been out of sight and out of the news, taking a sabbatical to finish a doctoral dissertation on ancient church music at Columbia University.
Then on the Fourth of July, the 69-year-old prelate tossed a firecracker into the welfare debate. In an op-ed article in The Washington Post, the Archibishop urged President Clinton to refuse the scores of Federal waivers necessary for Wisconsin's sweeping reform of its welfare system. 
 Although Mr. Clinton said in May that he would approve Wisconsin's plan, the issue is now bound up with whether he will sign Congressional legislation that, like Wisconsin's plan, would end guaranteed welfare payments to the poor.
Archbishop Weakland wrote that the plan, Wisconsin Works, or W-2, which requires almost all welfare recipients to take jobs, some for subsidized wages, was "not morally justifiable."
In Wisconsin, where Archbishop Weakland's statement was quickly reported and reprinted, it set off a whole string of firecrackers. The noise drew attention not only to the issues of welfare and the place of religion in politics but also to the personality of one of the governors most frequently mentioned as Bob Dole's possible running mate.
"The Bishop should come back to Wisconsin and read his Bible instead of playing piano in New York," snapped Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin. The Governor's chief spokesman, Kevin W. Keane, portrayed the churchman as an impractical meddler, an image favored by conservatives and liberals alike when they do not like a religious leader's message.
Local cartoonists had a great time with images of Archbishop Weakland at his piano and Governor Thompson in a pulpit.
What particularly angered the Governor was his impression that Archbishop Weakland had called the state's plan harmful to children.
In fact, the Archbishop's major objection was subtler, and more basic.
"It is patently unjust," he wrote, to remove the basic guarantee of a "safety net" -- a minimal level of assistance for food, clothing and shelter -- for the poor and especially for poor children.
Indeed, although the plan would at least initially increase outlays for child care and job-related benefits -- unlike the welfare bills passed by the House and Senate -- it explicitly states that ultimately no one is guaranteed job help or any other government aid, regardless of meeting all the eligibility requirements.
Is this not exactly the kind of question of basic moral principle that religious leaders should address?
Perhaps the point could be illustrated by a hypothetical example: removing of warning signs and safety railings, or randomly installing nonworking air bags, in an effort to reduce the carnage on the highways since the resulting threat to life and limb would increase personal responsibility and make people drive more safely?
Would the suffering and death of reckless drivers who served as object lessons to others be justified? Would it make any difference if the victims included passengers or innocent people in other cars? Would it make a difference if the gain in accidents prevented and lives saved were a virtual certainty or simply a plausible but untested theory?
The example may be bizarre. But it dramatizes the questions of principle that Archbishop Weakland was posing about the removal of a guaranteed welfare safety net: Should society compel adults to change their behavior even if doing so means increasing the risk to their children?
Addressing such questions cannot stop with thought-provoking examples or with cost-benefit analysis abstracted from real-world circumstances and history.
Even questions of principle demand an immersion in the details of the problem -- Archbishop Weakland spent years leading the committee that drafted the Catholic bishops' pastoral letter on the American economy -- and demand the wisdom and intuition born from experience more than from theory.
But such questions also demand the accumulated thinking about moral conflicts that religious and philosophical traditions build up over time and express sometimes in explicit codes or commandments, sometimes in parables and proverbs or, in the Catholic case, in papal encyclicals, episcopal letters and moral theology.
In Wisconsin, the opening fireworks gave way to a moderately useful debate. Governor Thompson issued two much more reasoned replies to Archbishop Weakland. Besides defending his administration's concern for children and restating his criticism of the notion that welfare can be overhauled without new expenditures, he seemed to speak directly to the question of entitlements or a guaranteed safety net:
"Society can't expect people to work but then provide them with a guaranteed check if they don't," the Governor said. "You can't have it both ways and still expect to help children."
Yet Mr. Thompson hedged this apparently clear-cut principle with repeated assurances that "while eliminating the entitlement, we are clearly making a firm commitment to caring for the children" and that "no child will be allowed to go hungry or without shelter."
So is there a guaranteed safety net or not? Or is that deliberately to be kept ambiguous, with the government assuring worriers like Archbishop Weakland, "Trust me"?
These are issues that remain as unresolved, and as urgently in need of examination, at the national level as at Wisconsin's.
