HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRATS;
President's Theme: Layoffs Fall and Wages Rise

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
As Republicans ready an attack on President Clinton's economic record, Democrats are working to offset widespread anxiety among workers over layoffs and stagnant wages by arguing that the worst days of the downsizing era are over.
In interviews over the last week, the President's top economic advisers and Democratic leaders of Congress made clear that they were preparing to make a case in the election campaign that fewer and fewer people were losing their jobs and that wages were beginning to rise. 
 Over all, Democrats argue that four years of economic recovery have given Mr. Clinton a strong record to run on. But they are concerned that anxiety over job security and frustration over wages that barely seem to rise could be uppermost in voters' minds. Their response is the Administration's first public articulation of a campaign theme that the President's advisers have been hinting at for weeks.
The essence of the emerging argument -- endorsed by the President, his advisers say -- is this: Anxiety over job security is undeniable. Don't tell voters they have no grounds for concern. Instead, point out that the economic recovery (credit Administration policies for same) has created so many jobs and so much demand for workers, that layoffs have declined over the last two years and, for the first time in more than a decade, wages are beginning to rise by more than the inflation rate.
"The numbers suggest that the worst is over," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, director of Mr. Clinton's National Economic Council, referring to the wage stagnation that began in the 1970's and the tens of millions of layoffs that have characterized corporate downsizing.
Similar messages come from Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Joseph E. Stiglitz, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. For the first time in years, Mr. Rubin says, wages are going up for the bottom 40 percent of American wage earners as well as the upper 60 percent.
"When you have a sustained period of unemployment under 6 percent, as we have had," he said, "that shows up and down the income scale."
And Mr. Stiglitz, filling out the new theme, declared: "We will continue to emphasize that we are concerned about dislocated workers. But one of the benefits of strong economic growth is that the incidence of layoffs is lower and, with wages rising, those who are laid off have a better opportunity to get new jobs that pay well. That is what is happening now."
In support of such claims, Administration officials cite a half-dozen statistics that show improvement. No one denies that strong economic growth in recent quarters has pushed unemployment down, given a lift to wages and perhaps made job hunting less of a trauma for those laid off. But many economists wonder whether the improvement marks a turning point, as the Administration now asserts, or only a blip upward that will disappear in the inevitable next recession, which some forecasters expect by next year.
The Administration, for example, notes that the average hourly earnings of 80 million workers below managerial rank have been rising since 1993 at a faster pace than inflation, something that over the last 23 years has only happened for brief periods in the late 1970's and mid-1980's.
The Administration cites similarly inconclusive data on job loss through layoffs. The most authoritative count is done by the Labor Department in a biennial survey. The one covering 1994 and 1995 -- the turnaround years, in the Administration's view -- was done in January, but the results will not be tabulated until September, at the earliest.
In the interim, the Administration has cited "proxy" statistics -- particularly the number of unemployed Americans who recently lost their jobs. That number has been trending downward and Mr. Stiglitz, in a recent white paper, took this as a strong indication "that the job loss rate has declined since 1993."
Some labor economists question that assertion, noting that Mr. Stiglitz's proxy leaves out those laid off workers not counted among the unemployed because they have ceased to look for work.
Whatever the accuracy of the Administration's new campaign theme, it has so far drawn little challenge within Mr. Clinton's own party. Two Democratic Congressional leaders, Representatives Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, and David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the ranking Democrat on the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, have been outspoken about the need to improve wages and reduce layoffs. Now they have muted such talk and signed onto the new campaign theme, although with caveats.
"We are moving in the right direction," Mr. Gephardt said, offering a view similar to Mr. Obey's. "But I don't know I would say we have turned the corner."
Even the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is not challenging the Administration's job theme, "although we don't quite believe it," said Steve Rosenthal, the federation's political director.
"We are not convinced that America has turned the corner," Mr. Rosenthal said, "but on the other hand, we feel strongly that the President needs to be re-elected."
What criticism there is has come, not surprisingly, from the Republicans, although not from Bob Dole, the likely Presidential candidate. John Taylor, a Stanford University economist and a Dole adviser, says the Administration is simply wrong in its interpretation of the wage data.
"The numbers go up and down, but the trend continues," Mr. Taylor said. "Wage stagnation is the right word."
During the primary campaign, Mr. Dole had stayed largely silent on the wage and job security issues, while Pat Buchanan hammered away on these themes. Now he will recognize them once he has developed policies to deal with these problems, says Nelson Warfield, the Dole campaign's press secretary.
"I think that Bill Clinton has fallen into the flabby politics of self-satisfaction on wages and jobs," Mr. Warfield said.
By all accounts, the Dole solution, like the Clinton one, is an economic policy intended to stimulate more economic growth, thus sustaining the sort of demand for workers that raises wages and makes companies more reluctant to lay them off.
Most economists argue that a far more vigorous expansion than the present one is needed to raise wages significantly and minimize layoffs. But the economy, they say, may not be capable today of such strong growth, a caveat that does not show up in either the Republican or Democratic campaign commentary.
The Dole solution for greater growth is likely to be a proposal for a major tax cut, his advisers say, that would encourage investment in the new machinery and equipment that would make the growth possible without rising inflation. The Clinton Administration, however, says its mix of policies has already put the nation on this very growth path, particularly a reduction in the budget deficit that in effect frees up national savings for investment.
"If you think about what you can accomplish by economic policy at the Federal level to solve the job and wage problem," Ms. Tyson, the director of the National Economic Council, said, "what you do is put down a foundation for improved growth, and the most important element in that foundation is a significant improvement in the deficit."

HEADLINE: Protecting Pirates, Not Software

BYLINE: By Gary Hufbauer; Gary Hufbauer is a fellow at the Institute for International Economics.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
With gusto and fanfare, the Clinton Administration has been chasing down software pirates in China, Thailand and Mexico, and with good reason. High-tech products, especially software, are our fastest-growing exports.
The software industry employs 500,000 people. When knockoff copies of American software are manufactured abroad without royalty payments, the industry loses money that could be used to create new technology and jobs. 
 The time has now come for Clinton trade warriors, who have had some success abroad, to aim their firepower at a closer target: the Treasury Department. By upholding a shortsighted temporary regulation that was issued in 1987 and never made final and that denies a tax benefit to the software industry, the Treasury is injuring our software exports just as surely as any pirate factory in Guangdong Province does.
In 1971, Congress permitted companies to exclude from corporate taxes about 15 percent of profits from exports of "films, tapes, records or similar reproductions, for commercial or home use." Software was not listed because it barely existed at the time.
The reason for the tax advantage is that it often makes sense to export a master film or recording -- whether "Forrest Gump" or Windows 95 -- for the production and sale of copies abroad. First, this cuts down on shipment and inventory problems and avoids high tariffs. Second, it makes possible local modifications: in some markets, for example, Madonna's erotic phrasing gives offense.
The third reason for the exception, only vaguely appreciated in 1971, is that by licensing local companies toturn out products for distribution in countries like China, Thailand and Mexico, powerful local interests can be recruited against counterfeiters.
Indeed, a central strategy of President Clinton's trade policy is to convert Chinese and Thai counterfeiters, with all their high-quality reproduction equipment and distribution talents, into licensees of American film, audio and software companies.
In 1987, the Treasury, thinking that master software disks did not fall into the "films, tapes, records or similar reproductions" category, issued a temporary regulation that denied tax advantages for those who export them. In 1993, soon after Bill Clinton took office, the Internal Revenue Service reaffirmed this interpretation. Master films from Disney and master CD's featuring Michael Jackson can be exported with a tax benefit, but not master disks from Microsoft.
Hardware manufacturers abroad often install imported software in their equipment; sometimes, entrepreneurs combine the imports with local software. No one wants to purchase tens of thousands of diskettes; they want to license a master diskette.
The Treasury can give software disks the same favorable tax treatment as master film and audio recordings by routinely revising the regulation. It doesn't want responsibility for losing the revenue, and thus insists that it is Congress's job to rewrite the 1971 statute. But Congress would be no more eager than the Treasury Department to approve a measure that would cost the Government money -- an estimated $200 million over five years.
The Treasury and Congress have not estimated what offsetting revenues might result from increased software sales abroad. It is highly likely that such sales would generate tax revenues that would more than offset the imagined loss.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
President Ousts Finance Chief In Argentina

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, July 26

 BODY:
The Finance Minister, Domingo Cavallo, the architect of a program that brought economic stability to Argentina, was dismissed this afternoon after a heated argument with President Carlos Saul Menem over the pace of those policies.
While the dismissal raised questions about whether the Government would continue in Mr. Cavallo's direction, Mr. Menem said tonight that there would be no major shift in policy. 
 "I didn't fire him; I asked him to resign," Mr. Menem said. "Cavallo completed a very successful stage in Argentina's reforms, and I am grateful, but now we need changes." The President said the most significant change would involve a stepped-up tax collection, which the Government needed to balance its books and meet its debt payments.
Roque Fernandez, 47, the director of the central bank, was named to succeed Mr. Cavallo.
Argentine stocks and bonds tumbled late today on reports of Mr. Cavallo's departure. Traders and investors were concerned that the Government would abandon the Cavallo policies, which have been credited with bringing growth and stability to a country once plagued by hyperinflation, corruption and inefficiencies.
There had been talk for more than a year that Mr. Cavallo would be leaving the Government, and he often sparred publicly with the President, threatening to quit whenever his policies were opposed.
Political rivals and labor groups had long called for Mr. Cavallo's ouster, saying his policies had led to record unemployment and increased poverty.
But Mr. Cavallo, 50, a Harvard-trained economist, was highly respected by investors and bankers. His many threats to resign often sent Argentina's financial markets tumbling, as investors feared a currency crisis similar to the one that shattered Mexico's economy last year.
President Menem said at a news conference tonight that Argentina would not devalue its currency, as many investors and economists had speculated. He said the country would maintain its exchange-rate policy, which fixes the peso by law at a 1-to-1 ratio to the United States dollar and prohibits the printing of local currency unless it is backed by new capital. The exchange-rate policy is the cornerstone of the country's economic stability.
Mr. Menem said that before offering the Finance Minister's post to Mr. Fernandez, he had offered it to two other noted economists, Miguel Angel Broda and Roberto Alemann, both of whom declined. Mr. Fernandez said at the news conference that it was too early to comment on his plans but that tax collection would be his top priority.
Many investors, however, questioned whether Mr. Fernandez could maintain Mr. Cavallo's pace of change. The Merval index of the 28 most-traded stocks on the Buenos Aires stock exchange tumbled 21.57 points today, or 4.1 percent, to 504.86. In New York, Argentina's benchmark Brady bonds initially plunged 4.4 percent before a partial rebound.
The major challenge facing Mr. Fernandez will be convincing investors that Argentina is not another Mexico and that the economic changes begun by Mr. Cavallo will not be reversed.
"It's clear that Fernandez is a proponent of radical reform to Argentina's economy and from a technical perspective that's very pleasing," said Laurence Goodman, an economist specializing in Latin America for Salomon Brothers. "But the question remains whether he has the ability to push measures through Congress or thwart attempts to dilute reforms for social benefits."
Argentina's exchange-rate plan was introduced by Mr. Cavallo in 1991 with other economic changes, opening the economy to international competition and investment. Since the shift in policy, the inflation rate has fallen to less than 5 percent from more than 5,000 percent in 1989.
Along with the decline in inflation, Argentina has experienced industrial growth that has been among the highest in the world at 6 to 9 percent a year, fueled by a rise in investment and productivity. But the Mexican financial crisis led to a loss of foreign investment and plunged Argentina into a deep recession that wiped out its growth last year.
Today, the country is struggling to overcome the recession, and it badly needs foreign investment and tax collection to finance growth and meet its debt payments.
The budget deficit for the first half of 1996, at $2.51 billion, was $1.03 billion higher than the target set by the International Monetary Fund.
Mr. Cavallo had announced several belt-tightening measures to balance accounts during the second half of the year, including taxing meal vouchers that companies give to employees and reducing social benefits.
The measures were unpopular with labor unions and opposition parties, which held a huge demonstration today to denounce the Government's economic polices and the current 17 percent unemployment rate.
Some members of Congress, which is controlled by Mr. Menem's Peronist Party, had said they would oppose Mr. Cavallo's cutbacks and the minister had threatened to quit in a meeting Wednesday with Mr. Menem.
According to Government officials present at the meeting, Mr. Menem, who had been reluctant to dismiss Mr. Cavallo in the past for fear that his departure would cause havoc in the financial markets, replied: "I'm tired of your threats. If you wish to quit, then quit."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 39; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1713 words

HEADLINE: Picking Up the Tab For Fields of Dreams;
Taxpayers Build Stadiums; Owners Cash in

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In Baltimore, the Ravens, formerly the Cleveland Browns, are coming to a $200 million football stadium to be built on their behalf. Nashville has lured the Oilers from Houston with the promise of a sparkling new $389 million stadium. In New York, there is talk of a new ballpark for the Yankees, while discussion continues about replacing venerable Tiger Stadium in Detroit and Fenway Park in Boston, both now celebrating their 84th anniversaries.
But even as multimillion-dollar sports palaces are being proposed for assorted Bears, Bengals, Hawks, Vikings and other professional teams, a lot of people in Washington would like to clamp down on lucrative public subsidies that they contend do much more to help already-wealthy professional sports team owners than the communities that support the teams. 
 Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a New York Democrat, has fired the opening shot by introducing legislation to end the use of tax-free dollars to build sports stadiums. But, retreating under a hail of lobbying fire, Mr. Moynihan admits his measure has no chance of being enacted this year. Still, that has not stopped him from vigorously arguing that Federal tax dollars would be better devoted to public needs like higher education than subsidizing the current stadium building boom.
"Building new professional sports facilities is fine by me," Mr. Moynihan said. "Let the new stadiums be built. But, please, do not ask the American taxpayer to pay for them."
With an estimated $6 billion of new sports stadiums and arenas on the drawing boards, the mere introduction of a bill that would prevent local governments from tapping the tax-exempt municipal bond market for such projects is sending shock waves through the world of sports finance. "The Moynihan bill has had an immediate, horrendous impact," said Howard Richard, a lawyer at Katten Muchin & Zavis in Chicago. "There's intense lobbying. No one believes this bill will pass, but it is wreaking havoc with the market."
The controversy over stadium financing dates back to the 1986 Tax Reform Act, which was thought to have eliminated the public subsidies by forcing team owners to finance stadiums with taxable, rather than tax-free, dollars.
That effort, however, backfired. With team owners precluded from tapping the public bond markets and reluctant to use more costly taxable debt, sports-starved cities stepped in to build and own the stadiums themselves, using municipal bonds.
And since the 1986 tax act prevents stadium revenues from being used to pay off any tax-free, stadium-related debt, a bizarre situation has developed. The municipality is often forced to pay with its own dollars for all of the borrowings, but the team owner virtually alone gets the revenues from the stadium. Under the tax code, only a small portion of the stadium revenues and lease payments -- less than 10 percent -- can be drawn on by municipalities to repay tax-free stadium debt.
Some of the newest, and most stylish, stadiums rely exclusively on public debt: Camden Yards and Ravens Stadium in Baltimore and the new Comiskey Park in Chicago are just a few of many. To pay off this debt, local governments have had to raise taxes, tap lottery proceeds or use other public revenues. Other stadiums, like the indoor America West Arena in Phoenix, were built as public-private partnerships, with some construction costs footed by the team owner; it all depends on the bargain struck. In all, $3.9 billion in public debt for stadiums has been issued since 1990.
Team owners, to bring their franchise to town or to be persuaded to stay put, are demanding not just new and bigger stadiums, but more ways to make money from them: luxury skyboxes that rent for $50,000 to $200,000 a year; "personal seat licenses," which are options bought by ticket holders to insure season tickets in perpetuity; new tiers of "club seats" that cost more than regular seats. And then there are "pouring rights," which are paid by beverage companies to peddle their beers and soda; more "totem" space to sell advertising, and bigger car-parking concessions.
"We thought we shut down public financing to private sports stadiums in 1986," said Senator Byron L. Dorgan, a Democrat from North Dakota who is a supporter of the Moynihan measure. "Now a decade later, we see that the only remaining healthy public housing is in sports stadiums for wealthy team owners. We thought we closed a loophole and they found a way through it."
Brian McGough, who specializes in stadium financing for J. P. Morgan & Company, explained the unintended consequences of the legislation: "Congress forced public officials back into the arms of team owners. It was a sea change difference."
The effect of these changes has been to give team owners more financial leverage in bargaining with local governments. And experts say the new-found riches from stadium deals, television contracts and other sources have been an important factor in the escalating salaries in professional sports. When some team owners have more cash in hand, they bid up everyone's prices for top players -- witness the $98 million, seven-year contract for the basketball player Juwan Howard to join the Miami Heat or the $121 million, seven-year contract for Shaquille O'Neal to move to the Los Angeles Lakers.
"A lot of these financial benefits flow to the talent because talent is key, especially in basketball," said Mr. Richard, the Chicago lawyer. "Look at the Chicago Bulls. You are seeing a $25 million raise for Micheal Jordan and millions for others. They say that this is creating the necessity for a new stadium because they need the skybox revenues to pay for the players. When you see all these salaries and the new stadiums, what is the cause and what is the effect?"
More troubling to critics is the evidence that the money spent on sports stadiums provides few economic benefits to the surrounding community. Indeed, several studies indicate that communities could benefit more if these investments, which cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars a year, were spent on other forms of economic development.
"The economic research on whether these stadiums provide benefits for state and local taxpayers suggest that they do not," said Dennis Zimmerman, author of a Congressional Research Service report on stadium financing. "There are a lot more productive things that state and local governments could have done with this money."
Mr. Zimmerman, using data the State of Maryland offered in making the case for building the Ravens' new stadium, found that more jobs could be created by investing the same $177 million in the state's "Sunny Day" economic development fund. He also concluded that in many cases the money local governments saved by issuing tax-free municipal bonds to build these stadiums ended up costing Federal taxpayers more than the local benefit.
"It would be cheaper for the Federal Government to just give a subsidy for these stadiums," Mr. Zimmerman said.
Robert Baade, an economist at Lake Forest College, is one of the strongest critics of the present system. "The distribution of income and benefits is skewed: The owners and the players get the lion's share," Mr. Baade said. "If I've raised taxes to finance a stadium, I can't argue that every dollar of that stadium is a boon to the economy."
Opponents of Mr. Moynihan's measure argue that eliminating tax-free dollars for sports stadiums would take decision-making away from local officials and increase the costs to municipalities by forcing them to borrow in the taxable markets. Indeed, the only way some of these stadiums can be built, they say, is with lower-cost public debt. Football stadiums, in particular, could become endangered, since they often cost as much as $200 million, yet may be used for only eight to 10 games a year, making it hard to generate enough revenues to repay the debts.
"A stadium is not conceptually different from a lot of other public projects," said Micah Green, the Washington lobbyist for the Public Securities Association, a trade group representing the municipal bond industry. "If cities and states decide to raise taxes to pay for these stadiums, then that's O.K. That makes it a governmental bond. The local decision of the electorate is the best test."
(Sometimes, however, local sentiment has to be swayed. The Ravens Stadium proposal passed by only two votes amid controversy in the Maryland Senate. Cincinnati voters approved two new stadiums to replace Riverfront Stadium only after a hard-fought campaign by downtown boosters. In Nashville, opponents forced the city's first-ever bond referendum before the new Oilers stadium won approval.)
Six local government organizations, including the United States Conference of Mayors and the National League of Cities, sent a letter to Mr. Moynihan arguing against his proposal. "It is simply not good public policy to constrain local flexibility in deciding what projects to undertake on a tax-exempt basis," the letter said.
Cathy Spain, the Washington lobbyist for the Government Finance Officers Association, said her group opposes the strict restrictions that preclude the use of stadium-related revenues from repaying municipal debt. Ms. Spain said the association's warnings to Congress about the problem went unheeded when the tax act was changed in 1986. Now, she said, her group would like to allow, say, 25 percent of stadium revenues to be diverted to municipalities instead of team owners.
Stadium financing experts say that regardless of the economics, the lure of professional sports is so strong that politicians and communities will still seek to attract and keep the limited number of sports teams available.
And what about cities that just say no? They may be better off in purely economic terms, but still left with an empty feeling.
"St. Louis lost the football Cardinals to Phoenix because they refused to build a new stadium," said James Gray, assistant director at the National Sports Law Institute in Milwaukee. "Now they are paying triple to lure the Rams from Los Angeles. Being part of a major league is something unique in our society. Lots of people believe it's a worthwhile investment and will do anything to keep a team there."

HEADLINE: ATLANTA DAY 8 -- JOURNAL;
Yachting Crowds Create Barely a Ripple

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

DATELINE: SAVANNAH, Ga.

 BODY:
Olympics or no Olympics, midday feels as quiet as midnight here in the garden of good and evil.
"It's not slow; it's dead," said Shirley Hildreth, as she stood alone earlier this week in her gift shop, Mom's Country Crafts and Gifts, in the middle of Savannah's waterfront tourist district down the street from the hotel housing participants in the largest yachting regatta in Olympic history. "No one's here. This is supposed to be our busy season and it feels like January." 
 This eccentric, moss-draped coastal city immortalized in John Berendt's cheery tale of drag queens, voodoo and murder, "Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil," usually has as much in common with Atlanta as a bullfrog does with a cantaloupe. But the South's No. 2 Olympic site is suffering from its own version of the Olympic curse as grand expectations meet modest reality.
At the big show 250 miles northwest in Atlanta, the problems are managing transportation and spreading around the business of the hundreds of thousands of visitors jamming downtown every day.
The problem here is attendance nowhere close to what organizers had hoped for. Organizers had estimated that 100,000 people would flock to this city of 150,000 people for festivities that began with Savannah's own opening ceremony July 20 and continues with racing through Aug 2.
But tickets are readily available for all the Olympic events and the normal tourist business, which had been booming because of Mr. Berendt's book, has been scared away by the prospect of jammed hotels, inflated prices and clogged streets.
In fact, rooms are readily available and you could drag race around Savannah's elegant green squares for all the traffic on the street. And the 457 Olympic athletes and their entourages, weary from days that begin and end with hour or hour-and-a-half commutes from the Olympic Village to the sailing venues, are mostly staying put rather than shopping or going out to eat.
"We had Olympian expectations that have come down to earth," said Jack Leigh as he sat alone in his Southern Images Gallery. "People are talking about business being down 70 percent. We're just sitting here twiddling our thumbs."
Savannah's Olympic experience has been a little ragged from the start. Originally, Savannah was supposed to host both yachting and beach volleyball, but the volleyball was moved near Atlanta, taking away the most accessible spectator sport.
Hurricane Bertha forced frantic organizers to dismantle much of the marina built to handle the Games, a torrential downpour drenched athletes and guests at the opening ceremonies, and rain and bad weather plagued this week's sailing.
And the venue is getting mixed reviews from yachters, never known as an easy group to please. Tuesday's sailing conditions were described as excellent and the $10.8 million, E-shaped marina, big enough to handle 3,000 people, is getting rave reviews.
But everyone is grumbling about the long, tiring trip to the sailing in Wassaw Sound, 20 miles southeast of Savannah, and some of the athletes and teams say the expertise to run the sailing on a top-notch level is lacking.
"I must be a little rude," said Peer Bent Neilsen, team leader for the Danish team, "but it feels like the difference between putting on the event because you like sailing and putting on the event because you like money. We're getting no information while the races are going on. To get information, I'm picking up my cellular phone and calling friends in Denmark who are watching on television or listening on radio."
To be sure, there is a lot to be said for the low-key pageant here. Viewing conditions for spectators are spectacular. You get can reservations at any restaurant in town, and plenty of people would take Savannah's moldy architectural treasures, relaxed pace and weird characters over the corporate extravaganza in Atlanta any day.
"It's been incredible watching the racing from the middle of the sea," said Christian Kasper, a student from Switzerland who was here with Jochen Hurlebaus, a student from Germany. "People are great and this is so much better than Atlanta where everything is so commercial. Buy this, buy this, it's as if everyone's forgotten what the Olympics are about there."
Not every business is hurting and some optimists here say the big tourism rush may still come after the Games end in Atlanta and visitors have time to explore. Others say that though business may be disappointing, the Olympics will still be good for Savannah.
"The Olympic Arts Festival was a real high moment for everyone involved," Leigh said. "And long term, in terms of the international exposure, this will be good for Savannah. But as for any kind of economic boom, that's not happening.'
As a result, more than a few people here are wondering if the big cheeses in Atlanta sold them a bill of goods.
"You have to remember," said Alan Chiboucas, as he took in the empty scene on River Street, "the people who talked about 100,000 visitors in Savannah are the same ones who said the summer temperature in Atlanta was 76 degrees."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Most Prices Off as Data Are Awaited

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of most Treasury securities sagged yesterday heading into the weekend, as the bond market braced for a barrage of economic data next week that will set the tone of the market for weeks ahead, and perhaps even lead the Federal Reserve to alter its monetary policy.
The market has already begun pricing in the risk factor for potentially damaging news, and as a result bond prices could be discounted further, sending interest rates higher. 
 At the close of the New York cash market yesterday, the only maturity not lower was the 30-year bond, which was unchanged at a price of 8716/32 for a yield of 7.01 percent. Thin volume exaggerated price moves, with many investors having elected to lie low until next week.
Some of the key reports next week include the second-quarter Employment Cost Index, consumer confidence, new-home sales, the Chicago purchasing managers survey, the National Association of Purchasing Management survey, gross domestic product, motor vehicle sales and the employment report on Friday.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said: "Given next week's high-profile economic calendar, the market has the potential of experiencing the explosive effects of Independence Day all over again. Since Mr. Greenspan outlined his strategic blueprints for policy making during Congressional testimony, many traders will be testing whether they can take him at his word."
"Therefore," Mr. Chan continued, "if the Employment Cost Index, the N.A.P.M. and the overall employment report come in with a touch of firmness, Mr. Greenspan will be forced to pull the trigger, primarily because a failure to act by the Aug. 20 Federal Open Market Committee meeting could cause serious damage to Fed credibility."
The Employment Cost Index measures the cost of employing people, including pension and health benefits. Discussing it, Mr. Chan said, "So far, we already have some ugly preliminary evidence on wage pressures, as evidenced by last month's surge in average hourly earnings." That means inflationary pressures can be avoided only if the growth in benefits continues to remain in low or negative territory.
David Ader, managing analyst at Technical Data, Boston, said, "The Employment Cost Index should prove to be next week's most critical market event, with the Fed looking to get further indications of strength or weakness of the economy."
He said the consensus was for a gain of nine-tenths of a percent. "If the data are stronger, it could easily lead to a test of this year's low," he said. "If it is neutral, bordering on friendly, do not expect a break-out rally. With other scheduled releases, it is up to the subsequent data to take the market one way or another."
Kim Rupert, an economist with MMS International, San Francisco, said the September bond futures contract would head into next week in roughly the same shape it had been in ahead of the last few employment reports. She said that on May 1, just before the reports on advance first-quarter gross domestic product and April employment, the September bond was trading at a price of 10819/32 . On June 6, the contract was at 10826/32 before tumbling on the strong employment report, and it steadily rallied to 1098/32 on July 3 before the June employment report. Yesterday the September futures contract settled at a price of 10818/32 .
"Fundamentals and charts both suggest that the next move will be a big one," Ms. Rupert said, "taking us out of the trade range of 106 to 110 seen in the September bond over the past few months."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;
No Echo of Past Rancor as Bush Welcomes Dole

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., July 26

 BODY:
Today's trip to this coastal resort, the summer home of George Herbert Walker Bush, must have been a long one for Bob Dole.
Mr. Dole grew up poor in Kansas, and during at least one phase of his career he deeply resented Mr. Bush, to the manor born. 
 Campaigning in 1988 against Mr. Bush for the Republican Presidential nomination, Mr. Dole said: "I didn't start at the top and stay at the top. I started at the bottom."
Mr. Bush had equally harsh words then for Mr. Dole, who resigned from the Senate last month after 35 years in Congress. "I'm not sure being in Congress all your life is a part of the answer," Mr. Bush said during that campaign. "I think it may be part of the problem."
Now the 73-year-old former Senator and the 72-year-old former President seem to have settled into the truce that they declared after the 1988 primaries.
Mr. Bush welcomed Mr. Dole today to Walker's Point, the Bush homestead on prime Atlantic real estate here. The purpose was to hail each other for the Americans With Disabilities Act, barring discrimination against the disabled, which President Bush signed into law six years ago today. But equally useful politically were the tableaux for the cameras: Mr. Bush and Mr. Dole with their wives and with Mr. Bush's son George W. Bush, the popular Governor of Texas, and his wife, Laura.
"Barbara and I and all the Bushes," the former President said, "are in unanimous, enthusiastic agreement that America needs Bob Dole's character, his courage, his decency and his common sense in the White House."
Mr. Bush demurred when asked what advice he might give Mr. Dole on campaigning against Bill Clinton. Instead, he praised his onetime rival, saying, "He was at my side when the going was tough, he was there when the going got pretty darn good in 1988. He was there at my side, never jumped away, never tried to protect his own flank by jumping away from me as the President seeking re-election."
Mr. Dole, asked what he had learned from Mr. Bush, also demurred. "My view," the candidate said, "is that we had a good lunch. Great blueberry pie."
Renewed Defense
Mr. Bush, tanned and looking relaxed today, is nonetheless apparently still a bit miffed at the outcome of the 1992 election, and he could not resist asserting that whatever anyone's impression at the time, he had not been "out of touch" at all. He said:
"I would like to point out -- I know this will sound a little defensive -- but as I hear President Clinton talk about the great economy they've done, I would like to point out to some of you in this press corps, in case you missed it in 1992, we handed him an economy that was growing at 5.7 percent in the last quarter and the one that grew at 3.6 percent in the third quarter, and it grew in excess of three-point-something for the whole year. That was not recession. That was not out of touch."
'Oh, Come On'
With all the talk about drugs lately, it seemed inevitable that someone would pose the question to Representative Susan Molinari, the 38-year-old Staten Island Republican whom Mr. Dole has chosen as keynote speaker at the Republican National Convention.
Ms. Molinari said in a statement today that she had "experimented" with marijuana in college -- she graduated from the State University of New York at Albany in 1980 -- and now deeply regretted it.
Mr. Dole has been hammering the Clinton Administration lately because certain staff members were hired despite use of hard drugs within the prior five years. But today he shrugged off a question about Ms. Molinari.
"Oh, come on," he said.
"I'm talking about recent drug use," the candidate added, "hard drugs, cocaine, crack and other things."
Greet the Press
When Mr. Dole's plane lands at an airport, he usually emerges from the front while the traveling press climbs down the back staircase. Here there were no stairs to be wheeled to the front of the plane, and so Mr. Dole had to alight at the back with the press. Waiting in the rain to greet everyone was Mr. Bush, who cheerfully shook hands with reporters, many of whom had encamped here during Mr. Bush's vacations as President.
"Welcome back to Kennebunkport," he said, a natural host. "And welcome to those who haven't been here before."
At a joint news conference with Mr. Dole, Mr. Bush enjoyed playful banter with reporters. That did not go unnoticed by Mr. Dole, who has lately had an icier relationship with the traveling scribes.
"I know the President sees many of his friends in the press," Mr. Dole noted. "I'm still looking for one."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICANS;
Dole Appears Moving Toward Tax-Cut Stand

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
During his days as the Senate's deficit-fighter-in-chief, Bob Dole liked to joke about a bus carrying a group of supply-siders that plunged off a cliff. The bad news, he said, was that three of the seats were empty.
They're not telling that joke around Dole campaign headquarters. As he completes work on the economic platform for his Presidential campaign, Mr. Dole has surrounded himself with plenty of people who say that cutting taxes is the best way to stimulate more growth, and the platform could end up embracing the kinds of sweeping tax cuts he once disdained. 
 Just how Mr. Dole will choose among the variety of options being touted by his aides is an open question, Republican strategists inside and outside the campaign said. Mr. Dole said this week that he had not decided among a variety of tax-cut proposals, and several of his advisers said they had long since learned not to push Mr. Dole or predict his decisions.
Mr. Dole's economic policy formulation is being overseen by Donald Rumsfeld, whose support for tax cuts goes back to his days as President Gerald Ford's chief of staff, and the campaign is staffed with may other ardent supply-siders.
Still, Mr. Dole continues to be cautioned not to risk his credibility as a deficit cutter from some colleagues who were at his side when he put austerity ahead of tax cuts during the 1980's, including Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the chairman of the Budget Committee, and Sheila Burke, who was his chief of staff in the Senate, Republican strategists with ties to the campaign said.
"He wants to be totally comfortable" with the platform that is unveiled, said Steve Forbes, whose unsuccessful bid for the Republican Presidential nomination was built around a single-rate flat tax and who in recent weeks has become an influential voice in Mr. Dole's campaign. "If he's seen faltering on this, it's over. That's why he's being cautious."
But to a degree that many Republican strategists said amazed them, Mr. Dole appears to have already undergone a conversion, on both intellectual and political levels, to the need for tax-cutting, "pro-growth" policies that he once held in such disdain.
As a result, they said, the debate in the Dole camp is relatively narrow: whether to build the economic plan around an across-the-board tax reduction, which is seen as the more cautious choice, or to fashion a more radical package including rollbacks of 1993 and 1990 tax increases, reducing the capital gains tax and making Social Security taxes deductible.
Mr. Dole in recent weeks has asked for detailed advice from Mr. Forbes. Through his aides, he has reached out to Jack F. Kemp, the leading advocate of tax-based economic policies, who has long had a touchy relationship with Mr. Dole.
Mr. Dole has also been influenced by Vin Weber, a former Congressman from Minnesota who is also a leading policy adviser, and conservative economists including John Taylor of Stanford University and Gary S. Becker of the University of Chicago.
"I do think there has been an intellectual conversion or awakening, especially since the policies have been separated from the personalities" advocating them, like Mr. Kemp, said one Republican strategist who has been involved in the tax debate.
"And then on the political side, he knows he has to do something," the strategist said. "If the fight is not on taxes in September and in November, we're gone, no question."
At this point, much of the debate in the Dole camp is over the economic assumptions to be used in a plan that will call for large tax cuts while still promising to balance the budget by 2002.
In particular, there is discussion about how much economic growth the tax cuts would stimulate, and about how much additional tax revenue that growth would generate.
There is also a debate over how quickly Mr. Dole needs to come to a decision and unveil the plan, which aides said would be the centerpiece of his campaign. Mr. Dole's campaign is nearly out of money, and advisers fear that the candidate will not be able to respond to the barrage of advertising that the Clinton campaign has promised to unleash on the Dole economic plan.
Some advisers are arguing that Mr. Dole should hold off announcing the plan until the Republican National Convention in mid-August, when Mr. Dole will become his party's nominee and will be able to replenish his campaign finances.
"There's no question that when the plan goes out, there will be a very significant effort at selling it because it's not only very important for the nominee, but for the party itself," said one top campaign aide, noting that members of Congress were eager to run on a tax-cutting platform and to hold President Clinton's feet to the political fire for pushing through a tax increase in 1993.
Economic proposals in political campaigns often are built on optimistic assumptions, and this one appears to be no exception.
Advisers to Mr. Dole said the plan would assume that the large tax cuts, however they are structured, would provide the economy with a big boost, raising the growth rate from its current level of 2 percent to 2.5 percent a year to 3 percent or more over the six- or seven-year period that the plan would cover.
Many economists questioned whether the economy would indeed get such a big boost from a tax cut over such a long period. They said that unless the tax cuts led to fundamental improvements in the economy's productivity, such high rates of growth would fuel inflation and lead to higher interest rates.
Mr. Dole's advisers argue that the tax cuts would lead to increased savings and business investment, making their growth projections credible.
And by the Clinton Administration's own projections, they said, a one-percentage-point increase in growth would generate $60 billion in additional tax revenues on average over the next seven years, enough to offset nearly two-thirds of the annual cost of a 15 percent across-the-board reduction in personal income tax rates, one of the leading options being studied by Mr. Dole.
The Dole campaign has been working with a variety of models of the extent to which growth would generate additional revenues to offset lower tax rates. At the high end of their spectrum is a model assuming that 40 percent of the lost revenue would be recouped through additional growth and changes in economic behavior.
But that is a low level by the standards of the supply-side orthodoxy of the early 1980's, which held that tax cuts could nearly pay for themselves, but in the middle of the range of what most current research suggests.
The economic assumptions are crucial to the Dole plan, because the campaign wants to minimize the spending cuts that would be needed to pay for a tax cut. Mr. Dole's aides said that they want to avoid at all costs having to defend cuts in entitlement programs like Medicare and Medicaid, issues that the White House used to great advantage against the Republicans during the battle over balancing the budget.
"So many political leaders can't seem to grasp that you can have a very dynamic, positive program without throwing widows and orphans out in the snow," said Mr. Forbes, representing the view that growth will make up for a large part of the forgone tax revenue.

HEADLINE: Developer Carves a Niche In Small Boutique Hotels

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
In a trend toward smaller, less expensive hotels in New York City, a development firm that has carved out a niche in that category said yesterday that it planned to convert a gracious brick office building on East 44th Street east of Grand Central Terminal into a 162-room hotel.
The building was designed as an apartment house early in the century by Emery Roth & Sons, a renowned architectural firm. Renovation is to begin in January, and the hotel, to be called the Hotel Grand Central, will have a railroad theme. Its developer, Gotham Hospitality Group, has already bought 14 murals from the 1920's depicting trains and rail workers. 
 With 24.5 million visitors expected in New York City this year, the most since the 1980's, tourism is booming. Many, according to the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, can ill afford the room rates of the city's major hotels, but they still want something fancier than a bouncy mattress and a metal chair.
"There is a boomlet in the moderately priced boutique category," said Jeanine Moss, a spokeswoman for the bureau, "and that would be hotels with 200 rooms or less for $200 or less. When you're looking at an increase of a million visitors from 1993 to 1996, you're going to have many more people who need accommodations in that category. There was a demand."
The Gotham Hospitality Group, which has developed five other hotels in the last eight years with room rates averaging $140 to $170 a night, exemplifies the new approach, Ms. Moss said. "Today," she added, "the smart hotel people have found ways to get really nice design pieces inexpensively. Gotham has found a really good niche, and it's added enormously to New York City's mix."
The president of the Gotham group, Bernard Goldberg, a 63-year-old real estate lawyer, said yesterday that he had signed a contract on Thursday to buy the nine-story building and expected to close on the deal in January. He would not say what he was paying for the building. The current owner, a small partnership named for its address, 141 East 44th Street, has recently stopped renewing leases, Mr. Goldberg said, so half the offices are vacant.
There are six stores on the ground floor, including a shoe-repair business and a bagel shop. They will close as their leases expire, Mr. Goldberg said, and the space will be added to the lobby.
All of the other hotels in Gotham's small empire, from the 92-room Hotel Wales on Madison Avenue near 92d Street to the 129-room Mansfield Hotel at 14 West 44th Street, had been low-budget hotels, most "rundown and seedy," Mr. Goldberg said, but with "good bones."
One, the Roger Williams, at 31st Street and Madison Avenue, is being renovated and is scheduled to open in a year. With 211 rooms, it will be the firm's largest.
Joseph E. Spinnato, president of the Hotel Association of New York City, said that in the early 1990's there had been a spate of hotel development planned before the economic downturn.
That was followed by a quiet period, marked mostly by more intimate hotels. "Other than these very small hotels that have come on line," he said, "there have been no major projects."
As tourism has increased, so has the city's hotel occupancy rate, which is expected to reach 79 percent this year, the highest since 1990. Mr. Goldberg said the current occupancy rates of Gotham's hotels ranged from 84 percent to 96 percent.
The location of the Hotel Grand Central was a major attraction for Gotham. "In Europe," Mr. Goldberg said, "railroad terminals were always beautiful and romantic places. Paris and London both have these little boutique hotels right near the railroad stations. We think the project will complement the restoration of Grand Central."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Climb as Earnings Buoy Investor Confidence
Stocks advanced as positive corporate earnings reports restored investor confidence. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 51.05 points, to 5,473.06, a day after rallying 67.32 points. That brought its gain for the week to eight-tenths of 1 percent, despite sharp slides on Monday and Tuesday. The Nasdaq composite index rose 17.05 points, to 1,079.44, and the S.& P. 500 climbed 4.73 points, to 635.90.
Among the earnings surprises were: Gateway 2000, the computer maker; T. Rowe Price Associates, the mutual fund manager, and Whole Foods Market, a grocer. [Page 43.]
 
Prices of most Treasury securities sagged, as the bond market braced for a barrage of economic data next week, but the long bond held steady with a yield of 7.01 percent. [42.]
 
Agents Breach Airport Security
The Department of Transportation's inspector general reported two weeks before the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 that undercover Government agents, carrying fake bombs, had walked into secure areas at four of the nation's largest airports. Officials decided not to release the report for fear of encouraging terrorists. [1.]
 
Kellogg's Earnings Slide 42.5%
Kellogg, the cereal industry leader, reported a 42.5 percent slide in second-quarter profits, citing stiff competition and industry price cuts. The company predicted the year's earnings would match last year's, but analysts were skeptical. [41.]
 
Aetna Moves Into the Black
Aetna reported earnings of $288 million for the second quarter in contrast to a loss of $297 million in the corresponding period last year. The turnaround was driven mostly by the sale of Aetna's property-casualty operations to the Travelers Group. [41.]
 
German Media Rivals in Accord
In Germany, two rival media giants, Bertelsmann A.G. and the Kirch Group, said that they would develop a common decoder standard for digital television, ending a long battle over which technology would dominate. But competition will continue in the programming and customer service arenas of the two companies' digital-TV efforts. [40.]
 
U.S. and Japan Differ in Talks
The United States and Japan remain "pretty far" apart in talks on increasing access to Japan's $470 billion insurance market less than a week ahead of a deadline, the deputy United States trade representative, Ira S. Shapiro, said. He and Eisuke Sakakibara, director general of the Japanese Finance Ministry's international finance bureau, are meeting in Vancouver, British Columbia. [41.]
 
Milken's Probation Extended
Michael R. Milken's probation was extended by United States District Judge Kimba M. Wood for a third time, until Oct. 25, because of an S.E.C. investigation into whether Mr. Milken's recent business dealings have violated the terms of his punishment. Mr. Milken, the former junk bond king who has been barred from the securities business, has advised both Ted Turner and Rupert Murdoch in recent deals. His lawyer contends those activities are entirely proper. [40.]
 
Ford to Sell $3.5 Billion in Leases
Ford Motor said that it would sell $1.8 billion in leases to BankAmerica Corporation, and an additional $1.7 billion to a partnership formed by Ford and BankAmerica. The $3.5 billion in leases -- for planes, rail cars, ships and other industrial equipment and operations -- cover all the transportation and industrial financing assets of Ford's USL Capital unit. [41.]
 
British Economic Growth Slow
Britain's economy grew four-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, less than economists were expecting, as the "mad cow disease" scare cut farm production. [40.]

HEADLINE: David Valinsky, 81, Statistician on Rights Cases

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Dr. David Valinsky, a statistician who applied his skills to civil rights issues ranging from voting rights to police hiring, died on July 19 at the Westchester County Medical Center. He was 81 and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.
He had suffered a long illness, said a spokesman for Baruch College, where he was Distinguished Service Professor Emeritus of Statistics. 
 Dr. Valinksy was the principal architect of graduate programs in statistics and computer information systems at the City University of New York. He introduced more than 50 undergraduate and graduate courses in statistics, operations theory and decision theory during his 45 years as a teacher and administrator. As a statistician, he was frequently called on for expert testimony and advice on equal voting rights.
In 1972, a Federal court in Montgomery, Ala., ordered a drastic reapportionment of electoral districts for the State Legislature in a case brought by the American Civil Liberties Union on behalf of a group of disfranchised black Alabamans. After the Legislature failed to come up with a plan acceptable to the court, the A.C.L.U. brought in Dr. Valinsky, who did.
He also drew up electoral reapportionment plans for Mississippi in the 1970's and testified in cases involving jury selection and discrimination in police hiring and promotion.
He was a fellow of Britain's Royal Statistical Society as well as a consultant for the New York Mayor's office, the Justice Department and the Civil Aeronautics Board.
In New York, he advised on such matters as the optimal number of firefighting units and where to base them, and the most efficient deployment of blood banks, microscopy laboratories and operating-room schedules in city hospitals.
David Valinsky was born in Atlantic City and graduated from Temple University in science of education, specializing in sociology and economics. He received a master's degree in statistics from City College in 1943 and a Ph.D., also in statistics, from Columbia University in 1962.
He started his teaching career at Baruch in 1940. He was chairman of the department of statistics and computer information systems from 1970 to 1983 and developed the City University of New York's doctoral program in quantitative analysis, Baruch's M.B.A. program in operations research and many undergraduate specializations in statistics and computer operations. After retiring in 1985, he worked as a consultant and an expert witness in age discrimination cases brought against employers.
Dr. Valinsky is survived by his wife of 58 years, Helen Abrams Valinsky; a son, Eric, of Manhattan; a sister, Ruth Gove, of Philadelphia, and a grandson.

HEADLINE: Black, Successful and Safe And Gone From Capital

SERIES: MONUMENT TO DECAY -- Last of three articles.

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES and KAREN DE WITT 

DATELINE: FORT WASHINGTON, Md., July 26

 BODY:
Richard Jones moved here to the suburbs in 1979 to shield his children from the drugs and street crime that were rampant in his southeast Washington neighborhood. Yet 17 years later and now retired as an air traffic controller, Mr. Jones still does volunteer work with poor children in his old neighborhood, and every now and then he yearns to move back into the city.
"I would like to go back," he said, seated at the dining room table of his tidy four-bedroom home. "I think that it's people like me who have to go back. At some point, we need middle-class black people to go back and reclaim the city." 
 Across the table, his wife, Linda, emphatically shook her head no.
Two decades after the District of Columbia and its black majority won the long-coveted right of limited self-government, significant numbers of the city's black middle class have fled to the suburbs in disillusionment and transplanted ambition, an exodus that is both primary effect and cause of the District's continuing decline.
According to census data, nearly 50,000 blacks moved out of Washington in the 1980's, a net decline of about 11 percent in the city's black population. In the same period, the city's white population increased by nearly 8,000. The District is thus one of the few American cities that have become whiter while growing poorer.
This exodus of Washington's black residents to here in Prince George's County, which borders the District on the east, has transformed a formerly white-majority county with a bitter history of racial segregation into a new emblem of rising black prosperity and political power.
The search for a cure for the nation's capital is now focusing on the middle class -- on keeping those who have stayed, even luring back some who have left. But as they look back at their old and troubled hometown -- now with a population estimated at 554,000, about 65 percent black and about 32 percent white -- some of the people here find themselves torn between the powerful political, economic and emotional pull of the District and a determination to preserve and nurture the lives and the communities they have created here. People like Mr. Jones, who is in his early 50's, may talk about returning, but they are hard to find.
Among them is Sandy Davis, a research librarian for The Washington Post, who five years ago moved from Washington to Mount Rainier, just across the District line.
"I wouldn't come back into the city because of all the problems that have cropped up since I left, basically the poor city services," Ms. Davis said. "I love Mount Rainier. It's like a little town with a mayor you can call up and who will come over on his bike."

 The Reaction
 
Anger at Congress, A Sense of Disquiet
A number of the blacks who have left Washington for the suburbs react to the District's fiscal woes with a mixture of anger at Congress for allowing the city to slide into bankruptcy, and sadness at what they see as waste and mismanagement by local officials. Some feel uneasy that their departure contributed to the decline of the place affectionately known as the Chocolate City because of its long and well-cultivated history of black ownership, black institutions and black achievement.
"Everybody out here understands that there but for the grace of God go I," said Lucenia Dunn, 53, who in 1989 moved from Washington to the Woodmore development, a predominantly black, gated community in the county, with private security, town houses, sprawling estates and a golf course.
"We were first proud of the Chocolate City," Ms. Dunn said, "and it's hard to unloosen that level of loyalty to the concept of having a successful African-American-owned and -operated and -run city. It grieves us that it's in trouble."
In those days of hope and pride, at the dawning of limited home rule, Washington was the unofficial capital of the nation's black middle class. Its flight did more than erode an already slipping tax base; it gradually robbed the District of a stability rare in inner-city America.
"What has most affected this city is what happened to its black middle class," said Eleanor Holmes Norton, Washington's nonvoting delegate to Congress.
Ms. Norton has sponsored legislation to lure back the middle class, or at least keeping what is left, through sharply lower Federal income taxes for District residents and other tax breaks. That legislation has recently drawn the support of Speaker Newt Gingrich and other Congressional Republican leaders.
For those who have relocated, the reasons differ little from ones voiced by people of all races, in all regions of the country, who took part in the great migration to the suburbs after World War II: a hope for more living space, a desire for better schools or simply a yearning for a bigger and less-expensive home.
"I was looking for safety, new brick construction and a price tag under $200,000," said Janet Lane, a native Washingtonian who moved to the Woodmore development two years ago.
But there are those who say the black flight from Washington signifies something more: a vote of no-confidence on the District's experiment in self-government.
"We had a larger black middle class than many cities," said James O. Gibson, a former city planning commissioner, "and for a long time it didn't move.
"Initially, it didn't move because of segregation in the suburbs. But even after desegregation, there was an identification with this black government and a desire to see this experiment work. It was when that vision defaulted that the exodus stepped up."

 The County
 
High Achievement And High Hopes
The migration to Prince George's County is something of a homecoming for African-Americans. In 1860, they made up about 60 percent of the county's population, 9 out of 10 of them slaves. But from the 1920's through the 1950's, blacks left in droves for jobs in the cities.
Then from 1980 to 1990, the black population of Prince George's County, which comprises 487 square miles in Maryland, grew by 155,000, an increase of almost 63 percent. A 1994 survey by The Washington Post indicated that 60 percent of the county's black residents once lived in Washington. In contrast, only 20 percent of the county's white residents had come from the District.
The influx of blacks, along with the migration of the county's whites, has made Prince George's the nation's first black-majority suburban county: African-Americans make up 52.2 percent of its population. And as the county's racial complexion changed, the income and educational attainment of its population rose.
From 1990 to 1995, household income in the county grew faster than it did in surrounding jurisdictions, including Montgomery County, Md., northwest of the District and long considered one of the area's most affluent. A study by Prince George's County in February of this year indicated that the proportion of Prince George's households with incomes of $50,000 to $100,000 range is comparable to wealthy counties like Montgomery and Fairfax County, Va., west of Washington.
Last year, nearly 46 percent of Prince George's black high school seniors said they planned to attend a four-year college, a higher proportion than the 41.6 percent of the whites in the county who said they would.
Wayne K. Curry, the first black elected County Executive of Prince George's, offered this observation in his victory speech two years ago: "Normally, the mere arrival of an African-American majority is like a fire alarm going off, saying, 'Don't use the elevator. Use the staircase and get out!' " "Well, that's not what we are."
Meanwhile, as the black middle class arrived in the county, so did a number of black institutions. Last year the Industrial Bank, Washington's largest black-owned bank, moved its headquarters to Prince George's from the District, after 60 years there. One black church is building a 10,000-seat sanctuary in Temple Hill, just across the Maryland line, while two others are building 5,000-seat houses of worship elsewhere in the county.
In 1983 the Ebenezer A.M.E. Zion Church sold its valuable piece of land in the Georgetown section and moved to Fort Washington, in southwestern Prince George's. At the time, the church had 50 parishioners. Today it has 8,000 to 9,000.
The county does have its share of shortcomings. Some sections bordering the District have the city's problems of poverty, crime and low educational achievement. The county over all lacks quality, high-end shopping outlets and has fewer sit-down restaurants than in any of the other suburban counties adjacent to Washington. And its school system, which is 70 percent black, is the third-worst performer in Maryland, out of 24 counties, on standardized tests.
Nonetheless, Prince George's is fast becoming the capital of transplanted dreams. For years, especially since limited home rule, the black middle class in Washington focused on building the city into a magnet for ambitious African-Americans and making it a model of black achievement. So as the District has stumbled, the task of creating the black Xanadu has, for some, been passed to Prince George's, named for Prince George of Denmark, the consort of Queen Anne of England, on April 23, 1696.
"I really see the county as the next phase of the civil-rights movement," said the Rev. Grainger Browning Jr., the pastor of Ebenezer A.M.E. "Many persons in the county have been the beneficiaries of the 60's. We now have some economic ability to make changes, so we can own businesses and be in corporate, academic and political leadership, and really have the opportunity to become a model of black-white relations and black political empowerment."

The Conflicts
 
Problems of the Poor, Middle-Class Fears
Even as people in Prince George's seek a better life, they often seem concerned about not becoming too much of a haven for Washington's poor. In his campaign for county executive, Mr. Curry said developers were building too many high-density, low-income housing units in the county. And last year, after he assumed office, Mr. Curry threatened to deny water and sewer connections to several developments unless the builders made the houses larger and more expensive.
Mr. Curry has also asked a Federal judge to rescind a Federal court-ordered busing plan. The 1973 order, coming in the wake of desegregation, required the then predominantly white county to amend school boundaries to eliminate all black-majority schools and to insure that no school had a black population of less than 10 percent. Today African-Americans make up 55 percent of the school population.
"You have African-American kids being bused from one African-American community to another African-American community," said Reggie Parks, press secretary to Mr. Curry. "The commissioner and other elected officials feel that the busing order has outlived its usefulness."
Most on the 10-member Prince George's County school board are sympathetic. But both residents and board members recognize that some of the desire to keep poor black children from the areas bordering the District out of middle-class areas is behind the effort to get the busing order rescinded. Class, not race, is at stake, they say.
"That's a real issue and one that the board has to grapple with," said Marcy C. Canavan, the chairwoman of the Prince George's County school board. Mrs. Canavan, who is white, represents Tantallon and Accokeek, overwhelmingly black and middle- to upper-class neighborhoods in the southwestern part of the county.
"People have moved here away from crime to good schools, and it's very clear that some don't want ghetto kids in their school buildings," Mrs. Canavan said. "But it's the school board's job to represent all kids, and we know it's not good to have large concentration of poor kids in a single building. It's a dicey situation."
Alvin Thornton, a school board member and the chairman of the political science department at Howard University, said he favored having the busing order revoked. But Dr. Thornton sees broader ramifications to the issue both for blacks in the county and for upper-class blacks in general.
"What does black politics mean in this day and age?" he asked. "I don't think it means only carving out a piece of the pie for the black middle class. I don't think it means letting cities deteriorate so you have cores of decay ringed by rings of affluence."
Pointing out that nearly half of the children in county public elementary schools take part in the free-lunch program, Dr. Thornton added:
"If you live in a county where 40 percent of your kids are poor, where the achievement gap between lower- and upper-income children is so huge and persistent, instructional talent and resources so maldistributed, we ought to be able to agree that that is a problem. But some middle-class black people have the same prejudices as their older white counterparts."

 The Good Life
 
Isolated Self-Interest And Little Sympathy
The signs of contented suburban life can be found in areas like Fort Washington, a community of tidy single-family homes with neatly manicured lawns set along the shores of the Potomac River.
On a recent crisp sunny day in Fort Washington, the parents of the Raiders, a predominantly black soccer team, watched their 13- and 14-year-old sons scamper across a green field, cheering and harrying the referees.
"Oh, he pushed! He pushed, ref!" yelled Francis Taylor, an Air Force colonel whose son, Jason, plays left wing. "Hand ball! Hand ball! Come on ref, make the call!"
The boys ran up and down the field while parents lounged in folding chairs on the sidelines, taking in the game and talking about what was going on at local schools and about the girl scouts. Nearby, younger children cavorted in the playground of a school.
The community is racially integrated. And the median household income for blacks in sections like Tantallon, which is home to Mr. Jones, the retired air traffic controller, and Colonel Taylor and his wife, Constance, is more than $68,500, according to the 1990 census, far above the national median for all races. Houses in the area sell for $250,000 to $350,000, with those on the waterfront costing more than $400,000.
The Taylors began their married life in Prince George's County in 1983, living in a town house in Temple Hills. In 1984, when Mrs. Taylor was pregnant with the couple's third child, they bought their five-bedroom, Colonial-style house in Tantallon.
"I didn't feel I needed to be patriotic toward Washington," said Mrs. Taylor, who recently left the Air Force as a major to work for the Pentagon as a civilian employee. "I felt I needed to look out for what my family needed to prosper and grow."
Mrs. Taylor added that as the District plunged into its fiscal crisis, her feeling had only been become stronger. And Colonel Taylor, who works in the Air Force Inspector General's office, attributed the District's problems to an unwillingness by anyone -- politician or electorate -- to set high enough standards.
"I really do blame this on the city leadership," Colonel Taylor said. "I think we have created a situation where there is no accountability any more. In the military, you can always tell which units are going to fall apart. It's where the leadership fails to demand high standards of conduct and professionalism."

HEADLINE: Mayor Opposes Some Revisions In Welfare Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani says that a welfare bill speeding through Congress would impose immense new costs on New York City by cutting Federal aid for poor children, disabled people and legal immigrants.
In a letter this week to Congressional leaders, Mr. Giuliani said he supported the basic concept of the bill, which would eliminate the Federal guarantee of cash assistance for poor children and give states vast new authority to run their own welfare and work programs with lump sums of Federal money. 
 But he criticized almost every one of the bill's major provisions, saying they would simply "shift costs to local governments."
Mr. Giuliani, who has often found himself at odds with the national Republican Party and Republicans in Congress, said the bill could impose nearly $900 million a year in additional costs on New York City: $290 million for legal immigrants; $380 million to provide child care for welfare recipients, $100 million for work programs and $100 million to aid people cut from the Federal rolls because of a five-year limit on welfare payments to any family. (The city budget is $33 billion a year.)
In his letter, Mr. Giuliani said the welfare bill was "of enormous importance" to New York, the nation's largest city, because one million New York City residents receive public assistance. About 850,000 of them get benefits through Aid to Families With Dependent Children, which the legislation would abolish.
The bill's restrictions on aid to legal immigrants, which account for one-third of its savings, would have "a particularly serious impact in New York City, where 30 percent of the population is foreign-born," Mr. Giuliani wrote. His press secretary, Colleen A. Roche, said tonight that the Mayor was "just as concerned about the bill's effects on children."
Asked why the Mayor had not pressed Congress earlier, as versions of the bill were being considered by both houses, Richard J. Schwartz, senior adviser to the Mayor, said "the bill has reached a point where it's really quite serious."
The letter is unlikely to sway Republicans, who control both houses of Congress and previously passed two similar measures, only to see them vetoed by President Clinton. But Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, cited the letter as evidence that the bill would be "ruinous to New York City."
The new welfare bill has been passed in slightly different forms by both houses of Congress. Republican leaders of the two chambers say they will complete work on it next week, before starting a monthlong recess. President Clinton has sent conflicting signals about whether he will sign or veto the bill.
Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, has often staked out a course independent of his party, often infuriating Republican leaders. In 1994, the Mayor helped President Clinton sell his crime bill, and he later abandoned his party to support the re-election of Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat, as Governor. More recently, he criticized Bob Dole for supporting Republican legislation that would restrict aid to immigrants. At the same time, the White House has begun openly courting the Mayor's endorsement of President Clinton's re-election.
Mr. Giuliani is expected to run for re-election next year, and such positions are likely to help him appeal to the city's Democratic voters, who outnumber Republicans more than 4 to 1.
But Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a strong supporter of the welfare bill, said he did not see Mr. Giuliani's intervention in the debate as a political maneuver.
"It's a legitimate expression of concern," Mr. D'Amato said in an interview tonight. "The Mayor is concerned about the economic impact on New York City. I don't believe it's some attempt on his part to bash Republicans. I don't attribute it to any anti-Republican sentiment. If he thinks there will be an adverse impact in some areas, he has a right and an obligation to express his concerns."
New York City could not easily absorb the new costs cited by Mr. Giuliani. A report from the New York State Financial Control Board in March said that "the city's finances continue to deteriorate" despite the city's efforts to close the gap between spending and revenues. Under the city's financial plan for the next four years, the board said, spending is projected to grow about 2 percent a year, but revenues slightly less than 1 percent a year.
The Urban Institute, a research organization in Washington, estimated today that the welfare bill would push 2.6 million people, including 1.1 million children, into poverty.
The Senate Republican leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, brushed aside the estimate. "I don't put any credence in that at all," he said. "The best way to help children in poverty is for their parents to have a job." The welfare bill would require most adults to work within two years of receiving welfare.
The Federal welfare bill would impose a virtual ban on food stamps and other Federal benefits for most noncitizens. In his letter, Mr. Giuliani said these restrictions were "unfair to legal permanent residents, who would be denied many benefits which they help to finance through taxes."
In addition, he said, "the city opposes provisions in the House and Senate bills that would limit benefits to deserving disabled children by tightening eligibility requirements."
The Mayor also opposed most of the changes intended to cut the growth of food stamp spending. He said these changes would penalize places like New York, with a high cost of living and high shelter costs.
Mr. Giuliani also criticized a section of the welfare bill that would prevent states from using Federal money to provide vouchers to families who are denied cash benefits because of the five-year limit. President Clinton supports such vouchers as a way to help families buy diapers, clothing, medicine and other items for children.
Senator Lott said today that there was no prospect of such vouchers because the House and the Senate had rejected them. "The voucher plan is a way to get around ending welfare after five years," he said. "It's an escape hatch. And it's just not going to happen."
Mr. Giuliani's letter was sent to members of New York's Congressional delegation and to House and Senate negotiators who are writing the final version of the welfare bill.
