HEADLINE: Wooing The Women

BYLINE: By Gail Collins; Gail Collins is a member of the editorial board of The New York Times.

 BODY:
In the small world of political pollsters, the word is out that Linda DiVall is sick, sick, sick of talking about the gender gap. "I may have said that," admitted DiVall, a prominent polling expert and now a senior adviser to the Dole campaign. She's giving a slightly cranky phone interview -- it is, she claims, the first of 26 calls she's supposed to return from reporters who've called to ask why women seem to be abandoning the Republican Party in droves. "As I already told you," she says, sighing in the manner of a teacher who has drilled the same lesson over and over to stubbornly dimwitted pupils, "yes, there is a gender gap. Yes, it is significant. But it can be closed."
The gap is suddenly hot, very hot. It has already been around for nearly a generation, a 5 to 9 percentage point difference between the sexes in the candidates they support for President and a smaller gap in Congressional races. Early in the Clinton-Dole campaign, however, the gap turned epic -- 20 percent or more in some surveys. The Democrats are dying to talk about it. "My favorite subject," says Ann Lewis, a deputy manager of the Clinton re-election campaign. The Dole camp simply directs all questions to DiVall. 
 A century ago, suffrage leaders predicted that when women got the right to vote, they'd vote as a bloc for clean government, peace, temperance and progressive programs to protect children and families from the worst ravages of the Industrial Revolution. "That was the hope and expectation," says Lynn Sherr, a biographer of Susan B. Anthony and an ABC correspondent. Anthony told an interviewer in 1871 that when enfranchised, women "propose to do away with vice and immorality, to prevent the social evil" -- prostitution -- "by giving women remunerative employment, to forbid the sale of spiritous liquors and tobacco, and to teach men a higher and nobler life than the one they now follow."
Politicians, fearing for their lives as suffrage approached, passed a slew of laws on consumer protection, child labor and prenatal care in the early 1920's. But then nothing much happened. Women seemed to vote the same way men did, except in fewer numbers. Interest in women as a voting class vanished, and the prenatal-care program ran out of money.
When I was studying at the University of Massachusetts in 1969, women's political behavior took up a grand total of two paragraphs in our American politics textbook. The author, John H. Fenton, believed that women tended to cluster to the far left and far right, because they had little experience with the real world. "If a man becomes interested in extreme politics, his views are likely to be challenged by both his associates at work and his neighborhood friends," the book said. "Typically, women have a less variegated history of friendship and associations, and when they acquire extreme political views they are less likely to have them challenged by their friends or their experience." Fenton died recently, and I never had a chance to find out how he explained the Michigan Militia.
Studying women's voting behavior was difficult back then. Most researchers were poring over election data, trying to figure out where the Hungarians and Germans and WASP's and Jews lived and to chart the ebbs and flows of their precincts. Women had no special neighborhoods. They were all mixed in with men, difficult to quantify. It was easiest to assume that women voted the same way their husbands did.
Gallup polls did show differences between the sexes in voting in the post-World War II years, but they did not reveal a major difference in the way men and women regarded the political world. Women liked Ike better than male voters, and contrary to all the legends about John Kennedy's sexual charisma, they split, 51-49, for Nixon in 1960, while men voted for Kennedy, 52-48. Women were slightly more favorable to Hubert Humphrey than men in 1968 only because more men voted for the third-party candidate, George Wallace. Four years later, in Nixon's landslide over George McGovern, there was virtually no sex difference in the vote. But if only women had been voting in 1976, Jimmy Carter would have never beaten Gerald Ford.
Flash forward to 1979. The Republican pollster Richard B. Wirthlin, working on the Reagan campaign, peered into a stew of data and discerned an amazing new element floating just beneath the surface: women were pulling away from Ronald Reagan and toward the Democrats, while men were being drawn deeper into the orbit of the Republican Party. "It was one of those things that once you see it, you can't take your eyes off it," says Wirthlin reverently, in the tones of a scientist who has just discovered a new variation of the Ebola virus.
The gender gap had arrived. It was not exactly the mass movement the suffragists promised, but in the hypersensitive world of modern politics, a gap is almost as good as a bloc. Women were going off on their own, requiring special treatment. By 1984, Reagan was running ads on daytime television trying to convince housewives that he had really done something about inflation.
The cause of the gap seems to be remarkably basic. Both Republican and Democratic pollsters agree that women, as a group, believe in an activist government -- particularly the social safety net -- more than men do. "Women are more likely to believe government can work to help solve problems," says DiVall. "It's much more deep-seated than any one partisan election."
None of this, of course, refers to all women all the time. So pollsters slice and dice the statistics to compare the sexes in narrower categories: white independents, married senior citizens, parents of small children. When Wirthlin was helping the Reagan team prepare for the 1984 re-election campaign, he broke women down into 32 different groups and subgroups and gave them female names. "Some of these groups were more strongly Republican than males," he recalls. "Others were 90-10 against the Republicans." Reagan was strongest with Alice (younger, married, working) and weakest with Helen (younger, not married, not working). Middle-aged, nonworking women -- Frances (unmarried) and Evelyn (married) -- were a key target, even though Frances seemed to be a big Mondale backer. "They were very concerned about economic policy and very doubtful that Reagan's programs were working," Wirthlin says. "So we targeted ads and some direct mail to older women." The gap was never completely erased, but women did wind up supporting Reagan over Walter Mondale, 56-44. Men chose Reagan, 62-37.
Unmarried women are more likely to vote Democratic than their married sisters. "The new gap is the marriage gap," says Wirthlin. "Being married overrides male or female." Black voters of both sexes are so overwhelmingly Democratic that pollsters often restrict themselves to comparing different segments of white voters. But beyond that, the analysis of how the pieces of the female voting population shake down are often wildly at variance. Susan J. Carroll of the Center for the American Woman and Politics, at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, did an interesting analysis, beginning with the 1980 election, in which she concluded that women tended to vote more like men if they felt dependent because they did not work or had low-paying jobs. Women with "psychological autonomy," who were unmarried or had high-paying jobs, tended to be much more anti-Reagan than men in comparable positions, she said.
But one of Carroll's conclusions, that women who made good salaries were a big part of the gap, runs counter to Republican polling dogma that holds that those very people are a Republican oasis amid the parched desert of female votes. "The classic prototype of a feminist -- younger, college-educated, working -- was generally more, not less supportive of Reagan," claims Wirthlin.
Linda DiVall, after some protests ("I'm not going to tell you our strategy!"), says the Dole campaign believes women making more than $30,000 a year are promising Republican targets. Meanwhile Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster, says the gap between young, college-educated men and women is so vast that she is beginning to worry about who these people are going to marry.
All sorts of things can affect the conclusions a set of polls produce -- the way the results are sliced (when you're looking for a sample of relatively successful, sophisticated female voters, do you pick college graduates, or those making more than $30,000 a year?), the size of the sample and the way the questions are worded. Until just before an election, voters are extremely susceptible to the news of the moment. The excitement of a convention sends a nominee's numbers shooting up for a week or so, even if his long-term popularity is slightly lower than that of head lice.
A fascinating thing about the gender gap is the number of theories it has spawned about who is gapping and why. Among the more interesting:
 
Women Didn't Go Anywhere -- It's the Men Who Took a Hike
 If women are voting for candidates who will protect Medicare, Social Security, aid to education and a safety net for the poor, they're only behaving as both sexes did before the Reagan revolution. Barbara Ehrenreich, the essayist, argued in Newsweek that because of late marriage, single motherhood and the invention of 24-hour sports channels, "men are living in a state of radical disconnection from the women-and-children part of the human race," which still has to worry about caring for elderly parents and finding affordable day care and decent schools.
This theory is popular with people who resent the idea that men should always be regarded as the norm. Nancy Cott, a professor of American Studies at Yale University, complains that when newly enfranchised women started voting like their husbands, no one considered the possibility that "the husbands were voting the way their wives wanted all along."
 
Gender Pride
 Women may have deserted the Republican Party, this theory goes, because it does not seem hospitable to women. "American women need to see other faces of the party to show that there's more diversity," says DiVall. This theory is popular among Republicans (particularly the women), partly because the cure is so simple: nominate more Republican women for races they can win and appoint more Republican women to high-profile government positions.
The G.O.P. has actually made strides on this front, and Dole's team of top advisers certainly contains more women than Clinton's. But the Republicans have to erase a lot of old memories. Who can forget the golden moment in the 1992 Presidential debate when President Bush, trying to prove that he had plenty of key female advisers, pointed to Rose Zamaria, an aide assigned to duties like handing out Presidential souvenirs, and praised her as "about as tough as a boot."
 
It's Abortion, Stupid
 Abortion-rights advocates frequently take credit for the gender gap, but a look at the polls shows that men and women do not really differ on abortion. Men, in fact, turn out to be more supportive of abortion rights in some polls. But abortion, like gun control, is an intensity-of-preference issue: the power resides with the minority of voters who will change candidates over that single question.
Since 1989, when the Supreme Court shifted to a more restrictive stance on abortion, the swing voters have been pro-choice. A study by Debra L. Dodson of the Center for the American Woman and Politics found that among people who voted for George Bush in 1988 but not in 1992, the greatest drop-off came among pro-choice women.
 
The Loudness Factor
 Women are so turned off by any hint of aggression, says Celinda Lake, that they even reject propositions about curing the trade imbalance that lean too hard on the idea of competition, or "beating" the other countries. In other words, women will not vote for men who yell. Loud-candidate rejection would explain the relative shortage of women at Pat Buchanan rallies, the gender gap in the George Wallace campaigns and the fact that women who'd voted for Republican candidates in 1994 started deserting the new Congress as soon as Newt Gingrich began appearing on the evening news. It does not account for women's relative lack of enthusiasm for Reagan and Bush. But it may have been at least partly to blame for Ted Kennedy's gap problem during the Democratic primaries in 1980. One of his former campaign workers says: "He'd go out and scream on the podium, and I'd think, imagine you're a retired woman, having your dinner in front of the TV in your nice quiet house, and you see this out-of-control, red-faced guy yelling. Maybe the gap had as much to do with that as Chappaquiddick."
 
Does Character Count?
 Conventional wisdom has always held that female voters are particularly concerned about the Inner Candidate -- a politician's personality and character. How then to explain their enormous preference for Clinton, a man subject to investigations into his personal finances and political ethics, and dogged by questions about his own past sexual behavior? The answer may be that women are not all that obsessed with character issues, at least when they're choosing a President. Lake has asked voters whether they would rather support a candidate they agree with on the issues but who had character flaws or a candidate with a good character but with whom they disagree. Both sexes chose the candidate they agreed with on the issues, by a wide margin.
 
Rescuing Hillary
 Democrats are beginning to question whether the huge gap they've found between young college-educated women and men may have something to do with the Hillary factor. The non-surprise datum of the polling season: women are more likely than men to feel sympathy for Hillary Clinton. (Experts say neither male nor female voters yet know enough about Elizabeth Dole -- another strong, career-minded woman -- to have much of an opinion.)
Senator Christopher Dodd, the Democratic national chairman, has several nieces whom he has long suspected of being closet Republicans. But one of them, he says, told him she had an epiphany last winter when she saw Hillary Clinton on TV talking to Martha Stewart about holiday decorations. "She said, 'Here's Mrs. Clinton, graduate of Yale Law, one of the hundred best attorneys in America, and she's doing an interview about the gold leaf on a few wreaths.' " His niece, Dodd says, decided Republican Hillary-bashing had gone too far if the First Lady was being relegated to gilding pine cones.
All these theories broadcast the same message: women are nicer. Men will take a flier on deficit reduction, but women worry about the human consequences. Men like guns; women like nuclear disarmament, civilized discourse and Medicare. The gender gap winds up sounding like a battle between good and evil. It's enough to make you wonder why we let men vote. Challenged to make at least one unfavorable comparison between women and men, a Democratic analyst paused. "Women didn't build the country," he said finally.
This is why some folks get nervous over gender-gap spin. It tends to hark back to all the old stereotypes -- women are morally superior, but they're afraid of risk and yearn for protection. Better they should stay home and fret while men forge into the wilderness, taming continents and extending civilization.
"I'm always reluctant to make statements about how if you're in this class, this is the way you vote," says Ruth B. Mandel, director of the Eagleton Institute. "Not all women vote and think alike." Indeed, there are black women, unmarried women and college-educated women in this country who are planning to vote a straight Republican ticket this fall, just as there are middle-aged white men who prefer spending on social services to balancing the deficit. The generalizations that are central to the art of polling necessarily rob the population of its flavor and diversity, even when responses are divided into 32 subcategories and given homey names.
But Presidential campaigns are long past the sort of retail politics in which the candidates try to win over voters one by one. They aim their messages at the big targets highlighted by the polls. Support for Clinton among older, single and professional women has been enormous in many polls, so the President's campaign stretched its net in the direction of "married moms," one of the most conservative female voting groups. It was no coincidence that the President spent a great deal of the early campaign talking about curfews, school uniforms and television V-chips.
While the Democrats fantasize about winning every voter with two X chromosomes, the Republicans are counting on the gap, now in the double digits, to narrow considerably before Election Day. They have reason to be hopeful. The gap has never wound up higher than 9 percent in a Presidential election. Voters of both sexes tend to veer away from candidates who look like losers. The gap shrunk in 1984 when women perceived that Mondale's candidacy was going nowhere. When the Dole campaign was in a funk this summer, so many male voters migrated toward Clinton that the gap became negligible in some polls.
The Dole campaign desperately wants to send the message that the party is a place where women can feel comfortable and that its candidate, while opposed to abortion, should not be considered "extreme" on social issues. It's a delicate balancing act, since Republican women in many states have been known to bolt their party when a candidate seems likely to actually do something to restrict abortion access. (Douglas Wilder won a narrow Democratic victory in the 1989 Virginia governor's race thanks to pro-choice Republican women.) Thus Dole's painful struggle to get "tolerance" into the party platform, and his choice of the young, pro-choice Representative Susan Molinari of New York as the convention's keynote speaker.
Little of this gnawing over the gender gap, you will notice, has had much impact on actual government policy. By virtually every account, the most important single factor splitting women from men in the voting booth is women's greater confidence in government's ability to help people and their concern about the reduction in services for the young, old and needy. And ever since the gap first cropped up, the country has been moving away from activist government and the social safety net.
"Ouch," says Ann Lewis of the Clinton re-election campaign, when I suggest that the political response to the gender gap has been mainly cosmetic. "I know women have made a difference. Give me a second to think about this. I'm clutched over in pain." DiVall, meanwhile, says that Dole's campaign can appeal to women by doing "more personalizing." This means talking about his war injuries. Both parties still seem to regard the gap as a marketing problem that can be addressed by buying more advertising time on the Lifetime channel.
The gender gap era is just another stage in the evolution of the female voter that began with the struggle for suffrage. For generations after, politicians believed that to get women's votes, they had only to win over their husbands. Far more humiliating was when powerful campaign strategists thought what female voters wanted was a really cute guy. (Remember Dan Quayle?) Then there were all those campaigns in which Washington was obsessed with the angry white male. Now, women voters have reached a new plateau: They've arrived at the pander zone.

HEADLINE: Designs From the Dutch That Prompt a Smile

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
Today's designers of furnishings are thumbing their noses at some traditions and embracing others, finding fresh ways of merging high and low technologies. A plastic sack is filled with soil to become a flowerpot; broken bits of pottery are recycled as bowls, and space-age fibers are woven into a hammocklike chair and stiffened with epoxy.
The best of contemporary design is now "less indulgent and flashy than in the 80's," said Paola Antonelli, the curator of design at the Museum of Modern Art. "Examples of these trends can be found all over the world," she said. But, she noted, in recent years a group of designers from the Netherlands has achieved results that merit particular attention. 
 To illustrate the point, Ms. Antonelli chose 36 colorful objects that were produced in Amsterdam, Rotterdam and Voorburg over the last 10 years for "Thresholds: Contemporary Design From the Netherlands," an exhibition at the Modern through Nov. 5.
Not since Gerrit Rietveld designed his slab-back red-blue chair in 1918 has the Netherlands seen such innovations in design. Emulating Rietveld, his successors are using traditional craft methods to devise unconventional products.
Each piece in the show is characterized by an economical use of materials, a simplicity of form and an awareness of the environment. Several works are also witty, a quality absent in furnishings since the Italians began to dominate the design scene in the 1960's and early 70's.
In one case, trash is turned into trash baskets. For these works, discarded billboard posters are refashioned into what look like giant-size supermarket bags with bold graphic images. The designer, Jos van der Meulen, sewed the posters together so they could be flattened for shipping. Ms. Antonelli describes the resulting "Paper Bags" as an "ingenious example of the reuse of wasted materials."
To Dutch designers today, recycling and thrift are basic tenets of their unwritten professional code, and they consider ethics as important as esthetics, especially as they pertain to the environment. There is also a noticeable absence of bombast and ego in what they produce. In fact, some pieces look as if they were made for people with little money to spend on such objects. (It's an illusion, of course, considering the complexities of manufacturing these objects and the high prices asked for them. A plastic knob made to hang on a wall as a coat hook, for instance, costs $78.)
"It's as if designers never felt the need to mark their work with a personal signature," Ms. Antonelli said. "These products are so understated it's unbelievable. Of course, understatement is natural to Northern Europeans. But there's wit in these objects too, even though the Dutch seem so serious."
Take, for example, Henk Stallinga's flower holder made of a large kitchen sponge. The stems of the flowers are stuck into the top of the sponge, which is sealed on the bottom with polyurethane. Once the sponge is filled with water, the "vase" remains upright.
For his Blister lamps, Mr. Stallinga borrowed an idea from the world of packaging for a lighting fixture. He used the concept of snap-together clear-plastic packaging like that in which toothbrushes are sold to produce a string of lamps, each with a tapered round shade on a spherical base and a red bulb. The basic design is a cliche in lighting, but in this reincarnation it seems delightfully fresh.

THE MATERIALS USED IN most of the objects in the show are more experimental than the forms. Unlike the designers of the 80's, who seemed preoccupied with prettiness and self-conscious zaniness, today's innovators seem inspired by necessity rather than whim, even when the newness of their designs is sometimes literally skin deep. For example, the blackboard paint used by Djoke de Jong to create the slatelike surface on a Parsons-style table transforms this familiar-looking table into one you think you are seeing for the first time, especially when covered with a child's chalk drawings.
"Most of these works are formally austere but are made playful by their use," Ms. Antonelli said.
Two glass objects designed by Arnout Visser look as if they should be found in a laboratory. His bottle for salad dressing takes advantage of the fact that oil and vinegar do not mix. It has a spout on either side, one for oil at the top, the other for vinegar at the base. Each liquid is poured without disturbing the other.
Mr. Visser's Archimedes Letter Scale, adapts an ancient Greek principle of physics. A graduated cylinder of Pyrex floats in a liquid inside a larger cylinder. When a letter is placed on top of the floating cylinder, the cylinder is pushed down, registering the weight of the letter.
Sophistication rendered simply is the forte of the Dutch designers. "Their objects' apparent modesty has made them emblematic of what political correctness in design should be," Ms. Antonelli said.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 6; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1455 words

HEADLINE: Habitats/79th Street and First Avenue;
To an Architect, 1 Plus 1 Equals 3

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
WILLIAM M. BERNSTEIN wanted to psych out the real estate market, and he thought he had a smart way to do it.
"It seemed clear that the smaller apartments in New York City were not considered that desirable," he said, "and I figured that by putting two one-bedrooms together I could make a three-bedroom for a fraction of the price of just going out and buying an existing three-bedroom." 
 Mr. Bernstein knew that when he and his wife, Julia, had started looking to buy apartments a few years ago -- squeezed out of their one-bedroom rental -- small apartments were the dregs of the real estate market. He had not only read about it, he had gut-wrenching personal experience.
"I knew -- I'd bought a studio in 1986 and tried to sell it in the depth of the recession," he said ruefully. "I'd renovated it myself, and the whole thing was probably the worst financial decision I'll ever make." He hesitated. "At least I hope it's the worst financial decision I'll ever make."
He looked around his new three-bedroom apartment, his dream -- created by merging two one-bedroom apartments in a postwar building on 79th Street near First Avenue on the Upper East Side. He and his wife and their 2-year-old son, Sam, had moved in only the day before.
Mr. Bernstein, who heads a five-person architectural office, had prepared spread sheets for every number, every detail of the apartment reconstruction. ("I took two semesters of real estate finance," he said, jokingly, as he unveiled his accordion-folded sheets of graph paper, full of minuscule notations.)
But finding two apartments that could be combined -- without creating a monster of long hallways and awkward rooms -- was almost impossible, and Mr. Bernstein cautioned that, like experiments with explosive substances, combining apartments is not a game for amateurs.
"I heard of one job where the owners combined two apartments to make a four-bedroom -- but the master bedroom ended up without a window," he said with a shudder.
Yet even Mr. Bernstein, with his Yale architectural degree and his myriad contacts with general contractors, had a rough time finding something that would work.
From his bulging manila folder -- the record of his search -- he pulled out a stack of floor plans and agents' notations. He found a ruler in a drawer: The stack was an inch and a half thick. "I saw over 100 apartments," he said.
At first, the Bernsteins tried picking the possible combinations out of the newspaper classified advertisements. "We'd see two apartments advertised next to each other and we thought we'd just waltz in and buy them," he said, pausing. "We wasted a couple of Sundays that way."
THEY rethought their strategy. "So then we thought we'd take a flyer and just look at one-bedrooms and stick a note under the next-door neighbor's apartments, not mentioning the one we'd just looked at, saying we might be interested in buying their apartment," he said. "No one ever called us back."
They then tried calling brokers, but they found that most of the brokers shied away after hearing their requirements: doorman building, Upper East Side, high floors with views, low maintenance -- and the kicker: Both apartments for a total of less than $400,000.
"In our price range, we used to joke that our priority was 'west of the river,' " he said, mocking the real estate advertisements for blue chip apartments that read "between Fifth and Madison" or "west of Third Avenue." "We never got much beyond First Avenue."
As for finding possible combinations in prewar buildings, "we just looked at them from the sidewalk," Mr. Bernstein said. "We were pretty much stuck with postwars."
The search seemed interminable.
"When I filled up the book, I knew I was in trouble," said Mr. Bernstein, looking at his thick ring binder. At one point, they hired an appraiser to investigate the financial ramifications of buying the apartment above the one-bedroom apartment they were renting on East 74th Street, which might have been purchased from the owner, although itwasn't actually on the market.
But the maintenance payments were high, and, with what the sellers above were asking, they decided it wasn't worth it. Mr. Bernstein and his wife thought about giving up their search, but they already had their son, and they thought things would get even worse.
"It really struck us that the people in all those one-bedrooms were mirror images of ourselves," said Mrs. Bernstein. "They were people who were stuck; people who had one, or even two, children, who couldn't sell their one-bedrooms for anything like what they'd paid. I felt bad for them."
The worst scenario, she explained, was when the apartment was what agents call a convertible two-bedroom. "They'd converted the dining el to the child's bedroom and sometimes there was a baby-sitter, too, and it was all so crowded."
Nevertheless, Mrs. Bernstein, who supervises the production of women's clothes for a catalogue company, wryly retold how they tried to be secretive about their intentions to combine two apartments -- fearing that if they betrayed their concept, both owners would get together and raise their prices.
"It was a riot," she said. "Sometimes we'd look at one apartment and then there was a whole charade -- like we'd have to go back downstairs and wait 10 minutes and then come up again and make lots of noise to show we were just coming up for the first time."
When a real estate agent sent them floor plans for two apartments on 79th Street in a postwar building near First Avenue, "we thought they had the makings of the thing," said the architect. "And we were also desperate; the co-op board where we were renting had told the owners no more renting."
Using only the floor plans -- before they even visited the apartments -- Mr. Bernstein came up with a design.
"There was a very unpleasant woman in one of the apartments, a tenant," recalled Mrs. Bernstein, "and after we had visited she told the owner she was sure we weren't going to buy it, because I just walked in and out -- a sure sign of failure.
"But when we came in, we already knew we were taking it -- we just had to look around to see the light and stuff," she said. "I didn't have to look at the kitchen because I knew we were ripping it out."
Eventually, after they negotiated prices for the two apartments, they had to come out in the open; they had to make sure the co-op board would allow them to combine the apartments. They had put a contingency in the contracts that if the board did not allow the combination they could withdraw. The board agreed to their plans.
At the end of negotiating they paid $308,500 for the two one-bedroom apartments, and closed on May 6.
They moved in July 15, after doing $50,000 worth of work -- a figure Mr. Bernstein warned is misleading.
"I think it would have been 50 percent more if a person without experience went to a general contractor," he said.
By working out a deal by which the contractor acted as construction manager -- for a flat fee, with time and materials for the work added on -- Mr. Bernstein said, he achieved big savings. "I assumed all risk," he said. "The general contractor usually does that. I was comfortable with that, but I wouldn't recommend it to others."
WITH this system, the architect explained, it was easier to change things as the job went along.
"There's always lots of unforeseen things on a job -- that column wasn't supposed to be there," he said, gesturing toward a white column on one side of the kitchen opening. "But we found a floor-to-ceiling gas pipe, so we had to cover it up.
"With unexpected things, the general contractors on bid jobs tend to really whack you for changes," he said. "Then you say: 'That sounds like a lot of money for a little change,' and it can turn into a nasty wrangle. But because of working with time and materials -- and a flat fee for managing the whole job, including the changes -- we never really had to discuss the price of the changes."
The apartment is almost done. Only a few details in the kitchen are left: the trim for the front of the $2,900 (contractor's price) SubZero refrigerator, and some shelves Mr. Bernstein is designing for a spot against the wall above the granite-topped kitchen peninsula that separates the cooking area from the dining room.
And after living for several years with their son in a one-bedroom apartment, the new place seems luxurious beyond belief.
"Last night, Sam was in his bedroom and my mother, who's staying with us, was in her bedroom," said Mrs. Bernstein. "My husband was drafting in his office in the passageway and I was sitting in the living room." She paused.
"And we still had one whole bedroom with nobody in it."

GRAPHIC: Photos: William M. Bernstein, his wife, Julia, and their son, Sam, in the dining area of their co-op on East 79th Street near First Avenue. Living room is above right. (Photographs by Carol Halebian for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Phantom Hall Filled With Discord

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
IT FLOATS ABOVE DOWNTOWN LOS ANGELES, a mirage in the California sun. For Walt Disney, it offers remembrance with dignity; for Frank Gehry, a hometown monument to an architect's career. For the Los Angeles Philharmonic, it is an emblem of long-sought international eminence. For local politicians, it sings a siren song to far-flung Angelenos, drawing them inward to the troubled center of this exploding universe of a city.
It is the Walt Disney Concert Hall; that is, it would be if someone built it. Primed by an extravagant gift from Disney's widow nine years ago and originally expected to be well along in construction by now and to open next summer, Disney Hall is still a glorified hole in the ground, its assets-in-hand slowly bled away by mismanagement and delay, its original cost estimates nearly tripled. If the finances are not assured within one year, the hall will not be built at all. 
 Mr. Gehry's distinctive design has become both Holy Grail and albatross for the various players in the Disney Hall affair. A dangerous drain on money and civic confidence, it nevertheless holds up the seductive promise of a magical, magnetic cultural palace attractive not only to residents of Orange County but to the entire world. This is a quest not for just any symphony hall but for a particular one. A generic shoebox of a concert space would long since have been built.
If Disney Hall ever sets down to earth, there is a place waiting for it. The County of Los Angeles, which owns the land, has done its part by digging the subterranean garage on which Mr. Gehry's delicately designed structure is supposed to fit. This hole, capped like an oil well, sits across the street from the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, the orchestra's current home, which it shares with opera, ballet and, in spring, the Oscar ceremonies. For the moment, the parking garage looks like a low-slung warehouse, elegantly white. It is open for business, but business is reportedly sparse.
Hearts are being broken. Lillian Disney, who is said to be 97 years old, has seen no return on her generosity. Of the family's gifts, totaling $78 million (now more than $100 million with accumulated interest), $41 million has already been spent on "soft costs": architects' fees, drawings and specifications, lawyers, consultants. An accepted rule of thumb estimates soft costs of a construction project at 25 percent to 30 percent of hard, or actual building, costs. Here they have at times approached twice that.
Ernest Fleischmann, the Philharmonic's wily and intrepid managing director for 27 years, will retire from his job next year, and Disney Hall would have left behind even more for Los Angeles to remember him by. Mr. Fleischmann, a vigorous 71, expresses absolute certainty that the hall will be built, but it will not be easy.
Downtown Los Angeles needs saving, and Disney Hall, according to county planners, is to be among its saviors. The city center's cluster of tall buildings, set incongruously amid this vast grid of streets and boulevards, is busy by day but, given corporate mergers and suburban flight, not busy enough. The several hotels in the neighborhood do not appear full. Concert, opera, dance and theater audiences at the Music Center have few if any restaurants, cafes or safe promenades to tempt them on their way to their parking spaces. Spago is not far away, by car.
"Los Angeles was laid out in crossing boulevards and streets," said Mr. Gehry in his Santa Monica offices recently. "It was one of the first linear cities in existence, and Wilshire Boulevard stretched across it like connective tissue. But the city fathers thought every American city ought to have a downtown, so they turned their backs on Wilshire Boulevard and the linear city."
Irrelevant or not, downtown Los Angeles is there, looming out of the haze. So if Disney Hall is built, will people come and fill it? Despite local groanings, the network of Los Angeles freeways works remarkably well, yet the distances, and the travel times, are daunting. Can a nighttime downtown Los Angeles, no matter how brilliantly accoutered, seduce any more of what is largely an early-to-bed and early-to-rise work culture?
Optimists say yes, adding the hope that a less pressured Chandler Pavilion can become a center for the city's flourishing Pacific Rim cultures: Korean and Vietnamese theaters, for example. Whether Asian communities will actually get in their cars at night and pay the $7 evening parking fees is more fodder for debate.
Originally estimated at up to $100 million, Disney Hall's costs, according to the consulting firm brought in to clean up the current mess, will come to $264 million. (The $81 million parking garage was financed separately by a county bond issue.) The new completion date is 2001. But there is a catch. The project is $150 million short, and county officials, mixing hope with exasperation, have set a deadline for the raising of a major gift: $50 million or more, as a tangible demonstration that this hall can be paid for. If such a gift is not forthcoming by June 1997, Disney Hall will be dumped.
How did it happen? Mr. Gehry's design is a wonder. The interior curves like a boat: the orchestra settled in the prow, listeners seated all around, the ceiling undulating downward like blooming spinakers. To the sides of this boat are rectangular structures, housing everything patrons and performers will need. Around the design exterior walls bend, twist and swirl. Mrs. Disney is a gardener, and at her request, greenery and flowers will be everywhere. Disney Hall has been described flatteringly as a rose about to open and disparagingly as a collection of hatboxes sagging in the rain.

G IVEN AN ORIGINAL MANagement team that supposedly possessed experience, enthusiasm and political connections, Disney Hall went very wrong. One hears many explanations, often in the form of vague accusation, and one believes parts of all of them. Mea culpa is a phrase rarely come across in the brief annals of Disney Hall.
Mr. Gehry's firm, considerably smaller at the end of the 1980's than it is now, farmed out the architectural drawings to someone else. Mr. Gehry says the drawings "don't work" and will have to be done again (by Mr. Gehry's expanded forces and at a cost of $10 million). Harry L. Hufford, chief executive officer of the new management team, says the drawings work but are "incomplete." Dworsky Associates, who did the work, said, "The money wasn't there to do what was designed." Dworsky allies say privately that Gehry's work was confusing. Everyone agrees the drawings took much longer than anyone anticipated.
The county added to the confusion by attaching a hotel to the plan. New-found visitors to downtown would patronize it; visiting artists would travel from hotel room to dressing room in a single elevator ride. Designs were made to accommodate the hotel. (Mr. Gehry was enthusiastic, more so than the Disney family, which feared a clouding of the issue.) But when international hotel chains lost interest, the designs had to be undone and redone.
No one currently involved with Disney Hall wants to name names, but the original team does not seem to have done a very good job. Reins were loose. New managers hint at a prior preoccupation with self-protection. "The biggest mistake I made was not getting out of this thing a few years back," said Mr. Gehry, who is worried about Disney Hall's influence on his reputation and his future business. "I saw what was happening. I wrote letters of warning, but nothing happened."
Mr. Gehry points assertively to the branch of the Guggenheim Museum he is currently building in Bilbao, Spain. The design is similar to Disney Hall's, and Mr. Gehry says that despite distance and language barriers, the $100 million project is on budget and on schedule.
Los Angeles still bursts with money old and new. A number of film executives or local patriarchs could write out the requisite check for Disney Hall without a tremor. After taking hits from bank mergers and a post-cold-war malaise in the defense industry, Southern California's economy is picking up. Film and recording businesses here generate huge incomes from all over the world. The incidence of staggeringly expensive cars on Los Angeles freeways is staggering in itself.
But Disney Hall fund-raisers find themselves on a precarious ledge. For if Mrs. Disney's generosity goes unrequited, who among Southern California's philanthropists will be eager to give to the arts again? Asked whether Disney Hall is going beyond the Los Angeles community to get its money, Mr. Fleischmann will say only that the question is very delicate. Mayor Richard J. Riordan is an enthusiastic champion.
Disney Hall remains a tough sell, even though it is generally understood that a big gift will put the giver's name up in limestone. (The Disney name is, of course, not negotiable, but one possibility might be "The Walt Disney Concert Hall at the [blank] Symphony Center.")
General trends in giving run nowadays toward medical and social problems. In old Los Angeles, as in other American cities, culture was the purview and responsibility of an elite. Deficits at the symphony or opera were handled by a few personal checks. But the white, Anglo-Saxon and heavily moneyed class is dispersing in southern California, and the film community, heavily Jewish, was never readily invited into this cultural world. Today Disney Hall could use some of that Hollywood money, but Hollywood, a more or less self-contained community, seems uninterested in venturing where it was once made to feel unwelcome.

M R. FLEISCHMANN points out the city's lack of corporate headquarters, the favorite fishing grounds for arts organizations in Chicago, Pittsburgh or Detroit. As they immigrate farther into suburban southern California, people with money are making new artistic allegiances with performing-arts centers closer to home: the Thousand Oaks and the Cerritos Centers, the huge Orange County Performing Arts Center.
"Los Angeles is an entrepreneurial city," said Emily Laskin, who handles development for the Los Angeles Philharmonic. "People come here to develop a project, and then they leave. There are fewer fixed institutions, which is why many move here in the first place, to escape institutions. I worked in Minneapolis, and even those with modest incomes donated to the arts. They did it out of civic responsibility."
Disney Hall was in a hurry from the start, and that has been part of the problem. Though all parties agree that the Disney family has been unflaggingly supportive and patient, inescapable was the understanding that a generous patron, well along in years, wanted (and deserved) to see something in return. Disney Hall began on a fast-track basis; that is, plans went ahead without all the final details worked out. Mr. Gehry says fast-tracking is common practice, but Mr. Fleischmann, among others, regrets the lack of a specific budget.
Mr. Gehry says his original designs were scrupulously cost-effective, and subsequent studies indicate that the Disney project compares favorably to another troubled but now completed concert hall, the Meyerson, in Dallas.
There were other false starts: a downward revision with Mr. Gehry's proposed chamber-music hall excised; the replacement of the original limestone exteriors with more modest metal sheathing. There was the hotel idea, and legal fees have kept piling up. Each year Disney Hall is delayed means an additional $9 million.
The big trouble arrived two years ago, when construction bids came in. They were unexpectedly high, said Mr. Fleischmann. Feasibility studies were ordered from outside consultants (Hines Interests); professional fund-raisers (Milano, Ruff and Associates) were hired, and a new board was assembled to pull Disney Hall together. Mr. Gehry points out wryly that he is the only surviving member of the original team.
Does the Los Angeles Philharmonic really need a new orchestra hall? It would help. The Chandler is multipurpose, acoustically mushy, sedate and a little gloomy. Not much used in summer these days, it presents hectic competitions for space between orchestra, opera and other functions during high season.
"Large amounts of money are paid stagehands to take down and put up opera sets in a matter of hours so that the stage can be cleared for other things," said Mr. Fleischmann. "In that respect, the new hall saves money." More high-priced donor boxes have been allowed for, meaning added income for the orchestra.
The prospect of Disney Hall, furthermore, is a lure and an anchor for the orchestra's young, energetic music director, Esa-Pekka Salonen. Whether its failure would prompt Mr. Salonen to move on is unknown. He has, however, signed on until 2001, when the new hall is now scheduled to be completed.
Lev Yaroslavsky, a county supervisor, ticks off the usual reasons for building Disney Hall: the new restaurants, shops, hotels and cafes; the new jobs they will generate; in general, the reseeding of downtown Los Angeles for future growth. But Mr. Yaroslavsky, blunt and burly politician that he is, dreams the dream everyone else connected with this project continues to dream.
"One hundred years from now, if Disney Hall is still standing and even if the demographics here have changed, it will survive as a landmark, as an important expression of a community," he said. "The Gehry design is something unique, something very California. Is it necessary? William Mulholland, who designed the water system for Los Angeles, once said, 'If you don't bring the water, they won't need it.' Here it's the same. If they build this hall, it will become a destination point, a reason people go somewhere, like the Sydney opera house in Australia."

A ND WHAT IF THE BIG GIFT is not forthcoming by next June? Will the county grant more time? "I'm not in a position to say if an extension will be possible," Mr. Yaroslavsky said, "but if there is to be a major gift, we ought to know it in a year."
Meanwhile, don't underestimate the power of a monument. And Disney Hall promises a multipurpose monument to much and many: to Walt Disney, who posthumously will have paid for much of it; to Frank Gehry, who designed it, and Ernest Fleischmann, who imagined it, and to the people of Los Angeles, grasping for firm ground in this seductive, restless urban space.
"Maybe this hall is already obsolete," Mr. Gehry said in a moment of apparent whimsy. "Maybe I should start all over."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 25; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1094 words

HEADLINE: If It Feels Good, Don't Do It

BYLINE: By Richard Klein; Richard Klein's new book, "Eat Fat," a cultural history of fat, will be published in October.

 BODY:

The Pleasure Police
How Bluenose Busybodies and Lily-Livered Alarmists Are Taking All the Fun Out of Life.
By David Shaw.
307 pp. New York:
Doubleday. $23. 
 IN "The Pleasure Police," David Shaw updates what Michel Foucault called "the repressive hypothesis." The latest version of that old story, told by conventional wisdom, goes something like this: After the sexual repression of the 1950's, still bound by postwar morality, the 60's accomplished a cultural revolution, which proclaimed the rights and liberated the prerogatives of pleasure. "If it feels good, do it!" was the moral imperative at Woodstock, but since the advent of Jimmy Carter, the nation has been swept by a counterrevolution. Now the rule is: "If it feels good, it must be risky and bad, immoral and dangerous to your health."
This cyclical movement of repression and return of the repressed has brought us back to the point where all fun is barred. David Shaw thinks that the pendulum has swung too far. He advocates a more tolerant, more moderate attitude toward pleasure, and toward sexual behavior in general. But however welcome his moderation, it risks ignoring what was invasive in the 60's revolution and much that is interesting -- complex, intensifying -- in the current climate of alarm and disapproval.
Mr. Shaw, the media critic of The Los Angeles Times, has read everything; surveying the field (including my own work), he persuasively argues, and abundantly illustrates, that the pleasure police, with their dire threats and condemnations, have insinuated themselves into every aspect of our lives. A new complicity has grown up between the religious Ayatollahs on the right and the sanctimonious alarmists on the left, united in their common determination to make everything we touch or ingest illegal, immoral or fattening. In chapters devoted to eating and drinking, smoking and making love, Mr. Shaw documents the excessive prudery and exaggerated warnings that have come to surround our every indulgence. In American culture, all universal sources of pleasure are eventually medicalized, then politicized and finally policed (if not prohibited): witness alcohol, tobacco, cannabis, fat, pornography, masturbation, perfume. Mr. Shaw aptly quotes H. L. Mencken's eternal definition of puritanism as "the haunting fear that someone, somewhere, may be happy." All our most intimate spheres of solace and release are exposed to the prurient curiosity of those who cannot themselves enjoy, because of the envy they feel. We Americans, with our Puritan ancestors, are different from, say, the French, who are too busy passionately pursuing their own pleasure to worry much about other people's.
Mr. Shaw illuminates the strange contradiction that afflicts our society. At a time when Americans are living longer, with a generally improved standard of living, we have become excessively alarmed by the negligible and spurious risks in everything, frightened by the most peripheral and hypothetical problems. The media sell fear and anxiety to the middle class, grossly overplaying risks, overemphasizing the hazards of life. Obesity, for example, is treated like an epidemic, and now dieting is a $40 billion industry and eating disorders abound: already the fattest nation in the world, we are rapidly getting fatter.
Mr. Shaw's book belongs to a recent trend deploring the long season of whining about the somber state of American life; he suggests that it's perhaps some guilt over our very success that makes us susceptible to being told that "everything we eat, breathe, touch or see might hurt us." He defends those who take it as a sort of moral obligation to enjoy life, to partake exuberantly in the pleasures of our God-given bodies. "Don't people realize," Mr. Shaw quotes a sociologist friend, "every scientific study shows that the single best thing you can do for your health is have fun?"
But Mr. Shaw himself is no hedonist. Systematically, he deplores the excesses of the 60's and approves the new morality, up to the point where it crosses over into an anhedonic intolerance. One may wonder what gives Mr. Shaw the authority he exercises so confidently to set the margin between extremes, the limits of what is permissible pleasure and responsible behavior. He himself attributes his moderate view to Jewish culture. Although not a religious Jew, he aspires to embody Judaism's balance, its "stern discipline of moral restraints," its avoidance of "excessive prudery or asceticism." In its secular form, it is the morality of connoisseurship. In this highly personal account, Mr. Shaw tells us that he himself has only a few pleasures: food, wine, monogamy and an occasional cigar. But he surrounds each of them with a vast, meticulous economy of pleasure and a collector's attention to tiny detail. Under his pen, the details often acquire extravagantly refined proportions in discussions, say, of his beloved panatelas or the charms of his second wife.
Neither prudish nor ascetic, he has an immense, romantic enthusiasm for these things -- but only for these; hardly any other sort of pleasure interests him. His indifference seems at times smug and barely credible, at times perverse and a little alarming. Except for wine, he doesn't drink, not Scotch, not bourbon, beer or brandy; he's been drunk only once. He loves a good cigar, but wishes cigarette smoking would drop to zero. He doesn't drink coffee. He tried pot and didn't like it. He doesn't like skiing, surfing, gambling, golf, bowling, gardening, roller coasters, horror movies, opera, ballet, jazz, science fiction, risky sports or violence on television. He doesn't approve of adultery or fornication; he's had his orgies, but prefers sex with connection. He's personally disgusted by some pornography, and doesn't find the Dallas Cowboys cheerleaders sexy.
Unless a pleasure has become the object of connoisseurship, Mr. Shaw isn't interested; he enjoys only when he places between himself and the focus of his desire the little distance of knowing appreciation. It is as if he took all his pleasure under glass, under the injunction of a prescribed ceremony accompanied by the grateful blessings the connoisseur mutters before and after indulging his appetite. Mr. Shaw's obsessive moderation, his relentless taste for good taste, is no chopped liver. But it misses out on both the sublime hysteria of abstinence, celibacy and self-abnegation, and the pagan perversity of chaotic pleasures -- sudden, uncontrollable, disruptive -- that are nasty, down and dirty.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1455 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/'Cuomo Tax' Repeal;
Developers Praise End of Property-Transfer Surtax

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
MORE deals are going to be done and New York will again be an attractive place to invest capital, real estate professionals say, as a result of the recent repeal of the 10 percent surtax on capital gains on property transfers of over $1 million. The repeal came as part of the state's most recent budget act, which was signed by Gov. George E. Pataki on July 13.
The levy, known almost universally as the "Cuomo tax," was imposed by former Gov. MarioCuomo and the Legislature in 1983 at a time when the real estate market was hot and seemed like a good source of funds to balance a budget. During the good times it brought in more money than expected, making it harder for state officials to relinquish, although revenues have dropped sharply in recent years. 
 But since then the market has gone through a deep slump, one that those active in it say was aggravated by the tax, which was unique to New York State.
"It was a disaster, because it discouraged transactions," said William Lie Zeckendorf, the president of Zeckendorf Realty. "Transactions are important to a healthy real estate market because new buyers invest in properties. And the tax discouraged outside investors by telling them they had to pay a 10 percent exit tax."
Jerry I. Speyer, the president of Tishman Speyer Properties, which recently took over management of Rockefeller Center, said he believed "that from the first day this tax was discussed, it had a negative impact on commercial real estate."
"It made people think twice about deals," he said, "and they did not get done."
Mr. Speyer said that the tax did not affect his organization, because it sold no property in New York while the tax was in effect. Instead, he said, his objection was that the tax drained capital from the industry by reducing profits.
Mr. Cuomo did not respond to a request for comment on the tax and its effects.
With the repeal, many in the real estate business expect sales to increase, and for the city to be more attractive in general to outside investors. Although the tax applied statewide, most of the funds raised came from the city.
"The number of transactions will increase, no doubt about it," said Bruce Mosler, president of the Galbreath Company. "Better yet, it improves New York's competitive position with other cities. Now it looks like a lot better place to park capital."
Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, said the board had commissioned a study by the WEFA Group, an economic forecasting company, "that predicts an increase of 8.5 percent in activity in the industry without the tax."
"I personally think it will be more," Mr. Spinola said. "There are a lot of properties ready to go to market."
INDUSTRY participants said that in addition to discouraging transactions, the tax distorted the economics of the industry as the deals that did happen were structured to avoid its effects. Rather than making an outright sale, owners would take their profits out of a project by loading their properties with debt.
"You had instances where there were owners who would have loved to have sold, but could not because of the tax consequences," said Darcy Stacom, a senior director at Cushman and Wakefield. "Instead they cashed out by refinancing and putting big mortgages on their buildings."
But that just postponed the problem without solving it. If a long-held property that was purchased for $10 million many years ago rose to a value of $100 million in the mid-1980's, an owner could have probably got a mortgage for $80 million, real estate executives said. If it declined to $80 million and was sold, the owner would have no cash after paying the mortgage. Although the owner would have no cash from this transaction, the state would still calculate the gain as $70 million, and assess a $7 million tax.
The problem was particularly acute for family companies that own property for long periods of time and might be faced with issues of estate planning and other issues related to the operation of closely-held companies, even though a substantial part of the supposed increase in value was the result of inflation. Now that the tax has been repealed, industry officials said they expect some long-held properties, possibly including some controlled by the ailing Harry Helmsley, to come on to the market.
Loading up with debt was all right during the boom days of the 1980's, but it made it hard to meet mortgage payments when the crash came in 1990 and 1991 and rental rates tumbled. "Most of the transactions during that period were foreclosures," said Richard B. Baxter, a senior managing director at the Edward S. Gordon Company. "But you still had to file with the state and everything was delayed 30 to 40 days as the state did the processing."
Although the $1 million threshold for the tax was intended to exempt personal housing, sometimes it got in the way there too, brokers say. "Say you own a town house worth $1.075 million," said Howard Dolch, a broker at the Lansco Corporation. "If you pay 10 percent, you net $967,500. That's why you saw a lot of small buildings sold for $999,999. It was better than $1.1 million."
Similarly, the closing on a piece of property on Eighth Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets, now the site of a parking lot, was delayed until it became clear that exemption from the tax would be effective as of June 15. "They closed on July 11, the bill was signed on July 13 and the seller saved the Cuomo tax," said Mr. Baxter.
The 35,000-square-foot property was sold by Lennar NE Partners of Atlanta to Jack Resnick & Sons for $17 million. The Resnick organization plans to build a residential structure on the site.
The tax also had the probably unintended effect of greatly complicating corporate transfers of control where real estate was a major asset. "When you did a takeover, you had to go through a company and value every property to file the Cuomo tax," said Andrew J. Weiner, head of the East Coast real estate practice of the law firm Morrison & Foerster.
"It was a real headache in M&A and LBO circles," he said, referring to mergers and acquisitions and leveraged buyouts. "It meant that property in New York was less valuable than property located elsewhere, and we believe it had a negative impact on corporate siting decisions."
During the boom days the tax was a real money raiser for the state, with peak revenues of $792 million in the 1987 fiscal year. But as boom turned into bust and deals were put together to avoid the tax, revenues declined.
Mr. Spinola of the Real Estate Board said the WEFA study showed that by suppressing purchases and sales the tax was actually raising less money than it appeared. The state's projections, he said, were for revenue of $80 million from the tax this year. "But," he said, "if you have an increase in activity of 8.5 percent, the loss to the state is only $17 million because other types of revenues are generated. Meanwhile, New York City gets $200 million in new revenues from transfer taxes and other things related to growth."
If developers and brokers were unhappy with the tax, the manner in which it was calculated and collected drove them to fury. "It never was a 10 percent tax, it was closer to 30 percent," Mr. Zeckendorf said. "The calculations were arbitrary and you could spend months in audits."
UNDER the law, builders and converters were not allowed to deduct the soft, but very real, costs of development. These include interest on site acquisition loans, marketing and advertising expenses, brokerage commissions for leasing, the cost of carrying unsold space after construction and tenant relocation costs.
"You could lose money on a property and still end up owing tax," said Steven H. Shepsman, managing partner of E&Y Kenneth Leventhal Real Estate Group. "You could run huge losses for years, but if you sold for more than you paid it counted as a gain. It was an ill-conceived idea made worse by regulations that were not well thought out."
A big part of the problem, Mr. Spinola said, "was that the definition of a gain was always in dispute." And, as the level of transactions dropped off, the state began to rigorously audit projects in search of undisclosed gains.
"Of the $80 million in projected revenue, 25 percent of that was to have come from audits of projects that have already closed," Mr. Spinola said. "Even now there will probably be more audits."
"That tax had hefty fines and penalties, and the state was actually budgeting the fine and penalties they expected to collect," Mr. Weiner said. But Mr. Zeckendorf thinks it was a futile effort. "By the end, it looks as if they were spending more on audit than they were collecting," he said.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 9; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 394 words

HEADLINE: ARTS FESTIVALS;
A Failed Effort? Says Who?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 As one who is active in support of Lincoln Center, its constituent organizations and their activities, and as chairman emeritus of Lincoln Center, I'm always delighted with favorable references to what Lincoln Center does and hopes to do. Nancy Malitz's article "Trying to Reinvent Summer in the City" [July 14] gives good reasons for what many of us hope and expect: a worthwhile and successful Lincoln Center Festival '96.
But regrettably Ms. Malitz refers to citywide festivals in 1988 and 1991 under the auspices of the New York International Festival of the Arts as a "failed effort." 
 Says who? A former employee of the New York International Festival of the Arts who did not serve in any capacity in the 1988 festival, made no constructive contributions to the 1991 festival and left long before final programs were in place?
The facts are these.
The International Festival of the Arts was designed to promote the city's pre-eminence and strengths as a center for the arts, to stimulate good will among participating countries and to bolster the economy of the city.
The two festivals featured some 500 events, with more than 6,000 performers at more than 60 locations in all 5 boroughs. Many of the events were free, and the festival provided 15,000 free or subsidized tickets to students, teachers, older people and underprivileged children.
Attendance exceeded 750,000 people, a third of them visitors to the city. These programs pumped more than $200 million into the city's economy and provided some $10 million in local taxes. More than 100 works were either performed for the first time in New York or commissioned by the festival.
Festival offerings received many favorable reviews worldwide (including those of New York Times critics) as well as some ecstatic ones. Naturally, there were criticisms, too, from The Times and others.
Were there some failures among the programs offered? Of course. What organization has only successes?
Did the International Festival of the Arts constitute a failed effort? Of course not. It accomplished all of its major goals and did so without public funds and without deficits.
We welcome constructive criticism. Unfounded allegations should have no place.
 
MARTIN SEGAL
New York
 
The writer was the chairman of the New York International Festival of the Arts.

HEADLINE: Q. & A.

 BODY:

Problems About a Terrace
 
Q I live in a penthouse apartment in a rental building in the West Village. The apartment has a 200-square-foot terrace that runs along the front of it. It is one of the best features of the apartment. For the last three months I have had limited use of my terrace because the rental company is redoing the roof of the building and the terraces of all the penthouse apartments. All my patio furniture has been removed and I have not been able to plant a flower garden as I have in past years. Do I have the right to the return of any of my rent due to loss of use? . . . Kevin McCarthy, Manhattan.
 
 A Peter Schwartz, a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in landlord-tenant matters, said that the answer depends on whether the inability to use the terrace amounts to a decrease in services or a breach of the warranty of habitability on the part of the landlord. 
 If the apartment is rent-regulated, Mr. Schwartz said, the tenant may have a claim for a rent reduction as the result of a decrease in services. To make such a claim, he said, the tenant would have to file a complaint with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. The division would then inspect the property, notify the landlord of its findings and give him an opportunity to respond.
Under the circumstances, Mr. Schwartz said, it is possible that the agency could determine that the situation is only temporary or the result of a necessity to make other repairs and would not warrant a rent reduction.
If the apartment is not rent-regulated, Mr. Schwartz said, the tenant would have to file a claim in Housing Court based upon a breach of the warranty of habitability. The claim, if successful, could result in a rent reduction.
"But if the owner is making capital improvements or conducting preventive maintenance," Mr. Schwartz said, "it would appear that the warranty of habitability is not being breached."
 
Security Issues In a Co-op
 
Q I recently moved into a four-unit co-op in Brooklyn. My upstairs neighbor on the top floor has no security gates or bars on her windows, making entry into the building possible from the roof. I've been told that there has been an intruder in the past and that my neighbor refuses to cooperate and get some kind of security device installed. Do we have any legal recourse or regulations we can utilize to press this issue? . . . Geri Ness, Brooklyn.
 
 A "The writer does not state if she is the owner of the apartment or a rental subtenant," said Sherwin Belkin, a Manhattan real estate lawyer.
If she is a subtenant, Mr. Belkin said, her landlord is the owner of the apartment and the terms of the tenancy would be spelled out in the rental lease.
"But I doubt that the unit-owner would make any representations about or warranties against events concerning other units," he said. "So I doubt that there would be a truly viable remedy."
On the other hand, Mr. Belkin said, if the letter writer owns the apartment, there may be provisions in the proprietary lease that mandate the installation of such security devices. If that is the case, he said, she should ask the board to require the upstairs unit owner to comply with the terms of the proprietary lease.
If such a provision is not in the lease, he said, the letter writer could ask the board to amend the bylaws or establish a requirement for the installation of security devices for the benefit of all shareholders.
The co-op board does not, however, have unfettered discretion in such matters.
Mr. Belkin said he believed that a co-op board cannot require "such Draconian steps as would destroy the value or enjoyment of the top floor unit that would be directly affected."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Developer Catches Golf-Housing Trend on Upswing

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
AFTER six years of planning and review, mostly involving environmental concerns, a 520-acre residential development with a golf course is beginning to rise in the Atlantic County township of Egg Harbor, 25 minutes from Atlantic City.
Now that 124 acres in the southern corner of the site, including 60 acres of wetlands, have been protected, Max Gurwicz & Son of Northfield is poised to start work on the first 133 of 246 one-family detached homes that will frame an 18-hole golf course and overlook a dozen manmade ponds. 
 The houses, which will be built only after they are sold, will sit on 15,000- to 27,000-square-foot lots, have 1,850 to 3,300 square feet of space and range in price from $195,000 to $350,000. Since sales opened in May, 19 homes have been sold.
All of the land improvements for the first phase are also in place, as is the course, which is to open to the public by the end of the summer. Construction is under way on an 18,000-square-foot clubhouse that is scheduled for completion next spring.
The site of the $93 million project, Harbor Pines Golf Club & Estates, was once mostly woodlands. It lies at the intersection of Ocean Heights Avenue (Route 559) and Steelmanville Road near Exit 30 of the Garden State Parkway.
It will be built in two phases over eight years, said H. Edward Gurwicz, president of the development firm, long active in South Jersey. Harbor Pines is its first golf-housing project.
The company secured an $8 million loan from Collective Federal Bank in Egg Harbor Township to prepare the site for development, build the course and start the housing. The rest of the project will be financed through the revenue generated from the sale of the houses and club memberships.
Harbor Pines is proceeding at a time when golf-housing projects have rebounded from their recessionary slump. The reason, say industry experts, is the state's slowly improving housing market and the steady growth in the sport.
According to the National Golf Foundation in Jupiter, Fla., of the 468 courses that opened or were under way in 1995, 147 -- or 31 percent -- have housing. While that percentage is lower than the 1989 peak when 50 percent of the courses built were tied to housing, the actual number of residential golf projects is slightly higher, indicating renewed developer interest.
In New Jersey, of the 11 courses opened or under way as of 1995, six have or will have housing. Ten more projects are planned.
Challenges persist, including the high cost and scarcity of suitable land, along with the huge expense associated with building the course. The use of pesticides at golf courses also remains a concern, but industry experts say development techniques have advanced and that chemicals applied properly will not hurt the environment.
DEVELOPERS consider the courses an amenity that will preserve open space and increase sales and land values. A 20 to 30 percent price increase can be expected for prime course-side homes over those without, said Gene Krekorian, senior vice president at Economics Research Associates, a real estate consulting firm in Los Angeles.
The trend in the 90's, he added, is toward building public instead of private courses, and golf clubs instead of country clubs. This way golf can stand on its own as a business and be less reliant on the housing, he said.
That is the approach at Harbor Pines. Mr. Gurwicz said he stayed the course through the long approval process because he felt "homes abutting golf courses is a lasting trend." It also is an opportunity to offer a housing option not now available in the township, he said, noting that the project was being marketed to move-up buyers, including empty-nesters.
Cheryl and Ralph DeMucy are buying a home on the 10th fairway overlooking a lake. Unlike most people who live on golf courses, the couple -- he is 53 and a consultant for a mortgage company, she is 46 and a homemaker -- play golf.
"This gives us what we have been looking for -- land, water and golf," said Mrs. DeMucy. "It's also a beautiful place to live and we feel the home will hold its value and increase."
Such projects also complement an initiative begun a year ago by the private Greater Atlantic City Golf Association.
Its aim is to promote Atlantic and Cape May Counties as golf travel destinations, in an area with many beaches and the attractions of Atlantic City close at hand.
Seven of the 12 casino hotels are being expanded, adding 3,000 rooms to the existing 9,500 and six more with some 9,000 additional rooms are planned.
In March the association -- which comprises nine courses, including Harbor Pines; 29 hotels and 22 allied businesses -- began to market golf travel packages via a computer network and automated software system. So far 4,130 packages have been booked, said Marcella Corti, its executive director.
"In the past golf travelers were hopscotching over us," Ms. Corti said.
A similar effort is under way in Sussex County. The nonprofit Sussex Golf Preserve Foundation hopes to promote private investment in open space and economic growth through the development of 15 to 20 golf courses by the year 2007. Half will be tied to housing, generating 1,500 residences.
Two courses are open, four are in the approval process and eight more are planned, said Jack Kurlander, one of the founders of the golf foundation three years ago. He is also a partner in the Black Bear Golf Club, in Franklin, one of the new courses.
Max Gurwicz & Son assembled the 520-acre site for Harbor Pines over the last 20 years but did not develop it because the area was not served by a public sewage system. That changed in the late 80's when both the township and county sewer authorities sought to bring sewer lines through the Harbor Pines site to mitigate septic problems at an adjacent housing community.
Still, progress was slow. Because the tract is in an environmentally sensitive coastal zone, governed by state regulations, its development required extra layers of review.
THE discovery of wetlands on the site, which is zoned for 30,000-square-foot lots, was another issue. State law prohibits wetlands from being developed and establishes buffers around them, which meant preserving the 124 acres and downscaling the project from the 330 homes allowed. By negotiating a modification to the zoning to permit the smaller lots, the developer minimized the loss of homes to 84.
"It is a decent trade-off for the benefit the township got," said Randall E. Scheule, its director of planning and development.
To soothe concerns over the environmental issues of golf courses, Mr. Scheule said, the developer agreed to the township's request to adhere to more strigent management guidelines. If followed, he said, "there should be no problems." The state also monitors the impact on the groundwater.
He said the project also brings diversity to the township's housing stock. Entry-level homes predominate in Egg Harbor, where population grew by 6,163 to 25,717 from 1980 to 1994. Some 200 to 250 housing permits are issued a year, he added.
The homes at Harbor Pines, designed by the Johnson Group, of Margate, will have two to four bedrooms and two-car garages. Six models are available, which buyers can customize. They can also come up with their own designs.
Up to 70 homes will also be custom built on prime lots, with up to $50,000 premiums, some possibly on combined lots, said Robert A Johnson, principal of the architectural firm. He said design guidelines had been set up by an architectural review committee, including the developer.
Residents have the option of joining the golf club. Memberships, range from $300 to $6,000 depending on length and family size. Daily fees are $45 to $85.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Rendering of homes at Harbor Pines Golf Club & Estates in Egg Harbor (left); golfer tees off near 18,000-square-foot clubhouse now under construction. (Grant B. Melvin Jr.) (Allen Oliver for The New York Times)
