SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 5; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 3008 words

HEADLINE: Top-End Condos Start With the Finish;
The Upper Level ... And the Middle of the Road

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
IN the thick sales brochure for 353 Central Park West, a small and elegant new condominium at 95th Street, the developer lists 10 great qualities of his full-floor apartments, which sell for a fraction under $2 million each.
A decade ago, any developer worth his blueprints was bragging of beautiful views or great concierge service or a "swinging" address -- and, according to sales agents and the developers themselves, wasn't saying much about the interior fittings. But now, the developer of 353 Central Park West chooses to boast instead of a "marble entry gallery," "high ceilings in every room," "prewar crown moldings," a "mahogany paneled library" and "rosewood floors set in herringbone patterns." 
 Another new condominium, the Knickerbocker, at 308 East 72d Street, instructs the reader of its whimsical sales brochure to "Think of double sinks. Separate shower and bath. Smashing glass partitions. A phone! 3-paneled mirrored medicines, with 9 inches between countertops and cabinets. And plenty of drawers for your necessities."
In the mid-90's, developers say they are building far better, more luxurious, more brand-name-studded apartments than they have ever built before.
These developers, and the real estate agents who sell their apartments, are increasingly touting the small things, the things that, beyond the number of bedrooms, today's buyers are thought to crave.
The developers who are now building the city's luxury condominiums -- there are few other condominiums being built -- say they must spend more money than ever on interior finishes to keep up with the marketplace.
For William Lie Zeckendorf, who with his partner, Makoto Okuyama of Sumitomo Real Estate, developed Millennium Tower on West 67th Street, spending money on fancy finishes was a hard-fought decision. "The deal was committed to before the recession," he said. "We talked about putting in the standard cookie-cutter finishes that would have cost $4.50 a square foot. But in the end, we thought the situation was so scary that we decided to be one of the top 10 buildings in the city for finishes and we spent another $3 a square foot."
With an overheated rental market and a concurrent desire for bigger, more expensive condominium apartments, the developers of condominiums and rental buildings seem vehemently competitive in pointing out the width of their bedroom doors, the class of their marble ("This isn't just any beige marble," said Donald Trump, the developer), the thickness of their herringbone parquet and the joints -- or lack thereof -- in their granite countertops.
Every detail -- no matter how minuscule -- is duly pointed out to the prospective buyer or visitor. "Remember the old security chain?" said Robert Skolnick, vice president of sales for the Knickerbocker, with a disdainful snicker. "We prefer the fitted brass hasp; it doesn't swing loose and damage our wall finishes."
The developers of the condominiums billed as "luxury" or "superluxury" -- where an average two-bedroom price ranges from $600,000 to $2 million -- appear to believe, at least as judged by their comments, that each one is the only one to offer the so-called luxury finishes.
Erden Arkan, president of Kiska Development, which built 353 Central Park West: "I visited other developments and I saw many things that are different: We have solid-core doors, for instance."
Mr. Trump, discussing his new condominium at Columbus Circle: "With Trump International Tower, I'm offering top-of-the-line finishes, things that nobody else is offering -- things like solid-core doors."
William Lie Zeckendorf, touring his Millennium Towers condo on West 67th Street: "You know, we have solid-core doors; other developers don't do that."
In fact, every luxury developer -- at least in buildings built in the last few years -- seems to offer solid-core doors, even Daniel Brodsky, the developer respected as a master of the middle-income rental apartment.
Shown a typed list given a reporter by one of the developers interviewed, a list that purportedly compared details in luxury buildings with those in lesser cost buildings, Mr. Brodsky looked puzzled.
"What are they talking about?" he said. "I use solid-core doors," he said, talking about West End Towers, his sold-out new rental buildings at West End Avenue between 61st and 63d Streets.
AT West End Towers, a two-bedroom apartment rents for $2,650 a month, compared to between $4,000 and $5,700 for a two-bedroom apartment in the luxury rental just going up at the Strathmore at 84th Street and First Avenue, developed by the Related Group -- a building designed by Costas Kondylis that, of course, will have solid-core doors, along with a plethora of elegant carpets and floors and "upscale" appliances.
Mr. Brodsky is the first to agree that the level of finish, of details, in his rental apartments is a far cry from the finishes in the much-higher-priced residential units going up around town.
But the difference is "a conscious decision," said Mr. Brodsky, made in order to rent his apartments for much less money.
It is in the kitchen and bathroom at West End Towers that the difference becomes most clear.
The biggest difference is the pre-molded "granite look" laminate that blankets the countertops in the less-expensive rental apartments and juts out into the living room, not quite fitting against the wall without a large blob of caulk. In contrast with their marble-encrusted cousins, the bathrooms at West End Towers are windowless, with a tasteful mix of black and white ceramic tile instead of marble, a low enameled steel tub and basic white fixtures.
A quick price comparison illustrates the point: At a wholesale plumbing supply house in lower Manhattan, steel tubs sell for $ 108.50; a white Kohler cast iron steeping tub similar to one used at the Knickerbocker sells for $471.75. A plain white toilet sells for $85.50; a one-piece beige Kohler, similar to those at Trump International, sells for $334.13. One square foot of black and white tile mosaic sells for a little over $2; the most expensive 1/4-inch marble tile at a wholesale marble distributor may run as high as $10 a square foot. Developers, of course, pay less than wholesale prices on many items because of volume .
The rather perfunctory kitchens and bathrooms at West End Towers look very much like those in the "luxury" condominiums that went up on Manhattan's East Side in the 80's.
In fact, many agents point to the early Trump luxury towers as exemplifying the philosophy of architectural finishes in the 80's: Don't bother spending too much on details, because rich people are just going to have their decorators come in and rip it all out anyway.
And Mr. Trump, who has changed his strategy and freely concedes he has upgraded his finishes to satisfy the millionaire apartment buyer of the 90's, says he is still annoyed that decorators rip out his details to put in their own.
His newest project, Trump International Hotel and Tower, at One Central Park West -- his inside-out gutting of the old Gulf and Western Building -- now comes with higher quality kitchen cabinets and marble bathrooms than he has ever used before.
"They'll take the highest quality bathrooms and rip them out anyway," he said. "All because their decorators -- who are making a lot more than 10 percent of the cost of the materials, I can tell you -- tell them they don't want a beige bathroom; they want a black bathroom.
"Well, black bathrooms are magnificent, but you wouldn't build a building with all black bathrooms," Mr. Trump said.
While Mr. Trump said he was installing white lacquered kitchen cabinets manufactured by a Canadian firm for Trump International, he added, "You have to have flexibility, you have to have cabinets you can take off the wall without destroying the wall."
At the earlier Trump Tower, the developer said, "I did something different. I put in good cabinets that were easily removable, very practical cabinets but they were not of such high quality" as at Trump International Tower.
That choice was "both good and bad," he said. "It was good because the primary thing was easy removal; the bad thing was that I never liked the cabinets at Trump Tower.
"You hate to spend thousands of dollars, with 48 coats of lacquer, just to see a designer make a fee by ripping them out," he continued. "It's such a waste."
NEVERTHELESS, Mr. Trump said, he was forced to spend $10,000 to $25,000 more per kitchen at Trump International "because the market demands it now."
It is difficult to trace exactly when developers started stressing better kitchen cabinets and countertops -- and higher ceilings and better tubs -- but it may have started with Jack Heller and his partner, Duncan Macaulay, and their project at 1049 Fifth Avenue, a complete rebuild of the old Adams Hotel on 86th Street, right off Fifth Avenue.
In 1992, at the height of the real estate recession, Heller-Macaulay Equities unveiled a series of then-wildly expensive apartments with floors of rosewood parquet with ebony borders and separate maid's rooms for sale on the lower floors. It was a new concept -- and it has taken a while to sell out; there is still one sponsor apartment left. But Rush Limbaugh bought an apartment there -- along with one of the maid's rooms, which he turned into a 260-square-foot exercise room. And the scramble for luxury was on.
Mr. Macaulay said that although certain developers -- he discreetly did not name any -- plan their kitchens to be ripped out, he and Mr. Heller have had different results.
"Of the 44 apartments we've sold -- for $2 million and $3 million -- we don't know of one where they ripped out the kitchens and bath," the developer said. "They've added lots of moldings, and bookcases and bits and pieces, but there's been only one major makeover -- and they left the kitchens and baths."
WHILE 1049 was planned with excellent finishes from the start of construction, another condominium, the Europa, at 22 West 66th Street, originally was designed with cheaper details. Caught in the real estate recession of the early 90's, construction came to a halt. By the time the apartments were ready to be sold 14 months ago, the whole marketing strategy had changed.
The Europa was conceived in the mid-80's as a high-rise tower with lovely views. The recession hit, and the Europa was foreclosed upon and put up for sale. It was sold to Sterling Realty, a company composed primarily of Italian and Swiss investors, according to Joseph Pell Lombardi, the architect who was hired to transform it.
There was only bare concrete; there were no wooden floors. There were some walls, but only a stack of doors -- the much-maligned hollow-core doors -- leaning against the walls. There was the plan: for two apartments on each floor.
So the investors switched to one apartment per floor, and substantially upgraded the way the raw apartments were to be finished. "They went with classic prewar interiors," Mr. Lombardi said. "The original finishes had been planned at such a low level because that was all the mid-80's had demanded."
What had been mapped as two back-to-back kitchens in the two apartments were merged into one. Cherrywood kitchen cabinets were ordered. Granite -- the countertop material that seems to be mandatory now -- was laid on the counters; in this case, 3/4 inches thick with an applied bullnose, or curved strip, which makes the countertop look as if it is the thickness of the bullnose: an inch and a half. A SubZero refrigerator (contractors' price: $3,400) was installed, along with a top-of-the-line General Electric oven.
"It's these few things that people look at when they look at apartments now," Mr. Lombardi said. "A SubZero stands out."
So do the solid oak strip floors with the dark walnut borders, the 8-inch baseboards and the 3-inch cornice moldings (some prewar buildings have even higher cornice moldings). The hollow-core doors were thrown away, and full 2-inch solid paneled doors were hung, punctuated with Baldwin brass levers. A reddish-orange 6-inch-square Sienna marble alternates with white marble in a striking checkerboard design in one of the bathrooms. There is a separate marble-lined shower enclosure, a massive white pedestal sink and brick-shaped marble slabs on the walls.
These finishes, the architect said, may cost $50,000 more per apartment, "but they're worth hundreds of thousands more; you've got to have a sense of the market."
The 26 full-floor apartments at the Europa went on sale 14 months ago, with prices ranging from $815,000 to $2.6 million. Last week, there were only two left.
The market is very different in TriBeCa and SoHo, where the approach to finishes couldn't be more different.
"With loft conversions, you're furnishing clean white space," said Mr. Lombardi, who is involved in several conversions at the moment, including one at 55 Liberty Street, a 1909 Gothic revival skyscraper in downtown Manhattan. "To get the certificate of occupancy you put in a basic bathroom with the most inexpensive hexagonal tiles; you put in a steel tub and not much of a vanity."
Even though the huge new lofts might sell for over $1 million each, many do not even come with a kitchen, he said. "You just need an affidavit that the kitchen will be installed at a later date."
DOWNTOWN, Mr. Lombardi has found that a finished kitchen actually inhibits sales. "It's like buying some land in the country, in a development where everybody has to have the same builder's houses, maybe with slight variations," he said. "That wouldn't be the downtown buyer's cup of tea."
But uptown, developers say, the buyer wants -- and compares -- all the finishes, seeking what can only be defined as a prewar English look, which Mr. Skolnick, at the Knickerbocker, defines as "old world charm."
In the Knickerbocker's brochure, the sections on bathrooms ends: "I say. Be a good sort, Jeeves, and run me a bloody bath!"
To Mr. Macaulay, of Heller-Macaulay, developers of 1049 Fifth, the rush toward the English upper-class is amusing.
"New York is the ultimate city of new money, and new money wants nothing more than to look like old money, and the English aristocracy is perfect," he said. "So they dress in Ralph Lauren, they live in buildings called the Richmond and the Fairfax and they stare at their crown moldings -- and they feel good about themselves."
To Mr. Skolnick, such a sense of well-being is better induced through a series of elaborate and well-thought-out details -- but not necessarily the most expensive of everything. "You don't need a SubZero to score a 10," he said.
Passing through the spacious corridors, Mr. Skolnick pointed out one detail not seen in other new apartments: plinth blocks, the large wooden squares at the bottom of the door moldings, "so the porter didn't scrape them up when vacuuming," he explained. On the entrance doors, there are heavy round door knockers and a brass knob set with the number of the apartment etched into it.
At the Knickerbocker, the floors are a half-inch thick -- some building boast of three-quarter-inch floors -- but they are made of pecan, and set in a basketweave pattern, like many prewars. And, like many of the new buildings, there are 9-foot ceilings -- and 8-foot doors, which, because they are not the standard 6 feet, 6 inches, are easily double the price. (A 6-foot, 6-inch hollow-core door costs about $30, Mr. Skolnick said, while his taller doors cost $100 apiece if bought in quantity.)
THE 8-foot doors require four hinges, versus three for the shorter ones. "These taller solid doors weigh 78 pounds," said Mr. Skolnick, reciting the statistic from memory. "They feel like a bank vault -- it's kind of a subliminal thing."
There are many other little touches: the type of white marble ("statuary white -- 30 percent more than the ordinary white, which is really kind of gray"), the size of the marble tiles on the wall (12 by 18 inches, because it feels richer) and chrome fixtures rather than "old hat" brass.
The Knickerbocker, even though it is thought by brokers to be in a location that is slightly "off" -- 72d Street Street at Second Avenue -- seems to be an invigorating success. After only nine weeks of sales, 46 of the 74 apartments -- more than 60 percent -- have been sold.
To the developers, the little touches really make a difference to buyers, although the builders point out that without a good layout and a good location, apartments in today's picky market will be harder to sell.
But for Mr. Arkan of Kiska Development, who chose to build $2 million apartments at the corner of 95th Street and Central Park West, these details appear to be key to selling in what is normally considered another "off" location. That may be why his brochure emphasizes the finishes to an unusual degree, even for today's finish-conscious consumers.
To real estate brokers, to whom goes the task of selling these apartments, finishes assume differing levels of importance; agents disagree among themselves on the importance of the door heights (but all agree the doors must be thick and solid), the thickness of countertops (although all agree they must be granite) and whether the walls should be skim-coated with plaster or just taped with sheetrock tape and painted.
But they agree that the current competition over finishes is a reaction to the cookie-cutter condo apartments of the 80's.
"Developers are finding now that quality sells," said Peter Marra, president of William B. May Real Estate. "They only want jewelry from Tiffany and luxury cars.
"You want to live in a place that says you've made it and that seems to boil down to things like doorknobs," Mr. Marra said. "If you're spending $1 million on an apartment versus $100,000, you don't want 7-foot ceilings with hollow-core doors."
But Mr. Marra questioned whether "high ceilings and moldings and granite really improve the quality of your life."
"I mean, in the end, it's just fluff," he said. "Isn't it?"

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Whip Inflation Now? Lessons From the 70's

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
PRICES of commodities like oil, natural gas, wheat and corn have been rising this year; the question is whether the pricing pressures are merely a blip or signs of a longer-term inflationary trend.
At CDA/Wiesenberger, a fund information and tracking firm in Rockville, Md., analysts say evidence is mounting that many of the increases are, in fact, driven by demand and are not simply results of a one-time phenomenon like the weather. 
 If inflation is a concern, a look at recent history may provide clues about the best investments for inflationary times. Since sufficient mutual fund data became available in 1972, the worst such period was 1977 through 1980, when the Consumer Price Index rose an average of 10.34 percent a year. A look at the returns for each fund category then tracked by CDA/Wiesenberger shows an interesting correlation between fund performance in the late 70's and this year, the analysts said.
The most profitable funds to own then were those in gold and other precious metals, with average gains of nearly 58 percent a year. Similarly, those funds appear at the top of this year's list, with gains of 31.3 percent through May. In fact, the top 10 categories through May are the same as those in 1977 through 1980 (excluding two categories with insufficient data in the earlier years).
If you think inflation lies in wait, these numbers can provide a road map, the analysts said. Their conclusions: Stay out of income-dependent investments like bond and utility funds. Consider an equity-heavy portfolio with funds in the categories of energy and natural resources, small-company growth, technology and international issues. Stout-hearted souls might make a small allocation to gold and precious metals.

A Change in Pricing
One price for everyone. That's how Twentieth Century has always done business. Investors paid no sales charges when they bought shares, and they paid an annual flat rate to the company for managing their funds -- 1 percent for United States stock funds and 0.45 percent to 0.8 percent for bond funds.
The simplicity of Twentieth Century's pricing structure has stood out in an industry where front- and back-end loads, redemption fees and service fees, to name just a few, have made investment decisions more complex than ever.
But Twentieth Century is now joining the pack, with pricing changes that will take effect in October. The company will create four classes of shares: one for investors who buy directly from Twentieth Century, and others for the institutional market, for sales through financial intermediaries like Charles Schwab & Company and for sales through financial advisers.
Here is how the fees apply to domestic stock funds: Investors who buy directly will pay the same 1 percent as before, while institutional investors will pay less -- 0.8 percent. Shares sold through fund supermarkets will still have a maximum 1 percent sales charge, divided into an annual fee of 0.75 percent plus up to 0.25 percent in service fees. The adviser class will have fees of up to 1.25 percent, which includes an annual fee of 0.75 percent plus service and distribution fees of up to 0.5 percent, meaning that the shares can no longer be advertised as no-load shares.
"We feel that intermediaries provide a service and deserve to be compensated," said David F. Larrabee, vice president for alternate distribution at Twentieth Century. He said that of the company's $50 billion in assets, $18 billion was institutional money with about $8 billion or $9 billion coming through financial supermarkets, financial advisers, insurers and the like.
The new pricing is "a rational and fair response to market conditions," said Don Phillips, president of Morningstar Inc. But he said such pricing complexities "undermine the idea of funds as a simple product."

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Albany Bill Expands Managed Care in Worker Injuries

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
FOR the thousands of New York State businesses that pay a total of $5 billion for workers' compensation insurance each year, the significance of recently approved legislation revamping the system should be as clear as the numbers on their premium bills: it will help reduce rates by as much as 25 percent, state officials say.
But for the workers who depend on the system to provide medical care for work-related injuries and compensation for lost wages, the impact of the new measure will be less clear, and probably less consequential. It will neither increase their benefits, as the bill's authors once promised, nor cause the dire consequences its critics had predicted. 
 Perhaps most important to workers, the legislation will not impose the major changes that Gov. George E. Pataki had sought and that organized labor had opposed, like caps on benefits and stricter standards for determining disabilities. Though he did not win those initiatives, Mr. Pataki supported the final bill, which passed in the Legislature two weeks ago, and is expected to sign it soon.
The compromise legislation does nip and tuck at the fringes of the 82-year-old system, placing restrictions on certain types of lawsuits, toughening anti-fraud measures and expanding the use of managed care in the diagnosis and treatment of injured workers. But while those alterations will certainly touch some workers, most people using the system will continue to receive treatment and benefits in the same ways as before.
"The average worker who gets hurt on the job is not going to be affected by our legislation," said Assemblywoman Catherine T. Nolan, Democrat of Queens, chairwoman of the Assembly's labor committee. She opposed Mr. Pataki's original proposal.
The way that most workers will experience any changes is through the expansion of managed care. Currently, almost all workers can pick the doctors who will diagnose and treat their injuries. Critics contend that this freedom of choice has led to a pernicious form of "doctor shopping," in which workers move from physician to physician, searching for the one whose diagnosis will provide the most compensation.
The new system makes it easier for companies to use managed care by contracting with a single provider, usually a health maintenance organization, to handle compensation cases. That provider will diagnose and treat the injured workers, using all the standard techniques of managed care to reduce costs.
Critics of the change, mainly labor unions, said managed-care providers, because of their contractual relationships with employers, would be encouraged to skimp on care and overlook the severity of injuries. "Care won't be as good and medical claims will be rejected more often," predicted Arthur Wilcox, director of the public employee department at the state A.F.L.-C.I.O.
But Mr. Pataki argued that expanded use of managed care would simply bring the hide-bound workers' compensation system closer into line with changes occurring throughout the health care industry.
The legislation will also allow injured workers to circumvent the system and negotiate payments directly with insurers. Currently, insurers and workers often fight over an injury claim in cumbersome and time-consuming hearings that can delay benefit checks for months. Allowing workers to negotiate claims directly with insurance companies will speed up payments and reduce litigation, Mr. Pataki's advisers say.
But critics say workers who are not receiving advice from lawyers or a union might be gulled into accepting bad deals, especially if they are poor and in need of quick cash. "The economics of desperation will have a grave impact on people's rights," Mr. Wilcox said.
Though most workers are unlikely to notice many of the changes, there is one group that could be significantly affected by the legislation: the personal-injury lawyers who specialize in so-called third-party lawsuits in workers' compensation cases.
When required to pay damages to injured workers, makers of equipment can file such third-party lawsuits against employers as a way of recovering some of their litigation costs. The companies often claim that the employer misused the equipment or installed it incorrectly. Only New York State allows the suits, but the new legislation would restrict them solely to cases in which workers have suffered "grave injuries," like amputation or blindness. The new restrictions would reduce the cost of third-party suits by about half, state officials say.
The change will not prevent injured workers from suing manufacturers of defective equipment. But trial lawyers and union officials argue that if a manufacturer cannot punish an employer who misuses equipment through third-party lawsuits, workplace safety will be diminished.
Mr. Pataki's aides scoff at such arguments, saying that lawyers, not injured workers, were the major beneficiaries of third-party lawsuits, and that the legislation will not hurt workplace safety or workers' benefits.
Even Ms. Nolan largely agreed with that assessment. "The really seriously injured worker will still be able to get large settlements," she said.

LENGTH: 1203 words

HEADLINE: For a Pessimist, a Vindication of Sorts

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
STEVEN LEUTHOLD did more than just predict the latest stock market rout, he put his money on it.
Mr. Leuthold, an investment strategist with a decidedly bearish point of view and a big institutional following, pulled largely out of equities at the beginning of July. When the market tumbled two weeks later, the Leuthold Asset Allocation fund was only 9 percent invested in stocks and protected by a large cash cushion. 
 So during the unnerving week of July 15 -- which started with the major indexes plummeting and proceeded with stocks seesawing wildly -- the fund gained 0.7 percent as the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 1.15 percent.
It was something of a vindication for Mr. Leuthold, whose well-publicized bearishness during the last two years kept him mostly out of stocks during a bull market run. That, plus a too-heavy reliance on bonds, which performed badly earlier this year, dragged down the fledgling fund's returns. From its inception in November 1995 through July 19, the fund rose 4 percent, compared with 4.64 percent for all asset allocation funds and 8.11 percent for the S.& P., according to Morningstar, the Chicago fund researchers.
"The last couple of weeks feels better," Mr. Leuthold, 58, said in a telephone interview from Bailey Island, Maine, where he has ridden out the market swings in a vacation home equipped with a satellite dish and fax machine.
Mr. Leuthold, who was bullish for many years before turning pessimistic, relaxes by gardening: green beans, onions, beets, cucumbers and varieties of potatoes.
"I can get as much done here as I do in the office, maybe more," he said. "Then I can take a break and dig potatoes."
For his investment strategy, Mr. Leuthold relies on a proprietary trend index to help decide the mix of stocks, bonds and cash in his $32 million fund and for the $100 million in private accounts managed by Leuthold & Anderson in Minneapolis. The index was adjusted in February, with bigger weighting given to mutual fund cash inflows and several momentum measures.
The changes to the index kept it positive on equities, despite what Mr. Leuthold called the "radical overvaluation of the stock market." Still, he was uneasy and bought equity call options on the S.& P. 500, giving him the right to buy the basket of stocks in the index at a specific price by a specific date. That gave him equity exposure but limited the risk. If the market rose, the value of the call would rise, providing profits as if the fund owned the actual stocks. If prices fell, the fund would lose what it paid for the calls, a smaller loss than owning an equivalent amount of stocks.
Mr. Leuthold's trend index flashed red at the end of June, when mutual fund inflows began drying up. At the same time, new issues came to market faster than they could be absorbed.
Mr. Leuthold sold the call options and bought put options on the S.& P. 500. These options let holders sell the S.& P. index at a specific price by a certain date; if the market moves below that price, the put options increase in value. These options had accounted for 0.7 percent of the fund, but because of the market drop, they now account for 2.3 percent.
The puts hedged all but 9 percent of the fund's equity exposure. The remaining equities were all publicly traded real estate investment trusts. Half the fund was stashed in bonds, and the balance in cash. He has made no changes since then.
"We view this as a very dangerous stock market," Mr. Leuthold said, because valuation levels are extremely high, and the support for the market may be ending. Because of his bearishness, his accounts gained only 20 percent last year, much below the S.& P.'s increase of 37.6 percent. This year, he would be happy with gains of 12 to 15 percent, he said.
He called 1996 a repeat of the "great garbage market" of 1968 through 1970, when funds focusing on small stocks plunged 50 to 75 percent in value. With some shares selling for 100 times sales or earnings, "it's hard for me to look at the valuations and think that that's rational investment management."
Even so, he is hedging his bets. "I'm not exactly sure we're at the end and heading into a major bear market," he said. "But we are in a major topping-out phase." He added that the speculative part of the stock market had been broken, but there could be a rally in big, quality stocks.
"The risk is high enough," he said, "that we think it prudent to stay on the sidelines." He noted that if stocks reverted to normal, or median, historic valuation levels, the major market indices would be down more than 35 percent.
Is the fund's strategy suitable for the individual investor?
John Rekenthaler, publisher of Morningstar Mutual Funds, suggested that potential investors "wait and see how the fund does before investing, because it is run by someone without a public track record and it is poorly defined."
"It is just a bet on Steven Leuthold," he said.
To Mr. Leuthold, that is a good bet. Putting your money under the mattress may be one way for a bear to act, but "you still have to make the decision to re-enter the market," he said. He also noted that his fund was not just sitting on cash, but was half invested in bonds.
Mr. Leuthold said he believes he can make as much money in the next 12 months in bonds as in stocks, with much less risk. Of the bond portion of the portfolio, 25 percent is in Treasury bonds maturing in 23 and 25 years.
In his analysis, if inflation fears push yields on the long bond to 8 percent, from about 7 percent today, he would lose about 4 percent when he offsets the bond's lower price against the interest income that it pays. Should worries about inflation ease, however, and bond yields fall to 6 percent, he would gain 30 percent. "So the odds there look better to me than the stock market," he said.
Mr. Leuthold's fund also does not own gold, a typical inflation hedge. Although he said 5 percent of his own portfolio was in physical gold -- what he called an "apocalypse" investment -- the fund has not owned any gold stocks for two or three years, because he thinks they are too expensive.
Unlike many of the so-called contrarian mutual funds, Leuthold Asset Allocation does not short stocks, no matter how dark the managers' view of the market. "If you can run a fund 25 percent net short, that's more risk than we think appropriate for our investors," he said.
Besides, Mr. Leuthold said, "we're not necessarily trying to be contrarian."
"Contrarian means buying things just because they are out of favor," he said. "There are times when the majority is right on the market."
Still, the fund has risks other than that of underperforming if the stock market rises. The bonds can fall in price if interest rates rise. The portfolio's foreign bonds expose it to currency risks. In a worst case, the market could rise, rendering the fund's put contracts worthless, while the individual stocks it owns could fall.
How could this bear morph into a bull?
"Better inflation numbers combined with a resurgence of interest by the public in mutual funds, accompanied by a decline in interest rates, could get us back into a positive mode," Mr. Leuthold said.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 3; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
The Climate Is Colder For Home-Grown Funds

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
CHILL winds are blowing on single-state municipal bond funds, those popular havens from state income tax. And with nearly 700 funds representing 44 states holding $113 billion in assets, the problems may give the shivers to more than a few investors.
The changes -- fewer issues for funds to choose from, for instance, and growing doubts about issuers' willingness to repay their debts -- are making these popular funds more risky. And this may blind-side the typical investor in these funds, whose sights are traditionally trained on just two targets: tax avoidance and high yields. 
 Many muni fund managers play down the new dangers, saying that their strategies and a quiet market will allow them to keep risks low. And, of course, the wisdom of taking these now-higher risks depends on the tax savings received for doing so, and these savings can vary.
While all muni investors avoid paying Federal tax on the bonds' interest, shareholders in single-state muni funds also escape state and local taxes on the interest they earn. That is because single-state funds invest primarily in bonds issued within their home states, where the states and, often, any separate city tax authorities typically treat such at-home earnings as tax-free. But this means that the savings investors realize from single-state funds will hinge on their state and local tax rate.
Nevertheless, many experts sense a growing change in the climate of this important area of investing. Because of stable interest rates and taxpayer resistance to publicly financed projects, for example, state and local governments are issuing fewer tax-free bonds than they did just a few years ago. That gives fund managers fewer securities to choose from.
In 1995, state and local governments sold $156 billion in new long-term bonds, down from $162 billion in 1994, and new bond sales are still dropping. Therefore, managers may be forced to buy bonds they may otherwise have spurned simply because the supply of bonds is so tight.
At the same time, more than half the new bonds are insured these days. Insurance provides protection against default, but at the price of a lower yield on the securities, reflecting the lower risk. Insurers have also begun insuring more bonds at the lower end of the investment-grade spectrum. These trends leave a smaller pool of higher-yield securities -- the kind investors often seek in this income-oriented market.
With a smaller pool of bonds and with "people wanting everything under the sun insured," said James F. Lynch, editor of the Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory newsletter, "in the universe that is left, indeed there are more bonds that are risky than are not."
And despite Orange County, Calif., which jolted the muni market when it defaulted on some bonds 19 months ago, people may still underestimate the dangers of munis.
Specifically, investors may still be too complacent about general obligation muni bonds, which are those backed by the full faith and credit -- and taxing power -- of the issuer. And they may not realize that new risks are arising for buyers of revenue bonds -- which are bonds backed only by the fees or revenues generated by the toll roads, bridges or other projects they finance. These risks stem from exotic new securities like "certificates of participation" and lease-backed bonds, which are proliferating among the more familiar "plain vanilla" revenue bonds.
"This market does not properly evaluate municipal risk," said Joe Mysak, editor of Grant's Municipal Bond Observer.
This point seems proved by Orange County's political decision to file for bankruptcy rather than rile residents by raising taxes to pay general obligation bondholders.
"If you have to rely on politics for the bond repayments, it's kind of iffy," Mr. Mysak said.
While investors may not have learned lessons from the episode -- one reason may be that Orange County bondholders eventually were fully repaid under the bankruptcy's outcome -- other municipalities may have a new perspective: they may now realize that it is acceptable to go bankrupt in such a case. This may deepen the political risks for investors.
Muni investors have also been hurt by a long-term development -- the narrowing gap since the early 1980's between the yields of triple-A rated bonds, the highest-quality investments, and lower quality, single-A issues. Largely because of the smaller supply of lower-quality bonds, the spread is now about one-half of a percentage point, or 50 basis points, according to Delphis Hanover Corporation. But portfolio managers, like Robert A. Dennis at Massachusetts Financial Services, recall that back in 1976, when New York City's credit problems were roiling the market much as Orange County's are now, the spread between the bonds was more than 150 basis points.
A result is that the many muni investors who are seeking higher yields are receiving comparatively less income for their increased risk.
All these developments seem to heighten risk in the muni market. Investors who buy individual bonds should look closely at each issue. Investors in nationwide muni funds should be more vigilant, too, although those funds afford more diversification.
But investors in single-state funds should be the most alert to these market changes because they are especially vulnerable. Like other fund investors, they rarely scrutinize their funds' individual holdings, but unlike investors in national funds they often have less diversification.
Some muni fund managers, however, disagree about these risks. Because muni funds have had net outflows this year, managers have not had to consider buying riskier securities, said Thomas Kenny, director of the municipal bond department at the Franklin Templeton Group of Funds.
Thomas Spalding, vice president and manager of the Nuveen Advisory Corporation, said he was raising yields in Nuveen's muni funds by investing in intermediate and long-term bonds. Although these longer-term issues can be more volatile in price, he has not added to his credit risk, he said.
Managers note that even if a bond issue is troubled, it often represents only a small percentage of a large diversified fund's holdings. Even in other funds, a manager may have bought just a small amount of a such an issue.
Nevertheless, these risks have come home to roost in some funds. The $19 million Riverside Capital Tennessee Municipal fund, for example, was scorched last year after the city of Lewisburg, Tenn., defaulted on $7.1 million in nonrated bonds issued in 1993 to build a golf course. The Riverside fund had invested $550,000, or roughly 3 percent of its portfolio, in the issue.
The fund fell victim to both credit risk -- the danger that the issuer cannot make the payments -- and political risk, the threat that the issuer simply will not pay. The golf course failed to make enough money to pay on the bonds and a local court ruled that Lewisburg's taxpayers did not have to make up the shortfall. The bonds sank in value, and the fund plunged to become the worst-performing Tennessee fund last year.
Luckily for investors, Lewisburg officials eventually agreed to issue new bonds and to compensate the old bondholders. Largely as a result, the fund ranked first among Tennessee funds for the first half of 1996.
Larger funds are not always safe from these dangers, either. The mutual fund giant, Fidelity Investments, ran into trouble when its $1.1 billion Massachusetts Tax-Free fund bought $4.8 million of bonds issued by the Massachusetts Industrial Finance Agency on behalf of Jacob's Pillow, a dance center in Becket, Mass.
The bonds, issued in 1989 and 1991, defaulted last year after Jacob's Pillow missed some interest payments. Here, credit risk was the culprit; the dance center faced cuts in Federal funds and stagnating donations. Fidelity later settled with Jacob's Pillow for $1.25 million.
Given such incidents, some advisers caution against investing solely in a single-state fund. "A single-state fund is the antithesis of what we preach," said Mr. Lynch, the newsletter editor. "We preach diversification."
Such thoughts have led one firm, Sanford C. Bernstein & Company in New York, to offer single-state funds only for two large states: New York and California.
"A bond portfolio is supposed to be safe and if you're saying 'invest to diversify,' in a smaller state you really can't diversify," said Guy Davidson, director of the municipal bond department at Sanford Bernstein. While the Franklin New York Tax-Free Income Fund has 294 holdings, for instance, the Merrill Lynch Arizona Muni Bond Fund has 27 and the Tax-Free Fund of Vermont has only 18.
But concentrating on even one big state can be dangerous. A downturn, say, in New York City, could depress many of New York State's bond issues. And when Orange County defaulted, many California issues also fell in value, simply because of a "guilt by association" reaction in the market.
Moreover, "Your advantages to staying in-state are really less than meet the eye," Mr. Davidson said. "You're not saving that much money by avoiding state taxes."
While New York's highest marginal tax rate is a relatively high 7.125 percent, for example, Connecticut levies just a flat 4.5 percent rate -- almost 40 percent less. And, as with all state and local income taxes, investors can itemize these payments as Federal tax deductions and thus trim their Federal bills somewhat. With the rising risks of munis, Mr. Davidson said, investors may find that these tax benefits are simply not worth the worry.
 
If You're Buying: Items to Check
Here are some ways to assess a single-state municipal bond fund:
* Find out if your fund is insured, a word a fund can use in its description only if 65 percent of its assets are insured for payment of principal and interest. Compare the yields on insured and uninsured funds for your state to see if the protection is worth it.
 * Read the fund's prospectus and ask its representatives about how many bonds the fund holds at each credit rating. Is there another fund for your state with a better credit profile and an acceptable yield?
* Determine if your fund is diversified. A fund cannot call itself diversified if more than 5 percent of assets are in one security.
* Make sure that a single-state fund, which enables investors to avoid state as well as Federal taxes, is worth it for you. "I'd sit down with a pencil and paper and figure out the after-tax yield," one fund manager advised.
Consider a resident of Connecticut, which has a 4.5 percent flat income-tax rate. Then imagine a single-state muni fund that pays 5 percent, and a national muni fund -- which gives the investor only a Federal tax break -- that pays 5.2 percent. The investor's after-tax yield on the single-state fund is the same as before taxes, 5 percent, while on the national fund the after-tax yield is 4.97 percent. On a $10,000 investment, that's a difference of $3. An investor must judge if this money is worth the risk. At different relative returns and different tax rates, of course, the conclusion may change. SHARON R. KING

HEADLINE: Where Lenin Ruled, Stocks Gain

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
WHERE are the world's hottest stock markets? Not in the economic powerhouses of Asia, but in a region that largely spurned capitalism until recently: Russia and its former satellites in Eastern Europe.
The stock markets there carry substantial risks, and even willing investors find it hard to gain access to them. But the performances have been mouthwatering. 
 Russia's market is up 64.78 percent so far in 1996, based on the MT index. Poland's Warsaw Stock Market index has risen 53.53 percent, and Hungary's BTI Stock Market index is up 77.82 percent. The Czech Republic Stock Market index, the most modest performer of the group, is still up 27.63 percent this year.
Economic changes and apparently cheap stocks are the biggest reasons for the regional run-up. By decisively defeating his Communist opponent in the final round of presidential elections this month, Boris N. Yeltsin has sent a signal that Russia, like its former satellites, may be committed to democratic capitalism, even if its performance is wobbly for a while. The prospect of that victory is what drew foreign investors to Russia this year.
Money continues to flow in despite concerns about the health of Mr. Yeltsin, who postponed a meeting last week with Vice President Al Gore and seemed weak when they did meet at a sanitarium.
As for Russian stock prices, Michael Klebnikov of the stockbroker H. Rivkin & Company in New York reckons that Russia's big natural-resource companies are valued at a fraction of comparable Western companies. For instance, the reserves of Lukoil, which controls 15 percent of Russia's oil and gas, are priced at only 23 cents a barrel, versus $6 a barrel for Mobil's.
"The risks are greatest in Russia, but so is the long-term value," said Barbara Insel, head of emerging European market research at Salomon Brothers.
Low stock prices combined with continuing economic change also explain why foreign money has flowed into Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. Earlier this year, Eastern European shares were trading at 8 to 9 times earnings, compared with multiples of 20 to 25 on most Far Eastern emerging markets. And the tiny capitalizations of the Eastern European exchanges -- Poland's market is worth $6 billion, compared with $250 billion for Malaysia's -- means that a little money has a big effect on prices.
The good regional performance has inspired new investment vehicles and continuing confidence. Recently in the United States, Vontobel Asset Management in Zurich started the Vontobel East Europe Equity fund, a clone of its existing Eastern European fund. Arpad Pongracz, its manager, said he would "double our Russian exposure to 20 percent as fast as possible."
Since then, the Lexington Management Corporation of New Jersey and Troika Dialog of Moscow introduced the Lexington Troika Dialog Russia fund. "Shares have risen a lot, but we still think there is excellent value there," said Peter Derby, president of Troika Dialog.
Even with these new vehicles, however, eager investors will still find few points of entry for the markets. There are a few closed-end funds, and Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic have some companies whose shares trade in the United States as American depository receipts. But most of those A.D.R.'s are unavailable to the individual investor. Similarly, 11 Russian companies trade as A.D.R.'s, yet most investors can get shares of just a few blue chips, like Lukoil and GUM, the big department store.
Before seeking access, however, investors must decide if these markets will continue to shine. That is an open issue, even according to experts who are high on the region.
"The questions about Russia are macroeconomic now, no longer political," said Ms. Insel, meaning that it is the new Government's approach to the country's economic problems that will determine investor confidence. An immediate challenge for Mr. Yeltsin's Government is to increase revenue and to cut the budget deficit by tightening tax collection.
Brokers point out that securities in these soaring markets still carry special hazards. Regulation is minimal. Managers often resent foreign institutions' buying into their firms. And while registering shares is becoming easier, typically only a handful of companies trade regularly.
Company accounting is opaque at best in the region, and that makes one of the markets' apparent advantages, low prices, difficult to gauge. Some experts argue that Russia's chaotic, poorly regulated markets justify its shares' low prices.
In any case, the markets' gains in 1996 have made them less of a bargain. Hungarian shares now trade at 25 times earnings, for example, while Czech stocks trade at 15 times earnings. Fewer bargains may partly explain something that has surprised many Russia watchers: that Mr. Yeltsin's victory has not prompted a further surge in share values.
The markets have specific problems, too. Stefan Bottcher, investment adviser to Robert Fleming's Russia Securities Fund in London, thinks Hungary is the riskiest. It has high inflation and foreign debt and a big budget deficit, he said.
While the Czech market is the region's biggest, with 1,700 quoted companies, its tiny turnover shows that most stocks are illiquid. The Prague exchange, dominated by several large privatization funds, also has a reputation for insider trading, though a law passed this month may help minority shareholders.
Still, skeptics cannot argue about the region's performance, and for some the past will be prologue. "We are very optimistic about Russia," Ms. Insel said.

HEADLINE: Appeasement as a Way of Life

BYLINE: By John R. Bolton; John R. Bolton, president of the National Policy Forum, a Republican study organization, was an Assistant Secretary of State in the Bush Administration.

 BODY:
Our European allies are professing anger at a recent Congressional measure that would penalize any foreign company investing more than $40 million a year in the Iranian or Libyan oil and gas industries. The Europeans appeal to "free trade," but they miss the point; this dispute goes far beyond economics.
The real problem is that the West is divided and aimless in the face of real, direct and growing threats to the lives and security of its citizens. Although recent Congressional debate focused on Iran's and Libya's support for terrorism, the support of these and other nations for the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction -- nuclear, chemical and biological -- is even more pressing. 
 Congressional measures, however laudable, do not constitute adequate international leadership. That can come only from the President of the United States. So far, the field of battle is largely empty.
The supineness of our European allies toward Iran and Libya has been a painful thing to watch. Hugo Paemen, the European Union's representative in Washington, recently spoke of "countermeasures" against United States sanctions, but the real question is when the Europeans will take effective measures against the real enemy: outlaw regimes that threaten their national interests.
The Europeans oppose sanctions and other such "extraterritorial" measures, but they offer little to resolve the threat of mass destruction posed by Iran and Libya (and Iraq, Syria and North Korea). Citing the Iranian role in the recent exchange of Lebanese prisoners for the remains of Israeli soldiers, the Europeans argue that they have rendered Iran less dangerous by keeping up a "critical dialogue" with it and selling it high-technology equipment.
But this argument demonstrates only that some Europeans have never lost faith in appeasement as a way of life. It is clear that Iran is cynically manipulating gullible (or equally cynical) Europeans to advance its development of weapons of mass destruction. Iran has made the "critical dialogue" an end in itself, and many Europeans have acquiesced in the charade for financial gain.
But Euroblindness is not the only problem, and perhaps not even the main one. No serious analyst expects the European Union to lead on this issue. Whatever the difficulty of defining American national interests, weapons proliferation offers a clear case for asserting Presidential leadership.
Populist pressures here have led Congress to take on part of the problem, terrorism, and it would be a short leap to the even greater issue of proliferation. Lawmakers like Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, seeing a dangerous vacuum of leadership, are seeking to fill it the only way Congress can, through legislation.
But what is really necessary here, Congress cannot do. Building an international coalition against the purveyors of terror and fearsome weapons requires Presidential leadership, persistence and determination. It means taking risky political positions, like whether (and when) to take military measures against the proliferators. It means undertaking the arduous work of wrenching reluctant allies into line.
It means leading an American public on an issue that now seems obscure, but that could quickly become tragically immediate. So far President Clinton has attended a substance-free summit meeting on terrorism, but he has not seriously confronted the Western allies, choosing instead to act as though the Constitution left foreign affairs to Congress.
Directly opposing weapons proliferation and terrorism requires a long-term American commitment, starting at the top. For now, I'm not holding my breath. Neither are the Europeans.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

LENGTH: 2409 words

HEADLINE: Keeping Cool in a Roomful of Smoke at RJR Nabisco

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
PICTURE this job listing: Wanted, chief executive for tobacco/food company with restive shareholders; duties include shedding highly regarded food operations, reviving tobacco products that have been declining for decades and competing at home and overseas with larger, deeper-pocketed rivals; must have thick skin and get used to being called a "merchant of death."
Since leading such a company is not most top-flight managers' idea of fun, the board of RJR Nabisco Holdings had few obvious options when gruff Charles M. Harper told them he wanted to quit last December after 18 months on the job. They could have begun an arduous search for an impressive outsider, though experience suggested that any recruit might come with one eye on the exit. They could have promoted one of their two seasoned vice chairmen, but one of them, H. John Greeniaus, the chief executive of Nabisco Holdings, had scant interest in tobacco, and the other, James W. Johnston, had been shunted into restricted roles by Mr. Harper after failing to light up the struggling tobacco business. 
 The other choice -- and one reached unanimously and quickly -- was Steven F. Goldstone, who had recently been named president after coming to the company as part-time general counsel less than a year earlier. Mr. Goldstone, 50, who is shorter than average but not as slight as he looked next to the 6-foot, 6-inch Mr. Harper, had rapidly become the chief executive's most trusted strategic adviser. He had also impressed the board with his ability to speak clearly about the most complicated issues and won the respect of other RJR executives who found him far more approachable than his boss.
When the appointment of the little-known Mr. Goldstone was announced on Dec. 5, many on Wall Street regarded him as a possible short-timer in the executive parade that has marched through RJR's New York City headquarters since 1989 when RJR was taken private by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company in the largest leveraged buyout in history. Of his six predecessors, the longest reign had been the four-year stint of Louis V. Gerstner Jr., who cut out on the last year of his five-year contract in 1993 to take the more lucrative and influential job of turning around I.B.M.
These days, though, it looks as though Mr. Goldstone, a cigar smoker who gave up cigarettes at his doctor's insistence 17 years ago, has every intention of staying indefinitely -- and he has the directors' strong backing to do so. He was elected chairman in May as Mr. Harper completed his transition to retirement.
Clearly, stability at the top would give the company a better shot at solving some problems that have festered in the tumultuous years since the buyout. Like every tobacco company, RJR has had to battle growing public condemnation of its products and marketing practices, wave after wave of lawsuits and the threat of tougher Government regulation.
But it also has its own set of woes. Though it had revenue of $16 billion last year, it continues to lose ground at home to the Philip Morris Companies, a much larger rival, and is outgunned in the race to expand globally by both Philip Morris and B.A.T. Industries of Britain. It is still struggling to stem a long decline of premium brands like Winston and Salem. Mr. Goldstone, like his counterparts in the 1980's, is chafing at the low value Wall Street places on RJR stock.
"What the market wants out of this company is a sense it is in control of its fate," Mr. Goldstone said.
The closer Mr. Goldstone comes to satisfying the market, of course, the more assured will be his place in the anti-smoking lobby's pantheon of arch-villains. At the same time, though, Mr. Goldstone, a corporate lawyer who had never run a company, would win not just acclaim on Wall Street but the chance to cash in on a rich, incentive-laden contract, including a bonus of 200,000 shares if RJR's stock, which closed at $30.25 on Friday, reaches $43.75 in the next three years.
MR. GOLDSTONE sympathizes with Wall Street's skeptical attitude, which he sees as a predictable response to RJR's rocky history since 1988. It was in October of that year that F. Ross Johnson, then chairman and chief executive, ignored the advice of Mr. Goldstone, his outside lawyer, and announced a bid by an investment group that he led to take RJR private.
The ensuing buyout battle, which Mr. Johnson and his team, including the apprehensive Mr. Goldstone, lost to Kohlberg Kravis, raised RJR's stock price beyond Mr. Johnson's wildest dreams. But it also cost him and many of his senior lieutenants their jobs. And it saddled RJR with $25 billion of new debt, much of it junk bonds with interest rates that climbed as high as 17 percent.
As RJR's new owners, Kohlberg Kravis recruited high-profile executives to clean up the financial mess. First came Mr. Gerstner from American Express, who impressed subordinates with his attention to detail but who also made it clear from the start that he saw the company as a stepping stone to other jobs, several company insiders say.
After a brief interlude when two executives from the Gerstner team acted as co-chairmen, Kohlberg Kravis lured Mr. Harper, who was then 66, from Conagra Inc. to finish the financial restructuring. Mr. Harper, who had given up smoking after a heart attack, was renowned for building Conagra from a small Nebraska food company into a multinational giant. He closed his tenure with the introduction of the spectacularly successful Healthy Choice food products.
His primary missions at RJR were to pare debt and split off Nabisco, the food company, from RJR's tobacco operations. But the spinoff plan bogged down in a blizzard of anti-tobacco lawsuits after the initial public offering in January 1995 of 19.5 percent of Nabisco's stock. Frustrated, Mr. Harper announced plans in December to return to his home in Omaha to be with his ailing wife, and he persuaded the board to turn over the reins at RJR to Mr. Goldstone.
It was not a hard sell. Mr. Harper, who goes by the nickname "Mike" but has been called Big Foot behind his back, was known for intimidating subordinates. "Conflict is extraordinarily desirable in coming to good decisions," an unapologetic Mr. Harper said recently.
Maybe so, but in this case, it wasn't enough to produce the sort of results that would have made him a hero to the RJR board. The company's share price inched up 8 percent on his watch, to $30.25 from $28.125, while shares of RJR's archrival, Philip Morris, soared nearly 80 percent in the same period.
To be sure, Mr. Harper could assert that forces beyond his control were at work, including Kohlberg Kravis's sale of its 40 percent stake in the company. Earnings also suffered from a ferocious price war initiated by Philip Morris in 1993 in response to Mr. Gerstner's earlier bid to grab market share with bargain cigarette brands.
Still, Mr. Harper delivered no pleasant surprises to offset such setbacks, and Mr. Goldstone, who had joined RJR in February 1995, quickly established himself as a potential leader.
His rapid advance from part-time to full-time work, and in October, his promotion to president, were welcomed by many senior RJR managers, who were only too happy to drop by his office and let him serve as mediator with Mr. Harper.
Mr. Goldstone's most obvious assets -- the legal skills and financial experience accumulated during his years as a lawyer specializing in corporate mergers and acquisitions -- became steadily more valuable as lawsuits piled up, along with demands from dissatisfied shareholders led by Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn, to hasten the Nabisco spinoff.
"You couldn't have designed a better person to lead the battle against LeBow," said Lawrence R. Ricciardi, the former RJR general counsel and president, who eventually followed Mr. Gerstner to I.B.M.
Perhaps his most deft feat was winning the trust of so many senior RJR executives while working so closely with the increasingly unpopular Mr. Harper. "His fingerprints are on all my key decisions," Mr. Harper said. "He participated in the important people changes, and not just by saying, 'Yes, Mike.' "
Mr. Goldstone has been involved in RJR affairs much longer than most outsiders realize.
The son of a manager at a nightgown factory, he grew up in the Westchester County suburbs of New York City and went straight to work as a Wall Street lawyer after graduating from New York University Law School. He represented RJR when it acquired Del Monte in 1979 and Nabisco when it merged with Standard Brands in 1980, four years before the food company was acquired by RJR. He caught the attention of RJR's general counsel, Mr. Ricciardi, during a 1994 review of tobacco litigation and became Mr. Ricciardi's first choice as successor when he departed.
Before moving from his law firm to RJR, Mr. Goldstone said, he gave considerable thought to the anti-tobacco sentiment in the United States.
"If I believed a lot of the stuff I've read I'd be troubled," he said. "But I'm comfortable that it's a legitimate pleasure for adults with known risks." He noted that he takes flying lessons, exposing himself to a danger that his friends describe as lunatic. "Not to sound too red-white-and-blue about it, but taking risks is what this country is about," he added.
Asked about the recent comment of Bob Dole, the likely Republican Presidential nominee, that tobacco isn't necessarily addictive to all smokers, he said: "Millions of adults enjoy the products and also millions have chosen to stop smoking without the aid of treatment centers, clinics or drugs. I don't think there's a lot more to add on the issue."
Mr. Goldstone's more immediate concern is not smokers' perception of health risks, but investors' qualms about the risk of buying RJR stock. To court disgruntled shareholders, he pushed through a dividend increase and a $100 million share repurchasing program this spring.
The measures were modest compared with what investors have come to expect annually from Philip Morris, but RJR hopes that by moving in the same direction for the first time since 1988, it can show Wall Street that it no longer should be trading at such a large discount to its rival.
Mr. Goldstone also argues that the company is in a better competitive position overseas -- an explosive growth market -- than most American investors realize. While smoking in the United States has declined 20 percent in the last two decades, exports of American cigarettes have more than tripled. And the big producers, including RJR, have invested billions of dollars to acquire production capacity in newly open markets in Asia and Eastern Europe. In the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe alone, where tobacco was formerly controlled by state-run monopolies, smokers light up 700 billion cigarettes annually, compared with 500 billion in the United States.
American companies' share of world cigarette production is just 13 percent, but consumer surveys show smokers' preferences in many countries shifting toward "American blend" products like Philip Morris's Marlboro and RJR's Camel and Winston.
"There's a 10-year window to grab enough market share that you are too big for even Philip Morris to crush when the dust settles," said Jason Wright, a company spokesman. Mr. Goldstone predicts that the company's $3.2 billion international operations will grow at least 10 percent this year, and by steadily increasing percentages for many years after.
A REMINDER of how hard it could be to meet such goals cropped up in RJR's second-quarter earnings, reported on Tuesday. International sales were flat because of economic disruptions in Russia. Over all, the company had operating profits slightly above Wall Street forecasts, although there was a net loss of $27 million after absorbing a $246 million charge for restructuring at Nabisco.
For now, RJR is focusing most of its international effort on building its leading brands in big markets where the company already has a significant presence, like its heavily advertised program for Camel Lights in France. One of its toughest tasks will be reversing the decline in its share of cigarette sales in the United States, now down to about 25 percent. The erosion has come despite the strong performance of its discount Doral brand and the stunning turnaround of Camel, after decades of weakening sales, into one of the fastest-growing premium brands.
One of RJR's newest marketing ploys has been the creation of the Moonlight family of brands, specialty cigarettes like Metro and City Lights that are sold in nightclubs, discos and other urban gathering spots. They are aimed at smokers looking for novelty, juch as microbreweries have been a hit among beer drinkers seeking more variety.
The company also maintains hopes for Eclipse, the nearly smokeless cigarette that it is now test-marketing. So far, it is performing better than Premier, the company's previous stab at creating a market for products that primarily heat tobacco rather than burn it. If either the Moonlight line or Eclipse gains even 1 percent of the $45 billion market, it would be the industry's most successful product introduction since the 1970's.
At the same time, the company continues to experiment with adjustments in the taste, packaging and image of its mature brands. The newest Winston slogan, "No bull," for example, is an allusion to the absence of additives, like moisturizers and flavors, in the tobacco of Winstons being test-marketed in Florida.
"We are trying to put innovative ideas behind a portfolio of products," Mr. Goldstone said. "Salespeople get charged up if they get a sense they are working for a company that isn't brain-dead."
Most tobacco analysts say the industry is undervalued and a few argue that RJR is actually a better bet than Philip Morris at current levels. Still, Wall Street remains skeptical: in recent months, Philip Morris has traded roughly 12 times its projected cash earnings, while RJR has been at 8 times. If the gap closed to the single point that prevailed in 1988 before RJR became so beholden to its bondholders and to Kohlberg Kravis, RJR's share price would soar by about 40 percent, to around $42.
"Most companies trading at eight times cash earnings are in miserable shape," Mr. Goldstone said. "We're not. We've just got to demonstrate we're through punishing shareholders." Even a lawyer would have a hard time arguing.

HEADLINE: Word for Word/Officially English;
A Law to Learn 'Em a Thing or Two About the American Language

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

 BODY:
WILL Los Angeles change its name to "The Angels" if a new bill making English the official language of the United States becomes law?
Probably not. But it would likely end the printing of Social Security forms, Internal Revenue documents and United States Park Service pamphlets in any language other than English. Documents for public safety, health or national security would be exempt. 
 Last week the House Economic and Educational Opportunities Committee narrowly approved such a bill, 19 to 17, with all Republicans voting in favor and all Democrats voting against. The House may vote on the measure as early as September; the Senate is considering a similar bill.
Although English is indisputably the central language of American life, Republicans say its primacy needs to be codified because the Government is catering too heavily to a growing number of immigrants who do not speak English well. Democrats, disagreeing, say that more than 97 percent of Americans speak English well, and that an English-first law is unnecessary, unconstitutional and racist.
Legislators last week jousted over how language defines what it means to be American. They also joked about regional idiosyncrasies that make English spoken with a Texas twang unintelligible to a New Englander. The hearing, of course, included occasional lapses in grammar and syntax. ERIC SCHMITT
 
George Miller, Democrat of California: We promote Amtrak passes. We promote Park Services passes overseas. We use Federal dollars and Government officials to go overseas to promote American tourism. All of those pamphlets would have to be written in English?
Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina: The purpose is to conduct the official business of the Federal Government in English. However, exemptions the bill has include actions, documents or policies necessary for national security issues, international relations, trade or commerce would be exempt. I think Part B of the bill would exempt what you're talking about.
Miller: So we would have an exemption to try to get a tourist to come here from Italy, but we wouldn't help someone get their Social Security?
Graham: Well, if you want to put it that way, yeah.

When you're trying to restrict people from getting the information they need, or the communication, you're going to end up costing us a lot more money than you save us . . . From the beginning of the immigration of this country, all parents have wanted their children to learn English as well as they can . . .

Have you ever been in a foreign country and you hear someone speak English and it doesn't excite you? It empowers people. If you want to keep your people in a barrio, if you want to keep them restricted in little tight communities so only you can communicate with them, and we can't in English, then be my guest. But we're going to empower them to get out of that so they can have a piece of the American dream . . .
Martinez: I don't live in a ghetto. I wasn't raised in a ghetto. I was raised in a neighborhood of community people. I represent people from neighborhoods, not ghettos. Pat Williams, Democrat of Montana: I've been here 18 years and this is most maddening debate I've sat through, for me personally. It's absolutely maddening. We're missing each other on all sides. What is the problem and will this bill solve it?
Graham: One of the problems, for example, is the I.R.S. has sent out 500,000 publications that cost $113,000 in Spanish. They got 700-and-something replies back, and it was a $157 per publication. They're going to expand that program. I believe that's a problem we need to cut off now.

Robert E. Andrews, Democrat of New Jersey: The majority is guilty of a lot of things in pushing this legislation and one of the things they're guilty of is very sloppy drafting. I understand it was asserted by the sponsor of this amendment that coinage would not be covered, so that printing E Pluribus Unum on our money would not be against the laws of the United States. I'm not so sure that's right . . . If a citizen sues here and claims that they're somehow aggrieved by use of Latin on our money or our coins, there is very clearly an issue of whether Latin is necessary for trade.
Graham: The exception that I would point the gentleman to is not the trade, commerce or international relations exception. It would be the exception that says documents that utilize terms of art or phrases from languages other than English would be exempt. I think our money is a document that does that and is exempt.
Andrews: With all due respect, you may think so, but that doesn't preclude someone from filing a suit and wasting probably more money than the I.R.S. spent to send out those income tax forms . . .

Chaka Fattah, Democrat of Pennsylvania: Since we've all been speaking in English all day long, it's clear that we're not communicating very well with each other.
I hope that since there seems to be one thread of bipartisanship here, which is that we all agree, I think, that it'd be helpful to promote Americans learning other languages and that we probably ought to do more to make English available to people. And maybe one day soon we would spend all day actually working on that rather than working at cross-purposes.
Cunningham: People say symbolism isn't important . . . I think, for example, an American citizen, the very first time you take the oath of this country, that you do it in English. It's only symbolic but it's very powerful.
Fattah: I think as an American citizen, if you could not speak or read at all, what is important is that you be committed to the ideals of this country, and that you be given the protection of the United States Constitution. This issue of language is about communication. What we should be working on is the substance of being an American, not the symbols so much.
