HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Learning Curve

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
During the Israeli election campaign there was one commercial that the Likud used every night on TV. It was the sound of breaking glass, simulating the sound of a terrorist incident, followed by old news footage of Yasir Arafat and Shimon Peres walking hand-in-hand. I don't think we'll be seeing that commercial anymore. Last week, Israel's Foreign Minister, David Levy, went to Gaza and warmly shook hands with Mr. Arafat on behalf of Benjamin Netanyahu's new Government. As Israeli commentators noted the next day, "There was no sound of broken glass."
The sound you do hear coming out of Israel these days is the sound of Mr. Netanyahu bumping up against the reality of the peace process. So far, the new Israeli Prime Minister seems to be trying to avoid doing anything that would derail the peace process, while at the same time avoiding anything that might advance it and cause a split in his right-wing party. He is clearly probing for how far he can go toward implementing his campaign rhetoric without blowing up the peace process that has brought Israelis so many tangible economic benefits and openings to the world, which they don't want to sacrifice. Only when Mr. Netanyahu finishes probing and starts making decisions, or faces a crisis, will we know whether he is just a more articulate version of Yitzhak Shamir, only capable of treading water, or a Menachem Begin, capable of historic decisions, even though they might cause splits within his party and people. 
 Mr. Netanyahu's evolution will be shaped in large part by Wall Street and the Arab Street.
Mr. Netanyahu presented himself in the U.S. as an apostle of free-market capitalism and privatization, eager to sell off state-owned Israeli companies to global and local investors. But what Mr. Netanyahu obviously has not thought through is how he is going to privatize Israel's economy while nationalizing its politics. Privatization requires Israel to be connected to the global market and to have a stable political environment that will attract foreign investors. Nationalizing Israel's politics -- by freezing the peace process, building new settlements and keeping Yasir Arafat at a distance -- will lead to renewed friction between Israelis and Arabs. The reason the vast majority of Israel's business leaders voted against Mr. Netanyahu was that they understood how important the peace process has been for their country. Israel's economy grew at a stunning rate of 7.1 percent in 1995. Last year, it attracted $2 billion in foreign investment -- triple the year before.
But since Mr. Netanyahu's election, the Tel Aviv stock market has lost 16 percent of its value, largely because of investor uncertainty about his economic policies, and concerns that his global economics will clash with his nationalistic politics. Israeli companies cannot afford that sort of uncertainty. In the first five months of 1996, Israeli companies raised about $900 million for new investment. Some 75 percent of that had to come from Wall Street, because there isn't enough local capital. Israel cannot keep growing at its current pace without Wall Street, and Wall Street wants stability, and you're not going to have that without a meaningful peace process. Yes, violence will also attend any peace process. We've seen that. But terrorism under Yitzhak Rabin and Shimon Peres never really shook the Tel Aviv stock market because investors viewed such violence as going against the trend of events. But if violence erupts again now, with no peace process in sight, it will be viewed by many investors as a harbinger of things to come, and it could have a very negative economic impact.
As for the Arab street, Mr. Netanyahu seems to believe that Israel's military superiority over the Arab states will eventually lead to Arab passivity, and a peace process based on "peace for peace" instead of "land for peace." Golda Meir and Moshe Dayan had a similar view after the 1967 victory. The 1973 war cured them of that view. The Likud peddled the same illusion after Israel evicted the P.L.O. from Lebanon in 1982. That led to the intifada. Sooner or later, if the feeling takes hold that this Israeli Government does not want to treat Arabs with equality or keep open, however slightly, the possibility of trading land for real peace and personal security, there will be a reaction. It may not be from the Arab governments. It might simply erupt from below, and it would spoil any tranquillity in Israel -- sort of like the sound of breaking glass.

HEADLINE: The Language Wars;
To the Barricades, Speaking in Tongues

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
NEVER mind the French military might that rumbled down the Champs Elysees and roared overhead on Bastille Day. The struggle closest to French patriotic hearts is being fought out at the Olympic arenas of Atlanta -- and not by the athletes.
The French Foreign Ministry includes a whole office devoted to spreading the French language; its head, Margie Sudre, insisted vehemently on giving the French language its full due in Atlanta as the second official language of the Games. So 1,000 French-language interpreters have been in place to roam the Olympic village; scoreboards are written in French as well as English, and Mrs. Sudre was there in person on opening day to check up on how well the American organizers kept their promises to be multilingual.

 
 
French Fries Allowed
 
 Americans may have trouble understanding why the French care so much about their language's survival in an increasingly anglophone world. For all the official prickliness about French industrial espionage, no one in the United States talks of banning french fries as a subversive influence. But in French-speaking Quebec, stores are banned from using signs with English words in bolder type than their French equivalents.
There is lots of talk in Europe, too, about cultural diversity these days, but on this side of the Atlantic the phrase stands for the desire to preserve the separate cultural and linguistic identities of the European nation states even as they move toward closer unity. Nobody wants nationalistic rivalries like the ones that caused two world wars, but nowadays nobody wants a United States of Europe, either, a federal state where everybody sees the same movies, buys the same store brands and speaks the same language.
If that kind of federalism ever did triumph here, survival of the fittest would probably mean that the common lingo would turn out to be English. So France resists -- and so does Germany -- putting up a valiant fight to spread the culture and the values their languages bear, along with commerce.
In Germany's case, proselytizing for the tongue of Luther and Goethe is partly a way of telling people that Hitler and the Holocaust are not all there is to German history. The larger reason for the sensitivity, and the one Germany and France share, is that the Continental tongues are so badly outnumbered in the world today. French, notably, remains the official language of 21 countries and the co-official language of five more, including Canada. But the number of French speakers in all of them -- about 200 million -- does not even equal the population of Brazil, where the lingua franca is Portuguese. English, though, is used by one out of every seven people on the globe.
European colonialism is what originally spread French (as it did English, Portuguese, and Spanish) so widely. Now, the French language is helping keep the colonial-era ties alive. Mrs. Sudre, who heads the Francophone Secretariat in the French Foreign Ministry, was born in French Indochina in 1943 and didn't even learn French, her father's language, until she was 8 years old. Ho Chi Minh's revolutionaries expelled the French colonial regime in 1954, but Vietnam has invited France's President, Jacques Chirac, to Hanoi next year for the seventh annual meeting of the 49 nations of the francophone movement, or Francophonie, which includes lands where the language is culturally respected if not exactly widely spoken.
"I don't think that you can compare the situation of French in the world with English," she said. "The English that is spreading around the globe is really Anglo-American, not the pure English of Shakespeare's day. We want to try to preserve the richness, subtlety and precision of the French language against the challenge of this new form of English."
Purity of language and the ideals of freedom get talked about a lot at gatherings of the Francophonie, but France also wants to preserve economic influence in the world, and is wary of the advantage that speaking English gives to English-speaking countries like the United States in global trade.
French speakers are not the only ones with a messianic urge. The German Government spends $200 million a year spreading German and German culture through 150 Goethe Institutes in 70 countries, but the German effort lacks the defensive overtone of the campaign led by France, which spends $1 billion on francophony. It doesn't bother Germans, for example, to call the programs that run computers "die Software." The French, on the other hand, insist "logiciel" is better.

 
 
The New Battleground
 More people in places like Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic speak German than French, and the French fear that in the long run their influence in the European Union will wane as these countries become members. French used to be the language of diplomacy, not of war, and in part France yearns for the power and influence that it had when Cardinal Richelieu and Talleyrand had to be listened to in the royal courts of Europe.
So Mr. Chirac insists that the heads of international organizations nowadays should be able to speak French -- one reason France is eager to re-elect Boutros Boutros-Ghali, who speaks fluent French, as the United Nations Secretary General even though the United States opposes him.
In a moment of humility, Mr. Chirac might concede that the language spoken by most people today is Mandarin Chinese. But then, he might say, it does not need to struggle to preserve itself.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
America's Quiet Rebellion Against McDonaldization

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
AS millions of tourists flocked here for the Centennial Olympics this summer, many expected to find Tara and Scarlett and Rhett.
Instead, they found a Gap, a Gap Kids, the Limited and a Limited Too in a single mall. They also found that any anticipated charm had been muted by the kind of security that, since Lockerbie, the World Trade Center, Oklahoma City, and T.W.A. Flight 800, seems to have turned crowd events in so many American cities into near-military operations. 
 And any doubts that the security was needed evaporated early yesterday morning when an explosion rocked Centennial Olympic Park, killing at least two people and wounding more than 100 others.
The tourists may have concluded that whatever regional color Atlanta once had was long ago paved over.
Social scientists, too, have spent decades describing the nation's homogenization through network television and national brands, retailers and restaurant chains. "The McDonaldization of Society," one recent volume called it.
But arguably what's been happening in the mid-1990's is more like the Carolina-barbecuing, Cajun-seasoning and Tex-Mex-taco-stuffing of America. In regions often distinguished by common culture and not by the arbitrary political boundaries that define cities and states, a more mature sense of local identity has been thriving.
The Old, or Original, Regionalism grew from the earth and flourished under skies that gave the nation's distant locales their own foods, livelihoods, cultures and myths, from the cotton and salt-cured country ham of the South to the timber and planked salmon of the Northwest. Thriving in isolation, the Old Regionalism was above all provincial and humble.
The New Regionalism has seen the world and come back home. Forerunners of the New Regionalism can be found at least as far back as Charles Ives, who sent rivers of clashing rhythms coursing through his New England landscape, and William Faulkner. Even now, the regional revival is furthering the nation's long evolution from a provincial outpost of European tastes into a fresh cultural font, often removing the velvet ropes between high arts and low.
In Texas, a writer like Larry McMurtry, who once loudly rejected the tradition of historical cowboy novels, has since the 1980's returned to it with realism and harsh irony.
A decade ago, visitors to Dallas, Houston or Atlanta would be taken out for demonstrations that local chefs could cook authentic French or Continental cuisine -- at places invariably named La Maison de la Casa House, Calvin Trillin once said. Now they will have New Texan or New South, with chile verde or cheese grits.
If many corporations still impose their blandly uniform products on every corner of the nation, they are also spending more time scouring the country for regional trends, products and fashions that can be merchandised coast to coast.
Last year, Campbell Soup Company, knowing that salsa outsells ketchup, bought Pace Foods of San Antonio, a salsa maker, for $1.1 billion.

 
 
The Same Old Hops
 Now, behemoth breweries like Anheuser-Busch are trying to masquerade as local microbrewers. Elk Mountain Red Lager and Elk Mountain Amber Ale are named after Anheuser's hops farm in Idaho. For other beers made with the same hops, try Michelob or Bud.
Pollsters who can see past the Planet Hollywoods punctuating more and more cities notice that sharp distinctions between those cities persist.
"Regional differences tend to hold up over time," said Tom Smith, director of General Social Surveys at the University of Chicago.
In the 1970's, when these surveys began, Southerners were much more likely than other Americans to hunt, go to church and favor bans on homosexual college professors and racial intermarriage. Although every region has moderated its outlook on most racial and social matters since then, Southern ways on all these points remain just as distinctive, except that Southerners hunt less as they domesticate in suburbs and cities.

 
 
Stuck at Age Six
 As Mr. Smith of the University of Chicago notes, by the time children learn of national brands and network news, family, neighbors and schools have already passed along their local values. Racial attitudes are formed by age six, and most people practice our parents' religion.
Until yesterday's blast, Atlanta may have been viewed as the world's biggest billboard for plastic watchmakers and other proud Olympic sponsors. But in a week it goes back to being the sort of place whose suburbs sent Newt Gingrich to Washington, and where "How was church?" remains a standard Sunday afternoon greeting.
Far less reverent of the past than true antebellum citadels like Charleston and Savannah, Atlanta has thrived as a go-between, providing the transportation and services to link Northern markets and capital with the rest of the South. To appeal to all sides, Atlanta crafted a back-slapping but businesslike image. It was not exactly the stuff of carefully choreographed opening and closing Olympic ceremonies. "How are we supposed to make a number about economic opportunity?" the director of the ceremonies recently complained. "Have 5,000 dancing guys with briefcases?"
For all the new business executives, though, the region is as likely to change them as the other way around. Migrants generally absorb many of the values of their new communities.
"People move, neighborhoods stay the same," said Michael J. Weiss, author of "Latitudes and Attitudes: An Atlas of American Tastes, Trends, Politics and Passions" (Little, Brown, 1994).
Regional differences are now being reinforced by foreign ties too, as trade, international investment and immigration swell.
The Northeast is most closely tied to Europe and its fashions, food and culture. Miami is a Latin American capital and airline hub. Texas, responsible for nearly half the nation's exports to Mexico, has become a state of two nations. The West Coast depends more and more on the rest of the Pacific Rim, while the Northwest welcomes shoppers and immigrants from the newly opened Russian Far East.
Despite the debate over immigration, the nation's growing appreciation of its own regional diversity is tied to its growing tolerance that surveys indicate for racial and ethnic diversity.
Tourism has given the New Regionalism an added payoff. But if tourism furthers historic preservation in cities like Savannah, it also fosters a Disneyesque packaging designed to fulfill tourists' fantasies about what a city or region should look like. Movie-set Hawaii blooms at zillion-dollar Maui resorts, movie-set Atlanta thrives at a downtown restaurant like Pittypat's Porch, named for Scarlett's aunt, and movie-set New York is beginning to spring up in the rebuilding of Times Square, in which Disney has a stake.
Increasingly, though, many of the nation's habits and trends flow not from the cosmopolitan coasts, but outward from the Nashvilles, Austins and Santa Fes. Some of New York's most savvy restaurateurs, the owners of the Ollie's Chinese Noodle Shops and Carmine's Italian restaurants around Times Square and elsewhere, have most recently given midtown Manhattan a Virgil's, offering barbecue platters including Owensboro (Ky.) lamb, Memphis pork ribs and pulled Carolina pork shoulder.
Still, the New York state of mind requires the menu to note that the 1994 Chateau de la Chaise Brouilly goes well with Texas hot links and the ribs.

Data was from Claritas Inc. and Simmons Market Research Bureau market research.)

HEADLINE: Get a Job;
The New Contract With America's Poor

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS the movement to repeal welfare boiled across the Senate last week, a noteworthy chart appeared on the chamber floor. Decorated with a sketch of a creeping infant, it advertised a Democratic amendment to provide vouchers to those children -- as many as four million -- who could be dropped from government rolls if the bill becomes law.
Through an eerie enumeration, the poster specified what the vouchers could buy: 
 Clothing.
Diapers.
Cribs.
Medicine.
School Supplies.
That the Democrats' hopes for the welfare poor has been reduced to a plan to salvage some diapers speaks volumes about the national debate. That the amendment failed says even more.
There's no doubt that the Republican bill, which passed the House and Senate and will be sent to the White House as soon as this week, would "end welfare as we know it." (To quote a certain President, now immersed in his re-election drive.)
The risk is that it may also end poverty as we know it. By making it even worse.
To the public, that may seem unimaginable, so wretched are the nine million children and four million parents who now receive aid, and so discredited is the program that sustains them. But the Republican plan does not "reform" welfare, which is known as Aid to Families with Dependent Children. Technically, it abolishes it.

 
 
It's a Free Market
 In its place, it offers laissez-faire hopes that, faced with the consequences of bad luck and poor choices, the needy will somehow shape up. No doubt, some will.
But the weight of the evidence suggests that most either cannot or will not lift themselves from poverty in an economy where, for more than two decades, the bottom has been dropping out for low-skilled workers. In a nation that already has the highest child poverty rates in the industrialized world the poor may indeed get poorer. And more numerous and desperate as well.
Whatever the bill's substantive demerits, it succeeds brilliantly in what may be its deeper purpose: putting an electioneering President firmly on the spot.
If he signs the measure as is, President Clinton will appear to have fulfilled his famous pledge about ending welfare. In truth, he will have abandoned the vision that animated the slogan. Having sought office with the aim of a redefined social contract -- health care for every American -- he will be seeking re-election with a bill that begrudges poor infants their Pampers.
If he vetoes the bill, Mr. Clinton can preserve his allegiance to his original purpose, which promised more for the poor while demanding more from them. But he can also expect a rainstorm of Republican ridicule, from here to Election Day. In sending back a welfare bill for the third time, he will insure a parade of 30-second television ads calling him a back-tracker and a flip-flopper, a pledge-breaking defender of the status quo.
Welfare slogans are often at odds with welfare substance, as Mr. Clinton himself well knows, being a master of both. He underscored the distinction last week, in giving earthy consideration to what the Senate called welfare reform. "You can put wings on a pig, but you don't make it an eagle," he said.

 
 
No Promises Now
 But what the President didn't say last week was equally important. He didn't say he would veto the bill.
"He keeps his promise and he abandons his principles -- or he keeps his principles and abandons his promise," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, Mr. Clinton's most vocal Democratic critic. "That's the dilemma he's in."
While the President is caricatured as a defender of the status quo, it's his activism that has landed him in this thicket.
"End welfare as we know it" -- it was remarkably bold and utterly vague, this snippet of 1992 campaign rhetoric that now holds social policy hostage. Had a Republican first said it, he or she would have been diagnosed with a case of hard-heartedness. But Mr. Clinton, a child advocate and husband of a child advocate, brought the notion instant credibility.
And great misunderstanding. Many people heard only the first two words: end it. But Mr. Clinton was mindful of the as-we-know-it qualifier. He was talking about new training programs, expanded child care, universal health care and, if need be, last-resort government jobs for those who exhausted a two-year limit.
When he finally put his plan in writing, in June 1994, it would have "invested" an extra $10 billion over five years in the hopes of future payoffs. Now he faces a plan that heads $70 billion in the other direction. It cuts $60 billion from the anti-poverty budget and ends welfare by, well, ending welfare.
Under the Republican plan, families may receive no more than five years of benefits in a lifetime, and states can set much lower limits -- as little as, say, 30 days.
According to estimates by LaDonna Pavetti of the Urban Institute, if the five-year limit were in effect today, about 2 million adults, with 4.5 million children, would be instantly shorn from the rolls. They are among the nation's least educated people, and are concentrated in the most blighted areas. In Detroit, 67 percent of the children receive welfare in the course of a year; in New York it's 39 percent. On what will they get by?
The Republicans haven't answered that question as much as they've turned it around: the middle class supports itself, so why can't the poor? With a handful of Democratic allies, they've put the status quo on trial. "We know the present system is a complete disaster," said Representative Clay Shaw, a Florida Republican and an architect of the House bill.
Senator Joseph Lieberman, a Connecticut Democrat, says the apocalypse is now. "Millions of children are in poverty, with their parents leading lives of desperation and hopelessness," he wrote last week, in urging the President to sign the bill.
Virtually no one defends the current system, whose ameliorative successes are invisible (money for shoes or a bowl of cereal) and whose major flaws are on full display. It is an affront to prized values -- work, family, initiative and independence. The public hates it for good reasons (its indulgence of the indolent) and for bad reasons (its disproportionate support of racial minorities, who stay on the rolls longer).

 
 
The Risk of Chaos
 But to say the current system has failed is not to say it can't get worse. The few Democrats trying to salvage the safety net include the system's most acute detractors. Mr. Moynihan's fame originally derived from his warnings about illegitimacy. Edward I. Koch, former Mayor of New York, made a career of denouncing freeloaders. Now he asks, "Are we at the point in our history when we will permit children to starve?"
Of course not -- the Republican bill would not do that. Indeed, it offers more than last year's version (more day care money, more medical care), which is partly what tempts the President to sign it.
The risk isn't starvation; it's just additional chaos, hurt and need. The Urban Institute estimates the bill will drive 2.6 million people below the poverty line -- not to mention what it might do to those already there.
The nation's most successful job-placement program for welfare recipients, in Riverside, Calif., trimmed caseloads by about 10 percent; in removing anyone who has received benefits for more than five years, the Republicans assume that fully half of those on welfare can make it on their own. The Riverside program raised job earnings 26 percent -- to an average of $286 a month.
No doubt the harsh reality of an empty stomach will cause some people to do better. Some may indeed get jobs and marry, as Mr. Shaw predicts. Others may turn to prostitution or the drug trade. Or cling to abusive boyfriends. Or have more abortions. Or abandon their children. Or camp out on the streets and beg.
No one knows because no such risks have ever been taken. But if misery were motive enough, presumably the poor would have reformed themselves by now.
How odd that such a bill may become the chief legislative legacy of the first children's advocacy President. In deciding whether to affix his signature, Mr. Clinton will have to choose between welfare reform as he knew it and welfare repeal as his opponents came to define it.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 10; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1384 words

HEADLINE: Serbs in Pragmatic Pullout from Albanian Region

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: PRISTINA, Serbia, July 22

 BODY:
In 1989 the Serbian strongman, Slobodan Milosevic, swooped down in a helicopter onto the field where 600 years earlier the Turks had defeated the Serbs at the Battle of Kosovo. In a fervent speech before a million Serbs, he galvanized the nationalist passions that two years later fueled the Balkan conflict.
Now, in this bedraggled southern province of Kosovo, a predominantly Albanian Muslim region where President Milosevic promised a glorious future for the minority Serbs, the Balkan conflict appears to be playing out a subdued denouement. 
 More than 90 percent of Kosovo's two million people are Albanians, and their resentment of Serbia's assertion of dominance has long made Kosovo a tinderbox that has threatened to entangle Macedonia, Albania, Greece and Turkey in a wider Balkan conflict.
But instead of seeing Kosovo reinforced as a Serbian stronghold with the resettlement of Serbs from the former Yugoslavia, as Mr. Milosevic promised, the last Serbs of Kosovo are fleeing, embittered that their leader appears to be deserting them.
"Many Serbs are leaving right now," said Momcilo Tradkovic, a former Serbian Governor of Kosovo. "More than 50 percent of the Serbs in Kosovo have already built houses in Serbia. If this continues, the bulk of the Serbs will leave in the next five years, and after that it won't matter."
The idea that Mr. Milosevic might allow Kosovo, the cradle of Serb history and mythology, to drift away would have been preposterous at the height of the Balkan war.
But boxed in by the Dayton peace agreement, which requires Serbia to safeguard the rights of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo or forgo access to international credits, Mr. Milosevic appears to be undecided about what to do, Western diplomats say.
The United States, in an attempt to demonstrate its seriousness about enforcing the accord, opened an information center here on July 20 -- the first office of a foreign power in Kosovo's capital. And in another effort to keep Mr. Milosevic on better behavior, the Clinton Administration has said it will not send an ambassador to Belgrade while Serbian authorities continue to abuse Albanians' human rights.
The possibility that Mr. Milosevic may be preparing to soften his stance on Kosovo was further signaled in a recent paper by a member of the Serbian Academy of Science and Arts, who argued that the Albanians and Serbs should share power in Kosovo or divide the province into two ethnic enclaves. In the past, Mr. Milosevic has often used the academy as a harbinger of policy shifts.
And in a move that was interpreted by the Serbs of Kosovo as another betrayal by the leader they increasingly distrust, Mr. Milosevic signed an agreement with the German Government this month that calls for the return to Kosovo of 120,000 Albanian refugees now in Germany.
The tensions over Kosovo intensified in 1990 when Mr. Milosevic infuriated the Albanian majority by revoking Kosovo's autonomy and incorporating it into Serbia. He then strengthened the hand of the heavily armed Serbian police who, human rights monitors say, have made life miserable for the Albanians. About 120,000 Albanians have been dismissed from jobs in state-run plants in the last five years, the monitors say, and Albanians have been subject to arbitrary arrests, beatings and shakedowns.
In 1993 Zeljko Raznjatovic, the paramilitary leader known as Arkan, who did much of the "ethnic cleansing" of Bosnia for Mr. Milosevic, turned up in Kosovo to warn the Albanians what might be in store for them.
Human-rights abuses persist, said Fred Abraham, a monitor from Human Rights Watch in New York, who recently spent a month in Kosovo.
"The most severe problem is police violence and torture," he said, adding that Albanians were frequently stopped in their cars by the police and beaten. Detention and sometimes torture in prison were particularly directed to politically active Albanians, he said.
Ibrahim Rugova, a former Albanian Communist leader during Tito's rule, has been leading a campaign for Albanian independence. Some more moderate Albanian leaders say they would accept a halfway step of autonomy, leading to eventual independence. To underline this goal, Mr. Rugova has formed a shadow government and established separate Albanian schools, medical facilities and local councils, much of it with funds from Albanians abroad.
Mr. Rugova's nonviolent civil disobedience and his support from Albanian exiles in Switzerland, Germany and the United States have resulted in a parallel society. Satellite dishes directed toward Tirana, the capital of Albania, enhance even the poorest Albanian dwelling here, suggesting that while Albanians physically live in Serbian-ruled territory, mentally they are elsewhere.
The inability of the financially strapped Mr. Milosevic to prevent the economic free fall in Kosovo is also propelling the steady Serb exodus, Serbs say.
"There is no life for us here," said Milica Borzos, a Serbian pensioner whose ancestry in Kosovo goes back centuries and who has seen the once prosperous zinc mining town of Zvecan, where she lives, sink into despair.
With most industry shuttered and agriculture moribund, Kosovo is kept afloat largely from the proceeds of Albanian drug-running to Europe and remittances from Albanian expatriates.
With the help of the drug money that filters down into Albanian villages from the couriers who drive their flashy cars from Kosovo to Switzerland, many Albanians are able to build a future that some Serbs, Mr. Tradkovic asserted, are beginning to envy.
In Veliki Trnovac, a strategically located Serbian village that borders Kosovo, a handful of tightly knit Albanian families are reported by Western drug enforcement agencies to control the traffic of heroin as it passes from Turkey to Germany and Switzerland.
Expensive European cars with Swiss license plates and tinted windows parked on the village's narrow streets are the only outward signs of the courier system that is reportedly run out of the village. But a cafe owner gave a sense of the importance of the European connections.
"There are 25-year-old men who linger in the street who have never worked in their lives," said the owner, who would give his name only as Ibrahim. "They are just waiting for money to come from Switzerland."
To help pay the $300-a-month rent for his cafe, Ibrahim said, he received money from three brothers in Switzerland.
Fehmi Agani, a sociology professor and vice president of the main Albanian party, the Democratic Alliance of Kosovo, acknowledged that Albanians were involved in drug trafficking. But he said that the Albanians were not "in charge" of the drug trade and served only as couriers. "People have no other way to survive," he said.
And when Kosovo Albanians end up in Swiss jails on charges of drug trafficking -- about 3,000 are currently being held -- life is not so bad, he said.
"A large number of people live better in jail in Switzerland than here in freedom," said Mr. Agani, who gets by with the help of $150 his son sends each month from Germany.
The ability of the Albanians to survive economically, by legal or other means, rankles many Serbs, particularly those who arrived in Kosovo last year as refugees from Croatia.
In the basement of an ostentatious sports hall here built by Tito to celebrate the brotherhood of Yugoslavia's Serbs and Albanians languish about 500 ethnic Serbs who fled the Krajina region of Croatia last year as Croatian troops advanced and Mr. Milosevic failed to come to the Serbs' defense.
Instead of finding refuge in the heart of Serbdom, they now feel abandoned at the end of the world.
About 15,000 of the estimated 150,000 Krajina Serbs were sent by the Belgrade authorities to Kosovo. And like many of their Kosovo brethren, they are desperate to leave.
Mladenka Rajlic, the mother of two children, has visited all the shrines of Kosovo: ornate Orthodox churches, monasteries and the medieval battlefield where Mr. Milosevic proclaimed his vision of a new Serbia.
But history left her unimpressed.
"God forbid I should stay here; this place is 300 years behind civilization," Mrs. Rajlic shuddered as she sat in a makeshift room with no running water. "I'm only 36 and I'd rather die than remain in Kosovo."
